Fiji (03): fatal, children, sg.C, more cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5755546", "date": "2018-04-09 23:51:54", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TAIWAN: SEROGROUP B, CIPROFLOXACIN-RESISTANT, MILITARY BASE, 2017\n*********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Apr 2018\nSource: Taiwan Epidemiological Bulletin Volume 34, Number 7 [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov.tw/english/info.aspx?preview=true&treeid=3847719104BE0678&nowtreeid=5125C5DE158A5D51&tid=A5A0321FF0CAD68D\n\n\nAn Outbreak of Ciprofloxacin-Resistant Serogroup B Meningococcal Disease in a Military Base, 2017\n--------------------------\nHsueh-Mei Chiang, Chien-Shun Chiou, Chuen-Sheue Chiang, Shu-Man Yao,Hao-Hsin Wu, Yu-Ning Fan, Hsin-Yi Wei\n\nOn 23 Jul 2017, a hospital in Taoyuan reported a suspected case of meningococcal disease, who was a soldier in a military base, to Taoyuan Department of Health. After investigation, another 2 soldiers who served in the same base with the index case developed symptoms of meningitis and were reported subsequently. Blood cultures from all 3 cases yielded serogroup B _Neisseria meningitidis_ with indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis patterns. A total of 114 contacts received chemoprophylaxis with rifampin or ciprofloxacin. Nevertheless, the hospital laboratory found that the isolate from the index case was resistant to ciprofloxacin. Of the 98 contacts receiving ciprofloxacin as initial chemoprophylaxis, 54 contacts were offered azithromycin, while the rest 44 contacts declined. No secondary cases were identified in the contacts during the one-month follow-up period. The outbreak underscores the importance of antimicrobial surveillance of _Neisseria meningitidis_. The antimicrobial profiles of isolates from the cases should be reviewed and taken into consideration in terms of chemoprophylaxis for contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Angela Song-En Huang\n\n[Household and other close contacts of persons with invasive meningococcal disease have a higher risk for carriage and invasive disease, for which they should receive antibiotic chemoprophylaxis to eliminate nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ as soon as possible. Ciprofloxacin has been an effective single-dose oral chemoprophylaxis agent. However, sporadic isolates ciprofloxacin-resistant meningococci disease began to appear in the Americas, Europe, Australia, China, and India. As a result, in 2008, the U.S. CDC recommended ciprofloxacin should no longer be used for chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal disease in communities where fiprofloxacin-resistant strains have been identified (selected U.S. counties in North Dakota and Minnesota). Ceftriaxone and rifampin are alternative agents (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm). Azithromycin is also recommended in communities where ciprofloxacin resistance has been detected (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/surv-manual/chpt08-mening.html).\n\nMaps of Taiwan can be seen at http://www.mapsofworld.com/taiwan/taiwan-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/193. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan (02): fatal, military base, comment\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base\n.................................................ml/msp/ml/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taoyuan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MILITARY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ceftriaxone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5736191", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: sg.B, ciprofloxacin-resistant, military, 2017", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5736191", "date": "2018-04-09 23:51:54", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TAIWAN: SEROGROUP B, CIPROFLOXACIN-RESISTANT, MILITARY BASE, 2017\n*********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 3 Apr 2018\nSource: Taiwan Epidemiological Bulletin Volume 34, Number 7 [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov.tw/english/info.aspx?preview=true&treeid=3847719104BE0678&nowtreeid=5125C5DE158A5D51&tid=A5A0321FF0CAD68D\n\n\nAn Outbreak of Ciprofloxacin-Resistant Serogroup B Meningococcal Disease in a Military Base, 2017\n--------------------------\nHsueh-Mei Chiang, Chien-Shun Chiou, Chuen-Sheue Chiang, Shu-Man Yao,Hao-Hsin Wu, Yu-Ning Fan, Hsin-Yi Wei\n\nOn 23 Jul 2017, a hospital in Taoyuan reported a suspected case of meningococcal disease, who was a soldier in a military base, to Taoyuan Department of Health. After investigation, another 2 soldiers who served in the same base with the index case developed symptoms of meningitis and were reported subsequently. Blood cultures from all 3 cases yielded serogroup B _Neisseria meningitidis_ with indistinguishable pulsed-field gel electrophoresis patterns. A total of 114 contacts received chemoprophylaxis with rifampin or ciprofloxacin. Nevertheless, the hospital laboratory found that the isolate from the index case was resistant to ciprofloxacin. Of the 98 contacts receiving ciprofloxacin as initial chemoprophylaxis, 54 contacts were offered azithromycin, while the rest 44 contacts declined. No secondary cases were identified in the contacts during the one-month follow-up period. The outbreak underscores the importance of antimicrobial surveillance of _Neisseria meningitidis_. The antimicrobial profiles of isolates from the cases should be reviewed and taken into consideration in terms of chemoprophylaxis for contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Angela Song-En Huang\n\n[Household and other close contacts of persons with invasive meningococcal disease have a higher risk for carriage and invasive disease, for which they should receive antibiotic chemoprophylaxis to eliminate nasopharyngeal carriage of _N. meningitidis_ as soon as possible. Ciprofloxacin has been an effective single-dose oral chemoprophylaxis agent. However, sporadic isolates ciprofloxacin-resistant meningococci disease began to appear in the Americas, Europe, Australia, China, and India. As a result, in 2008, the U.S. CDC recommended ciprofloxacin should no longer be used for chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal disease in communities where fiprofloxacin-resistant strains have been identified (selected U.S. counties in North Dakota and Minnesota). Ceftriaxone and rifampin are alternative agents (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm). Azithromycin is also recommended in communities where ciprofloxacin resistance has been detected (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/surv-manual/chpt08-mening.html).\n\nMaps of Taiwan can be seen at http://www.mapsofworld.com/taiwan/taiwan-political-map.htm and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/193. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2017\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan (02): fatal, military base, comment\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base\n.................................................ml/msp/ml/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taoyuan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MILITARY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ceftriaxone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5735431", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Fiji (02): fatal, children", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5735431", "date": "2018-03-21 13:20:37", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - FIJI: FATAL\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 2018 10:22 FJT\nSource: FBC (Fiji Broadcasting Corporation) [edited]\nhttp://www.fbc.com.fj/fiji/61292/health-ministry-declares-meningococcal-disease-outbreak-\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has declared an outbreak of meningococcal disease in Fiji. Over recent years Fiji has had an increase in cases of meningococcal disease. Prior to 2016, there were 1 to 10 cases per year reported. In 2016 there were 29 cases, and in 2017 there were 48 cases. In 2018, there have been 18 cases as of [21 Feb 2018].\n\nEven with the recent increase in cases, meningococcal disease remains uncommon in Fiji; however, this disease has a high death rate. According to WHO, without appropriate medical treatment, up to 5 per cent of people who get the disease will die. Most people who get the disease, and are treated appropriately, will recover fully; however 10-15 per cent will still die, and around 2 per cent will have permanent disabilities, including severe brain damage.\n\nIn 2017, 14.4 per cent of all people who had meningococcal disease in Fiji died. To put this in context, the death rate for dengue fever in Fiji is 0.4-0.6 per cent annually, even during outbreaks. This is why the Ministry of Health and Medical Services is taking nationwide action.\n\nThe meningococcal disease bacteria are not easily transmitted but are spread from person to person via transfer of saliva or spit. This can happen when a person with the bacteria coughs on an uninfected person, or deeply kisses an uninfected person on the mouth. It may also be spread through sharing of drinks from the same glass/cup, water bottle or bowl, such as kava or taki alcohol at a nightclub. Babies and children under the age of 5 frequently put things into their mouths, therefore they are also at risk of getting the bacteria.\n\n[byline: Akosita Talei]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above fails to characterize the patients with invasive meningococcal disease; for example, were they part of the population at increased risk for meningococcal disease because of age; a medical condition (complement component deficiencies), HIV infection, or absent spleen; travel or residence in countries in which the disease is common; or being a college student or military recruit living in a residence hall. We are also not told the meningococcal serogroups involved.\n\nHowever, ProMED-mail reported in 2017 that a total of 8 cases, including 1 fatal case, of meningococcal serogroup C meningitis occurred on the campus of St John's College, a Roman Catholic secondary school located on the Fiji island of Ovalau (see alsos below). In 2015, 590 students were enrolled at the school, the majority coming to Fiji from Papua New Guinea (http://www.sjcawaci.school.fj).\n\nIn Fiji, infant, childhood, adolescent immunization schedules do not include a meningococcal vaccine: http://www.health.gov.fj/PDFs/policy/EPI%20Policy%202013-2016.pdf.\n\nFiji is an island nation of more than 330 islands in Melanesia in the South Pacific Ocean about 2000 km (1300 miles) north east of New Zealand's North Island (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiji). Fiji is divided into 4 major divisions, Central, Eastern, Northern, and Western, and 14 provinces. For a map of Fiji's divisions, see http://www.geographicguide.com/pictures/map-fiji.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Fiji is available at <http://healthmap.org/promed/p/167 - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2017\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Fiji (02): (LM) college, sg C 20170801.5220233\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Fiji: (LM) college 20170713.5171669\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Melanesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5727647", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, undiagnosed illness - Nigeria (03): fatal, schoolchildren", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5727647", "date": "2018-03-21 13:20:37", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - FIJI: FATAL\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 2018 10:22 FJT\nSource: FBC (Fiji Broadcasting Corporation) [edited]\nhttp://www.fbc.com.fj/fiji/61292/health-ministry-declares-meningococcal-disease-outbreak-\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has declared an outbreak of meningococcal disease in Fiji. In 2015, 590 students were enrolled at the school, the majority coming to Fiji from Papua New Guinea (http://www.sjcawaci.school.fj).\n\nIn Fiji, infant, childhood, adolescent immunization schedules do not include a meningococcal vaccine: http://www.health.gov.fj/PDFs/policy/EPI%20Policy%202013-2016.pdf.\n\nFiji is an island nation of more than 330 islands in Melanesia in the South Pacific Ocean about 2000 km (1300 miles) north east of New Zealand's North Island (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiji). Fiji is divided into 4 major divisions, Central, Eastern, Northern, and Western, and 14 provinces. For a map of Fiji's divisions, see http://www.geographicguide.com/pictures/map-fiji.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Fiji is available at <http://healthmap.org/promed/p/167 - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2017\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Fiji (02): (LM) college, sg C 20170801.5220233\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Fiji: (LM) college 20170713.5171669\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Melanesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5722030", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03): (KN) fatal, sgA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5722030", "date": "2018-03-21 13:20:37", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - FIJI: FATAL\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 2018 10:22 FJT\nSource: FBC (Fiji Broadcasting Corporation) [edited]\nhttp://www.fbc.com.fj/fiji/61292/health-ministry-declares-meningococcal-disease-outbreak-\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has declared an outbreak of meningococcal disease in Fiji. Over recent years Fiji has had an increase in cases of meningococcal disease. Prior to 2016, there were 1 to 10 cases per year reported. In 2016 there were 29 cases, and in 2017 there were 48 cases. In 2018, there have been 18 cases as of [21 Feb 2018].\n\nEven with the recent increase in cases, meningococcal disease remains uncommon in Fiji; however, this disease has a high death rate. According to WHO, without appropriate medical treatment, up to 5 per cent of people who get the disease will die. Most people who get the disease, and are treated appropriately, will recover fully; however 10-15 per cent will still die, and around 2 per cent will have permanent disabilities, including severe brain damage.\n\nIn 2017, 14.4 per cent of all people who had meningococcal disease in Fiji died. To put this in context, the death rate for dengue fever in Fiji is 0.4-0.6 per cent annually, even during outbreaks. This is why the Ministry of Health and Medical Services is taking nationwide action.\n\nThe meningococcal disease bacteria are not easily transmitted but are spread from person to person via transfer of saliva or spit. This can happen when a person with the bacteria coughs on an uninfected person, or deeply kisses an uninfected person on the mouth. It may also be spread through sharing of drinks from the same glass/cup, water bottle or bowl, such as kava or taki alcohol at a nightclub. Babies and children under the age of 5 frequently put things into their mouths, therefore they are also at risk of getting the bacteria.\n\n[byline: Akosita Talei]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above fails to characterize the patients with invasive meningococcal disease; for example, were they part of the population at increased risk for meningococcal disease because of age; a medical condition (complement component deficiencies), HIV infection, or absent spleen; travel or residence in countries in which the disease is common; or being a college student or military recruit living in a residence hall. We are also not told the meningococcal serogroups involved.\n\nHowever, ProMED-mail reported in 2017 that a total of 8 cases, including 1 fatal case, of meningococcal serogroup C meningitis occurred on the campus of St John's College, a Roman Catholic secondary school located on the Fiji island of Ovalau (see alsos below). In 2015, 590 students were enrolled at the school, the majority coming to Fiji from Papua New Guinea (http://www.sjcawaci.school.fj).\n\nIn Fiji, infant, childhood, adolescent immunization schedules do not include a meningococcal vaccine: http://www.health.gov.fj/PDFs/policy/EPI%20Policy%202013-2016.pdf.\n\nFiji is an island nation of more than 330 islands in Melanesia in the South Pacific Ocean about 2000 km (1300 miles) north east of New Zealand's North Island (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiji). Fiji is divided into 4 major divisions, Central, Eastern, Northern, and Western, and 14 provinces. For a map of Fiji's divisions, see http://www.geographicguide.com/pictures/map-fiji.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Fiji is available at <http://healthmap.org/promed/p/167 - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2017\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Fiji (02): (LM) college, sg C 20170801.5220233\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Fiji: (LM) college 20170713.5171669\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Melanesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5720372", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): fatal, sgA, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5720372", "date": "2018-03-21 13:20:37", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - FIJI: FATAL\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 20 2018 10:22 FJT\nSource: FBC (Fiji Broadcasting Corporation) [edited]\nhttp://www.fbc.com.fj/fiji/61292/health-ministry-declares-meningococcal-disease-outbreak-\n\n\nThe Health Ministry has declared an outbreak of meningococcal disease in Fiji. Over recent years Fiji has had an increase in cases of meningococcal disease. Prior to 2016, there were 1 to 10 cases per year reported. In 2016 there were 29 cases, and in 2017 there were 48 cases. In 2018, there have been 18 cases as of [21 Feb 2018].\n\nEven with the recent increase in cases, meningococcal disease remains uncommon in Fiji; however, this disease has a high death rate. According to WHO, without appropriate medical treatment, up to 5 per cent of people who get the disease will die. Most people who get the disease, and are treated appropriately, will recover fully; however 10-15 per cent will still die, and around 2 per cent will have permanent disabilities, including severe brain damage.\n\nIn 2017, 14.4 per cent of all people who had meningococcal disease in Fiji died. To put this in context, the death rate for dengue fever in Fiji is 0.4-0.6 per cent annually, even during outbreaks. This is why the Ministry of Health and Medical Services is taking nationwide action.\n\nThe meningococcal disease bacteria are not easily transmitted but are spread from person to person via transfer of saliva or spit. This can happen when a person with the bacteria coughs on an uninfected person, or deeply kisses an uninfected person on the mouth. It may also be spread through sharing of drinks from the same glass/cup, water bottle or bowl, such as kava or taki alcohol at a nightclub. Babies and children under the age of 5 frequently put things into their mouths, therefore they are also at risk of getting the bacteria.\n\n[byline: Akosita Talei]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above fails to characterize the patients with invasive meningococcal disease; for example, were they part of the population at increased risk for meningococcal disease because of age; a medical condition (complement component deficiencies), HIV infection, or absent spleen; travel or residence in countries in which the disease is common; or being a college student or military recruit living in a residence hall. We are also not told the meningococcal serogroups involved.\n\nHowever, ProMED-mail reported in 2017 that a total of 8 cases, including 1 fatal case, of meningococcal serogroup C meningitis occurred on the campus of St John's College, a Roman Catholic secondary school located on the Fiji island of Ovalau (see alsos below). In 2015, 590 students were enrolled at the school, the majority coming to Fiji from Papua New Guinea (http://www.sjcawaci.school.fj).\n\nIn Fiji, infant, childhood, adolescent immunization schedules do not include a meningococcal vaccine: http://www.health.gov.fj/PDFs/policy/EPI%20Policy%202013-2016.pdf.\n\nFiji is an island nation of more than 330 islands in Melanesia in the South Pacific Ocean about 2000 km (1300 miles) north east of New Zealand's North Island (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiji). Fiji is divided into 4 major divisions, Central, Eastern, Northern, and Western, and 14 provinces. For a map of Fiji's divisions, see http://www.geographicguide.com/pictures/map-fiji.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Fiji is available at <http://healthmap.org/promed/p/167 - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2017\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Fiji (02): (LM) college, sg C 20170801.5220233\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Fiji: (LM) college 20170713.5171669\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["dengue", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Melanesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5672461", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Nigeria: fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5672461", "date": "2017-12-22 14:13:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (07): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017 06:01 PM PST\nSource: Bend Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.bendbulletin.com/exports/newsletters/main/5858299-151/osu-requires-vaccine-amid-meningococcal-outbreak\n\n\nA 6th case in a meningococcal disease outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University [OSU] prompted school officials to require all students under age 25 be vaccinated for meningococcal B disease by [15 Feb 2018]. School officials did not detail how they would enforce the vaccination requirement but indicated they would have rules that could not be easily circumvented. \"If you are not vaccinated against this disease and you are a student on that campus, you are at risk for meningococcal infection,\" said Dr Paul Cieslak, medical director for communicable diseases and immunizations at the Oregon Health Authority Public Health Division. \"We do feel that now, because there is a break between classes, that this is the best time for students to get vaccinated.\"\n\nMeningococcal disease is not a highly contagious disease, but it has a 100 percent fatality rate without antibiotic treatment. Even with antibiotics, some 15 percent of those infected will die. Another 15 to 20 percent will incur long-term consequences such as brain damage or the loss of fingers or limbs. \"This disease can progress from sort of feeling like you have the flu and feeling crummy to being catastrophic very quickly,\" said Charlie Fautin, deputy director of the Benton County Health Department. \"We've been very fortunate in this outbreak. The 5 previous students all made full recoveries.\"\n\nThe outbreak began in November 2016 when 2 students were hospitalized with meningococcal B disease in less than a week. A 3rd student was diagnosed in March [2017], prompting a formal declaration of an outbreak.\n\nSchool officials organized 2 mass vaccination clinics in the spring and 3 more this fall [2017]. Vaccination efforts mainly targeted students with frequent close contact, including those living in residences and group housing, and on athletic teams. The school already had a requirement to get a meningococcal vaccine that protects against the A, C, Y, and W strains of the disease. But that vaccine offers no protection against the B strain that is currently circulating on the Corvallis campus. The school revised its vaccination guidelines for the current school year, requiring all incoming freshmen and transfer students to be vaccinated specifically for meningococcal B disease by the 1st week of November [2017] in order to register for winter term classes.\n\nBut a 4th student was diagnosed in October and a 5th in November [2017] while home for Thanksgiving [23 Nov 2017] outside of Corvallis. The 6th case was a 21-year-old student hospitalized [17 Dec 2017] while visiting family. Testing to confirm the strain has not been completed.\n\n\"We realize now, with this case which involves an older student not living in congregate housing, like residence halls or group living, that we need to up our requirements,\" said Steve Clark, OSU vice president for university relations and marketing, who has spearheaded the school's response to the outbreak.\n\nThe standard approach with a single case of meningococcal disease is to provide antibiotics to those in close contact with the infected person. But as the outbreak spread across the campus, with no obvious link between the 6 cases, officials had to broaden the scope of their interventions. \"The problem is the cat's out of the bag. It's spread completely through the campus,\" Cieslak said. \"It's not like it's in one dorm, one fraternity or one athletic team. Therefore the only way to protect people is to get them all immune.\"\n\nMeningococcal disease can include meningitis, an infection of the fluids that line the brain and spinal cord. Meningitis symptoms can include fever, headache, stiff neck, nausea and confusion. The bacteria can also cause a blood infection, known as meningococcemia, with symptoms such as fever, shaking chills, rash, fatigue, severe aches and pains and rapid breathing. The disease is spread when a healthy person comes in close contact with an infected person's nose or throat fluids, such as droplets from a sneeze, spit or saliva. It occurs most often among large groups of people living in close quarters, such as in university residences, group housing or fraternities or sororities. The bacteria are being spread from student to student on campus with most infections not causing recognizable symptoms. \"We don't know who they are, and we don't know who it's going to strike next,\" Cieslak said.\n\nPublic health officials urged families and friends to be on the lookout for symptoms of meningococcal disease, and recommend that doctors have a low threshold for suspecting the condition, particularly in OSU students.\n\nIn 2015, the University of Oregon had a meningococcal B outbreak affecting 6 students, one of whom died. The university held 4 mass vaccination clinics with the goal of immunizing all undergraduate students, but according to public health officials, only an estimated 6 percent of students were fully vaccinated.\n\n\"The best prevention is vaccination,\" Fautin said. \"This is the proven way to disrupt these kinds of outbreaks and our uptake unfortunately has not been as great as we would like.\" 2 brands of meningococcal vaccine are licensed for use in the United States from age 10 to 25. Bexsoro requires 2 doses given at least one month apart for full coverage. Trumemba requires 3 doses, with follow-up doses one month and 6 months after the 1st. Cieslak said a single dose of either vaccine is likely to provide only 40 to 60 percent effectiveness, compared to 80 to 90 percent effectiveness for the full series. The vaccines are not interchangeable so follow-up doses should be of the same brand.\n\nDoctors and county health officials in Central Oregon have been on alert for cases, particularly those involving college students. Deschutes County Health Services offers the vaccine and is compiling a list of pharmacies that offer it, including Rite Aid, Walgreens, Fred Meyer, and Safeway on Century Drive. St Charles Health System offers the vaccines in its family care and school-based clinics. The vaccine costs about USD 300 but is covered by insurance plans. Some university students, however, had trouble getting insurance coverage for the vaccine on campus because the providers were out-of-network. The Oregon Legislature passed House Bill 3276 to address that issue during outbreaks, and the governor signs the bill into law in August [2017].\n\nThe holiday break, however, often brings students back to their familiar doctors and pharmacists, or back home where parents can ensure their children get vaccinated. Cieslak stressed the importance of prevention as well as timely treatment if symptoms arise. \"It's a nasty virulent bacterium that can affect even perfectly healthy people,\" he said. \"And if you have it in your spinal fluid and you don't get antibiotics promptly, you are going to die.\"\n\n[Byline: Markian Hawryluk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in March 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298).\n\nIn October 2017, we posted a report of a 4th OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD; although we were not told at that time what the serogroup of the pathogen was, it apparently was also serogroup B (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497) and in Nov 2017 we were told of a 5th OSU student has developed IMD due to serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532). Now there is a 6th OSU student with IMD, but confirmation of the serogroup is still pending.\n\nThese cases occurred despite campus-wide vaccination programs with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD.\n\nOSU is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). OSU has a total student enrollment of 30 354. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nOregon State University, Oregon: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733\nOregon county map: http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5662466", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - South Sudan: (Imatong) fatal, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5662466", "date": "2017-12-22 14:13:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (07): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017 06:01 PM PST\nSource: Bend Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.bendbulletin.com/exports/newsletters/main/5858299-151/osu-requires-vaccine-amid-meningococcal-outbreak\n\n\nA 6th case in a meningococcal disease outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University [OSU] prompted school officials to require all students under age 25 be vaccinated for meningococcal B disease by [15 Feb 2018]. School officials did not detail how they would enforce the vaccination requirement but indicated they would have rules that could not be easily circumvented. \"If you are not vaccinated against this disease and you are a student on that campus, you are at risk for meningococcal infection,\" said Dr Paul Cieslak, medical director for communicable diseases and immunizations at the Oregon Health Authority Public Health Division. \"We do feel that now, because there is a break between classes, that this is the best time for students to get vaccinated.\"\n\nMeningococcal disease is not a highly contagious disease, but it has a 100 percent fatality rate without antibiotic treatment. Even with antibiotics, some 15 percent of those infected will die. Another 15 to 20 percent will incur long-term consequences such as brain damage or the loss of fingers or limbs. \"This disease can progress from sort of feeling like you have the flu and feeling crummy to being catastrophic very quickly,\" said Charlie Fautin, deputy director of the Benton County Health Department. \"We've been very fortunate in this outbreak. The 5 previous students all made full recoveries.\"\n\nThe outbreak began in November 2016 when 2 students were hospitalized with meningococcal B disease in less than a week. A 3rd student was diagnosed in March [2017], prompting a formal declaration of an outbreak.\n\nSchool officials organized 2 mass vaccination clinics in the spring and 3 more this fall [2017]. Vaccination efforts mainly targeted students with frequent close contact, including those living in residences and group housing, and on athletic teams. The school already had a requirement to get a meningococcal vaccine that protects against the A, C, Y, and W strains of the disease. But that vaccine offers no protection against the B strain that is currently circulating on the Corvallis campus. The school revised its vaccination guidelines for the current school year, requiring all incoming freshmen and transfer students to be vaccinated specifically for meningococcal B disease by the 1st week of November [2017] in order to register for winter term classes.\n\nBut a 4th student was diagnosed in October and a 5th in November [2017] while home for Thanksgiving [23 Nov 2017] outside of Corvallis. The 6th case was a 21-year-old student hospitalized [17 Dec 2017] while visiting family. Testing to confirm the strain has not been completed.\n\n\"We realize now, with this case which involves an older student not living in congregate housing, like residence halls or group living, that we need to up our requirements,\" said Steve Clark, OSU vice president for university relations and marketing, who has spearheaded the school's response to the outbreak.\n\nThe standard approach with a single case of meningococcal disease is to provide antibiotics to those in close contact with the infected person. But as the outbreak spread across the campus, with no obvious link between the 6 cases, officials had to broaden the scope of their interventions. \"The problem is the cat's out of the bag. It's spread completely through the campus,\" Cieslak said. \"It's not like it's in one dorm, one fraternity or one athletic team. Therefore the only way to protect people is to get them all immune.\"\n\nMeningococcal disease can include meningitis, an infection of the fluids that line the brain and spinal cord. Meningitis symptoms can include fever, headache, stiff neck, nausea and confusion. The bacteria can also cause a blood infection, known as meningococcemia, with symptoms such as fever, shaking chills, rash, fatigue, severe aches and pains and rapid breathing. The disease is spread when a healthy person comes in close contact with an infected person's nose or throat fluids, such as droplets from a sneeze, spit or saliva. It occurs most often among large groups of people living in close quarters, such as in university residences, group housing or fraternities or sororities. The bacteria are being spread from student to student on campus with most infections not causing recognizable symptoms. \"We don't know who they are, and we don't know who it's going to strike next,\" Cieslak said.\n\nPublic health officials urged families and friends to be on the lookout for symptoms of meningococcal disease, and recommend that doctors have a low threshold for suspecting the condition, particularly in OSU students.\n\nIn 2015, the University of Oregon had a meningococcal B outbreak affecting 6 students, one of whom died. The university held 4 mass vaccination clinics with the goal of immunizing all undergraduate students, but according to public health officials, only an estimated 6 percent of students were fully vaccinated.\n\n\"The best prevention is vaccination,\" Fautin said. \"This is the proven way to disrupt these kinds of outbreaks and our uptake unfortunately has not been as great as we would like.\" 2 brands of meningococcal vaccine are licensed for use in the United States from age 10 to 25. Bexsoro requires 2 doses given at least one month apart for full coverage. Trumemba requires 3 doses, with follow-up doses one month and 6 months after the 1st. Cieslak said a single dose of either vaccine is likely to provide only 40 to 60 percent effectiveness, compared to 80 to 90 percent effectiveness for the full series. The vaccines are not interchangeable so follow-up doses should be of the same brand.\n\nDoctors and county health officials in Central Oregon have been on alert for cases, particularly those involving college students. Deschutes County Health Services offers the vaccine and is compiling a list of pharmacies that offer it, including Rite Aid, Walgreens, Fred Meyer, and Safeway on Century Drive. St Charles Health System offers the vaccines in its family care and school-based clinics. The vaccine costs about USD 300 but is covered by insurance plans. Some university students, however, had trouble getting insurance coverage for the vaccine on campus because the providers were out-of-network. The Oregon Legislature passed House Bill 3276 to address that issue during outbreaks, and the governor signs the bill into law in August [2017].\n\nThe holiday break, however, often brings students back to their familiar doctors and pharmacists, or back home where parents can ensure their children get vaccinated. Cieslak stressed the importance of prevention as well as timely treatment if symptoms arise. \"It's a nasty virulent bacterium that can affect even perfectly healthy people,\" he said. \"And if you have it in your spinal fluid and you don't get antibiotics promptly, you are going to die.\"\n\n[Byline: Markian Hawryluk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in March 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298).\n\nIn October 2017, we posted a report of a 4th OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD; although we were not told at that time what the serogroup of the pathogen was, it apparently was also serogroup B (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497) and in Nov 2017 we were told of a 5th OSU student has developed IMD due to serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532). Now there is a 6th OSU student with IMD, but confirmation of the serogroup is still pending.\n\nThese cases occurred despite campus-wide vaccination programs with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD.\n\nOSU is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). OSU has a total student enrollment of 30 354. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nOregon State University, Oregon: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733\nOregon county map: http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5621382", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Meningitis - Spain (03): listeriosis, raw soft ewe cheese, Portugal, recall, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5621382", "date": "2017-12-22 14:13:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (07): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017 06:01 PM PST\nSource: Bend Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.bendbulletin.com/exports/newsletters/main/5858299-151/osu-requires-vaccine-amid-meningococcal-outbreak\n\n\nA 6th case in a meningococcal disease outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University [OSU] prompted school officials to require all students under age 25 be vaccinated for meningococcal B disease by [15 Feb 2018]. Some university students, however, had trouble getting insurance coverage for the vaccine on campus because the providers were out-of-network. The Oregon Legislature passed House Bill 3276 to address that issue during outbreaks, and the governor signs the bill into law in August [2017].\n\nThe holiday break, however, often brings students back to their familiar doctors and pharmacists, or back home where parents can ensure their children get vaccinated. Cieslak stressed the importance of prevention as well as timely treatment if symptoms arise. \"It's a nasty virulent bacterium that can affect even perfectly healthy people,\" he said. \"And if you have it in your spinal fluid and you don't get antibiotics promptly, you are going to die.\"\n\n[Byline: Markian Hawryluk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in March 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298).\n\nIn October 2017, we posted a report of a 4th OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD; although we were not told at that time what the serogroup of the pathogen was, it apparently was also serogroup B (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497) and in Nov 2017 we were told of a 5th OSU student has developed IMD due to serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532). Now there is a 6th OSU student with IMD, but confirmation of the serogroup is still pending.\n\nThese cases occurred despite campus-wide vaccination programs with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD.\n\nOSU is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). OSU has a total student enrollment of 30 354. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nOregon State University, Oregon: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733\nOregon county map: http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5618781", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Meningitis - Spain: (MD) foodborne, raw cheese, recall, alert, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5618781", "date": "2017-12-22 14:13:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (07): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017 06:01 PM PST\nSource: Bend Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.bendbulletin.com/exports/newsletters/main/5858299-151/osu-requires-vaccine-amid-meningococcal-outbreak\n\n\nA 6th case in a meningococcal disease outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University [OSU] prompted school officials to require all students under age 25 be vaccinated for meningococcal B disease by [15 Feb 2018]. School officials did not detail how they would enforce the vaccination requirement but indicated they would have rules that could not be easily circumvented. \"If you are not vaccinated against this disease and you are a student on that campus, you are at risk for meningococcal infection,\" said Dr Paul Cieslak, medical director for communicable diseases and immunizations at the Oregon Health Authority Public Health Division. \"We do feel that now, because there is a break between classes, that this is the best time for students to get vaccinated.\"\n\nMeningococcal disease is not a highly contagious disease, but it has a 100 percent fatality rate without antibiotic treatment. Even with antibiotics, some 15 percent of those infected will die. Another 15 to 20 percent will incur long-term consequences such as brain damage or the loss of fingers or limbs. \"This disease can progress from sort of feeling like you have the flu and feeling crummy to being catastrophic very quickly,\" said Charlie Fautin, deputy director of the Benton County Health Department. \"We've been very fortunate in this outbreak. The 5 previous students all made full recoveries.\"\n\nThe outbreak began in November 2016 when 2 students were hospitalized with meningococcal B disease in less than a week. A 3rd student was diagnosed in March [2017], prompting a formal declaration of an outbreak.\n\nSchool officials organized 2 mass vaccination clinics in the spring and 3 more this fall [2017]. Vaccination efforts mainly targeted students with frequent close contact, including those living in residences and group housing, and on athletic teams. The school already had a requirement to get a meningococcal vaccine that protects against the A, C, Y, and W strains of the disease. But that vaccine offers no protection against the B strain that is currently circulating on the Corvallis campus. The school revised its vaccination guidelines for the current school year, requiring all incoming freshmen and transfer students to be vaccinated specifically for meningococcal B disease by the 1st week of November [2017] in order to register for winter term classes.\n\nBut a 4th student was diagnosed in October and a 5th in November [2017] while home for Thanksgiving [23 Nov 2017] outside of Corvallis. The 6th case was a 21-year-old student hospitalized [17 Dec 2017] while visiting family. Testing to confirm the strain has not been completed.\n\n\"We realize now, with this case which involves an older student not living in congregate housing, like residence halls or group living, that we need to up our requirements,\" said Steve Clark, OSU vice president for university relations and marketing, who has spearheaded the school's response to the outbreak.\n\nThe standard approach with a single case of meningococcal disease is to provide antibiotics to those in close contact with the infected person. But as the outbreak spread across the campus, with no obvious link between the 6 cases, officials had to broaden the scope of their interventions. \"The problem is the cat's out of the bag. It's spread completely through the campus,\" Cieslak said. \"It's not like it's in one dorm, one fraternity or one athletic team. Therefore the only way to protect people is to get them all immune.\"\n\nMeningococcal disease can include meningitis, an infection of the fluids that line the brain and spinal cord. Meningitis symptoms can include fever, headache, stiff neck, nausea and confusion. The bacteria can also cause a blood infection, known as meningococcemia, with symptoms such as fever, shaking chills, rash, fatigue, severe aches and pains and rapid breathing. The disease is spread when a healthy person comes in close contact with an infected person's nose or throat fluids, such as droplets from a sneeze, spit or saliva. It occurs most often among large groups of people living in close quarters, such as in university residences, group housing or fraternities or sororities. The bacteria are being spread from student to student on campus with most infections not causing recognizable symptoms. \"We don't know who they are, and we don't know who it's going to strike next,\" Cieslak said.\n\nPublic health officials urged families and friends to be on the lookout for symptoms of meningococcal disease, and recommend that doctors have a low threshold for suspecting the condition, particularly in OSU students.\n\nIn 2015, the University of Oregon had a meningococcal B outbreak affecting 6 students, one of whom died. The university held 4 mass vaccination clinics with the goal of immunizing all undergraduate students, but according to public health officials, only an estimated 6 percent of students were fully vaccinated.\n\n\"The best prevention is vaccination,\" Fautin said. \"This is the proven way to disrupt these kinds of outbreaks and our uptake unfortunately has not been as great as we would like.\" 2 brands of meningococcal vaccine are licensed for use in the United States from age 10 to 25. Bexsoro requires 2 doses given at least one month apart for full coverage. Trumemba requires 3 doses, with follow-up doses one month and 6 months after the 1st. Cieslak said a single dose of either vaccine is likely to provide only 40 to 60 percent effectiveness, compared to 80 to 90 percent effectiveness for the full series. The vaccines are not interchangeable so follow-up doses should be of the same brand.\n\nDoctors and county health officials in Central Oregon have been on alert for cases, particularly those involving college students. Deschutes County Health Services offers the vaccine and is compiling a list of pharmacies that offer it, including Rite Aid, Walgreens, Fred Meyer, and Safeway on Century Drive. St Charles Health System offers the vaccines in its family care and school-based clinics. The vaccine costs about USD 300 but is covered by insurance plans. Some university students, however, had trouble getting insurance coverage for the vaccine on campus because the providers were out-of-network. The Oregon Legislature passed House Bill 3276 to address that issue during outbreaks, and the governor signs the bill into law in August [2017].\n\nThe holiday break, however, often brings students back to their familiar doctors and pharmacists, or back home where parents can ensure their children get vaccinated. Cieslak stressed the importance of prevention as well as timely treatment if symptoms arise. \"It's a nasty virulent bacterium that can affect even perfectly healthy people,\" he said. \"And if you have it in your spinal fluid and you don't get antibiotics promptly, you are going to die.\"\n\n[Byline: Markian Hawryluk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in March 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298).\n\nIn October 2017, we posted a report of a 4th OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD; although we were not told at that time what the serogroup of the pathogen was, it apparently was also serogroup B (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497) and in Nov 2017 we were told of a 5th OSU student has developed IMD due to serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532). Now there is a 6th OSU student with IMD, but confirmation of the serogroup is still pending.\n\nThese cases occurred despite campus-wide vaccination programs with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD.\n\nOSU is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). OSU has a total student enrollment of 30 354. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nOregon State University, Oregon: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733\nOregon county map: http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5598770", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Cryptococcus neoformans - USA: (CA) meningitis, immunocompet., marijuana smoker", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5598770", "date": "2017-12-22 14:13:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (07): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017 06:01 PM PST\nSource: Bend Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.bendbulletin.com/exports/newsletters/main/5858299-151/osu-requires-vaccine-amid-meningococcal-outbreak\n\n\nA 6th case in a meningococcal disease outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University [OSU] prompted school officials to require all students under age 25 be vaccinated for meningococcal B disease by [15 Feb 2018]. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5568890", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) middle school student", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5568890", "date": "2017-12-22 14:13:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (07): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017 06:01 PM PST\nSource: Bend Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.bendbulletin.com/exports/newsletters/main/5858299-151/osu-requires-vaccine-amid-meningococcal-outbreak\n\n\nA 6th case in a meningococcal disease outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University [OSU] prompted school officials to require all students under age 25 be vaccinated for meningococcal B disease by [15 Feb 2018]. School officials did not detail how they would enforce the vaccination requirement but indicated they would have rules that could not be easily circumvented. \"If you are not vaccinated against this disease and you are a student on that campus, you are at risk for meningococcal infection,\" said Dr Paul Cieslak, medical director for communicable diseases and immunizations at the Oregon Health Authority Public Health Division. \"We do feel that now, because there is a break between classes, that this is the best time for students to get vaccinated.\"\n\nMeningococcal disease is not a highly contagious disease, but it has a 100 percent fatality rate without antibiotic treatment.
