A 3rd student was diagnosed in March [2017], prompting a formal declaration of an outbreak.\n\nSchool officials organized 2 mass vaccination clinics in the spring and 3 more this fall [2017]. Vaccination efforts mainly targeted students with frequent close contact, including those living in residences and group housing, and on athletic teams. The school already had a requirement to get a meningococcal vaccine that protects against the A, C, Y, and W strains of the disease. But that vaccine offers no protection against the B strain that is currently circulating on the Corvallis campus. The school revised its vaccination guidelines for the current school year, requiring all incoming freshmen and transfer students to be vaccinated specifically for meningococcal B disease by the 1st week of November [2017] in order to register for winter term classes.\n\nBut a 4th student was diagnosed in October and a 5th in November [2017] while home for Thanksgiving [23 Nov 2017] outside of Corvallis. The 6th case was a 21-year-old student hospitalized [17 Dec 2017] while visiting family. Testing to confirm the strain has not been completed.\n\n\"We realize now, with this case which involves an older student not living in congregate housing, like residence halls or group living, that we need to up our requirements,\" said Steve Clark, OSU vice president for university relations and marketing, who has spearheaded the school's response to the outbreak.\n\nThe standard approach with a single case of meningococcal disease is to provide antibiotics to those in close contact with the infected person. But as the outbreak spread across the campus, with no obvious link between the 6 cases, officials had to broaden the scope of their interventions. \"The problem is the cat's out of the bag. It's spread completely through the campus,\" Cieslak said. \"It's not like it's in one dorm, one fraternity or one athletic team. Therefore the only way to protect people is to get them all immune.\"\n\nMeningococcal disease can include meningitis, an infection of the fluids that line the brain and spinal cord. Meningitis symptoms can include fever, headache, stiff neck, nausea and confusion. The bacteria can also cause a blood infection, known as meningococcemia, with symptoms such as fever, shaking chills, rash, fatigue, severe aches and pains and rapid breathing. The disease is spread when a healthy person comes in close contact with an infected person's nose or throat fluids, such as droplets from a sneeze, spit or saliva. It occurs most often among large groups of people living in close quarters, such as in university residences, group housing or fraternities or sororities. The bacteria are being spread from student to student on campus with most infections not causing recognizable symptoms. \"We don't know who they are, and we don't know who it's going to strike next,\" Cieslak said.\n\nPublic health officials urged families and friends to be on the lookout for symptoms of meningococcal disease, and recommend that doctors have a low threshold for suspecting the condition, particularly in OSU students.\n\nIn 2015, the University of Oregon had a meningococcal B outbreak affecting 6 students, one of whom died. The university held 4 mass vaccination clinics with the goal of immunizing all undergraduate students, but according to public health officials, only an estimated 6 percent of students were fully vaccinated.\n\n\"The best prevention is vaccination,\" Fautin said. \"This is the proven way to disrupt these kinds of outbreaks and our uptake unfortunately has not been as great as we would like.\" 2 brands of meningococcal vaccine are licensed for use in the United States from age 10 to 25. Bexsoro requires 2 doses given at least one month apart for full coverage. Trumemba requires 3 doses, with follow-up doses one month and 6 months after the 1st. Cieslak said a single dose of either vaccine is likely to provide only 40 to 60 percent effectiveness, compared to 80 to 90 percent effectiveness for the full series. The vaccines are not interchangeable so follow-up doses should be of the same brand.\n\nDoctors and county health officials in Central Oregon have been on alert for cases, particularly those involving college students. Deschutes County Health Services offers the vaccine and is compiling a list of pharmacies that offer it, including Rite Aid, Walgreens, Fred Meyer, and Safeway on Century Drive. St Charles Health System offers the vaccines in its family care and school-based clinics. The vaccine costs about USD 300 but is covered by insurance plans. Some university students, however, had trouble getting insurance coverage for the vaccine on campus because the providers were out-of-network. The Oregon Legislature passed House Bill 3276 to address that issue during outbreaks, and the governor signs the bill into law in August [2017].\n\nThe holiday break, however, often brings students back to their familiar doctors and pharmacists, or back home where parents can ensure their children get vaccinated. Cieslak stressed the importance of prevention as well as timely treatment if symptoms arise. \"It's a nasty virulent bacterium that can affect even perfectly healthy people,\" he said. \"And if you have it in your spinal fluid and you don't get antibiotics promptly, you are going to die.\"\n\n[Byline: Markian Hawryluk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in March 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298).\n\nIn October 2017, we posted a report of a 4th OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD; although we were not told at that time what the serogroup of the pathogen was, it apparently was also serogroup B (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497) and in Nov 2017 we were told of a 5th OSU student has developed IMD due to serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532). Now there is a 6th OSU student with IMD, but confirmation of the serogroup is still pending.\n\nThese cases occurred despite campus-wide vaccination programs with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD.\n\nOSU is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). OSU has a total student enrollment of 30 354. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nOregon State University, Oregon: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733\nOregon county map: http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5520017", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (07): (OR) college, sg B", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5520017", "date": "2017-12-22 14:13:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (07): (OREGON) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Dec 2017 06:01 PM PST\nSource: Bend Bulletin [edited]\nhttp://www.bendbulletin.com/exports/newsletters/main/5858299-151/osu-requires-vaccine-amid-meningococcal-outbreak\n\n\nA 6th case in a meningococcal disease outbreak on the Corvallis campus of Oregon State University [OSU] prompted school officials to require all students under age 25 be vaccinated for meningococcal B disease by [15 Feb 2018]. School officials did not detail how they would enforce the vaccination requirement but indicated they would have rules that could not be easily circumvented. \"If you are not vaccinated against this disease and you are a student on that campus, you are at risk for meningococcal infection,\" said Dr Paul Cieslak, medical director for communicable diseases and immunizations at the Oregon Health Authority Public Health Division. \"We do feel that now, because there is a break between classes, that this is the best time for students to get vaccinated.\"\n\nMeningococcal disease is not a highly contagious disease, but it has a 100 percent fatality rate without antibiotic treatment. Even with antibiotics, some 15 percent of those infected will die. Another 15 to 20 percent will incur long-term consequences such as brain damage or the loss of fingers or limbs. \"This disease can progress from sort of feeling like you have the flu and feeling crummy to being catastrophic very quickly,\" said Charlie Fautin, deputy director of the Benton County Health Department. \"We've been very fortunate in this outbreak. The 5 previous students all made full recoveries.\"\n\nThe outbreak began in November 2016 when 2 students were hospitalized with meningococcal B disease in less than a week. A 3rd student was diagnosed in March [2017], prompting a formal declaration of an outbreak.\n\nSchool officials organized 2 mass vaccination clinics in the spring and 3 more this fall [2017]. Vaccination efforts mainly targeted students with frequent close contact, including those living in residences and group housing, and on athletic teams. The school already had a requirement to get a meningococcal vaccine that protects against the A, C, Y, and W strains of the disease. But that vaccine offers no protection against the B strain that is currently circulating on the Corvallis campus. The school revised its vaccination guidelines for the current school year, requiring all incoming freshmen and transfer students to be vaccinated specifically for meningococcal B disease by the 1st week of November [2017] in order to register for winter term classes.\n\nBut a 4th student was diagnosed in October and a 5th in November [2017] while home for Thanksgiving [23 Nov 2017] outside of Corvallis. The 6th case was a 21-year-old student hospitalized [17 Dec 2017] while visiting family. Testing to confirm the strain has not been completed.\n\n\"We realize now, with this case which involves an older student not living in congregate housing, like residence halls or group living, that we need to up our requirements,\" said Steve Clark, OSU vice president for university relations and marketing, who has spearheaded the school's response to the outbreak.\n\nThe standard approach with a single case of meningococcal disease is to provide antibiotics to those in close contact with the infected person. But as the outbreak spread across the campus, with no obvious link between the 6 cases, officials had to broaden the scope of their interventions. \"The problem is the cat's out of the bag. It's spread completely through the campus,\" Cieslak said. \"It's not like it's in one dorm, one fraternity or one athletic team. Therefore the only way to protect people is to get them all immune.\"\n\nMeningococcal disease can include meningitis, an infection of the fluids that line the brain and spinal cord. Meningitis symptoms can include fever, headache, stiff neck, nausea and confusion. The bacteria can also cause a blood infection, known as meningococcemia, with symptoms such as fever, shaking chills, rash, fatigue, severe aches and pains and rapid breathing. The disease is spread when a healthy person comes in close contact with an infected person's nose or throat fluids, such as droplets from a sneeze, spit or saliva. It occurs most often among large groups of people living in close quarters, such as in university residences, group housing or fraternities or sororities. The bacteria are being spread from student to student on campus with most infections not causing recognizable symptoms. \"We don't know who they are, and we don't know who it's going to strike next,\" Cieslak said.\n\nPublic health officials urged families and friends to be on the lookout for symptoms of meningococcal disease, and recommend that doctors have a low threshold for suspecting the condition, particularly in OSU students.\n\nIn 2015, the University of Oregon had a meningococcal B outbreak affecting 6 students, one of whom died. The university held 4 mass vaccination clinics with the goal of immunizing all undergraduate students, but according to public health officials, only an estimated 6 percent of students were fully vaccinated.\n\n\"The best prevention is vaccination,\" Fautin said. \"This is the proven way to disrupt these kinds of outbreaks and our uptake unfortunately has not been as great as we would like.\" 2 brands of meningococcal vaccine are licensed for use in the United States from age 10 to 25. Bexsoro requires 2 doses given at least one month apart for full coverage. Trumemba requires 3 doses, with follow-up doses one month and 6 months after the 1st. Cieslak said a single dose of either vaccine is likely to provide only 40 to 60 percent effectiveness, compared to 80 to 90 percent effectiveness for the full series. The vaccines are not interchangeable so follow-up doses should be of the same brand.\n\nDoctors and county health officials in Central Oregon have been on alert for cases, particularly those involving college students. Deschutes County Health Services offers the vaccine and is compiling a list of pharmacies that offer it, including Rite Aid, Walgreens, Fred Meyer, and Safeway on Century Drive. St Charles Health System offers the vaccines in its family care and school-based clinics. The vaccine costs about USD 300 but is covered by insurance plans. Some university students, however, had trouble getting insurance coverage for the vaccine on campus because the providers were out-of-network. The Oregon Legislature passed House Bill 3276 to address that issue during outbreaks, and the governor signs the bill into law in August [2017].\n\nThe holiday break, however, often brings students back to their familiar doctors and pharmacists, or back home where parents can ensure their children get vaccinated. Cieslak stressed the importance of prevention as well as timely treatment if symptoms arise. \"It's a nasty virulent bacterium that can affect even perfectly healthy people,\" he said. \"And if you have it in your spinal fluid and you don't get antibiotics promptly, you are going to die.\"\n\n[Byline: Markian Hawryluk]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In November 2016, ProMED-mail posted a report that 2 Oregon State University (OSU) students in Corvallis, Oregon were diagnosed with invasive meningococcal disease (IMD) due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319) and in March 2017, meningococcal serogroup B meningitis was reported in a 3rd student on the Corvallis campus (see ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298).\n\nIn October 2017, we posted a report of a 4th OSU student on the Corvallis campus with IMD; although we were not told at that time what the serogroup of the pathogen was, it apparently was also serogroup B (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497) and in Nov 2017 we were told of a 5th OSU student has developed IMD due to serogroup B (Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532). Now there is a 6th OSU student with IMD, but confirmation of the serogroup is still pending.\n\nThese cases occurred despite campus-wide vaccination programs with a meningococcal serogroup B vaccine started in November 2016 and the requirement that incoming students at OSU be vaccinated against meningococcal serogroups A, C, W, and Y. The news report above does not give the vaccination status of the latest OSU student with IMD.\n\nOSU is a coeducational, public university; the main campus is located in the city of Corvallis in the Willamette Valley of the US state of Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_State_University#Main_campus_.28Corvallis.29). OSU has a total student enrollment of 30 354. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nOregon State University, Oregon: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20733\nOregon county map: http://geology.com/county-map/oregon-county-map.gif]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B 20171130.5473532\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00", "2015-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-10-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2016-11-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Corvallis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5497099", "headline": "PRO/EDR>  Meningitis - Ghana (07): (AH) fatal, students, NOT, influenza H1N1, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5497099", "date": "2017-11-30 21:40:24", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (06): (MASSACHUSETTS) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B, MASS SEROGROUP B VACCINATION\n********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 28 Nov 2017 6:13 pm\nSource: WWLP [edited]\nhttp://wwlp.com/2017/11/28/umass-amherst-preparing-to-vaccinate-students-after-meningitis-outbreak-declared/\n\n\nUMass Amherst [University of Massachusetts at Amherst] is preparing to vaccinate all 20 000 undergraduate students following an outbreak of meningitis. This is something that UMass trains for each year, but hasn't had to do in a real-world situation since the 2009 outbreak of Swine Flu.\n\nMeningitis is a potentially deadly bacterial infection. There are 2 confirmed cases at UMass and more may be carrying the bacteria. \"This bacteria exists as a carrier state mostly and it occasionally causes disease,\" explained Dr. George Corey, the Executive Director of UMass University Health Services. \"So for every case there could be many carriers who will never become ill.\"\n\nCDC testing shows the 2 sick students, who did not know each other, had the same genetic virus, which suggests that others who don't show symptoms may have the bacteria dormant in their body. That's why UMass is holding their 1st of 4 mass vaccination clinics [Thu 30 Nov 2017] inside the Student Union.\n\n\"There's a good chance or a worrisome chance that someone else could get ill,\" said UMass Public Health Nurse Ann Becker. \"The illness is severe enough that we really don't see any of our students get this, not one, one more is too many.\" Becker recommends students avoid sharing food, drinks, and close contact, and to wash your hands. \"I am certainly worried. I've been paying attention to e-mails,\" said UMass undergraduate student [MW]. \"I personally have not gotten the shot but a lot of my friends have so I think it's in everyone's minds across campus.\"\n\nUMass wants you to know this vaccine is different than the meningitis vaccine you were required to get before you enrolled. UMass will bill your insurance, so there should be no out of pocket cost. So far, UMass has vaccinated 1500 students. Faculty and staff are not considered at risk.\n\nAs for the 2 students who already have meningitis, UMass health officials would only say they are getting positive updates.\n\n[Byline: Matt Caron]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A primary case is one that occurs in the absence of previous known close contact with another case-patient.\n\nAn outbreak is defined by the occurrence of at least 3 confirmed or probable primary cases of the same serogroup meningococcal disease during a period of 3 months or less, with a resulting primary attack rate of 10 or more cases per 100 000 population. Two primary cases caused by serogroup B in 21 000 UMass Amherst undergraduates gives a primary attack rate of 9.5 / 100 000.\n\nIn some instances the attack rate will be greater than 10 cases per 100 000 population with only 2 cases. In these situations, vaccination may be considered after only 2 primary cases are identified (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6202a3.htm). For outbreaks caused by serogroup B, the CDC recommends vaccination with a serogroup B meningococcal vaccine for anyone 10 years or older identified as being at increased risk.\n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal disease are usually caused by the same or closely related strains. Molecular genotyping will help characterize an outbreak clone. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/224.\n\n]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (05): (MA) college, sg. This is something that UMass trains for each year, but hasn't had to do in a real-world situation since the 2009 outbreak of Swine Flu.\n\nMeningitis is a potentially deadly bacterial infection. There are 2 confirmed cases at UMass and more may be carrying the bacteria. \"This bacteria exists as a carrier state mostly and it occasionally causes disease,\" explained Dr. George Corey, the Executive Director of UMass University Health Services. \"So for every case there could be many carriers who will never become ill.\"\n\nCDC testing shows the 2 sick students, who did not know each other, had the same genetic virus, which suggests that others who don't show symptoms may have the bacteria dormant in their body. That's why UMass is holding their 1st of 4 mass vaccination clinics [Thu 30 Nov 2017] inside the Student Union.\n\n\"There's a good chance or a worrisome chance that someone else could get ill,\" said UMass Public Health Nurse Ann Becker. \"The illness is severe enough that we really don't see any of our students get this, not one, one more is too many.\" Becker recommends students avoid sharing food, drinks, and close contact, and to wash your hands. \"I am certainly worried. I've been paying attention to e-mails,\" said UMass undergraduate student [MW]. \"I personally have not gotten the shot but a lot of my friends have so I think it's in everyone's minds across campus.\"\n\nUMass wants you to know this vaccine is different than the meningitis vaccine you were required to get before you enrolled. UMass will bill your insurance, so there should be no out of pocket cost. So far, UMass has vaccinated 1500 students. Faculty and staff are not considered at risk.\n\nAs for the 2 students who already have meningitis, UMass health officials would only say they are getting positive updates.\n\n[Byline: Matt Caron]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A primary case is one that occurs in the absence of previous known close contact with another case-patient.\n\nAn outbreak is defined by the occurrence of at least 3 confirmed or probable primary cases of the same serogroup meningococcal disease during a period of 3 months or less, with a resulting primary attack rate of 10 or more cases per 100 000 population. Two primary cases caused by serogroup B in 21 000 UMass Amherst undergraduates gives a primary attack rate of 9.5 / 100 000.\n\nIn some instances the attack rate will be greater than 10 cases per 100 000 population with only 2 cases. In these situations, vaccination may be considered after only 2 primary cases are identified (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6202a3.htm). For outbreaks caused by serogroup B, the CDC recommends vaccination with a serogroup B meningococcal vaccine for anyone 10 years or older identified as being at increased risk.\n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal disease are usually caused by the same or closely related strains. Molecular genotyping will help characterize an outbreak clone. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/224.\n\n]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (05): (MA) college, sg. This is something that UMass trains for each year, but hasn't had to do in a real-world situation since the 2009 outbreak of Swine Flu.\n\nMeningitis is a potentially deadly bacterial infection. There are 2 confirmed cases at UMass and more may be carrying the bacteria. \"This bacteria exists as a carrier state mostly and it occasionally causes disease,\" explained Dr. George Corey, the Executive Director of UMass University Health Services. \"So for every case there could be many carriers who will never become ill.\"\n\nCDC testing shows the 2 sick students, who did not know each other, had the same genetic virus, which suggests that others who don't show symptoms may have the bacteria dormant in their body. That's why UMass is holding their 1st of 4 mass vaccination clinics [Thu 30 Nov 2017] inside the Student Union.\n\n\"There's a good chance or a worrisome chance that someone else could get ill,\" said UMass Public Health Nurse Ann Becker. \"The illness is severe enough that we really don't see any of our students get this, not one, one more is too many.\" Becker recommends students avoid sharing food, drinks, and close contact, and to wash your hands. \"I am certainly worried. I've been paying attention to e-mails,\" said UMass undergraduate student [MW]. \"I personally have not gotten the shot but a lot of my friends have so I think it's in everyone's minds across campus.\"\n\nUMass wants you to know this vaccine is different than the meningitis vaccine you were required to get before you enrolled. UMass will bill your insurance, so there should be no out of pocket cost. So far, UMass has vaccinated 1500 students. Faculty and staff are not considered at risk.\n\nAs for the 2 students who already have meningitis, UMass health officials would only say they are getting positive updates.\n\n[Byline: Matt Caron]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A primary case is one that occurs in the absence of previous known close contact with another case-patient.\n\nAn outbreak is defined by the occurrence of at least 3 confirmed or probable primary cases of the same serogroup meningococcal disease during a period of 3 months or less, with a resulting primary attack rate of 10 or more cases per 100 000 population. Two primary cases caused by serogroup B in 21 000 UMass Amherst undergraduates gives a primary attack rate of 9.5 / 100 000.\n\nIn some instances the attack rate will be greater than 10 cases per 100 000 population with only 2 cases. In these situations, vaccination may be considered after only 2 primary cases are identified (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6202a3.htm). For outbreaks caused by serogroup B, the CDC recommends vaccination with a serogroup B meningococcal vaccine for anyone 10 years or older identified as being at increased risk.\n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal disease are usually caused by the same or closely related strains. Molecular genotyping will help characterize an outbreak clone. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/224.\n\n]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (05): (MA) college, sg. B 20171117.5450880\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (04): (MA) college, sg. B 20171116.5448419\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (03): (OR) college, sg. B 20171105.5425383\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college 20171030.5412497\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Fiji (02): (LM) college, sg C 20170801.5220233\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Fiji: (LM) college 20170713.5171669\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine, RFI 20170305.4881298\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (NJ) college, sg. B 20160505.4204142\n.................................................sb/ml/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Amherst", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5491258", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (06): (VI) MSM, sg C, vaccine, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5491258", "date": "2017-11-30 21:40:24", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - USA (06): (MASSACHUSETTS) COLLEGE, SEROGROUP B, MASS SEROGROUP B VACCINATION\n********************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 28 Nov 2017 6:13 pm\nSource: WWLP [edited]\nhttp://wwlp.com/2017/11/28/umass-amherst-preparing-to-vaccinate-students-after-meningitis-outbreak-declared/\n\n\nUMass Amherst [University of Massachusetts at Amherst] is preparing to vaccinate all 20 000 undergraduate students following an outbreak of meningitis. This is something that UMass trains for each year, but hasn't had to do in a real-world situation since the 2009 outbreak of Swine Flu.\n\nMeningitis is a potentially deadly bacterial infection. There are 2 confirmed cases at UMass and more may be carrying the bacteria. \"This bacteria exists as a carrier state mostly and it occasionally causes disease,\" explained Dr. George Corey, the Executive Director of UMass University Health Services. \"So for every case there could be many carriers who will never become ill.\"\n\nCDC testing shows the 2 sick students, who did not know each other, had the same genetic virus, which suggests that others who don't show symptoms may have the bacteria dormant in their body. That's why UMass is holding their 1st of 4 mass vaccination clinics [Thu 30 Nov 2017] inside the Student Union.\n\n\"There's a good chance or a worrisome chance that someone else could get ill,\" said UMass Public Health Nurse Ann Becker. \"The illness is severe enough that we really don't see any of our students get this, not one, one more is too many.\" Becker recommends students avoid sharing food, drinks, and close contact, and to wash your hands. \"I am certainly worried. I've been paying attention to e-mails,\" said UMass undergraduate student [MW]. \"I personally have not gotten the shot but a lot of my friends have so I think it's in everyone's minds across campus.\"\n\nUMass wants you to know this vaccine is different than the meningitis vaccine you were required to get before you enrolled. UMass will bill your insurance, so there should be no out of pocket cost. So far, UMass has vaccinated 1500 students. Faculty and staff are not considered at risk.\n\nAs for the 2 students who already have meningitis, UMass health officials would only say they are getting positive updates.\n\n[Byline: Matt Caron]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A primary case is one that occurs in the absence of previous known close contact with another case-patient.\n\nAn outbreak is defined by the occurrence of at least 3 confirmed or probable primary cases of the same serogroup meningococcal disease during a period of 3 months or less, with a resulting primary attack rate of 10 or more cases per 100 000 population. Two primary cases caused by serogroup B in 21 000 UMass Amherst undergraduates gives a primary attack rate of 9.5 / 100 000.\n\nIn some instances the attack rate will be greater than 10 cases per 100 000 population with only 2 cases. In these situations, vaccination may be considered after only 2 primary cases are identified (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6202a3.htm). For outbreaks caused by serogroup B, the CDC recommends vaccination with a serogroup B meningococcal vaccine for anyone 10 years or older identified as being at increased risk.\n\nOutbreaks of meningococcal disease are usually caused by the same or closely related strains. Molecular genotyping will help characterize an outbreak clone. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/224.\n\n]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (05): (MA) college, sg. B 20160505.4204142\n.................................................sb/ml/ec/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Amherst", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5473532", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (06): (OR) college, sg B", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5473532", "date": "2017-11-03 12:01:43", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (04): (VICTORIA) VACCINE, ADOLESCENTS\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017 8:00 pm AEDT\nSource: Sunraysia Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.sunraysiadaily.com.au/story/5028793/vaccine-warning/\nVaccine warning\n\n\nFigures from the Department of Health and Human Services reveal that of the 24 cases of meningococcal disease diagnosed so far this year [2017] in regional Victoria, 2 were diagnosed in Greater Bendigo and one in the Swan Hill council area.\n\nThe Victorian Government is urging teenagers 15 to 19 to get the free meningococcal vaccine, available until [31 Dec 2017].\n\nOne in 5 people in this age bracket carry the bacteria, which can be passed on by close contact such as kissing, coughing or sneezing. In 10 percent of cases meningococcal disease proves to be fatal.\n\n[Byline: Ashlee Falvo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Sunraysia is an ill-defined district, located in northwestern Victoria and southwestern New South Wales in Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia). It can be can be found on the map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia#/media/File:Outline_map_of_the_Mallee_and_Sunraysia_regions.png. Greater Bendigo and Swan Hill are cities within the Loddon Mallee region that occupies more than a quarter of Victoria, known for its restaurants and wineries (http://www.rdv.vic.gov.au/victorian-regions/loddon-mallee).\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population in 2003 of serogroup C conjugated meningococcal vaccine, the incidence of disease due to serogroup C fell dramatically. Since 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 percent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 percent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 percent in 2003 to 83 percent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). Also see ProMED-mail posts: Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568 and Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868. ProMED-mail reported in 2016 that serogroup W, rather than B has become predominant in Western Australia (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W 20160925.4513543).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroups W and B, meningococcal serogroup B and quadrivalent conjugate (ACWY) vaccines are now funded for certain age groups in some Australian states \"in response to locally predominant meningococcal B or W disease\" (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf).\n\nThe quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017, in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288.]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20171014.5376391\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20170928.5345825\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (WA) sg Y 20170728.5211652\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W 20160925.4513543\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Greater Bendigo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5456199", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (05): (WA) sg W, sg Y", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5456199", "date": "2017-11-03 12:01:43", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (04): (VICTORIA) VACCINE, ADOLESCENTS\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017 8:00 pm AEDT\nSource: Sunraysia Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.sunraysiadaily.com.au/story/5028793/vaccine-warning/\nVaccine warning\n\n\nFigures from the Department of Health and Human Services reveal that of the 24 cases of meningococcal disease diagnosed so far this year [2017] in regional Victoria, 2 were diagnosed in Greater Bendigo and one in the Swan Hill council area.\n\nThe Victorian Government is urging teenagers 15 to 19 to get the free meningococcal vaccine, available until [31 Dec 2017].\n\nOne in 5 people in this age bracket carry the bacteria, which can be passed on by close contact such as kissing, coughing or sneezing. In 10 percent of cases meningococcal disease proves to be fatal.\n\n[Byline: Ashlee Falvo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Sunraysia is an ill-defined district, located in northwestern Victoria and southwestern New South Wales in Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia). It can be can be found on the map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia#/media/File:Outline_map_of_the_Mallee_and_Sunraysia_regions.png. Greater Bendigo and Swan Hill are cities within the Loddon Mallee region that occupies more than a quarter of Victoria, known for its restaurants and wineries (http://www.rdv.vic.gov.au/victorian-regions/loddon-mallee).\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population in 2003 of serogroup C conjugated meningococcal vaccine, the incidence of disease due to serogroup C fell dramatically. Since 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 percent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 percent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 percent in 2003 to 83 percent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). Also see ProMED-mail posts: Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568 and Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868. ProMED-mail reported in 2016 that serogroup W, rather than B has become predominant in Western Australia (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W 20160925.4513543).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroups W and B, meningococcal serogroup B and quadrivalent conjugate (ACWY) vaccines are now funded for certain age groups in some Australian states \"in response to locally predominant meningococcal B or W disease\" (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf).\n\nThe quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017, in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288.]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20171014.5376391\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20170928.5345825\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (WA) sg Y 20170728.5211652\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. In 10 percent of cases meningococcal disease proves to be fatal.\n\n[Byline: Ashlee Falvo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Sunraysia is an ill-defined district, located in northwestern Victoria and southwestern New South Wales in Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia). It can be can be found on the map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia#/media/File:Outline_map_of_the_Mallee_and_Sunraysia_regions.png. Greater Bendigo and Swan Hill are cities within the Loddon Mallee region that occupies more than a quarter of Victoria, known for its restaurants and wineries (http://www.rdv.vic.gov.au/victorian-regions/loddon-mallee).\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population in 2003 of serogroup C conjugated meningococcal vaccine, the incidence of disease due to serogroup C fell dramatically. Since 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 percent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 percent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 percent in 2003 to 83 percent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). Also see ProMED-mail posts: Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568 and Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868. ProMED-mail reported in 2016 that serogroup W, rather than B has become predominant in Western Australia (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W 20160925.4513543).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroups W and B, meningococcal serogroup B and quadrivalent conjugate (ACWY) vaccines are now funded for certain age groups in some Australian states \"in response to locally predominant meningococcal B or W disease\" (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf).\n\nThe quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017, in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288.]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20171014.5376391\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20170928.5345825\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (WA) sg Y 20170728.5211652\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. In 10 percent of cases meningococcal disease proves to be fatal.\n\n[Byline: Ashlee Falvo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Sunraysia is an ill-defined district, located in northwestern Victoria and southwestern New South Wales in Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia). It can be can be found on the map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia#/media/File:Outline_map_of_the_Mallee_and_Sunraysia_regions.png. Greater Bendigo and Swan Hill are cities within the Loddon Mallee region that occupies more than a quarter of Victoria, known for its restaurants and wineries (http://www.rdv.vic.gov.au/victorian-regions/loddon-mallee).\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population in 2003 of serogroup C conjugated meningococcal vaccine, the incidence of disease due to serogroup C fell dramatically. Since 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 percent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 percent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 percent in 2003 to 83 percent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). Also see ProMED-mail posts: Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568 and Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868. ProMED-mail reported in 2016 that serogroup W, rather than B has become predominant in Western Australia (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W 20160925.4513543).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroups W and B, meningococcal serogroup B and quadrivalent conjugate (ACWY) vaccines are now funded for certain age groups in some Australian states \"in response to locally predominant meningococcal B or W disease\" (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf).\n\nThe quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017, in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288.]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20171014.5376391\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20170928.5345825\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (WA) sg Y 20170728.5211652\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W 20160925.4513543\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5425383", "date": "2017-11-03 12:01:43", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (04): (VICTORIA) VACCINE, ADOLESCENTS\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017 8:00 pm AEDT\nSource: Sunraysia Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.sunraysiadaily.com.au/story/5028793/vaccine-warning/\nVaccine warning\n\n\nFigures from the Department of Health and Human Services reveal that of the 24 cases of meningococcal disease diagnosed so far this year [2017] in regional Victoria, 2 were diagnosed in Greater Bendigo and one in the Swan Hill council area.\n\nThe Victorian Government is urging teenagers 15 to 19 to get the free meningococcal vaccine, available until [31 Dec 2017].\n\nOne in 5 people in this age bracket carry the bacteria, which can be passed on by close contact such as kissing, coughing or sneezing. In 10 percent of cases meningococcal disease proves to be fatal.\n\n[Byline: Ashlee Falvo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Sunraysia is an ill-defined district, located in northwestern Victoria and southwestern New South Wales in Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia). It can be can be found on the map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia#/media/File:Outline_map_of_the_Mallee_and_Sunraysia_regions.png. Greater Bendigo and Swan Hill are cities within the Loddon Mallee region that occupies more than a quarter of Victoria, known for its restaurants and wineries (http://www.rdv.vic.gov.au/victorian-regions/loddon-mallee).\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population in 2003 of serogroup C conjugated meningococcal vaccine, the incidence of disease due to serogroup C fell dramatically. Since 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 percent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 percent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 percent in 2003 to 83 percent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf). Also see ProMED-mail posts: Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568 and Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868. ProMED-mail reported in 2016 that serogroup W, rather than B has become predominant in Western Australia (ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W 20160925.4513543).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroups W and B, meningococcal serogroup B and quadrivalent conjugate (ACWY) vaccines are now funded for certain age groups in some Australian states \"in response to locally predominant meningococcal B or W disease\" (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf).\n\nThe quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017, in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288.]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20171014.5376391\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20170928.5345825\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (WA) sg Y 20170728.5211652\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. It can be can be found on the map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia#/media/File:Outline_map_of_the_Mallee_and_Sunraysia_regions.png. Greater Bendigo and Swan Hill are cities within the Loddon Mallee region that occupies more than a quarter of Victoria, known for its restaurants and wineries (http://www.rdv.vic.gov.au/victorian-regions/loddon-mallee).\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population in 2003 of serogroup C conjugated meningococcal vaccine, the incidence of disease due to serogroup C fell dramatically. Since 2003, there has been a significant and sustained reduction in serogroup C meningococcal cases from 34 percent of cases in 2003 to 5.7 percent in 2012, accompanied by an increase in serogroup B from 60 percent in 2003 to 83 percent in 2012 (http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cda-cdi3703-pdf-cnt.htm/$FILE/cdi3703e.pdf).
