W 20160925.4513543).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroups W and B, meningococcal serogroup B and quadrivalent conjugate (ACWY) vaccines are now funded for certain age groups in some Australian states \"in response to locally predominant meningococcal B or W disease\" (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf).\n\nThe quadrivalent (A, C, W, Y) meningococcal conjugate vaccines are available through private prescription and also through state-funded adolescent programs in 5 states (New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia) starting in 2017, for those aged 15-19 years or school years 10-12 (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). The B vaccine is available through private prescription and in South Australia from April 2017, in a statewide 2-year clinical study for students enrolled in years 10, 11, and 12 in 2017 at participating schools (http://www.ncirs.edu.au/assets/provider_resources/fact-sheets/meningococcal-vaccines-fact-sheet.pdf). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288.]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20171014.5376391\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children 20170928.5345825\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (WA) sg Y 20170728.5211652\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (WA) sg. W 20160925.4513543\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-04-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Greater Bendigo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunraysia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5412497", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5412497", "date": "2017-08-05 14:56:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TAIWAN (02): FATAL, MILITARY BASE, COMMENT\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Aug 2017\nFrom: Peter M B English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nI was particularly interested to see this report from Taiwan, having just been involved in a vaccination programme in response to 3 cases of meningococcal disease at the University of Surrey (Guildford, United Kingdom).\n\nA few points...\n1. Do we know what strain(s) of meningococcal disease the Taiwan cases had? Were they all the same? If the organisms are distinguishable, we would not consider this an outbreak but, rather, a cluster.\n2. Much of the evidence on which chemoprophylaxis policies are based is now rather old. At the time, it was far more common for students to live in \"dormitories\", with 2 or more students sharing a bedroom. Now -- at least in the UK -- this is extremely unusual: most student accommodation has only one student (or couple) per bedroom - no sharing with a relative stranger. A high proportion even have en-suite bathroom facilities. Is that the same in USA? Perhaps the Taiwanese military provides less comfortable lodgings!\n3. What is the basis for the moderator's comment that \"The choice of vaccine will depend on knowing the serogroup of the outbreak strain, because the quadrivalent (ACYW) meningococcal vaccine will cover serogroups A, C, Y, and W, and the serogroup B vaccine will cover only serogroup B, without cross-coverage.\" I'm particularly interested in the comment that the \"serogroup B vaccine will only cover...\". Since the so-called serogroup B vaccines do not use the polysaccharide capsule ABCWY antigens, but rather antigens from different part of the organism, they are independent of the ABCWY antigens, and the group B vaccines can be expected to be effective against meningococci independent of the ABCWY classification.\n4. Experience with these new so-called serogroup B vaccines remains limited. At present we do not have evidence to clarify the extent of \"herd immunity\" they will provide, but we have some evidence to suggest that they prevent disease (invasion), but not colonization (infection), and are therefore unlikely to have a significant effect on herd immunity.\n5. The rationale for chemoprophylaxis based on the hypothesis that a more-than-usually virulent strain has evolved, with the argument going as follows:\na. Meningococcal carriage is common - in some studies, over a 3rd of 1rst-year university students will be carrying the organism after 2-3 months at university (a combination of the carriage rates in this age-group, and the social-mixing effect of starting at university, presumably).\nb. People [who] become ill with invasive meningococcal disease almost invariably get sick within 5 days of acquiring the organism. If somebody has been colonized for 7 days or more, they are extremely unlikely to get sick with it.\nc. Some strains -- like the C strain that caused outbreaks in teenagers in the UK in the 90s -- are considerably more virulent, with very little asymptomatic carriage. (The virulence genes are unrelated to the capsular phenotype, and capsular switching, maintaining the same virulence factors, is possible and appears to have happened with the increase in W serogroup disease in the UK, for example.[1])\nd. For the less virulent strains at least...\ne. When somebody becomes ill, it could be because of individual factors (the case was unusually susceptible -- for underlying reasons, such as inherited complement deficiencies, or because of an unfortunate timing eg recent viral infection); or because of pathogen associated factors -- the organism had evolved to become more than usually virulent.\nf. Given the high carriage rates, there's little point in chemoprophylaxis for normally virulent organisms.\ng. So chemoprophylaxis is based on the hypothesis that the case may have acquired their infection from a healthy carrier of a more virulent organism. The purpose is to eliminate carriage of this organism. The contacts targeted are therefore those from whom the case is most likely to have acquired their infection. (There is very little evidence of benefit for treating other people exposed to the case.)\nh. There is also a hypothesis -- supported, I believe, by some evidence -- that healthy carriers of meningococci and related organisms (such as _N. lactamica_) can benefit from \"competitive inhibition\". This means that the presence of the organism they are carrying reduces their chances of acquiring a new, potentially more virulent strain - see b. above.\ni. For this reason, extending chemoprophylaxis to people other than those from whom the case acquired their infection might do more harm than good (by increasing people's susceptibility to new infections).\n\n1. Campbell H, Parikh SR, Borrow R, Kaczmarski E, Ramsay ME, Ladhani SN. Presentation with gastrointestinal symptoms and high case fatality associated with group W meningococcal disease (MenW) in teenagers, England, July 2015 to January 2016. Euro Surveill 2016;21(12):3 DOI: 10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.12.30175 (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21422).\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Peter M B English\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nSurrey & Sussex Health Protection Team (SSHPT),\nPublic Health England (South East)\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates Dr English's comments in regard to the recent ProMED-mail post: Meningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924.\n\nIn regard to the activity of meningococcal serogroup B vaccines against non-serogroup B disease, since the surface protein antigens in the serogroup B meningococcal vaccines may also be present and expressed in meningococci belonging to non-B serogroups, there may be the potential for serogroup B vaccines to offer a some level of protection against non-B serogroups. Protection against invasive meningococcal disease is conferred mainly by complement-mediated antibody-dependent killing of _Neisseria meningitidis_. Studies that tested in an in vitro bactericidal assay against serogroup C, W and Y meningococci using sera collected in the UK, Germany, France and Brazil from individuals immunized with one of the B serogroup vaccines found that sera from was bactericidal \"in a range from 45 per cent to 90 per cent\" (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4755123/#R11), the preliminary data having been presented in poster sessions.\n\nHowever, on the basis of what we know for sure at present, \"experts from the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\" (http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_meningococcal_b.asp), say that meningococcal polysaccharide and conjugate vaccines \"provide no protection against serogroup B disease, and meningococcal serogroup B vaccines (MenB) provide no protection against serogroup A, C, W, or Y disease. For protection against all 5 serogroups of meningococcus, it is necessary to receive MenACWY or MPSV4 and MenB.\" And the CDC's recommendations (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/vis/vis-statements/mening-serogroup.html) clearly state, \"Serogroup B meningococcal (MenB) vaccines can help prevent meningococcal disease caused by serogroup B. Other meningococcal vaccines are recommended to help protect against serogroups A, C, W, and Y.\"\n\nIn regard to antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis, its rationale for close contacts of cases of meningococcal disease is based on the high attack rate of secondary meningococcal disease among these contacts, which has been estimated to be 500-800 times greater than for the general population (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046263.htm). Because the attack rate for close contacts is highest during the 1st few days after onset of disease in the primary patient, antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924\n.................................................ml/ec/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MILITARY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TAIWAN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ABCWY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "abcwy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5391253", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Japan: airplane exposure, boy scouts, 2015", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5391253", "date": "2017-08-05 14:56:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TAIWAN (02): FATAL, MILITARY BASE, COMMENT\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Aug 2017\nFrom: Peter M B English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nI was particularly interested to see this report from Taiwan, having just been involved in a vaccination programme in response to 3 cases of meningococcal disease at the University of Surrey (Guildford, United Kingdom).\n\nA few points...\n1. Do we know what strain(s) of meningococcal disease the Taiwan cases had? Were they all the same? If the organisms are distinguishable, we would not consider this an outbreak but, rather, a cluster.\n2. Much of the evidence on which chemoprophylaxis policies are based is now rather old. At the time, it was far more common for students to live in \"dormitories\", with 2 or more students sharing a bedroom. Now -- at least in the UK -- this is extremely unusual: most student accommodation has only one student (or couple) per bedroom - no sharing with a relative stranger. A high proportion even have en-suite bathroom facilities. Is that the same in USA? Perhaps the Taiwanese military provides less comfortable lodgings!\n3. What is the basis for the moderator's comment that \"The choice of vaccine will depend on knowing the serogroup of the outbreak strain, because the quadrivalent (ACYW) meningococcal vaccine will cover serogroups A, C, Y, and W, and the serogroup B vaccine will cover only serogroup B, without cross-coverage.\" I'm particularly interested in the comment that the \"serogroup B vaccine will only cover...\". Since the so-called serogroup B vaccines do not use the polysaccharide capsule ABCWY antigens, but rather antigens from different part of the organism, they are independent of the ABCWY antigens, and the group B vaccines can be expected to be effective against meningococci independent of the ABCWY classification.\n4. Experience with these new so-called serogroup B vaccines remains limited. At present we do not have evidence to clarify the extent of \"herd immunity\" they will provide, but we have some evidence to suggest that they prevent disease (invasion), but not colonization (infection), and are therefore unlikely to have a significant effect on herd immunity.\n5. The rationale for chemoprophylaxis based on the hypothesis that a more-than-usually virulent strain has evolved, with the argument going as follows:\na. Meningococcal carriage is common - in some studies, over a 3rd of 1rst-year university students will be carrying the organism after 2-3 months at university (a combination of the carriage rates in this age-group, and the social-mixing effect of starting at university, presumably).\nb. People [who] become ill with invasive meningococcal disease almost invariably get sick within 5 days of acquiring the organism. If somebody has been colonized for 7 days or more, they are extremely unlikely to get sick with it.\nc. Some strains -- like the C strain that caused outbreaks in teenagers in the UK in the 90s -- are considerably more virulent, with very little asymptomatic carriage. (The virulence genes are unrelated to the capsular phenotype, and capsular switching, maintaining the same virulence factors, is possible and appears to have happened with the increase in W serogroup disease in the UK, for example.[1])\nd. For the less virulent strains at least...\ne. When somebody becomes ill, it could be because of individual factors (the case was unusually susceptible -- for underlying reasons, such as inherited complement deficiencies, or because of an unfortunate timing eg recent viral infection); or because of pathogen associated factors -- the organism had evolved to become more than usually virulent.\nf. Given the high carriage rates, there's little point in chemoprophylaxis for normally virulent organisms.\ng. So chemoprophylaxis is based on the hypothesis that the case may have acquired their infection from a healthy carrier of a more virulent organism. The purpose is to eliminate carriage of this organism. The contacts targeted are therefore those from whom the case is most likely to have acquired their infection. (There is very little evidence of benefit for treating other people exposed to the case.)\nh. There is also a hypothesis -- supported, I believe, by some evidence -- that healthy carriers of meningococci and related organisms (such as _N. lactamica_) can benefit from \"competitive inhibition\". This means that the presence of the organism they are carrying reduces their chances of acquiring a new, potentially more virulent strain - see b. above.\ni. For this reason, extending chemoprophylaxis to people other than those from whom the case acquired their infection might do more harm than good (by increasing people's susceptibility to new infections).\n\n1. Campbell H, Parikh SR, Borrow R, Kaczmarski E, Ramsay ME, Ladhani SN. Presentation with gastrointestinal symptoms and high case fatality associated with group W meningococcal disease (MenW) in teenagers, England, July 2015 to January 2016. Euro Surveill 2016;21(12):3 DOI: 10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.12.30175 (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21422).\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Peter M B English\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nSurrey & Sussex Health Protection Team (SSHPT),\nPublic Health England (South East)\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates Dr English's comments in regard to the recent ProMED-mail post: Meningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924.\n\nIn regard to the activity of meningococcal serogroup B vaccines against non-serogroup B disease, since the surface protein antigens in the serogroup B meningococcal vaccines may also be present and expressed in meningococci belonging to non-B serogroups, there may be the potential for serogroup B vaccines to offer a some level of protection against non-B serogroups. Protection against invasive meningococcal disease is conferred mainly by complement-mediated antibody-dependent killing of _Neisseria meningitidis_. Studies that tested in an in vitro bactericidal assay against serogroup C, W and Y meningococci using sera collected in the UK, Germany, France and Brazil from individuals immunized with one of the B serogroup vaccines found that sera from was bactericidal \"in a range from 45 per cent to 90 per cent\" (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4755123/#R11), the preliminary data having been presented in poster sessions.\n\nHowever, on the basis of what we know for sure at present, \"experts from the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\" (http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_meningococcal_b.asp), say that meningococcal polysaccharide and conjugate vaccines \"provide no protection against serogroup B disease, and meningococcal serogroup B vaccines (MenB) provide no protection against serogroup A, C, W, or Y disease. For protection against all 5 serogroups of meningococcus, it is necessary to receive MenACWY or MPSV4 and MenB.\" And the CDC's recommendations (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/vis/vis-statements/mening-serogroup.html) clearly state, \"Serogroup B meningococcal (MenB) vaccines can help prevent meningococcal disease caused by serogroup B. Other meningococcal vaccines are recommended to help protect against serogroups A, C, W, and Y.\"\n\nIn regard to antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis, its rationale for close contacts of cases of meningococcal disease is based on the high attack rate of secondary meningococcal disease among these contacts, which has been estimated to be 500-800 times greater than for the general population (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046263.htm). Because the attack rate for close contacts is highest during the 1st few days after onset of disease in the primary patient, antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924\n.................................................ml/ec/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MILITARY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TAIWAN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ABCWY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "abcwy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5386595", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - USA (02): (NV, CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5386595", "date": "2017-08-05 14:56:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TAIWAN (02): FATAL, MILITARY BASE, COMMENT\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Aug 2017\nFrom: Peter M B English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nI was particularly interested to see this report from Taiwan, having just been involved in a vaccination programme in response to 3 cases of meningococcal disease at the University of Surrey (Guildford, United Kingdom).\n\nA few points...\n1. Do we know what strain(s) of meningococcal disease the Taiwan cases had? Were they all the same? If the organisms are distinguishable, we would not consider this an outbreak but, rather, a cluster.\n2. Much of the evidence on which chemoprophylaxis policies are based is now rather old. At the time, it was far more common for students to live in \"dormitories\", with 2 or more students sharing a bedroom. Now -- at least in the UK -- this is extremely unusual: most student accommodation has only one student (or couple) per bedroom - no sharing with a relative stranger. A high proportion even have en-suite bathroom facilities. Is that the same in USA? Perhaps the Taiwanese military provides less comfortable lodgings!\n3. What is the basis for the moderator's comment that \"The choice of vaccine will depend on knowing the serogroup of the outbreak strain, because the quadrivalent (ACYW) meningococcal vaccine will cover serogroups A, C, Y, and W, and the serogroup B vaccine will cover only serogroup B, without cross-coverage.\" I'm particularly interested in the comment that the \"serogroup B vaccine will only cover...\". Since the so-called serogroup B vaccines do not use the polysaccharide capsule ABCWY antigens, but rather antigens from different part of the organism, they are independent of the ABCWY antigens, and the group B vaccines can be expected to be effective against meningococci independent of the ABCWY classification.\n4. Experience with these new so-called serogroup B vaccines remains limited. At present we do not have evidence to clarify the extent of \"herd immunity\" they will provide, but we have some evidence to suggest that they prevent disease (invasion), but not colonization (infection), and are therefore unlikely to have a significant effect on herd immunity.\n5. The rationale for chemoprophylaxis based on the hypothesis that a more-than-usually virulent strain has evolved, with the argument going as follows:\na. Meningococcal carriage is common - in some studies, over a 3rd of 1rst-year university students will be carrying the organism after 2-3 months at university (a combination of the carriage rates in this age-group, and the social-mixing effect of starting at university, presumably).\nb. People [who] become ill with invasive meningococcal disease almost invariably get sick within 5 days of acquiring the organism. If somebody has been colonized for 7 days or more, they are extremely unlikely to get sick with it.\nc. Some strains -- like the C strain that caused outbreaks in teenagers in the UK in the 90s -- are considerably more virulent, with very little asymptomatic carriage. (The virulence genes are unrelated to the capsular phenotype, and capsular switching, maintaining the same virulence factors, is possible and appears to have happened with the increase in W serogroup disease in the UK, for example.[1])\nd. For the less virulent strains at least...\ne. When somebody becomes ill, it could be because of individual factors (the case was unusually susceptible -- for underlying reasons, such as inherited complement deficiencies, or because of an unfortunate timing eg recent viral infection); or because of pathogen associated factors -- the organism had evolved to become more than usually virulent.\nf. Given the high carriage rates, there's little point in chemoprophylaxis for normally virulent organisms.\ng. So chemoprophylaxis is based on the hypothesis that the case may have acquired their infection from a healthy carrier of a more virulent organism. The purpose is to eliminate carriage of this organism. The contacts targeted are therefore those from whom the case is most likely to have acquired their infection. (There is very little evidence of benefit for treating other people exposed to the case.)\nh. There is also a hypothesis -- supported, I believe, by some evidence -- that healthy carriers of meningococci and related organisms (such as _N. lactamica_) can benefit from \"competitive inhibition\". This means that the presence of the organism they are carrying reduces their chances of acquiring a new, potentially more virulent strain - see b. above.\ni. For this reason, extending chemoprophylaxis to people other than those from whom the case acquired their infection might do more harm than good (by increasing people's susceptibility to new infections).\n\n1. Campbell H, Parikh SR, Borrow R, Kaczmarski E, Ramsay ME, Ladhani SN. Presentation with gastrointestinal symptoms and high case fatality associated with group W meningococcal disease (MenW) in teenagers, England, July 2015 to January 2016. Euro Surveill 2016;21(12):3 DOI: 10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.12.30175 (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21422).\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Peter M B English\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nSurrey & Sussex Health Protection Team (SSHPT),\nPublic Health England (South East)\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates Dr English's comments in regard to the recent ProMED-mail post: Meningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924.\n\nIn regard to the activity of meningococcal serogroup B vaccines against non-serogroup B disease, since the surface protein antigens in the serogroup B meningococcal vaccines may also be present and expressed in meningococci belonging to non-B serogroups, there may be the potential for serogroup B vaccines to offer a some level of protection against non-B serogroups. Protection against invasive meningococcal disease is conferred mainly by complement-mediated antibody-dependent killing of _Neisseria meningitidis_. Studies that tested in an in vitro bactericidal assay against serogroup C, W and Y meningococci using sera collected in the UK, Germany, France and Brazil from individuals immunized with one of the B serogroup vaccines found that sera from was bactericidal \"in a range from 45 per cent to 90 per cent\" (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4755123/#R11), the preliminary data having been presented in poster sessions.\n\nHowever, on the basis of what we know for sure at present, \"experts from the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\" (http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_meningococcal_b.asp), say that meningococcal polysaccharide and conjugate vaccines \"provide no protection against serogroup B disease, and meningococcal serogroup B vaccines (MenB) provide no protection against serogroup A, C, W, or Y disease. For protection against all 5 serogroups of meningococcus, it is necessary to receive MenACWY or MPSV4 and MenB.\" And the CDC's recommendations (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/vis/vis-statements/mening-serogroup.html) clearly state, \"Serogroup B meningococcal (MenB) vaccines can help prevent meningococcal disease caused by serogroup B. Other meningococcal vaccines are recommended to help protect against serogroups A, C, W, and Y.\"\n\nIn regard to antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis, its rationale for close contacts of cases of meningococcal disease is based on the high attack rate of secondary meningococcal disease among these contacts, which has been estimated to be 500-800 times greater than for the general population (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046263.htm). Because the attack rate for close contacts is highest during the 1st few days after onset of disease in the primary patient, antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924\n.................................................ml/ec/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MILITARY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TAIWAN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ABCWY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "abcwy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5376391", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (03): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5376391", "date": "2017-08-05 14:56:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TAIWAN (02): FATAL, MILITARY BASE, COMMENT\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Aug 2017\nFrom: Peter M B English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nI was particularly interested to see this report from Taiwan, having just been involved in a vaccination programme in response to 3 cases of meningococcal disease at the University of Surrey (Guildford, United Kingdom).\n\nA few points...\n1. Given the high carriage rates, there's little point in chemoprophylaxis for normally virulent organisms.\ng. The purpose is to eliminate carriage of this organism. The contacts targeted are therefore those from whom the case is most likely to have acquired their infection. (There is very little evidence of benefit for treating other people exposed to the case.)\nh. A high proportion even have en-suite bathroom facilities. Is that the same in USA? Perhaps the Taiwanese military provides less comfortable lodgings!\n3. What is the basis for the moderator's comment that \"The choice of vaccine will depend on knowing the serogroup of the outbreak strain, because the quadrivalent (ACYW) meningococcal vaccine will cover serogroups A, C, Y, and W, and the serogroup B vaccine will cover only serogroup B, without cross-coverage.\" I'm particularly interested in the comment that the \"serogroup B vaccine will only cover...\". Experience with these new so-called serogroup B vaccines remains limited. At present we do not have evidence to clarify the extent of \"herd immunity\" they will provide, but we have some evidence to suggest that they prevent disease (invasion), but not colonization (infection), and are therefore unlikely to have a significant effect on herd immunity.\n5. The rationale for chemoprophylaxis based on the hypothesis that a more-than-usually virulent strain has evolved, with the argument going as follows:\na. Meningococcal carriage is common - in some studies, over a 3rd of 1rst-year university students will be carrying the organism after 2-3 months at university (a combination of the carriage rates in this age-group, and the social-mixing effect of starting at university, presumably).\nb. People [who] become ill with invasive meningococcal disease almost invariably get sick within 5 days of acquiring the organism. If somebody has been colonized for 7 days or more, they are extremely unlikely to get sick with it.\nc. Some strains -- like the C strain that caused outbreaks in teenagers in the UK in the 90s -- are considerably more virulent, with very little asymptomatic carriage. (The virulence genes are unrelated to the capsular phenotype, and capsular switching, maintaining the same virulence factors, is possible and appears to have happened with the increase in W serogroup disease in the UK, for example.[1])\nd. For the less virulent strains at least...\ne. When somebody becomes ill, it could be because of individual factors (the case was unusually susceptible -- for underlying reasons, such as inherited complement deficiencies, or because of an unfortunate timing eg recent viral infection); or because of pathogen associated factors -- the organism had evolved to become more than usually virulent.\nf. Given the high carriage rates, there's little point in chemoprophylaxis for normally virulent organisms.\ng. So chemoprophylaxis is based on the hypothesis that the case may have acquired their infection from a healthy carrier of a more virulent organism. The purpose is to eliminate carriage of this organism. The contacts targeted are therefore those from whom the case is most likely to have acquired their infection. (There is very little evidence of benefit for treating other people exposed to the case.)\nh. There is also a hypothesis -- supported, I believe, by some evidence -- that healthy carriers of meningococci and related organisms (such as _N. lactamica_) can benefit from \"competitive inhibition\". This means that the presence of the organism they are carrying reduces their chances of acquiring a new, potentially more virulent strain - see b. above.\ni. For this reason, extending chemoprophylaxis to people other than those from whom the case acquired their infection might do more harm than good (by increasing people's susceptibility to new infections).\n\n1. Campbell H, Parikh SR, Borrow R, Kaczmarski E, Ramsay ME, Ladhani SN. Presentation with gastrointestinal symptoms and high case fatality associated with group W meningococcal disease (MenW) in teenagers, England, July 2015 to January 2016. Euro Surveill 2016;21(12):3 DOI: 10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.12.30175 (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21422).\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Peter M B English\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nSurrey & Sussex Health Protection Team (SSHPT),\nPublic Health England (South East)\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates Dr English's comments in regard to the recent ProMED-mail post: Meningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924.\n\nIn regard to the activity of meningococcal serogroup B vaccines against non-serogroup B disease, since the surface protein antigens in the serogroup B meningococcal vaccines may also be present and expressed in meningococci belonging to non-B serogroups, there may be the potential for serogroup B vaccines to offer a some level of protection against non-B serogroups. Protection against invasive meningococcal disease is conferred mainly by complement-mediated antibody-dependent killing of _Neisseria meningitidis_. Studies that tested in an in vitro bactericidal assay against serogroup C, W and Y meningococci using sera collected in the UK, Germany, France and Brazil from individuals immunized with one of the B serogroup vaccines found that sera from was bactericidal \"in a range from 45 per cent to 90 per cent\" (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4755123/#R11), the preliminary data having been presented in poster sessions.\n\nHowever, on the basis of what we know for sure at present, \"experts from the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\" (http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_meningococcal_b.asp), say that meningococcal polysaccharide and conjugate vaccines \"provide no protection against serogroup B disease, and meningococcal serogroup B vaccines (MenB) provide no protection against serogroup A, C, W, or Y disease. For protection against all 5 serogroups of meningococcus, it is necessary to receive MenACWY or MPSV4 and MenB.\" And the CDC's recommendations (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/vis/vis-statements/mening-serogroup.html) clearly state, \"Serogroup B meningococcal (MenB) vaccines can help prevent meningococcal disease caused by serogroup B. Other meningococcal vaccines are recommended to help protect against serogroups A, C, W, and Y.\"\n\nIn regard to antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis, its rationale for close contacts of cases of meningococcal disease is based on the high attack rate of secondary meningococcal disease among these contacts, which has been estimated to be 500-800 times greater than for the general population (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046263.htm). Because the attack rate for close contacts is highest during the 1st few days after onset of disease in the primary patient, antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924\n.................................................ml/ec/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MILITARY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TAIWAN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ABCWY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "abcwy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5345825", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (NT) sg W, Aboriginal children", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5345825", "date": "2017-08-05 14:56:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TAIWAN (02): FATAL, MILITARY BASE, COMMENT\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Aug 2017\nFrom: Peter M B English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nI was particularly interested to see this report from Taiwan, having just been involved in a vaccination programme in response to 3 cases of meningococcal disease at the University of Surrey (Guildford, United Kingdom).\n\nA few points...\n1. Do we know what strain(s) of meningococcal disease the Taiwan cases had? Were they all the same? If the organisms are distinguishable, we would not consider this an outbreak but, rather, a cluster.\n2. Much of the evidence on which chemoprophylaxis policies are based is now rather old. At the time, it was far more common for students to live in \"dormitories\", with 2 or more students sharing a bedroom. Now -- at least in the UK -- this is extremely unusual: most student accommodation has only one student (or couple) per bedroom - no sharing with a relative stranger. A high proportion even have en-suite bathroom facilities. Is that the same in USA? Perhaps the Taiwanese military provides less comfortable lodgings!\n3. What is the basis for the moderator's comment that \"The choice of vaccine will depend on knowing the serogroup of the outbreak strain, because the quadrivalent (ACYW) meningococcal vaccine will cover serogroups A, C, Y, and W, and the serogroup B vaccine will cover only serogroup B, without cross-coverage.\" I'm particularly interested in the comment that the \"serogroup B vaccine will only cover...\". Since the so-called serogroup B vaccines do not use the polysaccharide capsule ABCWY antigens, but rather antigens from different part of the organism, they are independent of the ABCWY antigens, and the group B vaccines can be expected to be effective against meningococci independent of the ABCWY classification.\n4. Experience with these new so-called serogroup B vaccines remains limited. At present we do not have evidence to clarify the extent of \"herd immunity\" they will provide, but we have some evidence to suggest that they prevent disease (invasion), but not colonization (infection), and are therefore unlikely to have a significant effect on herd immunity.\n5. The rationale for chemoprophylaxis based on the hypothesis that a more-than-usually virulent strain has evolved, with the argument going as follows:\na. Meningococcal carriage is common - in some studies, over a 3rd of 1rst-year university students will be carrying the organism after 2-3 months at university (a combination of the carriage rates in this age-group, and the social-mixing effect of starting at university, presumably).\nb. People [who] become ill with invasive meningococcal disease almost invariably get sick within 5 days of acquiring the organism. If somebody has been colonized for 7 days or more, they are extremely unlikely to get sick with it.\nc. Some strains -- like the C strain that caused outbreaks in teenagers in the UK in the 90s -- are considerably more virulent, with very little asymptomatic carriage. (The virulence genes are unrelated to the capsular phenotype, and capsular switching, maintaining the same virulence factors, is possible and appears to have happened with the increase in W serogroup disease in the UK, for example.[1])\nd. For the less virulent strains at least...\ne. When somebody becomes ill, it could be because of individual factors (the case was unusually susceptible -- for underlying reasons, such as inherited complement deficiencies, or because of an unfortunate timing eg recent viral infection); or because of pathogen associated factors -- the organism had evolved to become more than usually virulent.\nf. Given the high carriage rates, there's little point in chemoprophylaxis for normally virulent organisms.\ng. So chemoprophylaxis is based on the hypothesis that the case may have acquired their infection from a healthy carrier of a more virulent organism. The purpose is to eliminate carriage of this organism. The contacts targeted are therefore those from whom the case is most likely to have acquired their infection. (There is very little evidence of benefit for treating other people exposed to the case.)\nh. There is also a hypothesis -- supported, I believe, by some evidence -- that healthy carriers of meningococci and related organisms (such as _N. lactamica_) can benefit from \"competitive inhibition\". This means that the presence of the organism they are carrying reduces their chances of acquiring a new, potentially more virulent strain - see b. above.\ni. For this reason, extending chemoprophylaxis to people other than those from whom the case acquired their infection might do more harm than good (by increasing people's susceptibility to new infections).\n\n1. Campbell H, Parikh SR, Borrow R, Kaczmarski E, Ramsay ME, Ladhani SN. Presentation with gastrointestinal symptoms and high case fatality associated with group W meningococcal disease (MenW) in teenagers, England, July 2015 to January 2016. Euro Surveill 2016;21(12):3 DOI: 10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2016.21.12.30175 (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=21422).\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Peter M B English\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control\nSurrey & Sussex Health Protection Team (SSHPT),\nPublic Health England (South East)\n<peter.english@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates Dr English's comments in regard to the recent ProMED-mail post: Meningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924.\n\nIn regard to the activity of meningococcal serogroup B vaccines against non-serogroup B disease, since the surface protein antigens in the serogroup B meningococcal vaccines may also be present and expressed in meningococci belonging to non-B serogroups, there may be the potential for serogroup B vaccines to offer a some level of protection against non-B serogroups. Protection against invasive meningococcal disease is conferred mainly by complement-mediated antibody-dependent killing of _Neisseria meningitidis_. Studies that tested in an in vitro bactericidal assay against serogroup C, W and Y meningococci using sera collected in the UK, Germany, France and Brazil from individuals immunized with one of the B serogroup vaccines found that sera from was bactericidal \"in a range from 45 per cent to 90 per cent\" (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4755123/#R11), the preliminary data having been presented in poster sessions.\n\nHowever, on the basis of what we know for sure at present, \"experts from the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\" (http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_meningococcal_b.asp), say that meningococcal polysaccharide and conjugate vaccines \"provide no protection against serogroup B disease, and meningococcal serogroup B vaccines (MenB) provide no protection against serogroup A, C, W, or Y disease. For protection against all 5 serogroups of meningococcus, it is necessary to receive MenACWY or MPSV4 and MenB.\" And the CDC's recommendations (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/vis/vis-statements/mening-serogroup.html) clearly state, \"Serogroup B meningococcal (MenB) vaccines can help prevent meningococcal disease caused by serogroup B. Other meningococcal vaccines are recommended to help protect against serogroups A, C, W, and Y.\"\n\nIn regard to antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis, its rationale for close contacts of cases of meningococcal disease is based on the high attack rate of secondary meningococcal disease among these contacts, which has been estimated to be 500-800 times greater than for the general population (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046263.htm). Because the attack rate for close contacts is highest during the 1st few days after onset of disease in the primary patient, antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924\n.................................................ml/ec/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MILITARY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TAIWAN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ABCWY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "abcwy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5287927", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Meningitis - Yemen: susp. bacterial, not, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5287927", "date": "2017-08-05 14:56:51", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - TAIWAN (02): FATAL, MILITARY BASE, COMMENT\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 2 Aug 2017\nFrom: Peter M B English <peter.english@phe.gov.uk> [edited]\n\n\nI was particularly interested to see this report from Taiwan, having just been involved in a vaccination programme in response to 3 cases of meningococcal disease at the University of Surrey (Guildford, United Kingdom).\n\nA few points...\n1. A high proportion even have en-suite bathroom facilities. Is that the same in USA? Perhaps the Taiwanese military provides less comfortable lodgings!\n3. At present we do not have evidence to clarify the extent of \"herd immunity\" they will provide, but we have some evidence to suggest that they prevent disease (invasion), but not colonization (infection), and are therefore unlikely to have a significant effect on herd immunity.\n5. If somebody has been colonized for 7 days or more, they are extremely unlikely to get sick with it.\nc. Some strains -- like the C strain that caused outbreaks in teenagers in the UK in the 90s -- are considerably more virulent, with very little asymptomatic carriage. (The virulence genes are unrelated to the capsular phenotype, and capsular switching, maintaining the same virulence factors, is possible and appears to have happened with the increase in W serogroup disease in the UK, for example.[1])\nd. For the less virulent strains at least...\ne. When somebody becomes ill, it could be because of individual factors (the case was unusually susceptible -- for underlying reasons, such as inherited complement deficiencies, or because of an unfortunate timing eg recent viral infection); or because of pathogen associated factors -- the organism had evolved to become more than usually virulent.\nf. Given the high carriage rates, there's little point in chemoprophylaxis for normally virulent organisms.\ng. So chemoprophylaxis is based on the hypothesis that the case may have acquired their infection from a healthy carrier of a more virulent organism. The purpose is to eliminate carriage of this organism. The contacts targeted are therefore those from whom the case is most likely to have acquired their infection. (There is very little evidence of benefit for treating other people exposed to the case.)\nh. There is also a hypothesis -- supported, I believe, by some evidence -- that healthy carriers of meningococci and related organisms (such as _N. lactamica_) can benefit from \"competitive inhibition\". This means that the presence of the organism they are carrying reduces their chances of acquiring a new, potentially more virulent strain - see b. above.\ni. (The virulence genes are unrelated to the capsular phenotype, and capsular switching, maintaining the same virulence factors, is possible and appears to have happened with the increase in W serogroup disease in the UK, for example.[1])\nd. Given the high carriage rates, there's little point in chemoprophylaxis for normally virulent organisms.\ng. The purpose is to eliminate carriage of this organism. The contacts targeted are therefore those from whom the case is most likely to have acquired their infection. Protection against invasive meningococcal disease is conferred mainly by complement-mediated antibody-dependent killing of _Neisseria meningitidis_. Studies that tested in an in vitro bactericidal assay against serogroup C, W and Y meningococci using sera collected in the UK, Germany, France and Brazil from individuals immunized with one of the B serogroup vaccines found that sera from was bactericidal \"in a range from 45 per cent to 90 per cent\" (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4755123/#R11), the preliminary data having been presented in poster sessions.\n\nHowever, on the basis of what we know for sure at present, \"experts from the National Center for Immunization and Respiratory Diseases at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\" (http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_meningococcal_b.asp), say that meningococcal polysaccharide and conjugate vaccines \"provide no protection against serogroup B disease, and meningococcal serogroup B vaccines (MenB) provide no protection against serogroup A, C, W, or Y disease. For protection against all 5 serogroups of meningococcus, it is necessary to receive MenACWY or MPSV4 and MenB.\" And the CDC's recommendations (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/vis/vis-statements/mening-serogroup.html) clearly state, \"Serogroup B meningococcal (MenB) vaccines can help prevent meningococcal disease caused by serogroup B. Other meningococcal vaccines are recommended to help protect against serogroups A, C, W, and Y.\"\n\nIn regard to antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis, its rationale for close contacts of cases of meningococcal disease is based on the high attack rate of secondary meningococcal disease among these contacts, which has been estimated to be 500-800 times greater than for the general population (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046263.htm). Because the attack rate for close contacts is highest during the 1st few days after onset of disease in the primary patient, antimicrobial chemoprophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Taiwan: fatal, military base 20170801.5218924\n.................................................ml/ec/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-07-16 00:00:00", "2016-01-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MILITARY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TAIWAN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ABCWY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "abcwy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5220233", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Fiji (02): (LM) college, sg C", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5220233", "date": "2017-06-21 13:13:12", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - ROMANIA: (BRASOV) BACTERIAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jun 2017\nSource: Romania Insider [edited]\nhttps://www.romania-insider.com/romanian-teenager-meningitis-dies-hospital-2017/\n\n\nA 17-year-old Romanian student diagnosed with bacterial meningitis died last week [15 Jun 2017] at the Pediatric Hospital in Brasov, central Romania, while 18 other teenagers were hospitalized with similar symptoms.\n\nThe classmates of the young Romanian who died on [15 Jun 2017], as well as other people he came into contact with, were sent to the doctor for consultations. Their number reached 200 by [18 Jun 2017], reports local News.ro.\n\nMoreover, 18 young people were admitted to the Hospital for Infectious Diseases in Brasov, on suspicion of meningitis. One of them was diagnosed with this disease.\n\nMeanwhile, the authorities disinfected the high school where the young boy was a student, as well as the Pediatric Hospital, which doesn't have a department for infectious diseases.\n\nThe 17-year-old student who died last week [15 Jun 2017] was from the Tarlungeni commune, in Brasov county. He and his friends had attended a party in the Purcareni village [Brasov county] tone week before. The students started to feel bad after this party.\n\nMeningitis is an inflammation (swelling) of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. A bacterial or viral infection of the fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord usually causes the swelling. However, injuries, cancer, certain drugs, and other types of infections can also cause meningitis, according to information posted on the website of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMeningitis symptoms include sudden onset of fever, headache, and stiff neck, but there are also other symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, photophobia (increased sensitivity to light), and altered mental status (confusion).\n\n[Byline: Irina Marica]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that one teenage boy has died of bacterial meningitis and 18 of his friends were hospitalized with suspected meningitis; this diagnosis was subsequently confirmed in one. However, the bacterial species that caused the disease is not specified.\n\nAcute bacterial meningitis is a rapidly progressive disease. In a patient with suspected acute bacterial meningitis, blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cultures will indicate the causative organism and its antibiotic susceptibilities. An empiric intravenous antibiotic regimen that has a spectrum broad enough to cover the most likely bacterial pathogens is started as quickly as possible until the specific bacterial etiology is known. It is vital to begin treatment as early as possible in the course of the disease, as delay may contribute significantly to morbidity and mortality. Adjunctive dexamethasone is also given before or with the 1st antibiotic dose. Once a pathogen is known, the antibiotic regimen can be tailored to the antibiotic susceptibilities of the pathogen.\n\nCommon causes of bacterial meningitis vary by age group. Outbreaks of meningitis in the community are often due to _Neisseria meningitidis_. More information on this outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nBrasov is a city with a population of 253 200 residents in Romania and the administrative centre of Brasov County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bra\u0219ov). Tarlungeni is a commune with a population of 7820 residents in Brasov County; it is composed of 4 villages: Carpinis, Purcareni, Tarlungeni and Zizin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T\u0103rlungeni). A map showing the location of Tarlungeni can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/T\u0103rlungeni+507220,+Romania.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Romania can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6163. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nMeningitis - Solomon Islands: (ML) susp. bacterial, RFI 20160925.4513490\nMeningitis, bacterial - Cote d'Ivoire: S. pneumoniae st.1 predominates 20160315.4095606\n2014\n----\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\n2007\n----\nMeningitis, bacterial, airplane exposure - USA (KS ex FL): alert 20070724.2378\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["7820-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zizin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarlungeni", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasov County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasov county", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5218924", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Their number reached 200 by [18 Jun 2017], reports local News.ro.\n\nMoreover, 18 young people were admitted to the Hospital for Infectious Diseases in Brasov, on suspicion of meningitis. One of them was diagnosed with this disease.\n\nMeanwhile, the authorities disinfected the high school where the young boy was a student, as well as the Pediatric Hospital, which doesn't have a department for infectious diseases.\n\nThe 17-year-old student who died last week [15 Jun 2017] was from the Tarlungeni commune, in Brasov county. He and his friends had attended a party in the Purcareni village [Brasov county] tone week before. The students started to feel bad after this party.\n\nMeningitis is an inflammation (swelling) of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. A bacterial or viral infection of the fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord usually causes the swelling. In a patient with suspected acute bacterial meningitis, blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cultures will indicate the causative organism and its antibiotic susceptibilities. An empiric intravenous antibiotic regimen that has a spectrum broad enough to cover the most likely bacterial pathogens is started as quickly as possible until the specific bacterial etiology is known. An empiric intravenous antibiotic regimen that has a spectrum broad enough to cover the most likely bacterial pathogens is started as quickly as possible until the specific bacterial etiology is known. Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\n2007\n----\nMeningitis, bacterial, airplane exposure - USA (KS ex FL): alert 20070724.2378\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["7820-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zizin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarlungeni", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasov County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasov county", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5120576", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Romania: (BV) bacterial, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5120576", "date": "2017-06-21 13:13:12", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - ROMANIA: (BRASOV) BACTERIAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jun 2017\nSource: Romania Insider [edited]\nhttps://www.romania-insider.com/romanian-teenager-meningitis-dies-hospital-2017/\n\n\nA 17-year-old Romanian student diagnosed with bacterial meningitis died last week [15 Jun 2017] at the Pediatric Hospital in Brasov, central Romania, while 18 other teenagers were hospitalized with similar symptoms.\n\nThe classmates of the young Romanian who died on [15 Jun 2017], as well as other people he came into contact with, were sent to the doctor for consultations. Their number reached 200 by [18 Jun 2017], reports local News.ro.\n\nMoreover, 18 young people were admitted to the Hospital for Infectious Diseases in Brasov, on suspicion of meningitis. One of them was diagnosed with this disease.\n\nMeanwhile, the authorities disinfected the high school where the young boy was a student, as well as the Pediatric Hospital, which doesn't have a department for infectious diseases.\n\nThe 17-year-old student who died last week [15 Jun 2017] was from the Tarlungeni commune, in Brasov county. He and his friends had attended a party in the Purcareni village [Brasov county] tone week before. The students started to feel bad after this party.\n\nMeningitis is an inflammation (swelling) of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. A bacterial or viral infection of the fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord usually causes the swelling. However, injuries, cancer, certain drugs, and other types of infections can also cause meningitis, according to information posted on the website of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMeningitis symptoms include sudden onset of fever, headache, and stiff neck, but there are also other symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, photophobia (increased sensitivity to light), and altered mental status (confusion).\n\n[Byline: Irina Marica]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that one teenage boy has died of bacterial meningitis and 18 of his friends were hospitalized with suspected meningitis; this diagnosis was subsequently confirmed in one. However, the bacterial species that caused the disease is not specified.\n\nAcute bacterial meningitis is a rapidly progressive disease. In a patient with suspected acute bacterial meningitis, blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cultures will indicate the causative organism and its antibiotic susceptibilities. An empiric intravenous antibiotic regimen that has a spectrum broad enough to cover the most likely bacterial pathogens is started as quickly as possible until the specific bacterial etiology is known. It is vital to begin treatment as early as possible in the course of the disease, as delay may contribute significantly to morbidity and mortality. Adjunctive dexamethasone is also given before or with the 1st antibiotic dose. Once a pathogen is known, the antibiotic regimen can be tailored to the antibiotic susceptibilities of the pathogen.\n\nCommon causes of bacterial meningitis vary by age group. Outbreaks of meningitis in the community are often due to _Neisseria meningitidis_. More information on this outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nBrasov is a city with a population of 253 200 residents in Romania and the administrative centre of Brasov County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bra\u0219ov). Tarlungeni is a commune with a population of 7820 residents in Brasov County; it is composed of 4 villages: Carpinis, Purcareni, Tarlungeni and Zizin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T\u0103rlungeni). A map showing the location of Tarlungeni can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/T\u0103rlungeni+507220,+Romania.\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Romania can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6163. - UK (02): Pasteurella multocida, background 20140422.2420130\nMeningitis, bacterial - UK: (England) domestic cat-to-human infant transm. 20140420.2417385\n2009\n----\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region 20090313.1038\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\n2007\n----\nMeningitis, bacterial, airplane exposure - USA (KS ex FL): alert 20070724.2378\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["7820-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zizin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarlungeni", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasov County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brasov county", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5085277", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (10): fatal, serogroup C", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5085277", "date": "2017-06-21 13:13:12", "main_text": "MENINGITIS - ROMANIA: (BRASOV) BACTERIAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jun 2017\nSource: Romania Insider [edited]\nhttps://www.romania-insider.com/romanian-teenager-meningitis-dies-hospital-2017/\n\n\nA 17-year-old Romanian student diagnosed with bacterial meningitis died last week [15 Jun 2017] at the Pediatric Hospital in Brasov, central Romania, while 18 other teenagers were hospitalized with similar symptoms.\n\nThe classmates of the young Romanian who died on [15 Jun 2017], as well as other people he came into contact with, were sent to the doctor for consultations. Their number reached 200 by [18 Jun 2017], reports local News.ro.\n\nMoreover, 18 young people were admitted to the Hospital for Infectious Diseases in Brasov, on suspicion of meningitis. One of them was diagnosed with this disease.\n\nMeanwhile, the authorities disinfected the high school where the young boy was a student, as well as the Pediatric Hospital, which doesn't have a department for infectious diseases.\n\nThe 17-year-old student who died last week [15 Jun 2017] was from the Tarlungeni commune, in Brasov county. He and his friends had attended a party in the Purcareni village [Brasov county] tone week before. The students started to feel bad after this party.\n\nMeningitis is an inflammation (swelling) of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. A bacterial or viral infection of the fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord usually causes the swelling. However, injuries, cancer, certain drugs, and other types of infections can also cause meningitis, according to information posted on the website of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMeningitis symptoms include sudden onset of fever, headache, and stiff neck, but there are also other symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, photophobia (increased sensitivity to light), and altered mental status (confusion).\n\n[Byline: Irina Marica]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The news report above says that one teenage boy has died of bacterial meningitis and 18 of his friends were hospitalized with suspected meningitis; this diagnosis was subsequently confirmed in one. However, the bacterial species that caused the disease is not specified.\n\nAcute bacterial meningitis is a rapidly progressive disease. In a patient with suspected acute bacterial meningitis, blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cultures will indicate the causative organism and its antibiotic susceptibilities. An empiric intravenous antibiotic regimen that has a spectrum broad enough to cover the most likely bacterial pathogens is started as quickly as possible until the specific bacterial etiology is known. It is vital to begin treatment as early as possible in the course of the disease, as delay may contribute significantly to morbidity and mortality. Adjunctive dexamethasone is also given before or with the 1st antibiotic dose. Once a pathogen is known, the antibiotic regimen can be tailored to the antibiotic susceptibilities of the pathogen.\n\nCommon causes of bacterial meningitis vary by age group. Outbreaks of meningitis in the community are often due to _Neisseria meningitidis_. More information on this outbreak would be appreciated from knowledgeable sources.\n\nBrasov is a city with a population of 253 200 residents in Romania and the administrative centre of Brasov County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bra\u0219ov). Tarlungeni is a commune with a population of 7820 residents in Brasov County; it is composed of 4 villages: Carpinis, Purcareni, Tarlungeni and Zizin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T\u0103rlungeni). Liberia (08): fatal, meningitis diagnosed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5057681", "date": "2017-04-07 11:01:09", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (05): (CROSS RIVER) FATAL\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2017\nSource: Daily Post [edited]\nhttp://dailypost.ng/2017/04/05/meningitis-outbreak-hits-cross-river-one-person-confirmed-dead/\n\n\nCerebral meningitis outbreak has reportedly hit Cross River State with one person confirmed dead.\n\nCommissioner of Health in the state, Dr Inyang Asibong, addressing newsmen in Calabar (Capital of Cross River state), on [Wed 5 Apr 2017], shortly after visiting some victims at University of Calabar Teaching Hospital, said about 24 cases have been reported with one confirmed dead.\n\nThe Commissioner said the ministry has put facilities and personnel in place to reduce the impact of the disease, adding that most of the victims have been treated and discharged from the hospital. She added that the death toll would have been heavier if not for the prompt action of her ministry to contain its outbreak.\n\nAsibong said only about 3 people were currently undergoing treatment at the University of Calabar Teaching Hospital (UCTH) just as the situation in the state is calm.\n\nShe said, \"We have recorded one death but we have tried to ensure that the situation is contained, that is why we have put in place facilities and personnel to ensure that as much as possible, we do not record more cases of death.\n\n\"The ministry has started sensitizing the public on the dangers of meningitis in particular and other communicable diseases in general. Besides, the state government has given the ministry the needed support to contain the situation.\n\n\"We are fighting the outbreak of the disease with everything within our power to ensure that the disease is contained as soon as possible. We in the ministry are mobilizing to drastically reduce the Impact of the disease, so we are doing something about the situation.\"\n\n[Byline: John Owen Nwachukwu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A summary of the ongoing meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in Nigeria can be found in item 6 of the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments 20170403.4944602.\n\nCross River is a coastal state in southeastern Nigeria, bordering Cameroon to the east; its capital is Calabar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_River_State). A map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. Niger: fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5048548", "date": "2017-04-07 11:01:09", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (05): (CROSS RIVER) FATAL\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2017\nSource: Daily Post [edited]\nhttp://dailypost.ng/2017/04/05/meningitis-outbreak-hits-cross-river-one-person-confirmed-dead/\n\n\nCerebral meningitis outbreak has reportedly hit Cross River State with one person confirmed dead.\n\nCommissioner of Health in the state, Dr Inyang Asibong, addressing newsmen in Calabar (Capital of Cross River state), on [Wed 5 Apr 2017], shortly after visiting some victims at University of Calabar Teaching Hospital, said about 24 cases have been reported with one confirmed dead.\n\nThe Commissioner said the ministry has put facilities and personnel in place to reduce the impact of the disease, adding that most of the victims have been treated and discharged from the hospital. She added that the death toll would have been heavier if not for the prompt action of her ministry to contain its outbreak.\n\nAsibong said only about 3 people were currently undergoing treatment at the University of Calabar Teaching Hospital (UCTH) just as the situation in the state is calm.\n\nShe said, \"We have recorded one death but we have tried to ensure that the situation is contained, that is why we have put in place facilities and personnel to ensure that as much as possible, we do not record more cases of death.\n\n\"The ministry has started sensitizing the public on the dangers of meningitis in particular and other communicable diseases in general. Besides, the state government has given the ministry the needed support to contain the situation.\n\n\"We are fighting the outbreak of the disease with everything within our power to ensure that the disease is contained as soon as possible. We in the ministry are mobilizing to drastically reduce the Impact of the disease, so we are doing something about the situation.\"\n\n[Byline: John Owen Nwachukwu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A summary of the ongoing meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in Nigeria can be found in item 6 of the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments 20170403.4944602.\n\nCross River is a coastal state in southeastern Nigeria, bordering Cameroon to the east; its capital is Calabar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_River_State).
