Nigeria (08): fatal, sg C", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5032015", "date": "2017-04-07 11:01:09", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (05): (CROSS RIVER) FATAL\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2017\nSource: Daily Post [edited]\nhttp://dailypost.ng/2017/04/05/meningitis-outbreak-hits-cross-river-one-person-confirmed-dead/\n\n\nCerebral meningitis outbreak has reportedly hit Cross River State with one person confirmed dead.\n\nCommissioner of Health in the state, Dr Inyang Asibong, addressing newsmen in Calabar (Capital of Cross River state), on [Wed 5 Apr 2017], shortly after visiting some victims at University of Calabar Teaching Hospital, said about 24 cases have been reported with one confirmed dead.\n\nThe Commissioner said the ministry has put facilities and personnel in place to reduce the impact of the disease, adding that most of the victims have been treated and discharged from the hospital. She added that the death toll would have been heavier if not for the prompt action of her ministry to contain its outbreak.\n\nAsibong said only about 3 people were currently undergoing treatment at the University of Calabar Teaching Hospital (UCTH) just as the situation in the state is calm.\n\nShe said, \"We have recorded one death but we have tried to ensure that the situation is contained, that is why we have put in place facilities and personnel to ensure that as much as possible, we do not record more cases of death.\n\n\"The ministry has started sensitizing the public on the dangers of meningitis in particular and other communicable diseases in general. Besides, the state government has given the ministry the needed support to contain the situation.\n\n\"We are fighting the outbreak of the disease with everything within our power to ensure that the disease is contained as soon as possible. We in the ministry are mobilizing to drastically reduce the Impact of the disease, so we are doing something about the situation.\"\n\n[Byline: John Owen Nwachukwu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A summary of the ongoing meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in Nigeria can be found in item 6 of the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments 20170403.4944602.\n\nCross River is a coastal state in southeastern Nigeria, bordering Cameroon to the east; its capital is Calabar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_River_State). A map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. Nigeria (07): fatal, sg. C", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5027149", "date": "2017-04-07 11:01:09", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (05): (CROSS RIVER) FATAL\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2017\nSource: Daily Post [edited]\nhttp://dailypost.ng/2017/04/05/meningitis-outbreak-hits-cross-river-one-person-confirmed-dead/\n\n\nCerebral meningitis outbreak has reportedly hit Cross River State with one person confirmed dead.\n\nCommissioner of Health in the state, Dr Inyang Asibong, addressing newsmen in Calabar (Capital of Cross River state), on [Wed 5 Apr 2017], shortly after visiting some victims at University of Calabar Teaching Hospital, said about 24 cases have been reported with one confirmed dead.\n\nThe Commissioner said the ministry has put facilities and personnel in place to reduce the impact of the disease, adding that most of the victims have been treated and discharged from the hospital. She added that the death toll would have been heavier if not for the prompt action of her ministry to contain its outbreak.\n\nAsibong said only about 3 people were currently undergoing treatment at the University of Calabar Teaching Hospital (UCTH) just as the situation in the state is calm.\n\nShe said, \"We have recorded one death but we have tried to ensure that the situation is contained, that is why we have put in place facilities and personnel to ensure that as much as possible, we do not record more cases of death.\n\n\"The ministry has started sensitizing the public on the dangers of meningitis in particular and other communicable diseases in general. Besides, the state government has given the ministry the needed support to contain the situation.\n\n\"We are fighting the outbreak of the disease with everything within our power to ensure that the disease is contained as soon as possible. We in the ministry are mobilizing to drastically reduce the Impact of the disease, so we are doing something about the situation.\"\n\n[Byline: John Owen Nwachukwu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A summary of the ongoing meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in Nigeria can be found in item 6 of the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments 20170403.4944602.\n\nCross River is a coastal state in southeastern Nigeria, bordering Cameroon to the east; its capital is Calabar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_River_State). She added that the death toll would have been heavier if not for the prompt action of her ministry to contain its outbreak.\n\nAsibong said only about 3 people were currently undergoing treatment at the University of Calabar Teaching Hospital (UCTH) just as the situation in the state is calm.\n\nShe said, \"We have recorded one death but we have tried to ensure that the situation is contained, that is why we have put in place facilities and personnel to ensure that as much as possible, we do not record more cases of death.\n\n\"The ministry has started sensitizing the public on the dangers of meningitis in particular and other communicable diseases in general. Besides, the state government has given the ministry the needed support to contain the situation.\n\n\"We are fighting the outbreak of the disease with everything within our power to ensure that the disease is contained as soon as possible. We in the ministry are mobilizing to drastically reduce the Impact of the disease, so we are doing something about the situation.\"\n\n[Byline: John Owen Nwachukwu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A summary of the ongoing meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in Nigeria can be found in item 6 of the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments 20170403.4944602.\n\nCross River is a coastal state in southeastern Nigeria, bordering Cameroon to the east; its capital is Calabar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_River_State). A, B and C", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4976236", "date": "2017-04-07 11:01:09", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (05): (CROSS RIVER) FATAL\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2017\nSource: Daily Post [edited]\nhttp://dailypost.ng/2017/04/05/meningitis-outbreak-hits-cross-river-one-person-confirmed-dead/\n\n\nCerebral meningitis outbreak has reportedly hit Cross River State with one person confirmed dead.\n\nCommissioner of Health in the state, Dr Inyang Asibong, addressing newsmen in Calabar (Capital of Cross River state), on [Wed 5 Apr 2017], shortly after visiting some victims at University of Calabar Teaching Hospital, said about 24 cases have been reported with one confirmed dead.\n\nThe Commissioner said the ministry has put facilities and personnel in place to reduce the impact of the disease, adding that most of the victims have been treated and discharged from the hospital. She added that the death toll would have been heavier if not for the prompt action of her ministry to contain its outbreak.\n\nAsibong said only about 3 people were currently undergoing treatment at the University of Calabar Teaching Hospital (UCTH) just as the situation in the state is calm.\n\nShe said, \"We have recorded one death but we have tried to ensure that the situation is contained, that is why we have put in place facilities and personnel to ensure that as much as possible, we do not record more cases of death.\n\n\"The ministry has started sensitizing the public on the dangers of meningitis in particular and other communicable diseases in general. Besides, the state government has given the ministry the needed support to contain the situation.\n\n\"We are fighting the outbreak of the disease with everything within our power to ensure that the disease is contained as soon as possible. We in the ministry are mobilizing to drastically reduce the Impact of the disease, so we are doing something about the situation.\"\n\n[Byline: John Owen Nwachukwu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A summary of the ongoing meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in Nigeria can be found in item 6 of the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments 20170403.4944602.\n\nCross River is a coastal state in southeastern Nigeria, bordering Cameroon to the east; its capital is Calabar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_River_State). She added that the death toll would have been heavier if not for the prompt action of her ministry to contain its outbreak.\n\nAsibong said only about 3 people were currently undergoing treatment at the University of Calabar Teaching Hospital (UCTH) just as the situation in the state is calm.\n\nShe said, \"We have recorded one death but we have tried to ensure that the situation is contained, that is why we have put in place facilities and personnel to ensure that as much as possible, we do not record more cases of death.\n\n\"The ministry has started sensitizing the public on the dangers of meningitis in particular and other communicable diseases in general. Besides, the state government has given the ministry the needed support to contain the situation.\n\n\"We are fighting the outbreak of the disease with everything within our power to ensure that the disease is contained as soon as possible. We in the ministry are mobilizing to drastically reduce the Impact of the disease, so we are doing something about the situation.\"\n\n[Byline: John Owen Nwachukwu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A summary of the ongoing meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in Nigeria can be found in item 6 of the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments 20170403.4944602.\n\nCross River is a coastal state in southeastern Nigeria, bordering Cameroon to the east; its capital is Calabar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_River_State). Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region 20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\n.................................................ml/ec/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Asibong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "sg.susp", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Calabar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4953954", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (05): (CR) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4953954", "date": "2017-04-07 11:01:09", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (05): (CROSS RIVER) FATAL\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Apr 2017\nSource: Daily Post [edited]\nhttp://dailypost.ng/2017/04/05/meningitis-outbreak-hits-cross-river-one-person-confirmed-dead/\n\n\nCerebral meningitis outbreak has reportedly hit Cross River State with one person confirmed dead.\n\nCommissioner of Health in the state, Dr Inyang Asibong, addressing newsmen in Calabar (Capital of Cross River state), on [Wed 5 Apr 2017], shortly after visiting some victims at University of Calabar Teaching Hospital, said about 24 cases have been reported with one confirmed dead.\n\nThe Commissioner said the ministry has put facilities and personnel in place to reduce the impact of the disease, adding that most of the victims have been treated and discharged from the hospital. She added that the death toll would have been heavier if not for the prompt action of her ministry to contain its outbreak.\n\nAsibong said only about 3 people were currently undergoing treatment at the University of Calabar Teaching Hospital (UCTH) just as the situation in the state is calm.\n\nShe said, \"We have recorded one death but we have tried to ensure that the situation is contained, that is why we have put in place facilities and personnel to ensure that as much as possible, we do not record more cases of death.\n\n\"The ministry has started sensitizing the public on the dangers of meningitis in particular and other communicable diseases in general. Besides, the state government has given the ministry the needed support to contain the situation.\n\n\"We are fighting the outbreak of the disease with everything within our power to ensure that the disease is contained as soon as possible. We in the ministry are mobilizing to drastically reduce the Impact of the disease, so we are doing something about the situation.\"\n\n[Byline: John Owen Nwachukwu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A summary of the ongoing meningococcal meningitis serogroup C outbreak in Nigeria can be found in item 6 of the prior ProMED-mail post Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments 20170403.4944602.\n\nCross River is a coastal state in southeastern Nigeria, bordering Cameroon to the east; its capital is Calabar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross_River_State). A map of Nigerian states can be found at: http://dailymail.com.ng/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/10360606_10203337420937904_71905998820449261_n.jpg. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62. - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/41305.]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Niger (05): serogroup C, fatal, vaccine shortage 20150802.3552463\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Niger (04): serogroup C, fatal, WHO, update 20150724.3533998\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Niger (03): serogroup C, fatal, WHO, update 20150517.3368315\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Niger (02): fatal, update 20150506.3344024\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Niger: fatal, serogroups C, W 20150430.3332448\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): serogroup C, MSF, 2013-2014, follow-up 20150325.3252914\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: serogroup C, WHO 20150317.3236196\n2011\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: (YO), susp. 20110524.1581\n2009\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region 20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\n.................................................ml/ec/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Asibong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "sg.susp", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Calabar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4953952", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Ghana: (AH) fatal, high school students, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4953952", "date": "2017-02-26 11:25:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MALTA: FATAL, SEROGROUP B, VACCINE SHORTAGE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Feb 2017\nSource: Times of Malta [edited]\nhttp://www.com/articles/view/20170224/local/meningitis-b-vaccine-shortage-likely-to-persist.640542\n\n\nThe meningitis B vaccine shortage [is] likely to persist. Malta will have to wait its turn, manufacturers say. Global demand for the vaccine outstrips supply, manufacturers say.\n\nA one-year-old baby died of [meningococcal] meningitis [serogroup] B, a disease against which vaccines are currently unavailable, this newspaper is informed. Sources said the baby died last month [January 2017] after contracting the disease that affects the lining around the brain and spinal cord. The Central Procurement and Supplies Unit (CPSU) was informed that the local agent for the meningitis B vaccine had a stock of vaccines available in a number of local pharmacies, a Health Ministry spokeswoman said.\n\nThe representatives of international pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Malta were in liaison with their suppliers to hasten further delivery, and the CPSU was in liaison with both companies to monitor the situation, the spokeswoman added.\n\nThe ministry was also asked about the baby's death, but no reference was made to it in its reply late yesterday [23 Feb 2017] evening.\n\nThe government does not supply the vaccine against the specific strain that affected the infant, which can, however, be purchased from private hospitals and pharmacies. Paediatricians said private hospitals had purchased the vaccine from pharmacies abroad, but these too had since run out.\n\nAccording to one paediatrician, the unavailability of such a vaccine in light of the baby's death was very worrying, particularly to parents. Another paediatrician, however, warned against the matter getting out of hand, saying the issue was not as worrying as parents were making it out to be. Babies who were not vaccinated were not in any immediate danger, he said.\n\nA spokeswoman for the local representative of GSK confirmed that the vaccine was not available and it would not be for some time. She said no fixed date had yet been given as to when a supply would be made available to the local market. According to the spokeswoman, the vaccine was in high demand all over the world, and as GSK [GlaxoSmithKline] had agreements with a number of governments abroad, supplies would be shipped to these countries 1st. At present, demand exceeded the quantity manufactured.\n\n\"It's important to understand that, in these cases, we need to stock enough for boosters, so before sufficient doses are available, this will not be made available,\" the GSK spokeswoman said.\n\nAccording to the Maltese Paediatric Association, about 10 cases of meningitis have been reported among children. The signs of meningitis are fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, vomiting, dislike of bright light and drowsiness. Infants and younger children may not always show such symptoms but, instead, feed poorly or become very lethargic.\n\n[Byline: Claire Caruana]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are at least 13 _ Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W is most common. Meningococcal vaccines contain capsular polysaccharide for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A, C, Y, and W, either alone or conjugated to protein. The conjugate capsular polysaccharide vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines.\n\nSerogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. At least 2 serogroup B meningococcal vaccines -- Bexsero (GlaxoSmithKline, GSK) and Trumenba (Pfizer) -- are available.\n\nMeningococcal disease often occurs without warning and frequently progresses rapidly to death, even when it is treated appropriately. In addition, about 10-20 percent of survivors of meningococcal disease will suffer disabilities such as hearing loss, brain damage, and amputations. Vaccines are used to prevent meningococcal disease, not treat someone already ill from the disease. Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide the vaccine contains regarding the A, C, Y, and W polysaccharide or conjugate vaccines or the surface proteins regarding serogroup B vaccines, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal groups.\n\nVaccines are frequently used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in the face of an institutional or community outbreak (https://www.cdc.gov/meningococcal/downloads/interim-guidance.pdf). Antibiotics are also used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in persons who are at high risk because they have been in close contact (coughing or kissing) or lengthy contact, especially among people living in the same household.\n\nAccording to the 2017 Malta National Immunization Schedule, meningococcal vaccines are not included in the series of vaccines for infants and children (https://health.gov.mt/en/phc/pchyhi/Pages/National-Immunisation-Schedule.aspx). In the U.S., vaccination against meningococcal disease due to serogroups A, C, Y, and W is only recommended for children aged 2 months through 10 years who are at increased risk for meningococcal disease, i.e., have complement component deficiencies, have functional or anatomic asplenia (including sickle cell disease), are in the risk group for an outbreak for which vaccination is recommended, or are traveling to or residing in regions where meningitis is epidemic or hyper-endemic (for specifics, see Table at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6324a2.htm#Tab). The serogroup B vaccines Bexsero and Trumenba have been licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) only for individuals aged 10 through 25 years. However, the European Medicines Agency has approved Bexsero for use in individuals of 2 months of age and older, and Bexsero has been added to the routine childhood immunization schedule in the UK and Ireland (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine).\n\nMalta, a member of the EU, is a southern European island country consisting of an archipelago in the Mediterranean Sea, 80 km (50 miles) south of Italy, with a population of just under 450 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malta). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/77.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (04): (SA) sg B and W 20161118.4639691\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (NJ) college, sg. B 20160505.4204142\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Myanmar: (ML) fatal, sg B, RFI 20160324.4115532\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Ireland: 2010-2013, ext. family, sg.B, sg.B vaccine 20150529.3394758\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Canada: (NS) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150214.3166982\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-01-16 00:00:00", "2017-02-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malta", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4944602", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (04): mass vaccination, comments", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4944602", "date": "2017-02-26 11:25:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MALTA: FATAL, SEROGROUP B, VACCINE SHORTAGE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Feb 2017\nSource: Times of Malta [edited]\nhttp://www.com/articles/view/20170224/local/meningitis-b-vaccine-shortage-likely-to-persist.640542\n\n\nThe meningitis B vaccine shortage [is] likely to persist. Malta will have to wait its turn, manufacturers say. Global demand for the vaccine outstrips supply, manufacturers say.\n\nA one-year-old baby died of [meningococcal] meningitis [serogroup] B, a disease against which vaccines are currently unavailable, this newspaper is informed. Sources said the baby died last month [January 2017] after contracting the disease that affects the lining around the brain and spinal cord. The Central Procurement and Supplies Unit (CPSU) was informed that the local agent for the meningitis B vaccine had a stock of vaccines available in a number of local pharmacies, a Health Ministry spokeswoman said.\n\nThe representatives of international pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Malta were in liaison with their suppliers to hasten further delivery, and the CPSU was in liaison with both companies to monitor the situation, the spokeswoman added.\n\nThe ministry was also asked about the baby's death, but no reference was made to it in its reply late yesterday [23 Feb 2017] evening.\n\nThe government does not supply the vaccine against the specific strain that affected the infant, which can, however, be purchased from private hospitals and pharmacies. Paediatricians said private hospitals had purchased the vaccine from pharmacies abroad, but these too had since run out.\n\nAccording to one paediatrician, the unavailability of such a vaccine in light of the baby's death was very worrying, particularly to parents. Another paediatrician, however, warned against the matter getting out of hand, saying the issue was not as worrying as parents were making it out to be. Babies who were not vaccinated were not in any immediate danger, he said.\n\nA spokeswoman for the local representative of GSK confirmed that the vaccine was not available and it would not be for some time. She said no fixed date had yet been given as to when a supply would be made available to the local market. According to the spokeswoman, the vaccine was in high demand all over the world, and as GSK [GlaxoSmithKline] had agreements with a number of governments abroad, supplies would be shipped to these countries 1st. At present, demand exceeded the quantity manufactured.\n\n\"It's important to understand that, in these cases, we need to stock enough for boosters, so before sufficient doses are available, this will not be made available,\" the GSK spokeswoman said.\n\nAccording to the Maltese Paediatric Association, about 10 cases of meningitis have been reported among children. The signs of meningitis are fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, vomiting, dislike of bright light and drowsiness. Infants and younger children may not always show such symptoms but, instead, feed poorly or become very lethargic.\n\n[Byline: Claire Caruana]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are at least 13 _ Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W is most common. Meningococcal vaccines contain capsular polysaccharide for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A, C, Y, and W, either alone or conjugated to protein. The conjugate capsular polysaccharide vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines.\n\nSerogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. At least 2 serogroup B meningococcal vaccines -- Bexsero (GlaxoSmithKline, GSK) and Trumenba (Pfizer) -- are available.\n\nMeningococcal disease often occurs without warning and frequently progresses rapidly to death, even when it is treated appropriately. In addition, about 10-20 percent of survivors of meningococcal disease will suffer disabilities such as hearing loss, brain damage, and amputations. Vaccines are used to prevent meningococcal disease, not treat someone already ill from the disease. Antibiotics are also used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in persons who are at high risk because they have been in close contact (coughing or kissing) or lengthy contact, especially among people living in the same household.\n\nAccording to the 2017 Malta National Immunization Schedule, meningococcal vaccines are not included in the series of vaccines for infants and children (https://health.gov.mt/en/phc/pchyhi/Pages/National-Immunisation-Schedule.aspx). In the U.S., vaccination against meningococcal disease due to serogroups A, C, Y, and W is only recommended for children aged 2 months through 10 years who are at increased risk for meningococcal disease, i.e., have complement component deficiencies, have functional or anatomic asplenia (including sickle cell disease), are in the risk group for an outbreak for which vaccination is recommended, or are traveling to or residing in regions where meningitis is epidemic or hyper-endemic (for specifics, see Table at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6324a2.htm#Tab). However, the European Medicines Agency has approved Bexsero for use in individuals of 2 months of age and older, and Bexsero has been added to the routine childhood immunization schedule in the UK and Ireland (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine).\n\nMalta, a member of the EU, is a southern European island country consisting of an archipelago in the Mediterranean Sea, 80 km (50 miles) south of Italy, with a population of just under 450 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malta). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/77.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (04): (SA) sg B and W 20161118.4639691\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. Malta will have to wait its turn, manufacturers say. Global demand for the vaccine outstrips supply, manufacturers say.\n\nA one-year-old baby died of [meningococcal] meningitis [serogroup] B, a disease against which vaccines are currently unavailable, this newspaper is informed. Sources said the baby died last month [January 2017] after contracting the disease that affects the lining around the brain and spinal cord. The Central Procurement and Supplies Unit (CPSU) was informed that the local agent for the meningitis B vaccine had a stock of vaccines available in a number of local pharmacies, a Health Ministry spokeswoman said.\n\nThe representatives of international pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Malta were in liaison with their suppliers to hasten further delivery, and the CPSU was in liaison with both companies to monitor the situation, the spokeswoman added.\n\nThe ministry was also asked about the baby's death, but no reference was made to it in its reply late yesterday [23 Feb 2017] evening.\n\nThe government does not supply the vaccine against the specific strain that affected the infant, which can, however, be purchased from private hospitals and pharmacies. Paediatricians said private hospitals had purchased the vaccine from pharmacies abroad, but these too had since run out.\n\nAccording to one paediatrician, the unavailability of such a vaccine in light of the baby's death was very worrying, particularly to parents. Another paediatrician, however, warned against the matter getting out of hand, saying the issue was not as worrying as parents were making it out to be. Babies who were not vaccinated were not in any immediate danger, he said.\n\nA spokeswoman for the local representative of GSK confirmed that the vaccine was not available and it would not be for some time. She said no fixed date had yet been given as to when a supply would be made available to the local market. According to the spokeswoman, the vaccine was in high demand all over the world, and as GSK [GlaxoSmithKline] had agreements with a number of governments abroad, supplies would be shipped to these countries 1st. At present, demand exceeded the quantity manufactured.\n\n\"It's important to understand that, in these cases, we need to stock enough for boosters, so before sufficient doses are available, this will not be made available,\" the GSK spokeswoman said.\n\nAccording to the Maltese Paediatric Association, about 10 cases of meningitis have been reported among children. The signs of meningitis are fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, vomiting, dislike of bright light and drowsiness. Infants and younger children may not always show such symptoms but, instead, feed poorly or become very lethargic.\n\n[Byline: Claire Caruana]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are at least 13 _ Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W is most common. Meningococcal vaccines contain capsular polysaccharide for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A, C, Y, and W, either alone or conjugated to protein. The conjugate capsular polysaccharide vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines.\n\nSerogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. At least 2 serogroup B meningococcal vaccines -- Bexsero (GlaxoSmithKline, GSK) and Trumenba (Pfizer) -- are available.\n\nMeningococcal disease often occurs without warning and frequently progresses rapidly to death, even when it is treated appropriately. In addition, about 10-20 percent of survivors of meningococcal disease will suffer disabilities such as hearing loss, brain damage, and amputations. Vaccines are used to prevent meningococcal disease, not treat someone already ill from the disease. Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide the vaccine contains regarding the A, C, Y, and W polysaccharide or conjugate vaccines or the surface proteins regarding serogroup B vaccines, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal groups.\n\nVaccines are frequently used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in the face of an institutional or community outbreak (https://www.cdc.gov/meningococcal/downloads/interim-guidance.pdf). Antibiotics are also used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in persons who are at high risk because they have been in close contact (coughing or kissing) or lengthy contact, especially among people living in the same household.\n\nAccording to the 2017 Malta National Immunization Schedule, meningococcal vaccines are not included in the series of vaccines for infants and children (https://health.gov.mt/en/phc/pchyhi/Pages/National-Immunisation-Schedule.aspx). In the U.S., vaccination against meningococcal disease due to serogroups A, C, Y, and W is only recommended for children aged 2 months through 10 years who are at increased risk for meningococcal disease, i.e., have complement component deficiencies, have functional or anatomic asplenia (including sickle cell disease), are in the risk group for an outbreak for which vaccination is recommended, or are traveling to or residing in regions where meningitis is epidemic or hyper-endemic (for specifics, see Table at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6324a2.htm#Tab). The serogroup B vaccines Bexsero and Trumenba have been licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) only for individuals aged 10 through 25 years. However, the European Medicines Agency has approved Bexsero for use in individuals of 2 months of age and older, and Bexsero has been added to the routine childhood immunization schedule in the UK and Ireland (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine).\n\nMalta, a member of the EU, is a southern European island country consisting of an archipelago in the Mediterranean Sea, 80 km (50 miles) south of Italy, with a population of just under 450 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malta). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/77.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (04): (SA) sg B and W 20161118.4639691\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (NJ) college, sg. B 20160505.4204142\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Myanmar: (ML) fatal, sg B, RFI 20160324.4115532\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Ireland: 2010-2013, ext. family, sg.B, sg.B vaccine 20150529.3394758\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Canada: (NS) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150214.3166982\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-01-16 00:00:00", "2017-02-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malta", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4933744", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Cameroon: (Yaounde) fatal, sg W", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4933744", "date": "2017-02-26 11:25:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MALTA: FATAL, SEROGROUP B, VACCINE SHORTAGE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Feb 2017\nSource: Times of Malta [edited]\nhttp://www.com/articles/view/20170224/local/meningitis-b-vaccine-shortage-likely-to-persist.640542\n\n\nThe meningitis B vaccine shortage [is] likely to persist. Malta will have to wait its turn, manufacturers say. Global demand for the vaccine outstrips supply, manufacturers say.\n\nA one-year-old baby died of [meningococcal] meningitis [serogroup] B, a disease against which vaccines are currently unavailable, this newspaper is informed. Sources said the baby died last month [January 2017] after contracting the disease that affects the lining around the brain and spinal cord. The Central Procurement and Supplies Unit (CPSU) was informed that the local agent for the meningitis B vaccine had a stock of vaccines available in a number of local pharmacies, a Health Ministry spokeswoman said.\n\nThe representatives of international pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Malta were in liaison with their suppliers to hasten further delivery, and the CPSU was in liaison with both companies to monitor the situation, the spokeswoman added.\n\nThe ministry was also asked about the baby's death, but no reference was made to it in its reply late yesterday [23 Feb 2017] evening.\n\nThe government does not supply the vaccine against the specific strain that affected the infant, which can, however, be purchased from private hospitals and pharmacies. Paediatricians said private hospitals had purchased the vaccine from pharmacies abroad, but these too had since run out.\n\nAccording to one paediatrician, the unavailability of such a vaccine in light of the baby's death was very worrying, particularly to parents. Another paediatrician, however, warned against the matter getting out of hand, saying the issue was not as worrying as parents were making it out to be. Babies who were not vaccinated were not in any immediate danger, he said.\n\nA spokeswoman for the local representative of GSK confirmed that the vaccine was not available and it would not be for some time. She said no fixed date had yet been given as to when a supply would be made available to the local market. According to the spokeswoman, the vaccine was in high demand all over the world, and as GSK [GlaxoSmithKline] had agreements with a number of governments abroad, supplies would be shipped to these countries 1st. At present, demand exceeded the quantity manufactured.\n\n\"It's important to understand that, in these cases, we need to stock enough for boosters, so before sufficient doses are available, this will not be made available,\" the GSK spokeswoman said.\n\nAccording to the Maltese Paediatric Association, about 10 cases of meningitis have been reported among children. The signs of meningitis are fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, vomiting, dislike of bright light and drowsiness. Infants and younger children may not always show such symptoms but, instead, feed poorly or become very lethargic.\n\n[Byline: Claire Caruana]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are at least 13 _ Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W is most common. Meningococcal vaccines contain capsular polysaccharide for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A, C, Y, and W, either alone or conjugated to protein. The conjugate capsular polysaccharide vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines.\n\nSerogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. At least 2 serogroup B meningococcal vaccines -- Bexsero (GlaxoSmithKline, GSK) and Trumenba (Pfizer) -- are available.\n\nMeningococcal disease often occurs without warning and frequently progresses rapidly to death, even when it is treated appropriately. In addition, about 10-20 percent of survivors of meningococcal disease will suffer disabilities such as hearing loss, brain damage, and amputations. Vaccines are used to prevent meningococcal disease, not treat someone already ill from the disease. Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide the vaccine contains regarding the A, C, Y, and W polysaccharide or conjugate vaccines or the surface proteins regarding serogroup B vaccines, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal groups.\n\nVaccines are frequently used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in the face of an institutional or community outbreak (https://www.cdc.gov/meningococcal/downloads/interim-guidance.pdf). Antibiotics are also used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in persons who are at high risk because they have been in close contact (coughing or kissing) or lengthy contact, especially among people living in the same household.\n\nAccording to the 2017 Malta National Immunization Schedule, meningococcal vaccines are not included in the series of vaccines for infants and children (https://health.gov.mt/en/phc/pchyhi/Pages/National-Immunisation-Schedule.aspx). In the U.S., vaccination against meningococcal disease due to serogroups A, C, Y, and W is only recommended for children aged 2 months through 10 years who are at increased risk for meningococcal disease, i.e., have complement component deficiencies, have functional or anatomic asplenia (including sickle cell disease), are in the risk group for an outbreak for which vaccination is recommended, or are traveling to or residing in regions where meningitis is epidemic or hyper-endemic (for specifics, see Table at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6324a2.htm#Tab). The serogroup B vaccines Bexsero and Trumenba have been licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) only for individuals aged 10 through 25 years. However, the European Medicines Agency has approved Bexsero for use in individuals of 2 months of age and older, and Bexsero has been added to the routine childhood immunization schedule in the UK and Ireland (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine).\n\nMalta, a member of the EU, is a southern European island country consisting of an archipelago in the Mediterranean Sea, 80 km (50 miles) south of Italy, with a population of just under 450 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malta). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/77.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (04): (SA) sg B and W 20161118.4639691\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (NJ) college, sg. B 20160505.4204142\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Myanmar: (ML) fatal, sg B, RFI 20160324.4115532\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Ireland: 2010-2013, ext. family, sg.B, sg.B vaccine 20150529.3394758\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Canada: (NS) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. Malta will have to wait its turn, manufacturers say. Global demand for the vaccine outstrips supply, manufacturers say.\n\nA one-year-old baby died of [meningococcal] meningitis [serogroup] B, a disease against which vaccines are currently unavailable, this newspaper is informed. Sources said the baby died last month [January 2017] after contracting the disease that affects the lining around the brain and spinal cord. The Central Procurement and Supplies Unit (CPSU) was informed that the local agent for the meningitis B vaccine had a stock of vaccines available in a number of local pharmacies, a Health Ministry spokeswoman said.\n\nThe representatives of international pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Malta were in liaison with their suppliers to hasten further delivery, and the CPSU was in liaison with both companies to monitor the situation, the spokeswoman added.\n\nThe ministry was also asked about the baby's death, but no reference was made to it in its reply late yesterday [23 Feb 2017] evening.\n\nThe government does not supply the vaccine against the specific strain that affected the infant, which can, however, be purchased from private hospitals and pharmacies. Paediatricians said private hospitals had purchased the vaccine from pharmacies abroad, but these too had since run out.\n\nAccording to one paediatrician, the unavailability of such a vaccine in light of the baby's death was very worrying, particularly to parents. Another paediatrician, however, warned against the matter getting out of hand, saying the issue was not as worrying as parents were making it out to be. Babies who were not vaccinated were not in any immediate danger, he said.\n\nA spokeswoman for the local representative of GSK confirmed that the vaccine was not available and it would not be for some time. She said no fixed date had yet been given as to when a supply would be made available to the local market. According to the spokeswoman, the vaccine was in high demand all over the world, and as GSK [GlaxoSmithKline] had agreements with a number of governments abroad, supplies would be shipped to these countries 1st. At present, demand exceeded the quantity manufactured.\n\n\"It's important to understand that, in these cases, we need to stock enough for boosters, so before sufficient doses are available, this will not be made available,\" the GSK spokeswoman said.\n\nAccording to the Maltese Paediatric Association, about 10 cases of meningitis have been reported among children. The signs of meningitis are fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, vomiting, dislike of bright light and drowsiness. Infants and younger children may not always show such symptoms but, instead, feed poorly or become very lethargic.\n\n[Byline: Claire Caruana]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are at least 13 _ Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W is most common. Meningococcal vaccines contain capsular polysaccharide for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A, C, Y, and W, either alone or conjugated to protein. The conjugate capsular polysaccharide vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines.\n\nSerogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. At least 2 serogroup B meningococcal vaccines -- Bexsero (GlaxoSmithKline, GSK) and Trumenba (Pfizer) -- are available.\n\nMeningococcal disease often occurs without warning and frequently progresses rapidly to death, even when it is treated appropriately. In addition, about 10-20 percent of survivors of meningococcal disease will suffer disabilities such as hearing loss, brain damage, and amputations. Vaccines are used to prevent meningococcal disease, not treat someone already ill from the disease. However, the European Medicines Agency has approved Bexsero for use in individuals of 2 months of age and older, and Bexsero has been added to the routine childhood immunization schedule in the UK and Ireland (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine).\n\nMalta, a member of the EU, is a southern European island country consisting of an archipelago in the Mediterranean Sea, 80 km (50 miles) south of Italy, with a population of just under 450 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malta). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/77.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (04): (SA) sg B and W 20161118.4639691\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. Global demand for the vaccine outstrips supply, manufacturers say.\n\nA one-year-old baby died of [meningococcal] meningitis [serogroup] B, a disease against which vaccines are currently unavailable, this newspaper is informed. Sources said the baby died last month [January 2017] after contracting the disease that affects the lining around the brain and spinal cord. The Central Procurement and Supplies Unit (CPSU) was informed that the local agent for the meningitis B vaccine had a stock of vaccines available in a number of local pharmacies, a Health Ministry spokeswoman said.\n\nThe representatives of international pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Malta were in liaison with their suppliers to hasten further delivery, and the CPSU was in liaison with both companies to monitor the situation, the spokeswoman added.\n\nThe ministry was also asked about the baby's death, but no reference was made to it in its reply late yesterday [23 Feb 2017] evening.\n\nThe government does not supply the vaccine against the specific strain that affected the infant, which can, however, be purchased from private hospitals and pharmacies. Paediatricians said private hospitals had purchased the vaccine from pharmacies abroad, but these too had since run out.\n\nAccording to one paediatrician, the unavailability of such a vaccine in light of the baby's death was very worrying, particularly to parents. Another paediatrician, however, warned against the matter getting out of hand, saying the issue was not as worrying as parents were making it out to be. Babies who were not vaccinated were not in any immediate danger, he said.\n\nA spokeswoman for the local representative of GSK confirmed that the vaccine was not available and it would not be for some time. She said no fixed date had yet been given as to when a supply would be made available to the local market. According to the spokeswoman, the vaccine was in high demand all over the world, and as GSK [GlaxoSmithKline] had agreements with a number of governments abroad, supplies would be shipped to these countries 1st. At present, demand exceeded the quantity manufactured.\n\n\"It's important to understand that, in these cases, we need to stock enough for boosters, so before sufficient doses are available, this will not be made available,\" the GSK spokeswoman said.\n\nAccording to the Maltese Paediatric Association, about 10 cases of meningitis have been reported among children. The signs of meningitis are fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, vomiting, dislike of bright light and drowsiness. Infants and younger children may not always show such symptoms but, instead, feed poorly or become very lethargic.\n\n[Byline: Claire Caruana]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are at least 13 _ Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W is most common. Meningococcal vaccines contain capsular polysaccharide for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A, C, Y, and W, either alone or conjugated to protein. The conjugate capsular polysaccharide vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines.\n\nSerogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. At least 2 serogroup B meningococcal vaccines -- Bexsero (GlaxoSmithKline, GSK) and Trumenba (Pfizer) -- are available.\n\nMeningococcal disease often occurs without warning and frequently progresses rapidly to death, even when it is treated appropriately. In addition, about 10-20 percent of survivors of meningococcal disease will suffer disabilities such as hearing loss, brain damage, and amputations. Vaccines are used to prevent meningococcal disease, not treat someone already ill from the disease. Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide the vaccine contains regarding the A, C, Y, and W polysaccharide or conjugate vaccines or the surface proteins regarding serogroup B vaccines, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal groups.\n\nVaccines are frequently used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in the face of an institutional or community outbreak (https://www.cdc.gov/meningococcal/downloads/interim-guidance.pdf). Antibiotics are also used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in persons who are at high risk because they have been in close contact (coughing or kissing) or lengthy contact, especially among people living in the same household.\n\nAccording to the 2017 Malta National Immunization Schedule, meningococcal vaccines are not included in the series of vaccines for infants and children (https://health.gov.mt/en/phc/pchyhi/Pages/National-Immunisation-Schedule.aspx). In the U.S., vaccination against meningococcal disease due to serogroups A, C, Y, and W is only recommended for children aged 2 months through 10 years who are at increased risk for meningococcal disease, i.e., have complement component deficiencies, have functional or anatomic asplenia (including sickle cell disease), are in the risk group for an outbreak for which vaccination is recommended, or are traveling to or residing in regions where meningitis is epidemic or hyper-endemic (for specifics, see Table at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6324a2.htm#Tab). The serogroup B vaccines Bexsero and Trumenba have been licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) only for individuals aged 10 through 25 years. However, the European Medicines Agency has approved Bexsero for use in individuals of 2 months of age and older, and Bexsero has been added to the routine childhood immunization schedule in the UK and Ireland (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine).\n\nMalta, a member of the EU, is a southern European island country consisting of an archipelago in the Mediterranean Sea, 80 km (50 miles) south of Italy, with a population of just under 450 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malta). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/77.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (04): (SA) sg B and W 20161118.4639691\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (NJ) college, sg. B 20160505.4204142\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Myanmar: (ML) fatal, sg B, RFI 20160324.4115532\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (OR) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150531.3398946\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Ireland: 2010-2013, ext. family, sg.B, sg.B vaccine 20150529.3394758\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Canada: (NS) fatal, college, sg. B, sg. B vaccine 20150214.3166982\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-01-16 00:00:00", "2017-02-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malta", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4865078", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Malta: fatal, serogroup B, vaccine shortage", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4865078", "date": "2017-02-26 11:25:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - MALTA: FATAL, SEROGROUP B, VACCINE SHORTAGE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Feb 2017\nSource: Times of Malta [edited]\nhttp://www.com/articles/view/20170224/local/meningitis-b-vaccine-shortage-likely-to-persist.640542\n\n\nThe meningitis B vaccine shortage [is] likely to persist. Malta will have to wait its turn, manufacturers say. Global demand for the vaccine outstrips supply, manufacturers say.\n\nA one-year-old baby died of [meningococcal] meningitis [serogroup] B, a disease against which vaccines are currently unavailable, this newspaper is informed. Sources said the baby died last month [January 2017] after contracting the disease that affects the lining around the brain and spinal cord. The Central Procurement and Supplies Unit (CPSU) was informed that the local agent for the meningitis B vaccine had a stock of vaccines available in a number of local pharmacies, a Health Ministry spokeswoman said.\n\nThe representatives of international pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in Malta were in liaison with their suppliers to hasten further delivery, and the CPSU was in liaison with both companies to monitor the situation, the spokeswoman added.\n\nThe ministry was also asked about the baby's death, but no reference was made to it in its reply late yesterday [23 Feb 2017] evening.\n\nThe government does not supply the vaccine against the specific strain that affected the infant, which can, however, be purchased from private hospitals and pharmacies. Paediatricians said private hospitals had purchased the vaccine from pharmacies abroad, but these too had since run out.\n\nAccording to one paediatrician, the unavailability of such a vaccine in light of the baby's death was very worrying, particularly to parents. Another paediatrician, however, warned against the matter getting out of hand, saying the issue was not as worrying as parents were making it out to be. Babies who were not vaccinated were not in any immediate danger, he said.\n\nA spokeswoman for the local representative of GSK confirmed that the vaccine was not available and it would not be for some time. She said no fixed date had yet been given as to when a supply would be made available to the local market. According to the spokeswoman, the vaccine was in high demand all over the world, and as GSK [GlaxoSmithKline] had agreements with a number of governments abroad, supplies would be shipped to these countries 1st. At present, demand exceeded the quantity manufactured.\n\n\"It's important to understand that, in these cases, we need to stock enough for boosters, so before sufficient doses are available, this will not be made available,\" the GSK spokeswoman said.\n\nAccording to the Maltese Paediatric Association, about 10 cases of meningitis have been reported among children. The signs of meningitis are fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, vomiting, dislike of bright light and drowsiness. Infants and younger children may not always show such symptoms but, instead, feed poorly or become very lethargic.\n\n[Byline: Claire Caruana]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are at least 13 _ Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W is most common. Meningococcal vaccines contain capsular polysaccharide for _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroups A, C, Y, and W, either alone or conjugated to protein. The conjugate capsular polysaccharide vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines.\n\nSerogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B outer membrane vesicle protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen. At least 2 serogroup B meningococcal vaccines -- Bexsero (GlaxoSmithKline, GSK) and Trumenba (Pfizer) -- are available.\n\nMeningococcal disease often occurs without warning and frequently progresses rapidly to death, even when it is treated appropriately. In addition, about 10-20 percent of survivors of meningococcal disease will suffer disabilities such as hearing loss, brain damage, and amputations. Vaccines are used to prevent meningococcal disease, not treat someone already ill from the disease. Immunity following use of a meningococcal vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide the vaccine contains regarding the A, C, Y, and W polysaccharide or conjugate vaccines or the surface proteins regarding serogroup B vaccines, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal groups.\n\nVaccines are frequently used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in the face of an institutional or community outbreak (https://www.cdc.gov/meningococcal/downloads/interim-guidance.pdf). Antibiotics are also used to prevent spread of meningococcal disease in persons who are at high risk because they have been in close contact (coughing or kissing) or lengthy contact, especially among people living in the same household.\n\nAccording to the 2017 Malta National Immunization Schedule, meningococcal vaccines are not included in the series of vaccines for infants and children (https://health.gov.mt/en/phc/pchyhi/Pages/National-Immunisation-Schedule.aspx). In the U.S., vaccination against meningococcal disease due to serogroups A, C, Y, and W is only recommended for children aged 2 months through 10 years who are at increased risk for meningococcal disease, i.e., have complement component deficiencies, have functional or anatomic asplenia (including sickle cell disease), are in the risk group for an outbreak for which vaccination is recommended, or are traveling to or residing in regions where meningitis is epidemic or hyper-endemic (for specifics, see Table at https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6324a2.htm#Tab). The serogroup B vaccines Bexsero and Trumenba have been licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) only for individuals aged 10 through 25 years. However, the European Medicines Agency has approved Bexsero for use in individuals of 2 months of age and older, and Bexsero has been added to the routine childhood immunization schedule in the UK and Ireland (http://www.meningitis.org/menb-vaccine).\n\nMalta, a member of the EU, is a southern European island country consisting of an archipelago in the Mediterranean Sea, 80 km (50 miles) south of Italy, with a population of just under 450 000 residents (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malta). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/77.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (OR) college, sg B, sg B vaccine 20161123.4649319\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (04): (SA) sg B and W 20161118.4639691\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B vaccine 20150214.3166982\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2017-01-16 00:00:00", "2017-02-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malta", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4863648", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Togo: fatal, emergence of serogroup W", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4863648", "date": "2016-09-25 12:56:52", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AUSTRALIA (03): (WESTERN AUSTRALIA) SEROGROUP W\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 24 Sep 2016\nSource: The West Australian [edited]\nhttps://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/wa/a/32713148/rare-strain-of-bacteria-on-the-rise/#page1\n\n\n3/4ths of the cases of meningococcal disease in WA [Western Australia] so far this year [2016] have been caused by rare W strains [_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup W] that very few people are vaccinated against. Figures obtained by The Weekend West show 9 of the 12 cases of the disease this year have been linked to strains from the bacteria group W. Type B [_Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup B] caused the other 3.\n\nMeningococcal disease is a rare, life-threatening illness caused by a bacterial infection of the blood or the membranes that line the spinal cord and brain.\n\nA young WA child -- the 12th case this year [2016] -- died from the disease last week. In the past, there have been virtually no local cases caused by W strains, but there were 2 in 2014, 4 cases last year [2015] and 9 this year. The WA Health Department said this week it was monitoring the trend, which was also being seen in states including Victoria and could have implications for vaccination recommendations.\n\nVictorian authorities have seen a sharp rise in a group W strain known as ST11, which was responsible for 4 per cent of meningococcal cases in 2013 but 30 percent of cases last year [2015].\n\nAt present, a vaccine to protect against type C meningococcal disease, historically the most common in Australia, is free for children and given at 12 months [of age]. A vaccine against meningococcal B, the most common type in WA [the 1st paragraph above says that this year [2016] serogroup W, not serogroup B, is the most common serogroup], is available but not government-funded. There is a privately funded vaccine against W strains, but it is usually only advised for overseas travellers.\n\nThe Health Department spokesman said that while the overall number of invasive meningococcal disease cases in WA had been falling since 2000, there had been a recent increase in cases linked to W strains.\n\nThe Telethon Kids Institute is doing a trial of a vaccine against the A, C, W and Y strains in young children.\n\n[Byline: Cathy O'Leary]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Neisseria meningitidis_ only infects humans; there is no animal reservoir, and the organism dies quickly outside the human host. _N. meningitidis_ colonizes the mucosal membranes of the nose and throat; up to 5-10 percent of a population may be asymptomatic nasopharyngeal carriers, but the carrier rate may be higher in epidemic situations. Droplets of nasopharyngeal secretions from these carriers are responsible for the spread of the disease. Close and prolonged contact with an infected person or a carrier facilitates the spread of the disease. The average incubation period is 4 days but can range between 2 and 10 days.\n\nImmunity following use of a meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide that the vaccine contains, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. Although there are at least 13 _N. meningitidis_ serogroups, based on the antigenic specificity of their capsular polysaccharides, disease due to serogroups A, B, C, Y, and W135 are most common.\n\nThere are vaccines that contain capsular polysaccharide (A, C, Y, W135), either alone or conjugated to protein. Conjugate vaccines are preferable, because, unlike the polysaccharide vaccines, conjugate vaccines immunize infants, reduce the carriage of meningococci in the throat and thus its transmission, as well as confer a more sustained immune response, and, therefore, longer-term protection than the polysaccharide vaccines. Serogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen.\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population of a vaccine specific for one particular serogroup, the incidence of disease due to that serogroup has been found to fall dramatically, e.g., serogroup C disease in the UK following the introduction of C vaccine and serogroup A in the African Meningitis Belt following A vaccine, only to be replaced by emergence of disease due to other meningococcal serogroups.\n\nSimilarly, serotype replacement has been observed following pneumococcal vaccination programs, which necessitated expansion of serotypes covered by the vaccine (see ProMED-mail post Streptococcus pneumoniae, non-vaccine strain emergence - USA (AK) 20070425.1348).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroup W ST-11 as a cause of invasive meningococcal disease in the UK, the UK is now offering an expanded conjugated serogroup vaccine, Men ACWY, for adolescents, who are more likely to carry meningococcal bacteria than any other age group, to stop the spread of serogroup W. This is being done by replacing the routine teenage Men C booster with the Men ACWY vaccine (http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/vaccinations/Pages/men-acwy-vaccine.aspx).\n\nWestern Australia, covering the entire western 1/3rd of Australia, is mostly arid, its population being concentrated in the fertile southwest corner and its capital, Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Australia). - Mod.ML\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/289.]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (SA) sg. B 20160515.4222568 13 May Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (SA) RFI 20160513.4220868\n2015\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - UK: emergence of serogroup W, changed vaccine policy 20150926.3673122\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Niger (05): serogroup C, fatal, vaccine shortage 20150802.3552463\nMeningitis - Sudan (Khartoum) RFI 20150531.3398711\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Niger (03): serogroup C, fatal, WHO, update 20150517.3368315\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia (QL) fatal 20110801.2310\n.................................................sb/ml/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khartoum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perth", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4808261", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Undiagnosed illness - The average incubation period is 4 days but can range between 2 and 10 days.\n\nImmunity following use of a meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is specific for the type of capsular polysaccharide that the vaccine contains, with no cross-protection against infection due to other meningococcal polysaccharide groups. Serogroup B vaccines are based upon meningococcal B protein antigens, because group B polysaccharide is poorly immunogenic in humans and is a potential auto-antigen.\n\nFollowing the mass introduction into the population of a vaccine specific for one particular serogroup, the incidence of disease due to that serogroup has been found to fall dramatically, e.g., serogroup C disease in the UK following the introduction of C vaccine and serogroup A in the African Meningitis Belt following A vaccine, only to be replaced by emergence of disease due to other meningococcal serogroups.\n\nSimilarly, serotype replacement has been observed following pneumococcal vaccination programs, which necessitated expansion of serotypes covered by the vaccine (see ProMED-mail post Streptococcus pneumoniae, non-vaccine strain emergence - USA (AK) 20070425.1348).\n\nBecause of the replacement of serogroup C by serogroup W ST-11 as a cause of invasive meningococcal disease in the UK, the UK is now offering an expanded conjugated serogroup vaccine, Men ACWY, for adolescents, who are more likely to carry meningococcal bacteria than any other age group, to stop the spread of serogroup W.
