Chile: (VS, RM) RFI 20121016.1346329\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nChile is currently facing an increase of meningococcal disease and also a shift of serotypes compared to the year 2011.\n\nThe surveillance system of the Chilean Ministry of Health has reported the following numbers, which reflect the epidemiological situation of meningococcal disease for 2012 from week 1 to 40 [1 Jan-6 Oct 2012]:\n\nThere are a total of 83 accumulated cases compared with 52 for the total of 2011 (median number of cases 2007-2011: 76). The increase is mainly observed in 2 Chilean regions: the Metropolitan Region (RM), which includes Santiago, with 58 percent of cases and the region of Valparaiso with 21 percent of cases. The RM is divided into several health administrative regions; of those, 3 were mostly affected.\n\nInterestingly, in the RM 76 percent of cases were caused by serogroup W135, compared with 14 percent and 48 percent in the years 2010 and 2011, respectively. This epidemiological change is not observed in the other regions, where serogroup B is predominant.\n\nThe most affected age groups are children under the age of 5 (48 percent of cases); almost half of those are 9 months or younger. In the age group under 5 years, 55 percent of the cases are caused by serogroup W135.\n\nThe reported case fatality rate reached 20 percent (17/83) and seems to be higher than in previous years (2011: 15 percent). This increase might be related to serogroup W135, since, of 9 fatal cases with available serogroup, 6 belonged to this group. According to our information, the Chilean Ministry of Health is planning to start a targeted vaccination campaign (with quadrivalent conjugate vaccine) focusing on the areas and age groups mostly affected by serotype W135 by the end of October 2012.\n\n--\nJeannette Dabanch, Alberto Fica, and Thomas Weitzel\nComite de Infecciones Emergentes\nSociedad Chilena de Infectologia, Santiago, Chile\nAv Bernarda Morin 488\nSantiago\nChile\n<thomas.weitzel@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks the authors for a more detailed, authoritative description of the outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in Chile.\n\nA map of Chile's regions can be seen at http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/chilfung/chile_regions.gif. Chile (05): (RM) airplane exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1464977", "date": "2012-10-17 14:54:29", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHILE (02): (VALPARAISO, SANTIAGO METROPOLITAN REGION) UPDATE\n*****************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Oct 2012\nFrom: Thomas Weitzel <thomas.weitzel@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile: (VS, RM) RFI 20121016.1346329\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nChile is currently facing an increase of meningococcal disease and also a shift of serotypes compared to the year 2011.\n\nThe surveillance system of the Chilean Ministry of Health has reported the following numbers, which reflect the epidemiological situation of meningococcal disease for 2012 from week 1 to 40 [1 Jan-6 Oct 2012]:\n\nThere are a total of 83 accumulated cases compared with 52 for the total of 2011 (median number of cases 2007-2011: 76). The increase is mainly observed in 2 Chilean regions: the Metropolitan Region (RM), which includes Santiago, with 58 percent of cases and the region of Valparaiso with 21 percent of cases. The RM is divided into several health administrative regions; of those, 3 were mostly affected.\n\nInterestingly, in the RM 76 percent of cases were caused by serogroup W135, compared with 14 percent and 48 percent in the years 2010 and 2011, respectively. This epidemiological change is not observed in the other regions, where serogroup B is predominant.\n\nThe most affected age groups are children under the age of 5 (48 percent of cases); almost half of those are 9 months or younger. In the age group under 5 years, 55 percent of the cases are caused by serogroup W135.\n\nThe reported case fatality rate reached 20 percent (17/83) and seems to be higher than in previous years (2011: 15 percent). This increase might be related to serogroup W135, since, of 9 fatal cases with available serogroup, 6 belonged to this group. According to our information, the Chilean Ministry of Health is planning to start a targeted vaccination campaign (with quadrivalent conjugate vaccine) focusing on the areas and age groups mostly affected by serotype W135 by the end of October 2012.\n\n--\nJeannette Dabanch, Alberto Fica, and Thomas Weitzel\nComite de Infecciones Emergentes\nSociedad Chilena de Infectologia, Santiago, Chile\nAv Bernarda Morin 488\nSantiago\nChile\n<thomas.weitzel@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks the authors for a more detailed, authoritative description of the outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in Chile.\n\nA map of Chile's regions can be seen at http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/chilfung/chile_regions.gif. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Chile can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aht. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chile: (VS, RM) RFI 20121016.1346329\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (NY) fatal, MSM 20120929.1315676\nMeningitis, meningococcal - France ex African Meningitis Belt 20120526.1145958\nMeningitis, meningococcal - USA: (CA) lab-acquired, fatal 20120505.1124002\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Australia: (QL) 20120415.1101797\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa 20120325.1080222\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Ghana: (Upper East Region), susp. 20120225.1052072\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Viet Nam: (Ho Chi Minh City) 20120117.1012861\n2011\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: (YO), susp. 20110524.1581\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad: WHO 20110309.0763\n.................................................ml/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Valparaiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santiago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "RM", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1414639", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile (04): (RM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1414639", "date": "2012-10-17 14:54:29", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CHILE (02): (VALPARAISO, SANTIAGO METROPOLITAN REGION) UPDATE\n*****************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Oct 2012\nFrom: Thomas Weitzel <thomas.weitzel@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Meningitis, meningococcal - Chile: (VS, RM) RFI 20121016.1346329\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nChile is currently facing an increase of meningococcal disease and also a shift of serotypes compared to the year 2011.\n\nThe surveillance system of the Chilean Ministry of Health has reported the following numbers, which reflect the epidemiological situation of meningococcal disease for 2012 from week 1 to 40 [1 Jan-6 Oct 2012]:\n\nThere are a total of 83 accumulated cases compared with 52 for the total of 2011 (median number of cases 2007-2011: 76). The increase is mainly observed in 2 Chilean regions: the Metropolitan Region (RM), which includes Santiago, with 58 percent of cases and the region of Valparaiso with 21 percent of cases. The RM is divided into several health administrative regions; of those, 3 were mostly affected.\n\nInterestingly, in the RM 76 percent of cases were caused by serogroup W135, compared with 14 percent and 48 percent in the years 2010 and 2011, respectively. This epidemiological change is not observed in the other regions, where serogroup B is predominant.\n\nThe most affected age groups are children under the age of 5 (48 percent of cases); almost half of those are 9 months or younger. In the age group under 5 years, 55 percent of the cases are caused by serogroup W135.\n\nThe reported case fatality rate reached 20 percent (17/83) and seems to be higher than in previous years (2011: 15 percent). This increase might be related to serogroup W135, since, of 9 fatal cases with available serogroup, 6 belonged to this group. According to our information, the Chilean Ministry of Health is planning to start a targeted vaccination campaign (with quadrivalent conjugate vaccine) focusing on the areas and age groups mostly affected by serotype W135 by the end of October 2012.\n\n--\nJeannette Dabanch, Alberto Fica, and Thomas Weitzel\nComite de Infecciones Emergentes\nSociedad Chilena de Infectologia, Santiago, Chile\nAv Bernarda Morin 488\nSantiago\nChile\n<thomas.weitzel@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks the authors for a more detailed, authoritative description of the outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in Chile.\n\nA map of Chile's regions can be seen at http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/chilfung/chile_regions.gif. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Chile can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1Aht. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chile: (VS, RM) RFI 20121016.1346329\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chile: (VS, RM) RFI 20121016.1346329\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nChile is currently facing an increase of meningococcal disease and also a shift of serotypes compared to the year 2011.\n\nThe surveillance system of the Chilean Ministry of Health has reported the following numbers, which reflect the epidemiological situation of meningococcal disease for 2012 from week 1 to 40 [1 Jan-6 Oct 2012]:\n\nThere are a total of 83 accumulated cases compared with 52 for the total of 2011 (median number of cases 2007-2011: 76). The increase is mainly observed in 2 Chilean regions: the Metropolitan Region (RM), which includes Santiago, with 58 percent of cases and the region of Valparaiso with 21 percent of cases. The RM is divided into several health administrative regions; of those, 3 were mostly affected.\n\nInterestingly, in the RM 76 percent of cases were caused by serogroup W135, compared with 14 percent and 48 percent in the years 2010 and 2011, respectively. This epidemiological change is not observed in the other regions, where serogroup B is predominant.\n\nThe most affected age groups are children under the age of 5 (48 percent of cases); almost half of those are 9 months or younger. In the age group under 5 years, 55 percent of the cases are caused by serogroup W135.\n\nThe reported case fatality rate reached 20 percent (17/83) and seems to be higher than in previous years (2011: 15 percent). This increase might be related to serogroup W135, since, of 9 fatal cases with available serogroup, 6 belonged to this group. According to our information, the Chilean Ministry of Health is planning to start a targeted vaccination campaign (with quadrivalent conjugate vaccine) focusing on the areas and age groups mostly affected by serotype W135 by the end of October 2012.\n\n--\nJeannette Dabanch, Alberto Fica, and Thomas Weitzel\nComite de Infecciones Emergentes\nSociedad Chilena de Infectologia, Santiago, Chile\nAv Bernarda Morin 488\nSantiago\nChile\n<thomas.weitzel@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks the authors for a more detailed, authoritative description of the outbreak of meningococcal meningitis in Chile.\n\nA map of Chile's regions can be seen at http://www.cybertruffle.org.uk/chilfung/chile_regions.gif. The RM is divided into several health administrative regions; of those, 3 were mostly affected.\n\nInterestingly, in the RM 76 percent of cases were caused by serogroup W135, compared with 14 percent and 48 percent in the years 2010 and 2011, respectively. This epidemiological change is not observed in the other regions, where serogroup B is predominant.\n\nThe most affected age groups are children under the age of 5 (48 percent of cases); almost half of those are 9 months or younger. In the age group under 5 years, 55 percent of the cases are caused by serogroup W135.\n\nThe reported case fatality rate reached 20 percent (17/83) and seems to be higher than in previous years (2011: 15 percent). This increase might be related to serogroup W135, since, of 9 fatal cases with available serogroup, 6 belonged to this group. Chile: (VS, RM) RFI"}, {"archive_id": "1337615", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aspergillus meningitis - USA (09): Exserohilum"}, {"archive_id": "1335715", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aspergillus meningitis - USA (08)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1335715", "date": "2012-10-04 10:49:49", "main_text": "ASPERGILLUS MENINGITIS - USA (02): CONTAMINATED DRUG\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 Oct 2012\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/10/03/cdc-rare-meningitis/1611095/\n\n\nAn outbreak of a rare and deadly form of meningitis has now sickened 26 people in 5 states who received steroid injections, health officials said Wed 3 Oct 2012. 4 people have died.\n\n18 of the cases are in Tennessee where a Nashville clinic received the largest shipment of the steroid suspected in the outbreak. The drug was made by a specialty pharmacy in Massachusetts that has since issued a recall.\n\n3 cases have been reported in Virginia, 2 in Maryland, 2 in Florida, and 1 in North Carolina. 2 of the deaths were in Tennessee; Virginia and Maryland had 1 each, the CDC said. More new cases are almost certain to appear in the coming days, said Tennessee Department of Health Commissioner John Dreyzehner. Cases in that state began in July 2012 and 5 new cases were confirmed over the past 24 hours, he said Wed 3 Oct 2012.\n\nInvestigators have been looking into at least 3 different products used for the back injections that could have been tainted by the fungus that appears to be behind the illnesses. None of the products have been ruled out. However, the primary suspicion is on steroid medication, which is commonly used for back pain.\n\nThe FDA identified the maker of the steroid as the New England Compounding Center, a specialty pharmacy in Framingham, Massachusetts. Last week [week of 24 Sep 2012], the company issued a recall of 3 lots of the steroid. Company officials could not be immediately reached Wednesday afternoon, 3 Oct 2012, by telephone; the company's website was unavailable.\n\nAn infectious diseases specialist at Vanderbilt University says he believes the country will see more cases in the upcoming weeks. Dr. William Schaffner chairs Vanderbilt's Department of Preventive Medicine. He has been following the investigation into the cause of the infection since it was first detected in a patient at the university's hospital about 2 weeks ago. Schaffner said he believes part of the reason for the Nashville cluster is early detection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More cases and more states are involved. To date, the mold has not yet been isolated from the suspected vehicle and the species of _Aspergillus_ has not been stated. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]\nSee Also\nAspergillus meningitis - USA: (TN, NC) contaminated drug 20121002.1320024\n2002\n----\nFungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA (03) 20021212.6046\nFungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA: alert (02) 20021117.5831\nFungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA: alert 20021002.5444\n.................................................ll/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-07-16 00:00:00", "2012-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "Nashville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Framingham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1333926", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aspergillus meningitis - USA (07)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1333926", "date": "2012-10-04 10:49:49", "main_text": "ASPERGILLUS MENINGITIS - USA (02): CONTAMINATED DRUG\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 Oct 2012\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/10/03/cdc-rare-meningitis/1611095/\n\n\nAn outbreak of a rare and deadly form of meningitis has now sickened 26 people in 5 states who received steroid injections, health officials said Wed 3 Oct 2012. 4 people have died.\n\n18 of the cases are in Tennessee where a Nashville clinic received the largest shipment of the steroid suspected in the outbreak. The drug was made by a specialty pharmacy in Massachusetts that has since issued a recall.\n\n3 cases have been reported in Virginia, 2 in Maryland, 2 in Florida, and 1 in North Carolina. 2 of the deaths were in Tennessee; Virginia and Maryland had 1 each, the CDC said. More new cases are almost certain to appear in the coming days, said Tennessee Department of Health Commissioner John Dreyzehner. Cases in that state began in July 2012 and 5 new cases were confirmed over the past 24 hours, he said Wed 3 Oct 2012.\n\nInvestigators have been looking into at least 3 different products used for the back injections that could have been tainted by the fungus that appears to be behind the illnesses. None of the products have been ruled out. However, the primary suspicion is on steroid medication, which is commonly used for back pain.\n\nThe FDA identified the maker of the steroid as the New England Compounding Center, a specialty pharmacy in Framingham, Massachusetts. Last week [week of 24 Sep 2012], the company issued a recall of 3 lots of the steroid. Company officials could not be immediately reached Wednesday afternoon, 3 Oct 2012, by telephone; the company's website was unavailable.\n\nAn infectious diseases specialist at Vanderbilt University says he believes the country will see more cases in the upcoming weeks. Dr. William Schaffner chairs Vanderbilt's Department of Preventive Medicine. He has been following the investigation into the cause of the infection since it was first detected in a patient at the university's hospital about 2 weeks ago. Schaffner said he believes part of the reason for the Nashville cluster is early detection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More cases and more states are involved. USA: alert 20021002.5444\n.................................................ll/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-07-16 00:00:00", "2012-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "Nashville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Framingham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1333004", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aspergillus meningitis - USA (06): CDC advice", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1333004", "date": "2012-10-04 10:49:49", "main_text": "ASPERGILLUS MENINGITIS - USA (02): CONTAMINATED DRUG\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 Oct 2012\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/10/03/cdc-rare-meningitis/1611095/\n\n\nAn outbreak of a rare and deadly form of meningitis has now sickened 26 people in 5 states who received steroid injections, health officials said Wed 3 Oct 2012. 4 people have died.\n\n18 of the cases are in Tennessee where a Nashville clinic received the largest shipment of the steroid suspected in the outbreak. The drug was made by a specialty pharmacy in Massachusetts that has since issued a recall.\n\n3 cases have been reported in Virginia, 2 in Maryland, 2 in Florida, and 1 in North Carolina. 2 of the deaths were in Tennessee; Virginia and Maryland had 1 each, the CDC said. More new cases are almost certain to appear in the coming days, said Tennessee Department of Health Commissioner John Dreyzehner. Cases in that state began in July 2012 and 5 new cases were confirmed over the past 24 hours, he said Wed 3 Oct 2012.\n\nInvestigators have been looking into at least 3 different products used for the back injections that could have been tainted by the fungus that appears to be behind the illnesses. None of the products have been ruled out. However, the primary suspicion is on steroid medication, which is commonly used for back pain.\n\nThe FDA identified the maker of the steroid as the New England Compounding Center, a specialty pharmacy in Framingham, Massachusetts. Last week [week of 24 Sep 2012], the company issued a recall of 3 lots of the steroid. Company officials could not be immediately reached Wednesday afternoon, 3 Oct 2012, by telephone; the company's website was unavailable.\n\nAn infectious diseases specialist at Vanderbilt University says he believes the country will see more cases in the upcoming weeks. Dr. William Schaffner chairs Vanderbilt's Department of Preventive Medicine. He has been following the investigation into the cause of the infection since it was first detected in a patient at the university's hospital about 2 weeks ago. Schaffner said he believes part of the reason for the Nashville cluster is early detection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More cases and more states are involved. To date, the mold has not yet been isolated from the suspected vehicle and the species of _Aspergillus_ has not been stated. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]\nSee Also\nAspergillus meningitis - USA: alert 20021002.5444\n.................................................ll/mj/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-07-16 00:00:00", "2012-09-24 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "Nashville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Framingham", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1330309", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aspergillus meningitis - USA (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1330309", "date": "2012-10-04 10:49:49", "main_text": "ASPERGILLUS MENINGITIS - USA (02): CONTAMINATED DRUG\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 Oct 2012\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/10/03/cdc-rare-meningitis/1611095/\n\n\nAn outbreak of a rare and deadly form of meningitis has now sickened 26 people in 5 states who received steroid injections, health officials said Wed 3 Oct 2012. 4 people have died.\n\n18 of the cases are in Tennessee where a Nashville clinic received the largest shipment of the steroid suspected in the outbreak. The drug was made by a specialty pharmacy in Massachusetts that has since issued a recall.\n\n3 cases have been reported in Virginia, 2 in Maryland, 2 in Florida, and 1 in North Carolina. 2 of the deaths were in Tennessee; Virginia and Maryland had 1 each, the CDC said. More new cases are almost certain to appear in the coming days, said Tennessee Department of Health Commissioner John Dreyzehner. Cases in that state began in July 2012 and 5 new cases were confirmed over the past 24 hours, he said Wed 3 Oct 2012.\n\nInvestigators have been looking into at least 3 different products used for the back injections that could have been tainted by the fungus that appears to be behind the illnesses. None of the products have been ruled out. However, the primary suspicion is on steroid medication, which is commonly used for back pain.\n\nThe FDA identified the maker of the steroid as the New England Compounding Center, a specialty pharmacy in Framingham, Massachusetts. Last week [week of 24 Sep 2012], the company issued a recall of 3 lots of the steroid. Company officials could not be immediately reached Wednesday afternoon, 3 Oct 2012, by telephone; the company's website was unavailable.\n\nAn infectious diseases specialist at Vanderbilt University says he believes the country will see more cases in the upcoming weeks. Dr. William Schaffner chairs Vanderbilt's Department of Preventive Medicine. He has been following the investigation into the cause of the infection since it was first detected in a patient at the university's hospital about 2 weeks ago. Schaffner said he believes part of the reason for the Nashville cluster is early detection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More cases and more states are involved. To date, the mold has not yet been isolated from the suspected vehicle and the species of _Aspergillus_ has not been stated. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]\nSee Also\nAspergillus meningitis - USA (04): more cases, 2nd fungus", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1328893", "date": "2012-10-04 10:49:49", "main_text": "ASPERGILLUS MENINGITIS - USA (02): CONTAMINATED DRUG\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 Oct 2012\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/10/03/cdc-rare-meningitis/1611095/\n\n\nAn outbreak of a rare and deadly form of meningitis has now sickened 26 people in 5 states who received steroid injections, health officials said Wed 3 Oct 2012. 4 people have died.\n\n18 of the cases are in Tennessee where a Nashville clinic received the largest shipment of the steroid suspected in the outbreak. The drug was made by a specialty pharmacy in Massachusetts that has since issued a recall.\n\n3 cases have been reported in Virginia, 2 in Maryland, 2 in Florida, and 1 in North Carolina. 2 of the deaths were in Tennessee; Virginia and Maryland had 1 each, the CDC said. More new cases are almost certain to appear in the coming days, said Tennessee Department of Health Commissioner John Dreyzehner. Cases in that state began in July 2012 and 5 new cases were confirmed over the past 24 hours, he said Wed 3 Oct 2012.\n\nInvestigators have been looking into at least 3 different products used for the back injections that could have been tainted by the fungus that appears to be behind the illnesses. None of the products have been ruled out. However, the primary suspicion is on steroid medication, which is commonly used for back pain.\n\nThe FDA identified the maker of the steroid as the New England Compounding Center, a specialty pharmacy in Framingham, Massachusetts. Last week [week of 24 Sep 2012], the company issued a recall of 3 lots of the steroid. Company officials could not be immediately reached Wednesday afternoon, 3 Oct 2012, by telephone; the company's website was unavailable.\n\nAn infectious diseases specialist at Vanderbilt University says he believes the country will see more cases in the upcoming weeks. Dr. William Schaffner chairs Vanderbilt's Department of Preventive Medicine. He has been following the investigation into the cause of the infection since it was first detected in a patient at the university's hospital about 2 weeks ago. Schaffner said he believes part of the reason for the Nashville cluster is early detection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More cases and more states are involved. The drug was made by a specialty pharmacy in Massachusetts that has since issued a recall.\n\n3 cases have been reported in Virginia, 2 in Maryland, 2 in Florida, and 1 in North Carolina. 2 of the deaths were in Tennessee; Virginia and Maryland had 1 each, the CDC said. More new cases are almost certain to appear in the coming days, said Tennessee Department of Health Commissioner John Dreyzehner. Cases in that state began in July 2012 and 5 new cases were confirmed over the past 24 hours, he said Wed 3 Oct 2012.\n\nInvestigators have been looking into at least 3 different products used for the back injections that could have been tainted by the fungus that appears to be behind the illnesses. None of the products have been ruled out. However, the primary suspicion is on steroid medication, which is commonly used for back pain.\n\nThe FDA identified the maker of the steroid as the New England Compounding Center, a specialty pharmacy in Framingham, Massachusetts. Last week [week of 24 Sep 2012], the company issued a recall of 3 lots of the steroid. Company officials could not be immediately reached Wednesday afternoon, 3 Oct 2012, by telephone; the company's website was unavailable.\n\nAn infectious diseases specialist at Vanderbilt University says he believes the country will see more cases in the upcoming weeks. Dr. William Schaffner chairs Vanderbilt's Department of Preventive Medicine. He has been following the investigation into the cause of the infection since it was first detected in a patient at the university's hospital about 2 weeks ago. The drug was made by a specialty pharmacy in Massachusetts that has since issued a recall.\n\n3 cases have been reported in Virginia, 2 in Maryland, 2 in Florida, and 1 in North Carolina. 2 of the deaths were in Tennessee; Virginia and Maryland had 1 each, the CDC said. More new cases are almost certain to appear in the coming days, said Tennessee Department of Health Commissioner John Dreyzehner. Cases in that state began in July 2012 and 5 new cases were confirmed over the past 24 hours, he said Wed 3 Oct 2012.\n\nInvestigators have been looking into at least 3 different products used for the back injections that could have been tainted by the fungus that appears to be behind the illnesses. None of the products have been ruled out. However, the primary suspicion is on steroid medication, which is commonly used for back pain.\n\nThe FDA identified the maker of the steroid as the New England Compounding Center, a specialty pharmacy in Framingham, Massachusetts. In October [2011], he was working on an organic farm on the Big Island when he ate fruit growing wild. He was hospitalized on 10 Nov 2011 for 7 weeks in Hilo.\n\nThe Honolulu Star-Advertiser (http://bit.ly/znWVbc) reported Mon 13 Feb 2012 that the patient said from his Watertown, Minnesota home that he wants to urge people in Hawaii to carefully wash produce to avoid ingesting slugs or snails that can spread rat lungworm disease.\n\nThe present patient is one of 37 cases confirmed or tested probable for the disease in Hawaii from 2005 to 2011. A Big Island baby is the only fatality since 2005, when the state Department of Health began collecting data.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail can only support the suggestion that fruits and vegetables be thoroughly cleaned before being consumed. - In October [2011], he was working on an organic farm on the Big Island when he ate fruit growing wild. He was hospitalized on 10 Nov 2011 for 7 weeks in Hilo.\n\nThe Honolulu Star-Advertiser (http://bit.ly/znWVbc) reported Mon 13 Feb 2012 that the patient said from his Watertown, Minnesota home that he wants to urge people in Hawaii to carefully wash produce to avoid ingesting slugs or snails that can spread rat lungworm disease.\n\nThe present patient is one of 37 cases confirmed or tested probable for the disease in Hawaii from 2005 to 2011. France ex African Meningitis Belt", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1145958", "date": "2012-02-16 16:29:35", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - USA: (HAWAII)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 Feb 2012\nSource: The Republic [edited]\nhttp://www.therepublic.com/view/story/5c3a3956b9074e2084218608e3cf1cce/HI--Rat-Lungworm-Disease/\n\n\nA 22 year old Minnesota man is recovering from a rare form of meningitis he believes he contracted by eating unwashed fruit in Hawaii. In October [2011], he was working on an organic farm on the Big Island when he ate fruit growing wild. He was hospitalized on 10 Nov 2011 for 7 weeks in Hilo.\n\nThe Honolulu Star-Advertiser (http://bit.ly/znWVbc) reported Mon 13 Feb 2012 that the patient said from his Watertown, Minnesota home that he wants to urge people in Hawaii to carefully wash produce to avoid ingesting slugs or snails that can spread rat lungworm disease.\n\nThe present patient is one of 37 cases confirmed or tested probable for the disease in Hawaii from 2005 to 2011. A Big Island baby is the only fatality since 2005, when the state Department of Health began collecting data.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail can only support the suggestion that fruits and vegetables be thoroughly cleaned before being consumed. - Ecuador: (Los Rios) 20081231.4123\n2007\n---\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - Brazil (ES) 20070414.1244\n2000\n---\nEosinophilic meningitis - USA (Chicago) ex Jamaica (03) 20000508.0705\n1998\n---\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis - Viet Nam: (Ho Chi Minh City)"}, {"archive_id": "975124", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Brazil: (BA)"}, {"archive_id": "946642", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, drug-induced - India (02): Mumbai, comment"}, {"archive_id": "945942", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, drug-induced - India: (Mumbai)"}, {"archive_id": "908372", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - Australia: Sydney"}, {"archive_id": "875862", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - New Zealand: (NO)"}, {"archive_id": "813259", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (02): (QL) fatal"}, {"archive_id": "804163", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Australia (QL) fatal"}, {"archive_id": "728785", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: (YO), susp."}, {"archive_id": "671338", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Chad: WHO"}, {"archive_id": "621264", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, postinf. hydrocephalus, Acinetobacter - Uganda"}, {"archive_id": "615580", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (03): (CO) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=615580", "date": "2010-08-13 16:00:04", "main_text": "ASEPTIC MENINGITIS - LATVIA, SERBIA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[The summary and conclusion sections of the following reports are posted to\nillustrate the diversity of the enteric viruses, predominantly\nenteroviruses, currently associated with outbreaks of aseptic meningitis in\nEuropean countries. Interested readers should access the full texts to view\nthe data and literature references. - Mod.CP]\n\n[1] Latvia\n[2] Serbia\n\n******\n[1] Latvia\nDate: Thu 12 Aug 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2010; 15(32) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19639>\n\n\nOngoing outbreak of aseptic meningitis in south-eastern Latvia, Jun-Aug 2010\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n[authors: J Perevoscikovs, A Brila, L Firstova, T Komarova, I et al, State\nAgency Infectology Center of Latvia, Riga, Latvia]\n\nSummary\n-------\nAn outbreak of aseptic meningitis has been ongoing in several areas of\nLatgale region, in the south-eastern part of Latvia since the end of June\n2010. By 9 Aug 2010, 114 cases had been notified. Most of the cases were\nregistered in the city and amalgamated municipality of Daugavpils and\nneighbouring territories. According to current evidence, 2 types of\nenteroviruses, coxsackie A-9 virus and echovirus 30, are the causative\nagents of the outbreak.\n\nDiscussion and conclusions\n--------------------------\nA large aseptic meningitis outbreak caused by at least 2 enteroviruses\n(coxsackie A-9 virus and echovirus 30) is still ongoing in the\nsouth-eastern part of Latvia. The epidemiological pattern of the outbreak\n(age and sex distribution of cases) corresponds to the usual characteristic\nof the enteroviral infection, with the majority of cases in males and young\nchildren or adolescents. The incidence of aseptic meningitis was high in\n2006 and 2007, and low in 2008 and 2009. Although in previous non-epidemic\nyears (2007-2009), seasonal increases of enteroviral meningitis began in\nMay to June, this year [2010] the outbreak started later, at the end of June.\n\nIn view of the seasonal character (summer-autumn) of enteroviral infections\nand taking into account reopening of schools after the summer holidays,\nfurther spread, importation, and transmission of infection to other Latvian\nregions cannot be excluded. The risk of international spread is assessed as\nnot significant. Further monitoring and data analysis are to be performed\non a regular basis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Latvia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/02yo>. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[2] Serbia\nDate: Thu 12 Aug 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2010; 15(32) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19638>\n\n\nOngoing outbreak of aseptic meningitis associated with echovirus 30 in the\ncity of Novi Sad, Autonomous province of Vojvodina, Serbia, Jun-Jul 2010\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\n[authors: G Cosic 1, P Duric 1, V Milosevic 2, J Dekic 1, G Canak 3, V\nTurkulov3\n1. Centre for Disease Control and Prevention, Institute of Public Health of\nVojvodina, Novi Sad, Autonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia\n2. Centre for Virology, Institute of Public Health of Vojvodina, Novi Sad,\nAutonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia\n3. Clinic for Infectious Diseases, Clinical Centre of Vojvodina, Novi Sad,\nAutonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia]\n\nSummary\n-------\nSince June 2010, incidence of aseptic meningitis has increased in Novi Sad,\nAutonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia. From 2 Jun to 25 Jul 2010, 80\ncases of aseptic meningitis were notified, with an incidence rate ranging\nfrom 10 to 366 per 100 000 population in different local communities. The\nmajority of cases (n=64) were aged between 2 and 15 years. Echovirus 30 was\ncultured from 2 of 4 cerebrospinal fluid specimens. The outbreak, for which\nno common source has yet been identified, is ongoing.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nOutbreaks of aseptic enteroviral meningitis are notified in the Autonomous\nProvince of Vojvodina every 4 to 5 years. The largest previous outbreak\noccurred in 2000, with 461 cases reported that year (the incidence rate in\nthe province was 23 per 100 000 population and incidence rate in the City\nof Novi Sad was 28 per 100 000 population). Outbreaks of aseptic\nenteroviral meningitis were notified in all neighbouring countries\n(Croatia, Hungary, and Romania) in the last 2 decades. In Kosovo under\nUnited Nations Security Council Resolution 1244, an outbreak with a total\nof 878 cases of acute neurological syndrome was reported in 2006 to the\nWorld Health Organization Regional Office for Europe: enteroviral origin\nwas detected. Enteroviral meningitis outbreaks involved many communities\nthroughout other countries within Europe and also other continents.\n\nAs expected in temperate climate, the ongoing outbreak has occurred in hot\nsummer months, spreading by direct or indirect contact. Although none of\nthe common sources (contaminated food or water) has yet been implicated,\nsince viral meningitis outbreaks are sometimes associated with recreational\nuse of water, the use of public swimming pools had been considered a\npotential source of infection in this outbreak but no such exposure of\ncases has been identified.\n\nPreviously reported outbreaks of enteroviral meningitis have demonstrated a\npredominance of males in child cases, with a sex ratio of 2:1. Our findings\nare consistent with this. They are also in line with these reports that\nfind a large proportion (70 per cent) of cases under 15 years of age, but\nthere was a higher incidence rate (149 per 100 000 population) in children\naged 5-15 years.\n\nAccording to its epidemiological features, this outbreak is likely to\ncontinue towards the autumn months. No specific control measures are\navailable for non-polio enteroviruses. Good personal and communal hygiene\nis recommended (thorough hand washing as a routine practice, prompt and\nsafe disposal of waste and faeces, and prompt washing or disposal of the\nsoiled articles in preschool and nursery facilities), as well as\ndisinfection of contaminated surfaces with household cleaning products, and\navoidance of shared utensils and drinking containers. All susceptible\npeople and parents of young children are advised to ask for medical help\nimmediately when there is onset of sudden headaches, fever, nausea, and\nvomiting.\n\nA 3-step model has been suggested for diagnostic procedures in order to\nensure comprehensive diagnostic investigation, including local medical\ninvestigation and usual analysis (polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and\nserology) of acute cases, then as a 2nd step, extended analysis of\nsuspected cases by a reference laboratory for commonly recognised causative\nagents (or less common agents if indicated, such as, in returning\ntravellers), and finally identification of specific pathogens in cases with\nunknown aetiology.\n\nMonitoring circulating enteroviruses is important because individual\nserotypes have different temporal patterns of circulation and the changes\nin predominant serotypes can be accompanied by large-scale outbreaks of\nenteroviral illnesses. Environmental surveillance has been used\nsuccessfully in monitoring enterovirus circulation and assessing the extent\nor duration of epidemic non-poliovirus enteroviruses in specific populations.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Serbia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/02yq>.\n\nViral (\"aseptic\") meningitis is serious but rarely fatal in people with\nnormal immune systems. Usually, the symptoms last from 7 to 10 days and the\npatient recovers completely. Different viral infections can lead to viral\nmeningitis. But most cases, particularly during the summer and fall months,\nare caused by enteroviruses (which include enteroviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nand echoviruses). Most people who are infected with enteroviruses either\nhave no symptoms or only get a cold, rash, or mouth sores with low-grade\nfever. And, only a small number of people with enterovirus infections\ndevelop meningitis.\n\nEnteroviruses, the most common cause of viral meningitis, are most often\nspread through direct contact with an infected person's stool. The virus is\nspread through this route mainly among small children who are not yet\ntoilet trained. It can also be spread this way to adults changing the\ndiapers of an infected infant.\n\nEnteroviruses and other viruses can also be spread through direct or\nindirect contact with respiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal\nmucus) of an infected person. This usually happens through kissing or\nshaking hands with an infected person or by touching something they have\nhandled and then rubbing your own nose or mouth. The viruses can also stay\non surfaces for days and can be transferred from objects. Viruses also can\nspread directly when infected people cough or sneeze and send droplets\ncontaining the virus into the air we breathe.\n\nThe time from when a person is infected until they develop symptoms\n(incubation period) is usually between 3 and 7 days for enteroviruses. An\ninfected person is usually contagious from the time they develop symptoms\nuntil the symptoms go away. Young children and people with low immune\nsystems may spread the infection even after symptoms have resolved. For\nmore detailed information see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/about/faq.html>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nAseptic meningitis, Toscana virus - Germany: (BW) 20100802.2587\n2009\n---\nAseptic meningitis, Toscana virus - Switzerland ex Italy (Elba) 20090108.0081\n2004\n---\nAseptic meningitis, school children - Russia (Ekaterinburg) 20041017.2820\nAseptic meningitis - Russia (Novosibirsk) (03) 20040828.2404\nAseptic meningitis - Russia (Novosibirsk) (02) 20040817.2277\n2003\n---\nEchovirus 9, aseptic meningitis - USA (CT) 2003 20040814.2253\nEchovirus 30, aseptic meningitis - Puerto Rico 20040810.2211\nAseptic meningitis - Russia (Novosibirsk) 20040803.2112\n1998\n---\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Minnesota) (02) 19980820.1664\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Iowa) 19980818.1650\nAseptic meningitis 19980817.1638\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Indiana) 19980813.1612\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Missouri) 19980813.1608\nAseptic meningitis - Canada (Saskatchewan) 19980812.1584\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Washington) 19980812.1583\nAseptic meningitis - USA (South Dakota) 19980811.1570\nAseptic meningitis - USA: RFI 19980808.1552\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Minnesota) 19980806.1515\n\n.................cp/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################"}, {"archive_id": "612096", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (02): (CO) fatal"}, {"archive_id": "546051", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Namibia: fatal, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=546051", "date": "2010-08-13 16:00:04", "main_text": "ASEPTIC MENINGITIS - LATVIA, SERBIA\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[The summary and conclusion sections of the following reports are posted to\nillustrate the diversity of the enteric viruses, predominantly\nenteroviruses, currently associated with outbreaks of aseptic meningitis in\nEuropean countries. Interested readers should access the full texts to view\nthe data and literature references. - Mod.CP]\n\n[1] Latvia\n[2] Serbia\n\n******\n[1] Latvia\nDate: Thu 12 Aug 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2010; 15(32) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19639>\n\n\nOngoing outbreak of aseptic meningitis in south-eastern Latvia, Jun-Aug 2010\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n[authors: J Perevoscikovs, A Brila, L Firstova, T Komarova, I et al, State\nAgency Infectology Center of Latvia, Riga, Latvia]\n\nSummary\n-------\nAn outbreak of aseptic meningitis has been ongoing in several areas of\nLatgale region, in the south-eastern part of Latvia since the end of June\n2010. By 9 Aug 2010, 114 cases had been notified. Most of the cases were\nregistered in the city and amalgamated municipality of Daugavpils and\nneighbouring territories. According to current evidence, 2 types of\nenteroviruses, coxsackie A-9 virus and echovirus 30, are the causative\nagents of the outbreak.\n\nDiscussion and conclusions\n--------------------------\nA large aseptic meningitis outbreak caused by at least 2 enteroviruses\n(coxsackie A-9 virus and echovirus 30) is still ongoing in the\nsouth-eastern part of Latvia. The epidemiological pattern of the outbreak\n(age and sex distribution of cases) corresponds to the usual characteristic\nof the enteroviral infection, with the majority of cases in males and young\nchildren or adolescents. The incidence of aseptic meningitis was high in\n2006 and 2007, and low in 2008 and 2009. Although in previous non-epidemic\nyears (2007-2009), seasonal increases of enteroviral meningitis began in\nMay to June, this year [2010] the outbreak started later, at the end of June.\n\nIn view of the seasonal character (summer-autumn) of enteroviral infections\nand taking into account reopening of schools after the summer holidays,\nfurther spread, importation, and transmission of infection to other Latvian\nregions cannot be excluded. The risk of international spread is assessed as\nnot significant. Further monitoring and data analysis are to be performed\non a regular basis.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Latvia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/02yo>. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[2] Serbia\nDate: Thu 12 Aug 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2010; 15(32) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19638>\n\n\nOngoing outbreak of aseptic meningitis associated with echovirus 30 in the\ncity of Novi Sad, Autonomous province of Vojvodina, Serbia, Jun-Jul 2010\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\n[authors: G Cosic 1, P Duric 1, V Milosevic 2, J Dekic 1, G Canak 3, V\nTurkulov3\n1. Centre for Disease Control and Prevention, Institute of Public Health of\nVojvodina, Novi Sad, Autonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia\n2. Centre for Virology, Institute of Public Health of Vojvodina, Novi Sad,\nAutonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia\n3. Clinic for Infectious Diseases, Clinical Centre of Vojvodina, Novi Sad,\nAutonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia]\n\nSummary\n-------\nSince June 2010, incidence of aseptic meningitis has increased in Novi Sad,\nAutonomous Province of Vojvodina, Serbia. From 2 Jun to 25 Jul 2010, 80\ncases of aseptic meningitis were notified, with an incidence rate ranging\nfrom 10 to 366 per 100 000 population in different local communities. The\nmajority of cases (n=64) were aged between 2 and 15 years. Echovirus 30 was\ncultured from 2 of 4 cerebrospinal fluid specimens. The outbreak, for which\nno common source has yet been identified, is ongoing.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nOutbreaks of aseptic enteroviral meningitis are notified in the Autonomous\nProvince of Vojvodina every 4 to 5 years. The largest previous outbreak\noccurred in 2000, with 461 cases reported that year (the incidence rate in\nthe province was 23 per 100 000 population and incidence rate in the City\nof Novi Sad was 28 per 100 000 population). Outbreaks of aseptic\nenteroviral meningitis were notified in all neighbouring countries\n(Croatia, Hungary, and Romania) in the last 2 decades. In Kosovo under\nUnited Nations Security Council Resolution 1244, an outbreak with a total\nof 878 cases of acute neurological syndrome was reported in 2006 to the\nWorld Health Organization Regional Office for Europe: enteroviral origin\nwas detected. Enteroviral meningitis outbreaks involved many communities\nthroughout other countries within Europe and also other continents.\n\nAs expected in temperate climate, the ongoing outbreak has occurred in hot\nsummer months, spreading by direct or indirect contact. Although none of\nthe common sources (contaminated food or water) has yet been implicated,\nsince viral meningitis outbreaks are sometimes associated with recreational\nuse of water, the use of public swimming pools had been considered a\npotential source of infection in this outbreak but no such exposure of\ncases has been identified.\n\nPreviously reported outbreaks of enteroviral meningitis have demonstrated a\npredominance of males in child cases, with a sex ratio of 2:1. Our findings\nare consistent with this. They are also in line with these reports that\nfind a large proportion (70 per cent) of cases under 15 years of age, but\nthere was a higher incidence rate (149 per 100 000 population) in children\naged 5-15 years.\n\nAccording to its epidemiological features, this outbreak is likely to\ncontinue towards the autumn months. No specific control measures are\navailable for non-polio enteroviruses. Good personal and communal hygiene\nis recommended (thorough hand washing as a routine practice, prompt and\nsafe disposal of waste and faeces, and prompt washing or disposal of the\nsoiled articles in preschool and nursery facilities), as well as\ndisinfection of contaminated surfaces with household cleaning products, and\navoidance of shared utensils and drinking containers. All susceptible\npeople and parents of young children are advised to ask for medical help\nimmediately when there is onset of sudden headaches, fever, nausea, and\nvomiting.\n\nA 3-step model has been suggested for diagnostic procedures in order to\nensure comprehensive diagnostic investigation, including local medical\ninvestigation and usual analysis (polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and\nserology) of acute cases, then as a 2nd step, extended analysis of\nsuspected cases by a reference laboratory for commonly recognised causative\nagents (or less common agents if indicated, such as, in returning\ntravellers), and finally identification of specific pathogens in cases with\nunknown aetiology.\n\nMonitoring circulating enteroviruses is important because individual\nserotypes have different temporal patterns of circulation and the changes\nin predominant serotypes can be accompanied by large-scale outbreaks of\nenteroviral illnesses. Environmental surveillance has been used\nsuccessfully in monitoring enterovirus circulation and assessing the extent\nor duration of epidemic non-poliovirus enteroviruses in specific populations.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Serbia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/02yq>.\n\nViral (\"aseptic\") meningitis is serious but rarely fatal in people with\nnormal immune systems. Usually, the symptoms last from 7 to 10 days and the\npatient recovers completely. Different viral infections can lead to viral\nmeningitis. But most cases, particularly during the summer and fall months,\nare caused by enteroviruses (which include enteroviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nand echoviruses). Most people who are infected with enteroviruses either\nhave no symptoms or only get a cold, rash, or mouth sores with low-grade\nfever. And, only a small number of people with enterovirus infections\ndevelop meningitis.\n\nEnteroviruses, the most common cause of viral meningitis, are most often\nspread through direct contact with an infected person's stool. The virus is\nspread through this route mainly among small children who are not yet\ntoilet trained. It can also be spread this way to adults changing the\ndiapers of an infected infant.\n\nEnteroviruses and other viruses can also be spread through direct or\nindirect contact with respiratory secretions (saliva, sputum, or nasal\nmucus) of an infected person. This usually happens through kissing or\nshaking hands with an infected person or by touching something they have\nhandled and then rubbing your own nose or mouth. The viruses can also stay\non surfaces for days and can be transferred from objects. Viruses also can\nspread directly when infected people cough or sneeze and send droplets\ncontaining the virus into the air we breathe.\n\nThe time from when a person is infected until they develop symptoms\n(incubation period) is usually between 3 and 7 days for enteroviruses. An\ninfected person is usually contagious from the time they develop symptoms\nuntil the symptoms go away. Young children and people with low immune\nsystems may spread the infection even after symptoms have resolved. For\nmore detailed information see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/meningitis/about/faq.html>. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nAseptic meningitis, Toscana virus - Germany: (BW) 20100802.2587\n2009\n---\nAseptic meningitis, Toscana virus - Switzerland ex Italy (Elba) 20090108.0081\n2004\n---\nAseptic meningitis, school children - Russia (Ekaterinburg) 20041017.2820\nAseptic meningitis - Russia (Novosibirsk) (03) 20040828.2404\nAseptic meningitis - Russia (Novosibirsk) (02) 20040817.2277\n2003\n---\nEchovirus 9, aseptic meningitis - USA (CT) 2003 20040814.2253\nEchovirus 30, aseptic meningitis - Puerto Rico 20040810.2211\nAseptic meningitis - Russia (Novosibirsk) 20040803.2112\n1998\n---\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Minnesota) (02) 19980820.1664\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Iowa) 19980818.1650\nAseptic meningitis 19980817.1638\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Indiana) 19980813.1612\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Missouri) 19980813.1608\nAseptic meningitis - Canada (Saskatchewan) 19980812.1584\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Washington) 19980812.1583\nAseptic meningitis - USA (South Dakota) 19980811.1570\nAseptic meningitis - USA: RFI 19980808.1552\nAseptic meningitis - USA (Minnesota) 19980806.1515\n\n.................cp/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################"}, {"archive_id": "492065", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aseptic meningitis - Latvia, Serbia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=492065", "date": "2010-08-13 16:00:04"}, {"archive_id": "481470", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Aseptic meningitis, Toscana virus - Germany: (BW)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=481470", "date": "2010-05-07 16:00:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA (03): BURKINA FASO\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 5 May 2010\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, Plan report [edited]\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/KHII-8573J3?OpenDocument>\n\n\n[Burkina Faso] is being hit especially hard by the disease, with a new\nstrain of the virus, known as strain X, already claiming half of all the\n718 meningitis-related deaths since the beginning of the year [2010]. In 5\ndistricts the disease is at epidemic level, and 9 more districts are on\nhigh alert.\n\nThe mortality rate is particularly high at 14 per cent. Worryingly,\nchildren and young people are the most affected group, with 80 per cent of\npatients aged between 2 and 30. There is no vaccine for strain X.\n\nPlan Burkina Faso has stepped up efforts to deal with the outbreak. Funding\nis planned for antibiotics, other treatments, laboratory use, and equipment\nand vaccines against the other strains of meningitis, which are still\nkilling many. So far 5118 people nationally have been treated for the disease.\n\nThe country has never seen so many cases of this new type of meningitis,\nstrain X. As there is no vaccine for it, the focus for the moment must\nremain on antibiotic treatment.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of deaths, the number of people nationally who have been\ntreated for meningitis, and the case fatality rate in Burkina Faso since\nthe start of 2010 reported in the news release above is about the same as\nthat reported in a prior ProMED-mail post, Meningitis, meningococcal -\nAfrica (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343. However, what is new is\nthe fact that _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup X is responsible for half\nof all the 718 meningitis-related deaths since the beginning of the year\n(2010).\n\nMass immunization with the appropriate polysaccharide vaccine is a useful\ncontrol measure during an epidemic. However, there is no vaccine for\nserogroup X. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended to eliminate nasopharyngeal\ncarriage of _N. meningitidis_ as soon as possible in close contacts of\npersons with invasive meningococcal disease (such as, household members,\nday-care center contacts, and persons directly exposed to the patient's\noral secretions), whose risk for acquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800\ntimes greater than among the general population (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). The rate of\nsecondary disease for close contacts is highest immediately after onset of\ndisease in the index patient.\n\nHowever, chemoprophylaxis has not generally been recommended during\nepidemics (see <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8625860>), because\nmultiple sources of exposure, prolonged risk of exposure, logistic\nproblems, and high cost make this an impractical alternative. When used,\nthe antimicrobials commonly used for chemoprophylaxis are rifampicin,\nciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and ceftriaxone, although rifampicin- and\nciprofloxacin-resistant meningococcal disease in close contacts has been\nreported following had chemoprophylaxis with these antibiotics (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no06/05-0143.htm> and\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm>).\n\nA map showing the regions in Burkina Faso can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Burkina_Faso>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0188>. A map of the African bacterial meningitis\nbelt can be found at <http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100225.0627\nMeningitis - Chad: (LR,MA) RFI 20100223.0600\nMeningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507\n2009\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR: (HC) 20091213.4233\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\n2002\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR (North Kivu) 20021129.5928\n\n.................ml/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "467020", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Mexico: (BN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=467020", "date": "2010-05-07 16:00:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA (03): BURKINA FASO\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 5 May 2010\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, Plan report [edited]\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/KHII-8573J3?OpenDocument>\n\n\n[Burkina Faso] is being hit especially hard by the disease, with a new\nstrain of the virus, known as strain X, already claiming half of all the\n718 meningitis-related deaths since the beginning of the year [2010]. In 5\ndistricts the disease is at epidemic level, and 9 more districts are on\nhigh alert.\n\nThe mortality rate is particularly high at 14 per cent. Worryingly,\nchildren and young people are the most affected group, with 80 per cent of\npatients aged between 2 and 30. There is no vaccine for strain X.\n\nPlan Burkina Faso has stepped up efforts to deal with the outbreak. Funding\nis planned for antibiotics, other treatments, laboratory use, and equipment\nand vaccines against the other strains of meningitis, which are still\nkilling many. So far 5118 people nationally have been treated for the disease.\n\nThe country has never seen so many cases of this new type of meningitis,\nstrain X. As there is no vaccine for it, the focus for the moment must\nremain on antibiotic treatment.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of deaths, the number of people nationally who have been\ntreated for meningitis, and the case fatality rate in Burkina Faso since\nthe start of 2010 reported in the news release above is about the same as\nthat reported in a prior ProMED-mail post, Meningitis, meningococcal -\nAfrica (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343. However, what is new is\nthe fact that _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup X is responsible for half\nof all the 718 meningitis-related deaths since the beginning of the year\n(2010).\n\nMass immunization with the appropriate polysaccharide vaccine is a useful\ncontrol measure during an epidemic. However, there is no vaccine for\nserogroup X. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended to eliminate nasopharyngeal\ncarriage of _N. meningitidis_ as soon as possible in close contacts of\npersons with invasive meningococcal disease (such as, household members,\nday-care center contacts, and persons directly exposed to the patient's\noral secretions), whose risk for acquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800\ntimes greater than among the general population (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). The rate of\nsecondary disease for close contacts is highest immediately after onset of\ndisease in the index patient.\n\nHowever, chemoprophylaxis has not generally been recommended during\nepidemics (see <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8625860>), because\nmultiple sources of exposure, prolonged risk of exposure, logistic\nproblems, and high cost make this an impractical alternative. When used,\nthe antimicrobials commonly used for chemoprophylaxis are rifampicin,\nciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and ceftriaxone, although rifampicin- and\nciprofloxacin-resistant meningococcal disease in close contacts has been\nreported following had chemoprophylaxis with these antibiotics (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no06/05-0143.htm> and\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm>).\n\nA map showing the regions in Burkina Faso can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Burkina_Faso>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0188>. A map of the African bacterial meningitis\nbelt can be found at <http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100225.0627\nMeningitis - Chad: (LR,MA) RFI 20100223.0600\nMeningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507\n2009\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR: (HC) 20091213.4233\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. However, there is no vaccine for\nserogroup X. The rate of\nsecondary disease for close contacts is highest immediately after onset of\ndisease in the index patient.\n\nHowever, chemoprophylaxis has not generally been recommended during\nepidemics (see <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8625860>), because\nmultiple sources of exposure, prolonged risk of exposure, logistic\nproblems, and high cost make this an impractical alternative. In 5\ndistricts the disease is at epidemic level, and 9 more districts are on\nhigh alert.\n\nThe mortality rate is particularly high at 14 per cent. Worryingly,\nchildren and young people are the most affected group, with 80 per cent of\npatients aged between 2 and 30. There is no vaccine for strain X.\n\nPlan Burkina Faso has stepped up efforts to deal with the outbreak. Funding\nis planned for antibiotics, other treatments, laboratory use, and equipment\nand vaccines against the other strains of meningitis, which are still\nkilling many. So far 5118 people nationally have been treated for the disease.\n\nThe country has never seen so many cases of this new type of meningitis,\nstrain X. As there is no vaccine for it, the focus for the moment must\nremain on antibiotic treatment.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of deaths, the number of people nationally who have been\ntreated for meningitis, and the case fatality rate in Burkina Faso since\nthe start of 2010 reported in the news release above is about the same as\nthat reported in a prior ProMED-mail post, Meningitis, meningococcal -\nAfrica (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343. However, what is new is\nthe fact that _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup X is responsible for half\nof all the 718 meningitis-related deaths since the beginning of the year\n(2010).\n\nMass immunization with the appropriate polysaccharide vaccine is a useful\ncontrol measure during an epidemic. However, there is no vaccine for\nserogroup X. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended to eliminate nasopharyngeal\ncarriage of _N. meningitidis_ as soon as possible in close contacts of\npersons with invasive meningococcal disease (such as, household members,\nday-care center contacts, and persons directly exposed to the patient's\noral secretions), whose risk for acquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800\ntimes greater than among the general population (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). The rate of\nsecondary disease for close contacts is highest immediately after onset of\ndisease in the index patient.\n\nHowever, chemoprophylaxis has not generally been recommended during\nepidemics (see <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8625860>), because\nmultiple sources of exposure, prolonged risk of exposure, logistic\nproblems, and high cost make this an impractical alternative. When used,\nthe antimicrobials commonly used for chemoprophylaxis are rifampicin,\nciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and ceftriaxone, although rifampicin- and\nciprofloxacin-resistant meningococcal disease in close contacts has been\nreported following had chemoprophylaxis with these antibiotics (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no06/05-0143.htm> and\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm>).\n\nA map showing the regions in Burkina Faso can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Burkina_Faso>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0188>. A map of the African bacterial meningitis\nbelt can be found at <http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100225.0627\nMeningitis - Chad: (LR,MA) RFI 20100223.0600\nMeningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507\n2009\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR: (HC) 20091213.4233\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\n2002\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR (North Kivu) 20021129.5928\n\n.................ml/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
