Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "428193", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Enteroviral meningitis - Canada: (BC) ex Dominican Republic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=428193", "date": "2010-05-07 16:00:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA (03): BURKINA FASO\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 5 May 2010\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, Plan report [edited]\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/KHII-8573J3?OpenDocument>\n\n\n[Burkina Faso] is being hit especially hard by the disease, with a new\nstrain of the virus, known as strain X, already claiming half of all the\n718 meningitis-related deaths since the beginning of the year [2010]. In 5\ndistricts the disease is at epidemic level, and 9 more districts are on\nhigh alert.\n\nThe mortality rate is particularly high at 14 per cent. Worryingly,\nchildren and young people are the most affected group, with 80 per cent of\npatients aged between 2 and 30. There is no vaccine for strain X.\n\nPlan Burkina Faso has stepped up efforts to deal with the outbreak. Funding\nis planned for antibiotics, other treatments, laboratory use, and equipment\nand vaccines against the other strains of meningitis, which are still\nkilling many. So far 5118 people nationally have been treated for the disease.\n\nThe country has never seen so many cases of this new type of meningitis,\nstrain X. As there is no vaccine for it, the focus for the moment must\nremain on antibiotic treatment.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of deaths, the number of people nationally who have been\ntreated for meningitis, and the case fatality rate in Burkina Faso since\nthe start of 2010 reported in the news release above is about the same as\nthat reported in a prior ProMED-mail post, Meningitis, meningococcal -\nAfrica (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343. However, what is new is\nthe fact that _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup X is responsible for half\nof all the 718 meningitis-related deaths since the beginning of the year\n(2010).\n\nMass immunization with the appropriate polysaccharide vaccine is a useful\ncontrol measure during an epidemic. However, there is no vaccine for\nserogroup X. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended to eliminate nasopharyngeal\ncarriage of _N. meningitidis_ as soon as possible in close contacts of\npersons with invasive meningococcal disease (such as, household members,\nday-care center contacts, and persons directly exposed to the patient's\noral secretions), whose risk for acquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800\ntimes greater than among the general population (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). The rate of\nsecondary disease for close contacts is highest immediately after onset of\ndisease in the index patient.\n\nHowever, chemoprophylaxis has not generally been recommended during\nepidemics (see <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8625860>), because\nmultiple sources of exposure, prolonged risk of exposure, logistic\nproblems, and high cost make this an impractical alternative. When used,\nthe antimicrobials commonly used for chemoprophylaxis are rifampicin,\nciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and ceftriaxone, although rifampicin- and\nciprofloxacin-resistant meningococcal disease in close contacts has been\nreported following had chemoprophylaxis with these antibiotics (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no06/05-0143.htm> and\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm>).\n\nA map showing the regions in Burkina Faso can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Burkina_Faso>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0188>. A map of the African bacterial meningitis\nbelt can be found at <http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100225.0627\nMeningitis - Chad: (LR,MA) RFI 20100223.0600\nMeningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507\n2009\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR: (HC) 20091213.4233\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\n2002\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR (North Kivu) 20021129.5928\n\n.................ml/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "423315", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa (03): Burkina Faso", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=423315", "date": "2010-05-07 16:00:03", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA (03): BURKINA FASO\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 5 May 2010\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, Plan report [edited]\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/KHII-8573J3?OpenDocument>\n\n\n[Burkina Faso] is being hit especially hard by the disease, with a new\nstrain of the virus, known as strain X, already claiming half of all the\n718 meningitis-related deaths since the beginning of the year [2010]. In 5\ndistricts the disease is at epidemic level, and 9 more districts are on\nhigh alert.\n\nThe mortality rate is particularly high at 14 per cent. Worryingly,\nchildren and young people are the most affected group, with 80 per cent of\npatients aged between 2 and 30. There is no vaccine for strain X.\n\nPlan Burkina Faso has stepped up efforts to deal with the outbreak. Funding\nis planned for antibiotics, other treatments, laboratory use, and equipment\nand vaccines against the other strains of meningitis, which are still\nkilling many. So far 5118 people nationally have been treated for the disease.\n\nThe country has never seen so many cases of this new type of meningitis,\nstrain X. As there is no vaccine for it, the focus for the moment must\nremain on antibiotic treatment.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of deaths, the number of people nationally who have been\ntreated for meningitis, and the case fatality rate in Burkina Faso since\nthe start of 2010 reported in the news release above is about the same as\nthat reported in a prior ProMED-mail post, Meningitis, meningococcal -\nAfrica (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343. However, what is new is\nthe fact that _Neisseria meningitidis_ serogroup X is responsible for half\nof all the 718 meningitis-related deaths since the beginning of the year\n(2010).\n\nMass immunization with the appropriate polysaccharide vaccine is a useful\ncontrol measure during an epidemic. However, there is no vaccine for\nserogroup X. Chemoprophylaxis is recommended to eliminate nasopharyngeal\ncarriage of _N. meningitidis_ as soon as possible in close contacts of\npersons with invasive meningococcal disease (such as, household members,\nday-care center contacts, and persons directly exposed to the patient's\noral secretions), whose risk for acquiring meningococcal disease is 500-800\ntimes greater than among the general population (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00046237.htm>). The rate of\nsecondary disease for close contacts is highest immediately after onset of\ndisease in the index patient.\n\nHowever, chemoprophylaxis has not generally been recommended during\nepidemics (see <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8625860>), because\nmultiple sources of exposure, prolonged risk of exposure, logistic\nproblems, and high cost make this an impractical alternative. When used,\nthe antimicrobials commonly used for chemoprophylaxis are rifampicin,\nciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and ceftriaxone, although rifampicin- and\nciprofloxacin-resistant meningococcal disease in close contacts has been\nreported following had chemoprophylaxis with these antibiotics (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol11no06/05-0143.htm> and\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5707a2.htm>).\n\nA map showing the regions in Burkina Faso can be seen at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Burkina_Faso>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the country is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0188>. A map of the African bacterial meningitis\nbelt can be found at <http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/images/380.ashx>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa (02): WHO meningitis region 20100426.1343\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100225.0627\nMeningitis - Chad: (LR,MA) RFI 20100223.0600\nMeningitis, pneumococcal - Africa: WHO meningitis region 20100213.0507\n2009\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR: (HC) 20091213.4233\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\n2002\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR (North Kivu) 20021129.5928\n\n.................ml/mj/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n\n(NOT to an individual moderator). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2010-05-05 00:00:00", "5118-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North Kivu", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "417389", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Undiagnosed fatalities - Uganda: (BG) meningitis susp. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=417389", "date": "2009-12-13 21:00:02", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CONGO DR: (ORIENTALE)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 12 Dec 2009\nSource: China View [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/02/content_12574856.htm>\n\n\nTen students at Maikazo Institute in Tshopo district in Kisangani,\nthe main town in Orientale province of the Democratic Republic of\nCongo (DRC), died in one week from an unknown disease, with\nmeningitis-like symptoms, the Congolese radio reported on Tuesday [1\nDec 2009?]. The last case of death came on Tuesday morning at the\nMangobo general hospital, where 3 of these students had been admitted\nsince Saturday [28 Nov 2009?], when 9 others died a few hours after\nthey had been taken to the hospital, Dr. Cecile Edambulu, chief\nmedical doctor in Tshopo zone, told the radio.\n\n\"The children had symptoms of headache, fever and convulsions. Upon\narrival at the health center, they died. The symptoms that they\nshowed made us think they were suffering from meningitis,\" Edambulu\nexplained. According to hospital sources, similar cases were\nidentified in Makiso and Mangobo districts in the neighborhood of\nTshopo. The children had been taken to Mangobo and Kisangani\nhospitals, they reported.\n\nThe provincial education minister, Polydore Latigo, has decided to\nmomentarily close down Maikazo Institute. \"This is a preventive\nmeasure to allow the administrative and medical authorities to carry\nout investigation on the situation,\" he said. The mayor of Kisangani\nhas brought together all education and health partners in the town to\nfind a way to curb the spread of the disease while awaiting the\nresults of tests on the samples taken to the capital Kinshasa and\nSouth Africa to determine the type of the virus.\n\n[Byline: Xiong Tong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 8 Dec 2009\nSource: Irin (UN Integrated Regional Information Ne2rks) Africa [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportID=87364>\n\n\nAn outbreak of meningitis that killed more than a dozen students from\nthe same school last week has spread throughout the city of\nKisangani, in central Democratic Republic of Congo, officials said\nMonday [30 Nov 2009?]. The strain of the meningococcal [serogroup] C,\nwhich was confirmed last week, had infected at least 100 people\nthroughout the port city on the Congo River, said the Minister of\nHealth, August Mopipi, on 7 Dec 2009. He visited the city to assess\nwhat local leaders have called an \"epidemic\". By 6 Dec 2009,\naccording to hospital officials and the UN radio service in\nKisangani, 17 had died from the bacterial infection, all students at\nthe local Maikazo Technical Institute.\n\n\"It's a source of hope that this deadly disease remains curable,\"\nMopipi said, adding that more than 40 of the cases had been cured.\nThe minister said the government was working on distributing\nvaccinations but warned they could be \"prohibitively\" expensive.\nAccording to Kisangani mayor Guy Shilton, crisis meetings between\nhospitals, local government authorities and religious leaders had\nbeen organized and an \"emergency protocol\" had been put in place,\nproviding for the distribution of drugs. \"Once the epidemic is\ndeclared, we will attack it in every way possible,\" Shilton said.\n\nThe 1st fatalities took place at the Maikazo Technical Institute,\nwhen 9 students from the school died at end-November 2009 after being\nchecked into the local hospital. According to the UN, doctors said\nthe patients all had signs of meningitis, but it could not be\nconfirmed. A 10th student died a week ago, and the school was closed\ndown by the state minister of education. \"It's a preventative and\ntemporary measure,\" said Minister Polydor Latigo, \"but we need to\ninvestigate the problem safely.\" Andre Kitenge, a press officer for\nthe UN in Kisangani, said that while all deaths related to the\noutbreak were from the school, cases in other parts of Kisangani were\n\"prevalent\".\n\nKisangani, one of the largest cities in the Congo, lies in the middle\nof Africa's \"meningitis belt\". During the dry season, it infects\nhundreds more people than the global average of 3 per 100 000.\nAccording to the World Health Organization, an affordable vaccine is\nsupposed to be on the way, but for poor and densely populated areas\nsuch as Kisangani, it still poses a serious threat. An outbreak of\nmeningitis at the beginning of 2009 across the \"belt\" infected nearly\n25 000, according to the UN, and killed more than 1500.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Orientale is a province in the northeastern corner of the Democratic\nRepublic of Congo (DRC). The 2005 Constitution divided Orientale\nProvince into 4 new provinces: Ituri, Haut-Uele, Tshopo, and Bas-Uele\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo>).\nThe provincial capital of Tshopo is Kisangani.\n\nEastern DRC has been the site of ongoing civil unrest. From an USAID\nreport: \"regional armed conflict across the Democratic Republic of\nthe Congo (DRC) has resulted in an estimated 5.4 million deaths since\n1998. Most deaths occurred due to indirect consequences of fighting,\nsuch as disease, malnutrition, and neonatal- and pregnancy-related\ncomplications. Overall, the decade of fighting displaced more than 3\nmillion Congolese across eastern and southern DRC and hindered access\nto agricultural land and traditional markets. Poverty continues to be\nwidespread, and the Congolese health care system has eroded due to a\nlack of resources and looting of medical assets\"\n(<http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/humanitarian_assistance/disaster_assistance/countries/drc/template/fs_sr/fy2009/drc_ce_sr04_08-06-2009.pdf>).\n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the \"Meningitis Belt\" each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). The\n\"Meningitis Belt\" extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nDuring the 1st 11 weeks of 2009 (1 Jan-15 Mar 2009), a total of 24\n868 suspected cases, including 1513 deaths were reported to WHO by\ncountries of the meningitis belt. The current epidemic has been the\ndeadliest outbreak since 1996, and 1/3rd of the world's emergency\nvaccine stockpile for meningococcal vaccine has been consumed\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_West_African_meningitis_outbreak#cite_note-reuter-1>).\nMore than 85 percent of the cases occurred in one epidemic focus that\nencompasses Northern Nigeria and Niger and is due primarily to\n_Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup A\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_25/en/index.html>).\n\nAlthough, the DRC is not considered a part of the usual African\nmeningitis belt\n(<20090124.0310,Y\">http://www.promedmail.org/pls/otn/f?p=2400:1001:1989031435171910::::F2400_P1001_BACK_PAGE,F2400_P1001_ARCHIVE_NUMBER,F2400_P1001_USE_ARCHIVE:1202,20090124.0310,Y>),\noutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis, some of which have been\nconfirmed to be due to meningococcus serogroup A, have occurred in\nthe past (see ProMED posts listed below).\n\nA map of the DRC is available at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/drcongo.pdf>. Maps\nof the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2002\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR (North Kivu) 20021129.5928\n1998\n----\nMeningitis advisory - Burundi & Congo, Dem.Rep. 19981219.2411\n1997\n----\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (03) 19970903.1868\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (02) 19970814.1701\nMeningitis - Dem.Rep.Congo (ex-Zaire) 19970717.1501\n.............................................ml/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-07 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1513-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Makiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "North Kivu", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Kisangani", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Orientale province", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of \n the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. The 2005 Constitution divided Orientale\nProvince into 4 new provinces: Ituri, Haut-Uele, Tshopo, and Bas-Uele\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo>).\nThe provincial capital of Tshopo is Kisangani.\n\nEastern DRC has been the site of ongoing civil unrest. From an USAID\nreport: \"regional armed conflict across the Democratic Republic of\nthe Congo (DRC) has resulted in an estimated 5.4 million deaths since\n1998. Most deaths occurred due to indirect consequences of fighting,\nsuch as disease, malnutrition, and neonatal- and pregnancy-related\ncomplications. Overall, the decade of fighting displaced more than 3\nmillion Congolese across eastern and southern DRC and hindered access\nto agricultural land and traditional markets. Poverty continues to be\nwidespread, and the Congolese health care system has eroded due to a\nlack of resources and looting of medical assets\"\n(<http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/humanitarian_assistance/disaster_assistance/countries/drc/template/fs_sr/fy2009/drc_ce_sr04_08-06-2009.pdf>).\n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the \"Meningitis Belt\" each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). The\n\"Meningitis Belt\" extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nDuring the 1st 11 weeks of 2009 (1 Jan-15 Mar 2009), a total of 24\n868 suspected cases, including 1513 deaths were reported to WHO by\ncountries of the meningitis belt. The current epidemic has been the\ndeadliest outbreak since 1996, and 1/3rd of the world's emergency\nvaccine stockpile for meningococcal vaccine has been consumed\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_West_African_meningitis_outbreak#cite_note-reuter-1>).\nMore than 85 percent of the cases occurred in one epidemic focus that\nencompasses Northern Nigeria and Niger and is due primarily to\n_Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup A\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_25/en/index.html>).\n\nAlthough, the DRC is not considered a part of the usual African\nmeningitis belt\n(<20090124.0310,Y\">http://www.promedmail.org/pls/otn/f?p=2400:1001:1989031435171910::::F2400_P1001_BACK_PAGE,F2400_P1001_ARCHIVE_NUMBER,F2400_P1001_USE_ARCHIVE:1202,20090124.0310,Y>),\noutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis, some of which have been\nconfirmed to be due to meningococcus serogroup A, have occurred in\nthe past (see ProMED posts listed below).\n\nA map of the DRC is available at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/drcongo.pdf>. Maps\nof the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2002\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR (North Kivu) 20021129.5928\n1998\n----\nMeningitis advisory - Burundi & Congo, Dem.Rep. 19981219.2411\n1997\n----\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (03) 19970903.1868\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (02) 19970814.1701\nMeningitis - Dem.Rep.Congo (ex-Zaire) 19970717.1501\n.............................................ml/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-07 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1513-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Makiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "North Kivu", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Kisangani", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Orientale province", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of \n the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Tshopo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "415207", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Russia: (KN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=415207", "date": "2009-12-13 21:00:02", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CONGO DR: (ORIENTALE)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 12 Dec 2009\nSource: China View [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/02/content_12574856.htm>\n\n\nTen students at Maikazo Institute in Tshopo district in Kisangani,\nthe main town in Orientale province of the Democratic Republic of\nCongo (DRC), died in one week from an unknown disease, with\nmeningitis-like symptoms, the Congolese radio reported on Tuesday [1\nDec 2009?]. The last case of death came on Tuesday morning at the\nMangobo general hospital, where 3 of these students had been admitted\nsince Saturday [28 Nov 2009?], when 9 others died a few hours after\nthey had been taken to the hospital, Dr. Cecile Edambulu, chief\nmedical doctor in Tshopo zone, told the radio.\n\n\"The children had symptoms of headache, fever and convulsions. Upon\narrival at the health center, they died. The symptoms that they\nshowed made us think they were suffering from meningitis,\" Edambulu\nexplained. According to hospital sources, similar cases were\nidentified in Makiso and Mangobo districts in the neighborhood of\nTshopo. The children had been taken to Mangobo and Kisangani\nhospitals, they reported.\n\nThe provincial education minister, Polydore Latigo, has decided to\nmomentarily close down Maikazo Institute. \"This is a preventive\nmeasure to allow the administrative and medical authorities to carry\nout investigation on the situation,\" he said. The mayor of Kisangani\nhas brought together all education and health partners in the town to\nfind a way to curb the spread of the disease while awaiting the\nresults of tests on the samples taken to the capital Kinshasa and\nSouth Africa to determine the type of the virus.\n\n[Byline: Xiong Tong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 8 Dec 2009\nSource: Irin (UN Integrated Regional Information Ne2rks) Africa [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportID=87364>\n\n\nAn outbreak of meningitis that killed more than a dozen students from\nthe same school last week has spread throughout the city of\nKisangani, in central Democratic Republic of Congo, officials said\nMonday [30 Nov 2009?]. The strain of the meningococcal [serogroup] C,\nwhich was confirmed last week, had infected at least 100 people\nthroughout the port city on the Congo River, said the Minister of\nHealth, August Mopipi, on 7 Dec 2009. He visited the city to assess\nwhat local leaders have called an \"epidemic\". By 6 Dec 2009,\naccording to hospital officials and the UN radio service in\nKisangani, 17 had died from the bacterial infection, all students at\nthe local Maikazo Technical Institute.\n\n\"It's a source of hope that this deadly disease remains curable,\"\nMopipi said, adding that more than 40 of the cases had been cured.\nThe minister said the government was working on distributing\nvaccinations but warned they could be \"prohibitively\" expensive.\nAccording to Kisangani mayor Guy Shilton, crisis meetings between\nhospitals, local government authorities and religious leaders had\nbeen organized and an \"emergency protocol\" had been put in place,\nproviding for the distribution of drugs. \"Once the epidemic is\ndeclared, we will attack it in every way possible,\" Shilton said.\n\nThe 1st fatalities took place at the Maikazo Technical Institute,\nwhen 9 students from the school died at end-November 2009 after being\nchecked into the local hospital. According to the UN, doctors said\nthe patients all had signs of meningitis, but it could not be\nconfirmed. A 10th student died a week ago, and the school was closed\ndown by the state minister of education. \"It's a preventative and\ntemporary measure,\" said Minister Polydor Latigo, \"but we need to\ninvestigate the problem safely.\" Andre Kitenge, a press officer for\nthe UN in Kisangani, said that while all deaths related to the\noutbreak were from the school, cases in other parts of Kisangani were\n\"prevalent\".\n\nKisangani, one of the largest cities in the Congo, lies in the middle\nof Africa's \"meningitis belt\". During the dry season, it infects\nhundreds more people than the global average of 3 per 100 000.\nAccording to the World Health Organization, an affordable vaccine is\nsupposed to be on the way, but for poor and densely populated areas\nsuch as Kisangani, it still poses a serious threat. An outbreak of\nmeningitis at the beginning of 2009 across the \"belt\" infected nearly\n25 000, according to the UN, and killed more than 1500.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Orientale is a province in the northeastern corner of the Democratic\nRepublic of Congo (DRC). The 2005 Constitution divided Orientale\nProvince into 4 new provinces: Ituri, Haut-Uele, Tshopo, and Bas-Uele\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo>).\nThe provincial capital of Tshopo is Kisangani.\n\nEastern DRC has been the site of ongoing civil unrest. From an USAID\nreport: \"regional armed conflict across the Democratic Republic of\nthe Congo (DRC) has resulted in an estimated 5.4 million deaths since\n1998. Most deaths occurred due to indirect consequences of fighting,\nsuch as disease, malnutrition, and neonatal- and pregnancy-related\ncomplications. Overall, the decade of fighting displaced more than 3\nmillion Congolese across eastern and southern DRC and hindered access\nto agricultural land and traditional markets. Poverty continues to be\nwidespread, and the Congolese health care system has eroded due to a\nlack of resources and looting of medical assets\"\n(<http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/humanitarian_assistance/disaster_assistance/countries/drc/template/fs_sr/fy2009/drc_ce_sr04_08-06-2009.pdf>).\n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the \"Meningitis Belt\" each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). The\n\"Meningitis Belt\" extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nDuring the 1st 11 weeks of 2009 (1 Jan-15 Mar 2009), a total of 24\n868 suspected cases, including 1513 deaths were reported to WHO by\ncountries of the meningitis belt. The current epidemic has been the\ndeadliest outbreak since 1996, and 1/3rd of the world's emergency\nvaccine stockpile for meningococcal vaccine has been consumed\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_West_African_meningitis_outbreak#cite_note-reuter-1>).\nMore than 85 percent of the cases occurred in one epidemic focus that\nencompasses Northern Nigeria and Niger and is due primarily to\n_Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup A\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_25/en/index.html>).\n\nAlthough, the DRC is not considered a part of the usual African\nmeningitis belt\n(<20090124.0310,Y\">http://www.promedmail.org/pls/otn/f?p=2400:1001:1989031435171910::::F2400_P1001_BACK_PAGE,F2400_P1001_ARCHIVE_NUMBER,F2400_P1001_USE_ARCHIVE:1202,20090124.0310,Y>),\noutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis, some of which have been\nconfirmed to be due to meningococcus serogroup A, have occurred in\nthe past (see ProMED posts listed below).\n\nA map of the DRC is available at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/drcongo.pdf>. Maps\nof the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2002\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR (North Kivu) 20021129.5928\n1998\n----\nMeningitis advisory - Burundi & Congo, Dem.Rep. 19981219.2411\n1997\n----\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (03) 19970903.1868\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (02) 19970814.1701\nMeningitis - Dem.Rep.Congo (ex-Zaire) 19970717.1501\n.............................................ml/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-07 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1513-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Makiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "North Kivu", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Kisangani", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Orientale province", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of \n the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. The current epidemic has been the\ndeadliest outbreak since 1996, and 1/3rd of the world's emergency\nvaccine stockpile for meningococcal vaccine has been consumed\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_West_African_meningitis_outbreak#cite_note-reuter-1>).\nMore than 85 percent of the cases occurred in one epidemic focus that\nencompasses Northern Nigeria and Niger and is due primarily to\n_Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup A\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_25/en/index.html>).\n\nAlthough, the DRC is not considered a part of the usual African\nmeningitis belt\n(<20090124.0310,Y\">http://www.promedmail.org/pls/otn/f?p=2400:1001:1989031435171910::::F2400_P1001_BACK_PAGE,F2400_P1001_ARCHIVE_NUMBER,F2400_P1001_USE_ARCHIVE:1202,20090124.0310,Y>),\noutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis, some of which have been\nconfirmed to be due to meningococcus serogroup A, have occurred in\nthe past (see ProMED posts listed below).\n\nA map of the DRC is available at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/drcongo.pdf>. Maps\nof the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2002\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR (North Kivu) 20021129.5928\n1998\n----\nMeningitis advisory - Burundi & Congo, Dem.Rep. 19981219.2411\n1997\n----\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (03) 19970903.1868\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (02) 19970814.1701\nMeningitis - Dem.Rep.Congo (ex-Zaire) 19970717.1501\n.............................................ml/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-07 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1513-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Makiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "North Kivu", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Kisangani", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Orientale province", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of \n the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Tshopo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "386214", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Chad: (LR,MA) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=386214", "date": "2009-12-13 21:00:02", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CONGO DR: (ORIENTALE)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 12 Dec 2009\nSource: China View [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/02/content_12574856.htm>\n\n\nTen students at Maikazo Institute in Tshopo district in Kisangani,\nthe main town in Orientale province of the Democratic Republic of\nCongo (DRC), died in one week from an unknown disease, with\nmeningitis-like symptoms, the Congolese radio reported on Tuesday [1\nDec 2009?]. The last case of death came on Tuesday morning at the\nMangobo general hospital, where 3 of these students had been admitted\nsince Saturday [28 Nov 2009?], when 9 others died a few hours after\nthey had been taken to the hospital, Dr. Cecile Edambulu, chief\nmedical doctor in Tshopo zone, told the radio.\n\n\"The children had symptoms of headache, fever and convulsions. Upon\narrival at the health center, they died. The symptoms that they\nshowed made us think they were suffering from meningitis,\" Edambulu\nexplained. According to hospital sources, similar cases were\nidentified in Makiso and Mangobo districts in the neighborhood of\nTshopo. The children had been taken to Mangobo and Kisangani\nhospitals, they reported.\n\nThe provincial education minister, Polydore Latigo, has decided to\nmomentarily close down Maikazo Institute. \"This is a preventive\nmeasure to allow the administrative and medical authorities to carry\nout investigation on the situation,\" he said. The mayor of Kisangani\nhas brought together all education and health partners in the town to\nfind a way to curb the spread of the disease while awaiting the\nresults of tests on the samples taken to the capital Kinshasa and\nSouth Africa to determine the type of the virus.\n\n[Byline: Xiong Tong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 8 Dec 2009\nSource: Irin (UN Integrated Regional Information Ne2rks) Africa [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportID=87364>\n\n\nAn outbreak of meningitis that killed more than a dozen students from\nthe same school last week has spread throughout the city of\nKisangani, in central Democratic Republic of Congo, officials said\nMonday [30 Nov 2009?]. The strain of the meningococcal [serogroup] C,\nwhich was confirmed last week, had infected at least 100 people\nthroughout the port city on the Congo River, said the Minister of\nHealth, August Mopipi, on 7 Dec 2009. He visited the city to assess\nwhat local leaders have called an \"epidemic\". By 6 Dec 2009,\naccording to hospital officials and the UN radio service in\nKisangani, 17 had died from the bacterial infection, all students at\nthe local Maikazo Technical Institute.\n\n\"It's a source of hope that this deadly disease remains curable,\"\nMopipi said, adding that more than 40 of the cases had been cured.\nThe minister said the government was working on distributing\nvaccinations but warned they could be \"prohibitively\" expensive.\nAccording to Kisangani mayor Guy Shilton, crisis meetings between\nhospitals, local government authorities and religious leaders had\nbeen organized and an \"emergency protocol\" had been put in place,\nproviding for the distribution of drugs. \"Once the epidemic is\ndeclared, we will attack it in every way possible,\" Shilton said.\n\nThe 1st fatalities took place at the Maikazo Technical Institute,\nwhen 9 students from the school died at end-November 2009 after being\nchecked into the local hospital. According to the UN, doctors said\nthe patients all had signs of meningitis, but it could not be\nconfirmed. A 10th student died a week ago, and the school was closed\ndown by the state minister of education. \"It's a preventative and\ntemporary measure,\" said Minister Polydor Latigo, \"but we need to\ninvestigate the problem safely.\" Andre Kitenge, a press officer for\nthe UN in Kisangani, said that while all deaths related to the\noutbreak were from the school, cases in other parts of Kisangani were\n\"prevalent\".\n\nKisangani, one of the largest cities in the Congo, lies in the middle\nof Africa's \"meningitis belt\". During the dry season, it infects\nhundreds more people than the global average of 3 per 100 000.\nAccording to the World Health Organization, an affordable vaccine is\nsupposed to be on the way, but for poor and densely populated areas\nsuch as Kisangani, it still poses a serious threat. An outbreak of\nmeningitis at the beginning of 2009 across the \"belt\" infected nearly\n25 000, according to the UN, and killed more than 1500.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Orientale is a province in the northeastern corner of the Democratic\nRepublic of Congo (DRC). The 2005 Constitution divided Orientale\nProvince into 4 new provinces: Ituri, Haut-Uele, Tshopo, and Bas-Uele\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo>).\nThe provincial capital of Tshopo is Kisangani.\n\nEastern DRC has been the site of ongoing civil unrest. From an USAID\nreport: \"regional armed conflict across the Democratic Republic of\nthe Congo (DRC) has resulted in an estimated 5.4 million deaths since\n1998. Most deaths occurred due to indirect consequences of fighting,\nsuch as disease, malnutrition, and neonatal- and pregnancy-related\ncomplications. Overall, the decade of fighting displaced more than 3\nmillion Congolese across eastern and southern DRC and hindered access\nto agricultural land and traditional markets. Poverty continues to be\nwidespread, and the Congolese health care system has eroded due to a\nlack of resources and looting of medical assets\"\n(<http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/humanitarian_assistance/disaster_assistance/countries/drc/template/fs_sr/fy2009/drc_ce_sr04_08-06-2009.pdf>).\n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the \"Meningitis Belt\" each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). The\n\"Meningitis Belt\" extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nDuring the 1st 11 weeks of 2009 (1 Jan-15 Mar 2009), a total of 24\n868 suspected cases, including 1513 deaths were reported to WHO by\ncountries of the meningitis belt. The current epidemic has been the\ndeadliest outbreak since 1996, and 1/3rd of the world's emergency\nvaccine stockpile for meningococcal vaccine has been consumed\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_West_African_meningitis_outbreak#cite_note-reuter-1>).\nMore than 85 percent of the cases occurred in one epidemic focus that\nencompasses Northern Nigeria and Niger and is due primarily to\n_Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup A\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_25/en/index.html>).\n\nAlthough, the DRC is not considered a part of the usual African\nmeningitis belt\n(<20090124.0310,Y\">http://www.promedmail.org/pls/otn/f?p=2400:1001:1989031435171910::::F2400_P1001_BACK_PAGE,F2400_P1001_ARCHIVE_NUMBER,F2400_P1001_USE_ARCHIVE:1202,20090124.0310,Y>),\noutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis, some of which have been\nconfirmed to be due to meningococcus serogroup A, have occurred in\nthe past (see ProMED posts listed below).\n\nA map of the DRC is available at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/drcongo.pdf>. Maps\nof the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2002\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR (North Kivu) 20021129.5928\n1998\n----\nMeningitis advisory - Burundi & Congo, Dem.Rep. 19981219.2411\n1997\n----\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (03) 19970903.1868\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (02) 19970814.1701\nMeningitis - Dem.Rep.Congo (ex-Zaire) 19970717.1501\n.............................................ml/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-07 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1513-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Makiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "North Kivu", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Kisangani", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Orientale province", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of \n the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-07 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1513-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Makiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "North Kivu", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Kisangani", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Orientale province", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of \n the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Tshopo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "350566", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR: (HC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=350566", "date": "2009-12-13 21:00:02", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - CONGO DR: (ORIENTALE)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 12 Dec 2009\nSource: China View [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/02/content_12574856.htm>\n\n\nTen students at Maikazo Institute in Tshopo district in Kisangani,\nthe main town in Orientale province of the Democratic Republic of\nCongo (DRC), died in one week from an unknown disease, with\nmeningitis-like symptoms, the Congolese radio reported on Tuesday [1\nDec 2009?]. The last case of death came on Tuesday morning at the\nMangobo general hospital, where 3 of these students had been admitted\nsince Saturday [28 Nov 2009?], when 9 others died a few hours after\nthey had been taken to the hospital, Dr. Cecile Edambulu, chief\nmedical doctor in Tshopo zone, told the radio.\n\n\"The children had symptoms of headache, fever and convulsions. Upon\narrival at the health center, they died. The symptoms that they\nshowed made us think they were suffering from meningitis,\" Edambulu\nexplained. According to hospital sources, similar cases were\nidentified in Makiso and Mangobo districts in the neighborhood of\nTshopo. The children had been taken to Mangobo and Kisangani\nhospitals, they reported.\n\nThe provincial education minister, Polydore Latigo, has decided to\nmomentarily close down Maikazo Institute. \"This is a preventive\nmeasure to allow the administrative and medical authorities to carry\nout investigation on the situation,\" he said. The mayor of Kisangani\nhas brought together all education and health partners in the town to\nfind a way to curb the spread of the disease while awaiting the\nresults of tests on the samples taken to the capital Kinshasa and\nSouth Africa to determine the type of the virus.\n\n[Byline: Xiong Tong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 8 Dec 2009\nSource: Irin (UN Integrated Regional Information Ne2rks) Africa [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportID=87364>\n\n\nAn outbreak of meningitis that killed more than a dozen students from\nthe same school last week has spread throughout the city of\nKisangani, in central Democratic Republic of Congo, officials said\nMonday [30 Nov 2009?]. The strain of the meningococcal [serogroup] C,\nwhich was confirmed last week, had infected at least 100 people\nthroughout the port city on the Congo River, said the Minister of\nHealth, August Mopipi, on 7 Dec 2009. He visited the city to assess\nwhat local leaders have called an \"epidemic\". By 6 Dec 2009,\naccording to hospital officials and the UN radio service in\nKisangani, 17 had died from the bacterial infection, all students at\nthe local Maikazo Technical Institute.\n\n\"It's a source of hope that this deadly disease remains curable,\"\nMopipi said, adding that more than 40 of the cases had been cured.\nThe minister said the government was working on distributing\nvaccinations but warned they could be \"prohibitively\" expensive.\nAccording to Kisangani mayor Guy Shilton, crisis meetings between\nhospitals, local government authorities and religious leaders had\nbeen organized and an \"emergency protocol\" had been put in place,\nproviding for the distribution of drugs. \"Once the epidemic is\ndeclared, we will attack it in every way possible,\" Shilton said.\n\nThe 1st fatalities took place at the Maikazo Technical Institute,\nwhen 9 students from the school died at end-November 2009 after being\nchecked into the local hospital. According to the UN, doctors said\nthe patients all had signs of meningitis, but it could not be\nconfirmed. A 10th student died a week ago, and the school was closed\ndown by the state minister of education. \"It's a preventative and\ntemporary measure,\" said Minister Polydor Latigo, \"but we need to\ninvestigate the problem safely.\" Andre Kitenge, a press officer for\nthe UN in Kisangani, said that while all deaths related to the\noutbreak were from the school, cases in other parts of Kisangani were\n\"prevalent\".\n\nKisangani, one of the largest cities in the Congo, lies in the middle\nof Africa's \"meningitis belt\". During the dry season, it infects\nhundreds more people than the global average of 3 per 100 000.\nAccording to the World Health Organization, an affordable vaccine is\nsupposed to be on the way, but for poor and densely populated areas\nsuch as Kisangani, it still poses a serious threat. An outbreak of\nmeningitis at the beginning of 2009 across the \"belt\" infected nearly\n25 000, according to the UN, and killed more than 1500.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Orientale is a province in the northeastern corner of the Democratic\nRepublic of Congo (DRC). The 2005 Constitution divided Orientale\nProvince into 4 new provinces: Ituri, Haut-Uele, Tshopo, and Bas-Uele\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo>).\nThe provincial capital of Tshopo is Kisangani.\n\nEastern DRC has been the site of ongoing civil unrest. From an USAID\nreport: \"regional armed conflict across the Democratic Republic of\nthe Congo (DRC) has resulted in an estimated 5.4 million deaths since\n1998. Most deaths occurred due to indirect consequences of fighting,\nsuch as disease, malnutrition, and neonatal- and pregnancy-related\ncomplications. Overall, the decade of fighting displaced more than 3\nmillion Congolese across eastern and southern DRC and hindered access\nto agricultural land and traditional markets. Poverty continues to be\nwidespread, and the Congolese health care system has eroded due to a\nlack of resources and looting of medical assets\"\n(<http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/humanitarian_assistance/disaster_assistance/countries/drc/template/fs_sr/fy2009/drc_ce_sr04_08-06-2009.pdf>).\n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the \"Meningitis Belt\" each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). The\n\"Meningitis Belt\" extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nDuring the 1st 11 weeks of 2009 (1 Jan-15 Mar 2009), a total of 24\n868 suspected cases, including 1513 deaths were reported to WHO by\ncountries of the meningitis belt. The current epidemic has been the\ndeadliest outbreak since 1996, and 1/3rd of the world's emergency\nvaccine stockpile for meningococcal vaccine has been consumed\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_West_African_meningitis_outbreak#cite_note-reuter-1>).\nMore than 85 percent of the cases occurred in one epidemic focus that\nencompasses Northern Nigeria and Niger and is due primarily to\n_Neisseria meningitides_ serogroup A\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_25/en/index.html>).\n\nAlthough, the DRC is not considered a part of the usual African\nmeningitis belt\n(<20090124.0310,Y\">http://www.promedmail.org/pls/otn/f?p=2400:1001:1989031435171910::::F2400_P1001_BACK_PAGE,F2400_P1001_ARCHIVE_NUMBER,F2400_P1001_USE_ARCHIVE:1202,20090124.0310,Y>),\noutbreaks of meningococcal meningitis, some of which have been\nconfirmed to be due to meningococcus serogroup A, have occurred in\nthe past (see ProMED posts listed below).\n\nA map of the DRC is available at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/drcongo.pdf>. Maps\nof the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif> and\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Meningitis-Epedemics-World-Map.png>.\n- Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (03) 20090509.1731\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2002\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Congo DR (North Kivu) 20021129.5928\n1998\n----\nMeningitis advisory - Burundi & Congo, Dem.Rep. 19981219.2411\n1997\n----\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (03) 19970903.1868\nMeningitis - Democratic Republic of Congo (02) 19970814.1701\nMeningitis - Dem.Rep.Congo (ex-Zaire) 19970717.1501\n.............................................ml/msp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Poverty continues to be\nwidespread, and the Congolese health care system has eroded due to a\nlack of resources and looting of medical assets\"\n(<http://www.usaid.gov/our_work/humanitarian_assistance/disaster_assistance/countries/drc/template/fs_sr/fy2009/drc_ce_sr04_08-06-2009.pdf>).\n\nNumerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the \"Meningitis Belt\" each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-20 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2021-08-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-07 00:00:00", "2009-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "1513-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Makiso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "North Kivu", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Mangobo", "country": "Sierra Leone"}, {"location": "Kisangani", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Orientale province", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of \n the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Tshopo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "330933", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (04): (MA) lab-acquired", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=330933", "date": "2009-05-09 15:00:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (03)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu May 7 2009\nSource: Reuters [edited]\n<http://in.reuters.com/article/health/idINTRE5456R120090506>\n\n\nA meningitis outbreak in Nigeria is more serious than initially\nfeared with the death toll rising more than 6-fold over the past 2\nmonths, the Health Ministry said on Wednesday.\n\nDeaths from the epidemic have risen to 2148 since the 1st case was\nrecorded in December [2008] from 333, announced by the health\nminister in early March [2009]. The number of reported cases has\nclimbed more than 8-fold to 47 902 over the same period. About 2-3rds\nof Nigeria's 36 states are affected by the epidemic, the ministry\nsaid. Nigeria is Africa's most populous country with a population of\nmore than 140 million.\n\nUNICEF said last month [April 2009] that more than 2500 people had\nbeen killed by meningitis this year in West and Central Africa in\nwhat could be the worst epidemic for 5 years. Nigeria, Niger, Burkina\nFaso and Chad are considered Africa's high-risk zone.\n\nMeningitis is the inflammation of the tissue surrounding the brain\nand spinal cord, and can be caused by viral or bacterial infections.\nIt spreads mainly through kisses, sneezes, coughs and in close living quarters.\n\nThe meningitis death toll in Nigeria since December [2008] is almost\n50 times the number of people killed worldwide by the H1N1 swine flu\nvirus. But the speed with which it has spread underscores the\npotential dangers if swine flu reaches Africa. Basic healthcare is\nlimited in rural parts of Nigeria, where most people live on less\nthan USD 2.00 a day, despite the country's huge oil resources. Many\nNigerians fear that an outbreak of swine flu would be devastating.\nThe Health Ministry said no suspected case of swine flu had been\nrecorded in the country but that it had taken steps to contain any outbreak.\n\nThe worst recent meningitis epidemic in West and Central Africa\noccurred in 1996-97 when an estimated 100 000 people were infected in\nNigeria and 50 000 in Niger.\n\n[Byline: Camillus Eboh, Tume Ahemba, and Nick Tattersall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the \"Meningitis Belt\" each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). The\n\"Meningitis Belt\" extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east, and includes Nigeria\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nNigeria seems to have been hit hardest by the outbreak this year. WHO\nreported on 11 Mar 2009 that in Nigeria there were 9086 cases with\n562 deaths from meningococcal meningitis (see ProMED post Meningitis,\nbacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038) and that both serogroup A and W135 were involved. The\nnumber of cases of meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria have now\nincreased 5-fold and the number of deaths, 3.8-fold.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis\nregion 20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Italy (Veneto) 20071222.4120\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\nMeningitis - Namibia (North): RFI 20070906.2942\n2000\n----\nMeningitis - Namibia (North) 20001214.2182\n.................ml/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. WHO\nreported on 11 Mar 2009 that in Nigeria there were 9086 cases with\n562 deaths from meningococcal meningitis (see ProMED post Meningitis,\nbacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038) and that both serogroup A and W135 were involved. The\nnumber of cases of meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria have now\nincreased 5-fold and the number of deaths, 3.8-fold.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis\nregion 20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Italy (Veneto) 20071222.4120\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\nMeningitis - Namibia (North): RFI 20070906.2942\n2000\n----\nMeningitis - Namibia (North) 20001214.2182\n.................ml/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
