For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2148-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "234917", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - India (06): (ML)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=234917", "date": "2009-05-09 15:00:05", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (03)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu May 7 2009\nSource: Reuters [edited]\n<http://in.reuters.com/article/health/idINTRE5456R120090506>\n\n\nA meningitis outbreak in Nigeria is more serious than initially\nfeared with the death toll rising more than 6-fold over the past 2\nmonths, the Health Ministry said on Wednesday.\n\nDeaths from the epidemic have risen to 2148 since the 1st case was\nrecorded in December [2008] from 333, announced by the health\nminister in early March [2009]. The number of reported cases has\nclimbed more than 8-fold to 47 902 over the same period. About 2-3rds\nof Nigeria's 36 states are affected by the epidemic, the ministry\nsaid. Nigeria is Africa's most populous country with a population of\nmore than 140 million.\n\nUNICEF said last month [April 2009] that more than 2500 people had\nbeen killed by meningitis this year in West and Central Africa in\nwhat could be the worst epidemic for 5 years. Nigeria, Niger, Burkina\nFaso and Chad are considered Africa's high-risk zone.\n\nMeningitis is the inflammation of the tissue surrounding the brain\nand spinal cord, and can be caused by viral or bacterial infections.\nIt spreads mainly through kisses, sneezes, coughs and in close living quarters.\n\nThe meningitis death toll in Nigeria since December [2008] is almost\n50 times the number of people killed worldwide by the H1N1 swine flu\nvirus. But the speed with which it has spread underscores the\npotential dangers if swine flu reaches Africa. Basic healthcare is\nlimited in rural parts of Nigeria, where most people live on less\nthan USD 2.00 a day, despite the country's huge oil resources. Many\nNigerians fear that an outbreak of swine flu would be devastating.\nThe Health Ministry said no suspected case of swine flu had been\nrecorded in the country but that it had taken steps to contain any outbreak.\n\nThe worst recent meningitis epidemic in West and Central Africa\noccurred in 1996-97 when an estimated 100 000 people were infected in\nNigeria and 50 000 in Niger.\n\n[Byline: Camillus Eboh, Tume Ahemba, and Nick Tattersall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the \"Meningitis Belt\" each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). The\n\"Meningitis Belt\" extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east, and includes Nigeria\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nNigeria seems to have been hit hardest by the outbreak this year. WHO\nreported on 11 Mar 2009 that in Nigeria there were 9086 cases with\n562 deaths from meningococcal meningitis (see ProMED post Meningitis,\nbacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038) and that both serogroup A and W135 were involved. The\nnumber of cases of meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria have now\nincreased 5-fold and the number of deaths, 3.8-fold.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis\nregion 20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Basic healthcare is\nlimited in rural parts of Nigeria, where most people live on less\nthan USD 2.00 a day, despite the country's huge oil resources. Many\nNigerians fear that an outbreak of swine flu would be devastating.\nThe Health Ministry said no suspected case of swine flu had been\nrecorded in the country but that it had taken steps to contain any outbreak.\n\nThe worst recent meningitis epidemic in West and Central Africa\noccurred in 1996-97 when an estimated 100 000 people were infected in\nNigeria and 50 000 in Niger.\n\n[Byline: Camillus Eboh, Tume Ahemba, and Nick Tattersall]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Numerous cases of meningococcal meningitis are reported in the\nAfrican region known as the \"Meningitis Belt\" each year during the\ndry season, between December and June, and every 8-12 years large\noutbreaks occur\n(<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/yellowBookCh4-Menin.aspx>). The\n\"Meningitis Belt\" extends from Senegal in the west to Ethiopia and\nEritrea in the east, and includes Nigeria\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol9no10/03-0170.htm>).\n\nNigeria seems to have been hit hardest by the outbreak this year. WHO\nreported on 11 Mar 2009 that in Nigeria there were 9086 cases with\n562 deaths from meningococcal meningitis (see ProMED post Meningitis,\nbacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region\n20090313.1038) and that both serogroup A and W135 were involved. The\nnumber of cases of meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria have now\nincreased 5-fold and the number of deaths, 3.8-fold.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad (02) 20090424.1544\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Chad 20090416.1439\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis\nregion 20090313.1038\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria (02): WHO 20090305.0916\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, bacterial - Africa: WHO meningitis region, 2008 20090124.0310\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Italy (Veneto) 20071222.4120\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\nMeningitis - Namibia (North): RFI 20070906.2942\n2000\n----\nMeningitis - Namibia (North) 20001214.2182\n.................ml/ejp/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Senegal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "177714", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA: (FL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=177714", "date": "2009-03-05 23:00:50", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (02): WHO\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 4 March 2009\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) Disease\nOutbreak News [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_04/en/index.html>\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health of the Federal Republic of Nigeria has\nreported 5323 suspected cases of meningococcal disease, including 333\ndeaths (case-fatality rate: 6.3 percent) from 1 Jan to 22 Feb 2009.\nSuspected cases have been reported from 22 of 37 states. So far 89\nLocal Government Areas (LGA) across 12 states have crossed the alert\nor the epidemic threshold. In the last week alone, 1817 suspected\ncases including 105 deaths (case-fatality rate: 5.8 percent) have\nbeen reported, with 28 LGAs crossing the epidemic threshold, and 29\nthe alert threshold.\n\nCerebrospinal fluid specimens collected from Gombe, Jigawa, Kano, and\nKatsina states have tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup A by latex test and/or culture. The International\nCoordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis\nControl has approved the release of 1 010 000 doses of polysaccharide\nvaccine for mass vaccination campaigns in affected LGAs of Jigawa and\nKatsina states. Immunization campaigns will be implemented by Federal\nand National Ministry of Health with the support of WHO and partners,\nincluding the European Commission Humanitarian Aid Department (ECHO),\nMedecins sans Frontieres, and UNICEF.\n\nGiven the large population at risk, the early start of epidemics, and\ncurrent moderate global vaccine levels, a sound vaccination strategy\nis of particular importance. WHO is supporting the Federal and\nNational Ministry of Health in the assessment of vaccine needs. WHO\nis also providing technical and material support to the Ministry of\nHealth to strengthen epidemiological and laboratory surveillance,\nincluding provision of laboratory confirmation supplies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The number of cases of suspected meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria\nhas approximately quadrupled and the number of deaths tripled since\nthe last ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO\n20090220.0709). The plan is to use meningococcal polysaccharide\nvaccine in the population at risk, but it is unclear if any vaccine\nhas actually been given out as yet.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. So far 89\nLocal Government Areas (LGA) across 12 states have crossed the alert\nor the epidemic threshold. In the last week alone, 1817 suspected\ncases including 105 deaths (case-fatality rate: 5.8 percent) have\nbeen reported, with 28 LGAs crossing the epidemic threshold, and 29\nthe alert threshold.\n\nCerebrospinal fluid specimens collected from Gombe, Jigawa, Kano, and\nKatsina states have tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup A by latex test and/or culture. The International\nCoordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis\nControl has approved the release of 1 010 000 doses of polysaccharide\nvaccine for mass vaccination campaigns in affected LGAs of Jigawa and\nKatsina states. Immunization campaigns will be implemented by Federal\nand National Ministry of Health with the support of WHO and partners,\nincluding the European Commission Humanitarian Aid Department (ECHO),\nMedecins sans Frontieres, and UNICEF.\n\nGiven the large population at risk, the early start of epidemics, and\ncurrent moderate global vaccine levels, a sound vaccination strategy\nis of particular importance. WHO is supporting the Federal and\nNational Ministry of Health in the assessment of vaccine needs. WHO\nis also providing technical and material support to the Ministry of\nHealth to strengthen epidemiological and laboratory surveillance,\nincluding provision of laboratory confirmation supplies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The number of cases of suspected meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria\nhas approximately quadrupled and the number of deaths tripled since\nthe last ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO\n20090220.0709). The plan is to use meningococcal polysaccharide\nvaccine in the population at risk, but it is unclear if any vaccine\nhas actually been given out as yet.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. So far 89\nLocal Government Areas (LGA) across 12 states have crossed the alert\nor the epidemic threshold. In the last week alone, 1817 suspected\ncases including 105 deaths (case-fatality rate: 5.8 percent) have\nbeen reported, with 28 LGAs crossing the epidemic threshold, and 29\nthe alert threshold.\n\nCerebrospinal fluid specimens collected from Gombe, Jigawa, Kano, and\nKatsina states have tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup A by latex test and/or culture. The International\nCoordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis\nControl has approved the release of 1 010 000 doses of polysaccharide\nvaccine for mass vaccination campaigns in affected LGAs of Jigawa and\nKatsina states. Immunization campaigns will be implemented by Federal\nand National Ministry of Health with the support of WHO and partners,\nincluding the European Commission Humanitarian Aid Department (ECHO),\nMedecins sans Frontieres, and UNICEF.\n\nGiven the large population at risk, the early start of epidemics, and\ncurrent moderate global vaccine levels, a sound vaccination strategy\nis of particular importance. WHO is supporting the Federal and\nNational Ministry of Health in the assessment of vaccine needs. WHO\nis also providing technical and material support to the Ministry of\nHealth to strengthen epidemiological and laboratory surveillance,\nincluding provision of laboratory confirmation supplies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The number of cases of suspected meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria\nhas approximately quadrupled and the number of deaths tripled since\nthe last ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO\n20090220.0709). Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Jigawa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "168079", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - USA (02): (HI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=168079", "date": "2009-03-05 23:00:50", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (02): WHO\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 4 March 2009\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) Disease\nOutbreak News [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_04/en/index.html>\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health of the Federal Republic of Nigeria has\nreported 5323 suspected cases of meningococcal disease, including 333\ndeaths (case-fatality rate: 6.3 percent) from 1 Jan to 22 Feb 2009.\nSuspected cases have been reported from 22 of 37 states. So far 89\nLocal Government Areas (LGA) across 12 states have crossed the alert\nor the epidemic threshold. In the last week alone, 1817 suspected\ncases including 105 deaths (case-fatality rate: 5.8 percent) have\nbeen reported, with 28 LGAs crossing the epidemic threshold, and 29\nthe alert threshold.\n\nCerebrospinal fluid specimens collected from Gombe, Jigawa, Kano, and\nKatsina states have tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup A by latex test and/or culture. The International\nCoordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis\nControl has approved the release of 1 010 000 doses of polysaccharide\nvaccine for mass vaccination campaigns in affected LGAs of Jigawa and\nKatsina states. Immunization campaigns will be implemented by Federal\nand National Ministry of Health with the support of WHO and partners,\nincluding the European Commission Humanitarian Aid Department (ECHO),\nMedecins sans Frontieres, and UNICEF.\n\nGiven the large population at risk, the early start of epidemics, and\ncurrent moderate global vaccine levels, a sound vaccination strategy\nis of particular importance. WHO is supporting the Federal and\nNational Ministry of Health in the assessment of vaccine needs. WHO\nis also providing technical and material support to the Ministry of\nHealth to strengthen epidemiological and laboratory surveillance,\nincluding provision of laboratory confirmation supplies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The number of cases of suspected meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria\nhas approximately quadrupled and the number of deaths tripled since\nthe last ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO\n20090220.0709). The plan is to use meningococcal polysaccharide\nvaccine in the population at risk, but it is unclear if any vaccine\nhas actually been given out as yet.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Nigeria", "country": "Nigeria"}, {"location": "Jigawa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "164725", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, bacterial - Africa (02): Nigeria, WHO meningitis region", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=164725", "date": "2009-03-05 23:00:50", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - NIGERIA (02): WHO\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 4 March 2009\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) Disease\nOutbreak News [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2009_03_04/en/index.html>\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health of the Federal Republic of Nigeria has\nreported 5323 suspected cases of meningococcal disease, including 333\ndeaths (case-fatality rate: 6.3 percent) from 1 Jan to 22 Feb 2009.\nSuspected cases have been reported from 22 of 37 states. So far 89\nLocal Government Areas (LGA) across 12 states have crossed the alert\nor the epidemic threshold. In the last week alone, 1817 suspected\ncases including 105 deaths (case-fatality rate: 5.8 percent) have\nbeen reported, with 28 LGAs crossing the epidemic threshold, and 29\nthe alert threshold.\n\nCerebrospinal fluid specimens collected from Gombe, Jigawa, Kano, and\nKatsina states have tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup A by latex test and/or culture. The International\nCoordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis\nControl has approved the release of 1 010 000 doses of polysaccharide\nvaccine for mass vaccination campaigns in affected LGAs of Jigawa and\nKatsina states. Immunization campaigns will be implemented by Federal\nand National Ministry of Health with the support of WHO and partners,\nincluding the European Commission Humanitarian Aid Department (ECHO),\nMedecins sans Frontieres, and UNICEF.\n\nGiven the large population at risk, the early start of epidemics, and\ncurrent moderate global vaccine levels, a sound vaccination strategy\nis of particular importance. WHO is supporting the Federal and\nNational Ministry of Health in the assessment of vaccine needs. WHO\nis also providing technical and material support to the Ministry of\nHealth to strengthen epidemiological and laboratory surveillance,\nincluding provision of laboratory confirmation supplies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The number of cases of suspected meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria\nhas approximately quadrupled and the number of deaths tripled since\nthe last ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO\n20090220.0709). The plan is to use meningococcal polysaccharide\nvaccine in the population at risk, but it is unclear if any vaccine\nhas actually been given out as yet.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Nigeria is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=9.6,6.1,6>.\nA map of the African bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO 20090220.0709\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI) 20090120.0249\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda: (ARU, HOI) 20090115.0170\n2008\n----\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso (02): vaccinated areas 20080412.1334\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Burkina Faso 20080314.1017\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt 20080225.0756\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. So far 89\nLocal Government Areas (LGA) across 12 states have crossed the alert\nor the epidemic threshold. In the last week alone, 1817 suspected\ncases including 105 deaths (case-fatality rate: 5.8 percent) have\nbeen reported, with 28 LGAs crossing the epidemic threshold, and 29\nthe alert threshold.\n\nCerebrospinal fluid specimens collected from Gombe, Jigawa, Kano, and\nKatsina states have tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup A by latex test and/or culture. The International\nCoordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis\nControl has approved the release of 1 010 000 doses of polysaccharide\nvaccine for mass vaccination campaigns in affected LGAs of Jigawa and\nKatsina states. Immunization campaigns will be implemented by Federal\nand National Ministry of Health with the support of WHO and partners,\nincluding the European Commission Humanitarian Aid Department (ECHO),\nMedecins sans Frontieres, and UNICEF.\n\nGiven the large population at risk, the early start of epidemics, and\ncurrent moderate global vaccine levels, a sound vaccination strategy\nis of particular importance. WHO is supporting the Federal and\nNational Ministry of Health in the assessment of vaccine needs. WHO\nis also providing technical and material support to the Ministry of\nHealth to strengthen epidemiological and laboratory surveillance,\nincluding provision of laboratory confirmation supplies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The number of cases of suspected meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria\nhas approximately quadrupled and the number of deaths tripled since\nthe last ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO\n20090220.0709). So far 89\nLocal Government Areas (LGA) across 12 states have crossed the alert\nor the epidemic threshold. In the last week alone, 1817 suspected\ncases including 105 deaths (case-fatality rate: 5.8 percent) have\nbeen reported, with 28 LGAs crossing the epidemic threshold, and 29\nthe alert threshold.\n\nCerebrospinal fluid specimens collected from Gombe, Jigawa, Kano, and\nKatsina states have tested positive for _Neisseria meningitidis_\nserogroup A by latex test and/or culture. The International\nCoordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic Meningitis\nControl has approved the release of 1 010 000 doses of polysaccharide\nvaccine for mass vaccination campaigns in affected LGAs of Jigawa and\nKatsina states. Immunization campaigns will be implemented by Federal\nand National Ministry of Health with the support of WHO and partners,\nincluding the European Commission Humanitarian Aid Department (ECHO),\nMedecins sans Frontieres, and UNICEF.\n\nGiven the large population at risk, the early start of epidemics, and\ncurrent moderate global vaccine levels, a sound vaccination strategy\nis of particular importance. WHO is supporting the Federal and\nNational Ministry of Health in the assessment of vaccine needs. WHO\nis also providing technical and material support to the Ministry of\nHealth to strengthen epidemiological and laboratory surveillance,\nincluding provision of laboratory confirmation supplies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The number of cases of suspected meningococcal meningitis in Nigeria\nhas approximately quadrupled and the number of deaths tripled since\nthe last ProMED-mail post (Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria: WHO\n20090220.0709). / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nTchad / 185 / 21 / 11.4 / 0 / 0 / 100.0 / - / - / - /- / -\nTogo / 11 / 0 / 0.0 / 0 / 0 / 50.0 / - / - / - / - / -\nTotal / 959 / 121 / 12.6 / 2 / 1 / 58.9 / 9 / 0 / 0 / 1 / 2\n\n* identification by: PCR, LATEX, CULTURE.\n** Definition of alert/epidemic thresholds not\napplicable to this country outside the meningitis belt.\n\nComments:\n---------\nMali: District of Ouelessebougou in epidemic at\nweek 51 with an attack rate of 12.7. Cases come\nform the subdistrict of Ouelessebougou comprising\n5 health facilities. The district was immunized\nwith bivalent AC vaccine following isolation of\nNmA by the laboratory. 50 998 persons were\nimmunized out of 55 010 inhabitants (VC 93 percent).\nNiger: District of Mirriah in alert at week 51\nand 52. However, the sub-district comprising 4 HF\ncatchment areas crossed the epidemic threshold. 9\nNmA were isolated out of 14 CSF. The district of Mirriah have been immunized.\nBurkina Faso: District of Sapouy in alert at\nweeks 50 and 51. Gram Positive Diplococcus and\nGram Positive Bacillus have been isolated by the laboratory.\n\nContact us:\n-----------\nMulti Disease Surveillance Centre 01 BP 549 Ouagadougou 01, Burkina Faso\n<mdsc@oncho.oms.bf>\n<http://www.who.int/csr>\n\nNota bene: The data published in this bulletin\nconsist of weekly information. They are\nsusceptible to change after completeness and verification.\n\nTable 2: Synthesis of the epidemiological situation (reported weeks)\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nCountry / Cases / Deaths / Lethality (%) /\nDistrict in Alert / District in Epidemic /\nReported weeks / In districts (%) / In weeks [%]\nBenin / 414 / 55 / 13.3 / 2 / 0 / 01-52 / 98.7 / 100.0\nBurkina Faso / 10 401 /1 067 / 10.3 / 22 / 20 / 01-52 / 100.0 / 100.0\nCameroun /- / - / -\nGhana / 468 / 89 / 19.0 / 0 / 1 / 01-46 / - / -\nGuin\u00e9e / 263 / 58 / 22.1 / 0 / 1 / 01-13 / 100.0 / -\nMali / 1538 / 85 / 5.5 / 3 / 4 / 01-52 / 100.0 / 100.0\nNiger / 3757 / 246 / 6.5 / 10 / 5 / 01-52 / 100.0 / 99.5\nNigeria / 6835 / 492 / 7.2 / 27 / 51 / 01-52 / 70.4 / 100.0\nRD Congo** / 6125 / 685 / 11.2 / 28 / 14 / 01-47 / 35.0 / 56.4\nTchad / 1093 / 148 / 13.5 / 6 / 1 / 01-52 / 108.9 / 99.3\nTogo / 413 / 63 / 15.3 / 1 / 0 / 01-50 / 100.0 / 96.9\nTotal / 33 381 / 3 276 / 9.8 / 101 / 101 / 01-52 / 71.9 / 93.3\n\n** Definition of Alert/epidemic thresholds not\napplicable to this country outside the meningitis belt.\n\nComments:\n---------\nThe timely intervention in Mali and Niger\nhighlights that the subdivision of large\ndistricts in sub-districts of less than 100 000\ninhabitants (ref. definition of intervention\nthresholds) allows a timely detection of an\nemerging epidemic, the laboratory confirmation of\ngerms and undertake rapid control and prevention measures.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr. Mandy Kader Konde\nMultidisease Surveillance Center (MDSC), Ougadougou (Burkina Faso).\n<kondek@oncho.afro.who.int>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Kader Konde of the WHO\nMultidisease Surveillance Centre (MDSC) in\nOugadougou (Burkina Faso) for alerting ProMED to\nthe latest WHO data on bacterial meningitis in\ncountries under enhanced surveillance of meningitis in the WHO African Region.\n\nTable [1] above is a summary of the reports\nreceived for the month of December 2008. / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nGhana / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nGuin\u00e9e / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nMali /55 / 5 / 9.1 / 0 / 1 / 100.0\nNiger / 233 / 17 / 7.3 / 1 / 0 / 100.0 / 9 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nNigeria / 39 / 1 / 2.6 / 0 / 0 / 100.0\nRD Congo** / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nTchad / 185 / 21 / 11.4 / 0 / 0 / 100.0 / - / - / - /- / -\nTogo / 11 / 0 / 0.0 / 0 / 0 / 50.0 / - / - / - / - / -\nTotal / 959 / 121 / 12.6 / 2 / 1 / 58.9 / 9 / 0 / 0 / 1 / 2\n\n* identification by: PCR, LATEX, CULTURE.\n** Definition of alert/epidemic thresholds not\napplicable to this country outside the meningitis belt.\n\nComments:\n---------\nMali: District of Ouelessebougou in epidemic at\nweek 51 with an attack rate of 12.7. Cases come\nform the subdistrict of Ouelessebougou comprising\n5 health facilities. The district was immunized\nwith bivalent AC vaccine following isolation of\nNmA by the laboratory. 50 998 persons were\nimmunized out of 55 010 inhabitants (VC 93 percent).\nNiger: District of Mirriah in alert at week 51\nand 52. However, the sub-district comprising 4 HF\ncatchment areas crossed the epidemic threshold. 9\nNmA were isolated out of 14 CSF. The district of Mirriah have been immunized.\nBurkina Faso: District of Sapouy in alert at\nweeks 50 and 51. Gram Positive Diplococcus and\nGram Positive Bacillus have been isolated by the laboratory.\n\nContact us:\n-----------\nMulti Disease Surveillance Centre 01 BP 549 Ouagadougou 01, Burkina Faso\n<mdsc@oncho.oms.bf>\n<http://www.who.int/csr>\n\nNota bene: The data published in this bulletin\nconsist of weekly information. Gram Positive Diplococcus and\nGram Positive Bacillus have been isolated by the laboratory.\n\nContact us:\n-----------\nMulti Disease Surveillance Centre 01 BP 549 Ouagadougou 01, Burkina Faso\n<mdsc@oncho.oms.bf>\n<http://www.who.int/csr>\n\nNota bene: The data published in this bulletin\nconsist of weekly information. Cases come\nform the subdistrict of Ouelessebougou comprising\n5 health facilities. The district was immunized\nwith bivalent AC vaccine following isolation of\nNmA by the laboratory. 50 998 persons were\nimmunized out of 55 010 inhabitants (VC 93 percent).\nNiger: District of Mirriah in alert at week 51\nand 52. However, the sub-district comprising 4 HF\ncatchment areas crossed the epidemic threshold. 9\nNmA were isolated out of 14 CSF. The district of Mirriah have been immunized.\nBurkina Faso: District of Sapouy in alert at\nweeks 50 and 51. Gram Positive Diplococcus and\nGram Positive Bacillus have been isolated by the laboratory.\n\nContact us:\n-----------\nMulti Disease Surveillance Centre 01 BP 549 Ouagadougou 01, Burkina Faso\n<mdsc@oncho.oms.bf>\n<http://www.who.int/csr>\n\nNota bene: The data published in this bulletin\nconsist of weekly information. They are\nsusceptible to change after completeness and verification.\n\nTable 2: Synthesis of the epidemiological situation (reported weeks)\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nCountry / Cases / Deaths / Lethality (%) /\nDistrict in Alert / District in Epidemic /\nReported weeks / In districts (%) / In weeks [%]\nBenin / 414 / 55 / 13.3 / 2 / 0 / 01-52 / 98.7 / 100.0\nBurkina Faso / 10 401 /1 067 / 10.3 / 22 / 20 / 01-52 / 100.0 / 100.0\nCameroun /- / - / - / - / - / - / - / -\nCentrafrique / 345 / 89 / 25.8 / 2 / 1 / 01-52 / 100.0 / 99.8\nC\u00f4te d'Ivoire / 1117 / 181 / 16.2 / 0 / 2 / 01-51 / 100.0 / 60.5\nEthiopia / 612 / 18 / 2.9 / 0 / 1 / 01-26 / - / -\nGhana / 468 / 89 / 19.0 / 0 / 1 / 01-46 / - / -\nGuin\u00e9e / 263 / 58 / 22.1 / 0 / 1 / 01-13 / 100.0 / -\nMali / 1538 / 85 / 5.5 / 3 / 4 / 01-52 / 100.0 / 100.0\nNiger / 3757 / 246 / 6.5 / 10 / 5 / 01-52 / 100.0 / 99.5\nNigeria / 6835 / 492 / 7.2 / 27 / 51 / 01-52 / 70.4 / 100.0\nRD Congo** / 6125 / 685 / 11.2 / 28 / 14 / 01-47 / 35.0 / 56.4\nTchad / 1093 / 148 / 13.5 / 6 / 1 / 01-52 / 108.9 / 99.3\nTogo / 413 / 63 / 15.3 / 1 / 0 / 01-50 / 100.0 / 96.9\nTotal / 33 381 / 3 276 / 9.8 / 101 / 101 / 01-52 / 71.9 / 93.3\n\n** Definition of Alert/epidemic thresholds not\napplicable to this country outside the meningitis belt.\n\nComments:\n---------\nThe timely intervention in Mali and Niger\nhighlights that the subdivision of large\ndistricts in sub-districts of less than 100 000\ninhabitants (ref. definition of intervention\nthresholds) allows a timely detection of an\nemerging epidemic, the laboratory confirmation of\ngerms and undertake rapid control and prevention measures.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr. Mandy Kader Konde\nMultidisease Surveillance Center (MDSC), Ougadougou (Burkina Faso).\n<kondek@oncho.afro.who.int>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Kader Konde of the WHO\nMultidisease Surveillance Centre (MDSC) in\nOugadougou (Burkina Faso) for alerting ProMED to\nthe latest WHO data on bacterial meningitis in\ncountries under enhanced surveillance of meningitis in the WHO African Region.\n\nTable [1] above is a summary of the reports\nreceived for the month of December 2008. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2009-01-22 00:00:00", "2052-03-16 00:00:00", "2051-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mali", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "149285", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (03): (AW, HO, MC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=149285", "date": "2008-12-31 15:00:41", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS \u0096 ECUADOR: (LOS RIOS)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 30 Dec 2008\nSource: El Comercio, Ecuador [in Spanish, trans. & summ. Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.elcomercio.com/noticiaEC.asp?id_noticia=246645&id_seccion=8>\n\n\nA study by researcher Luiggi Martini has confirmed that consumption of\nraw snails caused an outbreak in the area of La Ercilia, San Eduardo,\nZapotal parish, Ventanas canton, in Los R\u00edos province. The inquiry by\nMartini, an official and former director of the Izquieta Perez\nInstitute of Hygiene, began after 10 patients were diagnosed with\neosinophilic meningoencephalitis, caused by a parasite found in snails.\n\nThe symptoms were: neurological disorders, constipation, vomiting,\nnausea, abdominal pain (see graphics in original). The 1st to be\naffected were from the coastal province. The provincial director of\nLos Rios province, Carlos Paz, confirmed to this newspaper that 10\npeople had been affected, and another 25-year-old man died [of it] in\nthe Luis Vernaza hospital of Guayaquil on 22 Jul 2008. Martini\nmaintains in his 21-page report that this is the 1st record of\ninfection in rats by the parasite _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in\nEcuador and in South America. [Not the 1st for S. America -- see\ncomment below. - Mod.JW]\n\nAccording to history, the parasite was 1st described by HT Chen in\n1935 and was the 1st rat lungworm. In 1937, another worm was obtained\nfrom a rat in Taiwan, a new species. This infection has also appeared\nin Egypt and in Southeast Asia, in Pacific Rim countries such as\nThailand, Vietnam, Japan, and in Hawaii.\n\nOn Mon 22 Dec 2008 there was a meeting of all health authorities to\ndetermine what action to take, because the problem also involves\ncommerce, the export of snails. Paz denied that the species which is\nused for human consumption is involved, because only wild-caught\nsnails were infected. Therefore, the official cautioned that he has\nset up an \"epidemiological barrier\" to prevent spread of the parasite.\n\nUsually, it lives in the pulmonary arteries of rats. Martini does not\nknow exactly how it came into the country. \"It most likely came in\nsnails imported by the domestic industry. When improperly handled on\nfarms, they were accessible to wild rats which became infected for the\n1st time.\"\n\nLos Rios is not only affected but also Santo Domingo de las Tsachilas.\nThe director of the Eugenio Espejo hospital in Quito [the capital],\nMarco Ortega, confirmed yesterday that 3 weeks ago 2 people in that\njurisdiction had this health problem. On 18 Nov 2008, 3 people were\nvisiting an area near Santo Domingo, where they collected at least 3\npounds of snails, which they ate raw with lemon and salt.\n\nDays later, one of them, a 20-year-old man, had abdominal pain, fever\nand pain in knees and hips. He was admitted to Eugenio Espejo hospital\non 26 Nov 2008. After 12 days his symptoms worsened, adding slightly\nstiff neck and alteration of consciousness. Doctors diagnosed severe\nmeningitis caused by the parasite, _A. cantonensis_, which lives in\nsnails. He remains hospitalized.\n\nHis brother, aged 17, entered this hospital on 1 Dec 2008, with\nsimilar symptoms. He, according to Flores, ate fewer snails. \"He was\ndischarged 15 days ago and is out of danger,\" doctors said. \"But he\nhas a lot of pain when walking.\" The 3rd person was not admitted to\nhospital; he had only tasted the flavored juice of the snails.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are the 1st human cases of angiostrongyliasis in humans from\nEcuador. All had been eating snails. Previously, the parasite has been\ndemonstrated in naturally infected snails of various genera and\nspecies in northeastern Brazil, which has also reported cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the same areas. As is well known, _A.\ncantonensis_ has repeatedly been reported as a cause of human disease\nin the Caribbean, particularly in Cuba, and reported previously by\nProMED from Dominica, Brazil, and the USA. It is a potential risk in\nNorth and Central America, where there are snails and rodents infected\nwith the parasite.\n\nPicture and life cycle of Agiostrongylus:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>\n- Mods.JT/EP]\n\n[A map showing the location of Ecuador in South America is available at:\n<http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcecuador.htm>\n- CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - Brazil (ES) 20070414.1244\n1998\n----\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis - USA (LA & MS) 19981113.2193\n1997\n----\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (05) 19970619.1306\n....................jt/ep/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "1935-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2008-12-16 00:00:00", "2008-11-18 00:00:00", "2008-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-12-01 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los Rios", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Comercio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dominica", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Domingo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Eduardo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quito", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ventanas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los R\u00edos", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "147812", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (02): (MSI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=147812", "date": "2008-12-31 15:00:41", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS \u0096 ECUADOR: (LOS RIOS)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 30 Dec 2008\nSource: El Comercio, Ecuador [in Spanish, trans. & summ. Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.elcomercio.com/noticiaEC.asp?id_noticia=246645&id_seccion=8>\n\n\nA study by researcher Luiggi Martini has confirmed that consumption of\nraw snails caused an outbreak in the area of La Ercilia, San Eduardo,\nZapotal parish, Ventanas canton, in Los R\u00edos province. The inquiry by\nMartini, an official and former director of the Izquieta Perez\nInstitute of Hygiene, began after 10 patients were diagnosed with\neosinophilic meningoencephalitis, caused by a parasite found in snails.\n\nThe symptoms were: neurological disorders, constipation, vomiting,\nnausea, abdominal pain (see graphics in original). The 1st to be\naffected were from the coastal province. The provincial director of\nLos Rios province, Carlos Paz, confirmed to this newspaper that 10\npeople had been affected, and another 25-year-old man died [of it] in\nthe Luis Vernaza hospital of Guayaquil on 22 Jul 2008. Martini\nmaintains in his 21-page report that this is the 1st record of\ninfection in rats by the parasite _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in\nEcuador and in South America. [Not the 1st for S. America -- see\ncomment below. - Mod.JW]\n\nAccording to history, the parasite was 1st described by HT Chen in\n1935 and was the 1st rat lungworm. In 1937, another worm was obtained\nfrom a rat in Taiwan, a new species. This infection has also appeared\nin Egypt and in Southeast Asia, in Pacific Rim countries such as\nThailand, Vietnam, Japan, and in Hawaii.\n\nOn Mon 22 Dec 2008 there was a meeting of all health authorities to\ndetermine what action to take, because the problem also involves\ncommerce, the export of snails. Paz denied that the species which is\nused for human consumption is involved, because only wild-caught\nsnails were infected. Therefore, the official cautioned that he has\nset up an \"epidemiological barrier\" to prevent spread of the parasite.\n\nUsually, it lives in the pulmonary arteries of rats. Martini does not\nknow exactly how it came into the country. \"It most likely came in\nsnails imported by the domestic industry. When improperly handled on\nfarms, they were accessible to wild rats which became infected for the\n1st time.\"\n\nLos Rios is not only affected but also Santo Domingo de las Tsachilas.\nThe director of the Eugenio Espejo hospital in Quito [the capital],\nMarco Ortega, confirmed yesterday that 3 weeks ago 2 people in that\njurisdiction had this health problem. On 18 Nov 2008, 3 people were\nvisiting an area near Santo Domingo, where they collected at least 3\npounds of snails, which they ate raw with lemon and salt.\n\nDays later, one of them, a 20-year-old man, had abdominal pain, fever\nand pain in knees and hips. He was admitted to Eugenio Espejo hospital\non 26 Nov 2008. After 12 days his symptoms worsened, adding slightly\nstiff neck and alteration of consciousness. Doctors diagnosed severe\nmeningitis caused by the parasite, _A. cantonensis_, which lives in\nsnails. He remains hospitalized.\n\nHis brother, aged 17, entered this hospital on 1 Dec 2008, with\nsimilar symptoms. He, according to Flores, ate fewer snails. \"He was\ndischarged 15 days ago and is out of danger,\" doctors said. \"But he\nhas a lot of pain when walking.\" The 3rd person was not admitted to\nhospital; he had only tasted the flavored juice of the snails.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are the 1st human cases of angiostrongyliasis in humans from\nEcuador. All had been eating snails. Previously, the parasite has been\ndemonstrated in naturally infected snails of various genera and\nspecies in northeastern Brazil, which has also reported cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the same areas. As is well known, _A.\ncantonensis_ has repeatedly been reported as a cause of human disease\nin the Caribbean, particularly in Cuba, and reported previously by\nProMED from Dominica, Brazil, and the USA. It is a potential risk in\nNorth and Central America, where there are snails and rodents infected\nwith the parasite.\n\nPicture and life cycle of Agiostrongylus:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>\n- Mods.JT/EP]\n\n[A map showing the location of Ecuador in South America is available at:\n<http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcecuador.htm>\n- CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - Brazil (ES) 20070414.1244\n1998\n----\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis - USA (LA & MS) 19981113.2193\n1997\n----\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (05) 19970619.1306\n....................jt/ep/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "1935-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2008-12-16 00:00:00", "2008-11-18 00:00:00", "2008-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-12-01 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los Rios", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Comercio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dominica", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Domingo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Eduardo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quito", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ventanas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los R\u00edos", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "146655", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - India: (ML)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=146655", "date": "2008-12-31 15:00:41", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS \u0096 ECUADOR: (LOS RIOS)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 30 Dec 2008\nSource: El Comercio, Ecuador [in Spanish, trans. & summ. Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.elcomercio.com/noticiaEC.asp?id_noticia=246645&id_seccion=8>\n\n\nA study by researcher Luiggi Martini has confirmed that consumption of\nraw snails caused an outbreak in the area of La Ercilia, San Eduardo,\nZapotal parish, Ventanas canton, in Los R\u00edos province. The inquiry by\nMartini, an official and former director of the Izquieta Perez\nInstitute of Hygiene, began after 10 patients were diagnosed with\neosinophilic meningoencephalitis, caused by a parasite found in snails.\n\nThe symptoms were: neurological disorders, constipation, vomiting,\nnausea, abdominal pain (see graphics in original). The 1st to be\naffected were from the coastal province. The provincial director of\nLos Rios province, Carlos Paz, confirmed to this newspaper that 10\npeople had been affected, and another 25-year-old man died [of it] in\nthe Luis Vernaza hospital of Guayaquil on 22 Jul 2008. Martini\nmaintains in his 21-page report that this is the 1st record of\ninfection in rats by the parasite _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in\nEcuador and in South America. [Not the 1st for S. America -- see\ncomment below. - Mod.JW]\n\nAccording to history, the parasite was 1st described by HT Chen in\n1935 and was the 1st rat lungworm. In 1937, another worm was obtained\nfrom a rat in Taiwan, a new species. This infection has also appeared\nin Egypt and in Southeast Asia, in Pacific Rim countries such as\nThailand, Vietnam, Japan, and in Hawaii.\n\nOn Mon 22 Dec 2008 there was a meeting of all health authorities to\ndetermine what action to take, because the problem also involves\ncommerce, the export of snails. Paz denied that the species which is\nused for human consumption is involved, because only wild-caught\nsnails were infected. Therefore, the official cautioned that he has\nset up an \"epidemiological barrier\" to prevent spread of the parasite.\n\nUsually, it lives in the pulmonary arteries of rats. Martini does not\nknow exactly how it came into the country. \"It most likely came in\nsnails imported by the domestic industry. When improperly handled on\nfarms, they were accessible to wild rats which became infected for the\n1st time.\"\n\nLos Rios is not only affected but also Santo Domingo de las Tsachilas.\nThe director of the Eugenio Espejo hospital in Quito [the capital],\nMarco Ortega, confirmed yesterday that 3 weeks ago 2 people in that\njurisdiction had this health problem. On 18 Nov 2008, 3 people were\nvisiting an area near Santo Domingo, where they collected at least 3\npounds of snails, which they ate raw with lemon and salt.\n\nDays later, one of them, a 20-year-old man, had abdominal pain, fever\nand pain in knees and hips. He was admitted to Eugenio Espejo hospital\non 26 Nov 2008. After 12 days his symptoms worsened, adding slightly\nstiff neck and alteration of consciousness. Doctors diagnosed severe\nmeningitis caused by the parasite, _A. cantonensis_, which lives in\nsnails. He remains hospitalized.\n\nHis brother, aged 17, entered this hospital on 1 Dec 2008, with\nsimilar symptoms. He, according to Flores, ate fewer snails. \"He was\ndischarged 15 days ago and is out of danger,\" doctors said. \"But he\nhas a lot of pain when walking.\" The 3rd person was not admitted to\nhospital; he had only tasted the flavored juice of the snails.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are the 1st human cases of angiostrongyliasis in humans from\nEcuador. All had been eating snails. Previously, the parasite has been\ndemonstrated in naturally infected snails of various genera and\nspecies in northeastern Brazil, which has also reported cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the same areas. As is well known, _A.\ncantonensis_ has repeatedly been reported as a cause of human disease\nin the Caribbean, particularly in Cuba, and reported previously by\nProMED from Dominica, Brazil, and the USA. It is a potential risk in\nNorth and Central America, where there are snails and rodents infected\nwith the parasite.\n\nPicture and life cycle of Agiostrongylus:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>\n- Mods.JT/EP]\n\n[A map showing the location of Ecuador in South America is available at:\n<http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcecuador.htm>\n- CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - Brazil (ES) 20070414.1244\n1998\n----\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis - USA (LA & MS) 19981113.2193\n1997\n----\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (05) 19970619.1306\n....................jt/ep/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.elcomercio.com/noticiaEC.asp?id_noticia=246645&id_seccion=8>\n\n\nA study by researcher Luiggi Martini has confirmed that consumption of\nraw snails caused an outbreak in the area of La Ercilia, San Eduardo,\nZapotal parish, Ventanas canton, in Los R\u00edos province. The inquiry by\nMartini, an official and former director of the Izquieta Perez\nInstitute of Hygiene, began after 10 patients were diagnosed with\neosinophilic meningoencephalitis, caused by a parasite found in snails.\n\nThe symptoms were: neurological disorders, constipation, vomiting,\nnausea, abdominal pain (see graphics in original). The 1st to be\naffected were from the coastal province. The provincial director of\nLos Rios province, Carlos Paz, confirmed to this newspaper that 10\npeople had been affected, and another 25-year-old man died [of it] in\nthe Luis Vernaza hospital of Guayaquil on 22 Jul 2008. Martini\nmaintains in his 21-page report that this is the 1st record of\ninfection in rats by the parasite _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in\nEcuador and in South America. [Not the 1st for S. America -- see\ncomment below. - Mod.JW]\n\nAccording to history, the parasite was 1st described by HT Chen in\n1935 and was the 1st rat lungworm. In 1937, another worm was obtained\nfrom a rat in Taiwan, a new species. This infection has also appeared\nin Egypt and in Southeast Asia, in Pacific Rim countries such as\nThailand, Vietnam, Japan, and in Hawaii.\n\nOn Mon 22 Dec 2008 there was a meeting of all health authorities to\ndetermine what action to take, because the problem also involves\ncommerce, the export of snails. Paz denied that the species which is\nused for human consumption is involved, because only wild-caught\nsnails were infected. Therefore, the official cautioned that he has\nset up an \"epidemiological barrier\" to prevent spread of the parasite.\n\nUsually, it lives in the pulmonary arteries of rats. Martini does not\nknow exactly how it came into the country. \"It most likely came in\nsnails imported by the domestic industry. When improperly handled on\nfarms, they were accessible to wild rats which became infected for the\n1st time.\"\n\nLos Rios is not only affected but also Santo Domingo de las Tsachilas.\nThe director of the Eugenio Espejo hospital in Quito [the capital],\nMarco Ortega, confirmed yesterday that 3 weeks ago 2 people in that\njurisdiction had this health problem. On 18 Nov 2008, 3 people were\nvisiting an area near Santo Domingo, where they collected at least 3\npounds of snails, which they ate raw with lemon and salt.\n\nDays later, one of them, a 20-year-old man, had abdominal pain, fever\nand pain in knees and hips. He was admitted to Eugenio Espejo hospital\non 26 Nov 2008. After 12 days his symptoms worsened, adding slightly\nstiff neck and alteration of consciousness. Doctors diagnosed severe\nmeningitis caused by the parasite, _A. cantonensis_, which lives in\nsnails. He remains hospitalized.\n\nHis brother, aged 17, entered this hospital on 1 Dec 2008, with\nsimilar symptoms. He, according to Flores, ate fewer snails. \"He was\ndischarged 15 days ago and is out of danger,\" doctors said. \"But he\nhas a lot of pain when walking.\" The 3rd person was not admitted to\nhospital; he had only tasted the flavored juice of the snails.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are the 1st human cases of angiostrongyliasis in humans from\nEcuador. All had been eating snails. Previously, the parasite has been\ndemonstrated in naturally infected snails of various genera and\nspecies in northeastern Brazil, which has also reported cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the same areas. As is well known, _A.\ncantonensis_ has repeatedly been reported as a cause of human disease\nin the Caribbean, particularly in Cuba, and reported previously by\nProMED from Dominica, Brazil, and the USA. It is a potential risk in\nNorth and Central America, where there are snails and rodents infected\nwith the parasite.\n\nPicture and life cycle of Agiostrongylus:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>\n- Mods.JT/EP]\n\n[A map showing the location of Ecuador in South America is available at:\n<http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcecuador.htm>\n- CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - Brazil (ES) 20070414.1244\n1998\n----\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis - USA (LA & MS) 19981113.2193\n1997\n----\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (05) 19970619.1306\n....................jt/ep/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Switzerland ex Italy (Elba)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=143632", "date": "2008-12-31 15:00:41", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS \u0096 ECUADOR: (LOS RIOS)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 30 Dec 2008\nSource: El Comercio, Ecuador [in Spanish, trans. & summ. Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.elcomercio.com/noticiaEC.asp?id_noticia=246645&id_seccion=8>\n\n\nA study by researcher Luiggi Martini has confirmed that consumption of\nraw snails caused an outbreak in the area of La Ercilia, San Eduardo,\nZapotal parish, Ventanas canton, in Los R\u00edos province. The inquiry by\nMartini, an official and former director of the Izquieta Perez\nInstitute of Hygiene, began after 10 patients were diagnosed with\neosinophilic meningoencephalitis, caused by a parasite found in snails.\n\nThe symptoms were: neurological disorders, constipation, vomiting,\nnausea, abdominal pain (see graphics in original). The 1st to be\naffected were from the coastal province. The provincial director of\nLos Rios province, Carlos Paz, confirmed to this newspaper that 10\npeople had been affected, and another 25-year-old man died [of it] in\nthe Luis Vernaza hospital of Guayaquil on 22 Jul 2008. Martini\nmaintains in his 21-page report that this is the 1st record of\ninfection in rats by the parasite _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in\nEcuador and in South America. [Not the 1st for S. America -- see\ncomment below. - Mod.JW]\n\nAccording to history, the parasite was 1st described by HT Chen in\n1935 and was the 1st rat lungworm. In 1937, another worm was obtained\nfrom a rat in Taiwan, a new species. This infection has also appeared\nin Egypt and in Southeast Asia, in Pacific Rim countries such as\nThailand, Vietnam, Japan, and in Hawaii.\n\nOn Mon 22 Dec 2008 there was a meeting of all health authorities to\ndetermine what action to take, because the problem also involves\ncommerce, the export of snails. Paz denied that the species which is\nused for human consumption is involved, because only wild-caught\nsnails were infected. Therefore, the official cautioned that he has\nset up an \"epidemiological barrier\" to prevent spread of the parasite.\n\nUsually, it lives in the pulmonary arteries of rats. Martini does not\nknow exactly how it came into the country. \"It most likely came in\nsnails imported by the domestic industry. When improperly handled on\nfarms, they were accessible to wild rats which became infected for the\n1st time.\"\n\nLos Rios is not only affected but also Santo Domingo de las Tsachilas.\nThe director of the Eugenio Espejo hospital in Quito [the capital],\nMarco Ortega, confirmed yesterday that 3 weeks ago 2 people in that\njurisdiction had this health problem. On 18 Nov 2008, 3 people were\nvisiting an area near Santo Domingo, where they collected at least 3\npounds of snails, which they ate raw with lemon and salt.\n\nDays later, one of them, a 20-year-old man, had abdominal pain, fever\nand pain in knees and hips. He was admitted to Eugenio Espejo hospital\non 26 Nov 2008. After 12 days his symptoms worsened, adding slightly\nstiff neck and alteration of consciousness. Doctors diagnosed severe\nmeningitis caused by the parasite, _A. cantonensis_, which lives in\nsnails. He remains hospitalized.\n\nHis brother, aged 17, entered this hospital on 1 Dec 2008, with\nsimilar symptoms. He, according to Flores, ate fewer snails. \"He was\ndischarged 15 days ago and is out of danger,\" doctors said. \"But he\nhas a lot of pain when walking.\" The 3rd person was not admitted to\nhospital; he had only tasted the flavored juice of the snails.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are the 1st human cases of angiostrongyliasis in humans from\nEcuador. All had been eating snails. Previously, the parasite has been\ndemonstrated in naturally infected snails of various genera and\nspecies in northeastern Brazil, which has also reported cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the same areas. As is well known, _A.\ncantonensis_ has repeatedly been reported as a cause of human disease\nin the Caribbean, particularly in Cuba, and reported previously by\nProMED from Dominica, Brazil, and the USA. It is a potential risk in\nNorth and Central America, where there are snails and rodents infected\nwith the parasite.\n\nPicture and life cycle of Agiostrongylus:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>\n- Mods.JT/EP]\n\n[A map showing the location of Ecuador in South America is available at:\n<http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcecuador.htm>\n- CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - Brazil (ES) 20070414.1244\n1998\n----\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis - USA (LA & MS) 19981113.2193\n1997\n----\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (05) 19970619.1306\n....................jt/ep/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "1935-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2008-12-16 00:00:00", "2008-11-18 00:00:00", "2008-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-12-01 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los Rios", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Comercio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dominica", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Domingo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Eduardo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quito", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ventanas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los R\u00edos", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "142441", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - US: [HI]", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=142441", "date": "2008-12-31 15:00:41", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS \u0096 ECUADOR: (LOS RIOS)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 30 Dec 2008\nSource: El Comercio, Ecuador [in Spanish, trans. & summ. Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.elcomercio.com/noticiaEC.asp?id_noticia=246645&id_seccion=8>\n\n\nA study by researcher Luiggi Martini has confirmed that consumption of\nraw snails caused an outbreak in the area of La Ercilia, San Eduardo,\nZapotal parish, Ventanas canton, in Los R\u00edos province. The inquiry by\nMartini, an official and former director of the Izquieta Perez\nInstitute of Hygiene, began after 10 patients were diagnosed with\neosinophilic meningoencephalitis, caused by a parasite found in snails.\n\nThe symptoms were: neurological disorders, constipation, vomiting,\nnausea, abdominal pain (see graphics in original). The 1st to be\naffected were from the coastal province. The provincial director of\nLos Rios province, Carlos Paz, confirmed to this newspaper that 10\npeople had been affected, and another 25-year-old man died [of it] in\nthe Luis Vernaza hospital of Guayaquil on 22 Jul 2008. Martini\nmaintains in his 21-page report that this is the 1st record of\ninfection in rats by the parasite _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in\nEcuador and in South America. [Not the 1st for S. America -- see\ncomment below. - Mod.JW]\n\nAccording to history, the parasite was 1st described by HT Chen in\n1935 and was the 1st rat lungworm. In 1937, another worm was obtained\nfrom a rat in Taiwan, a new species. This infection has also appeared\nin Egypt and in Southeast Asia, in Pacific Rim countries such as\nThailand, Vietnam, Japan, and in Hawaii.\n\nOn Mon 22 Dec 2008 there was a meeting of all health authorities to\ndetermine what action to take, because the problem also involves\ncommerce, the export of snails. Paz denied that the species which is\nused for human consumption is involved, because only wild-caught\nsnails were infected. Therefore, the official cautioned that he has\nset up an \"epidemiological barrier\" to prevent spread of the parasite.\n\nUsually, it lives in the pulmonary arteries of rats. Martini does not\nknow exactly how it came into the country. \"It most likely came in\nsnails imported by the domestic industry. When improperly handled on\nfarms, they were accessible to wild rats which became infected for the\n1st time.\"\n\nLos Rios is not only affected but also Santo Domingo de las Tsachilas.\nThe director of the Eugenio Espejo hospital in Quito [the capital],\nMarco Ortega, confirmed yesterday that 3 weeks ago 2 people in that\njurisdiction had this health problem. On 18 Nov 2008, 3 people were\nvisiting an area near Santo Domingo, where they collected at least 3\npounds of snails, which they ate raw with lemon and salt.\n\nDays later, one of them, a 20-year-old man, had abdominal pain, fever\nand pain in knees and hips. He was admitted to Eugenio Espejo hospital\non 26 Nov 2008. After 12 days his symptoms worsened, adding slightly\nstiff neck and alteration of consciousness. Doctors diagnosed severe\nmeningitis caused by the parasite, _A. cantonensis_, which lives in\nsnails. He remains hospitalized.\n\nHis brother, aged 17, entered this hospital on 1 Dec 2008, with\nsimilar symptoms. He, according to Flores, ate fewer snails. \"He was\ndischarged 15 days ago and is out of danger,\" doctors said. \"But he\nhas a lot of pain when walking.\" The 3rd person was not admitted to\nhospital; he had only tasted the flavored juice of the snails.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are the 1st human cases of angiostrongyliasis in humans from\nEcuador. All had been eating snails. Previously, the parasite has been\ndemonstrated in naturally infected snails of various genera and\nspecies in northeastern Brazil, which has also reported cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the same areas. As is well known, _A.\ncantonensis_ has repeatedly been reported as a cause of human disease\nin the Caribbean, particularly in Cuba, and reported previously by\nProMED from Dominica, Brazil, and the USA. It is a potential risk in\nNorth and Central America, where there are snails and rodents infected\nwith the parasite.\n\nPicture and life cycle of Agiostrongylus:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>\n- Mods.JT/EP]\n\n[A map showing the location of Ecuador in South America is available at:\n<http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcecuador.htm>\n- CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - Brazil (ES) 20070414.1244\n1998\n----\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis - USA (LA & MS) 19981113.2193\n1997\n----\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (05) 19970619.1306\n....................jt/ep/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
