If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "1935-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2008-12-16 00:00:00", "2008-11-18 00:00:00", "2008-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-12-01 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los Rios", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Comercio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dominica", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Domingo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Eduardo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quito", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ventanas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los R\u00edos", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "142879", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - US: (HI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=142879", "date": "2008-12-31 15:00:41", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS \u0096 ECUADOR: (LOS RIOS)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 30 Dec 2008\nSource: El Comercio, Ecuador [in Spanish, trans. & summ. Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://www.elcomercio.com/noticiaEC.asp?id_noticia=246645&id_seccion=8>\n\n\nA study by researcher Luiggi Martini has confirmed that consumption of\nraw snails caused an outbreak in the area of La Ercilia, San Eduardo,\nZapotal parish, Ventanas canton, in Los R\u00edos province. The inquiry by\nMartini, an official and former director of the Izquieta Perez\nInstitute of Hygiene, began after 10 patients were diagnosed with\neosinophilic meningoencephalitis, caused by a parasite found in snails.\n\nThe symptoms were: neurological disorders, constipation, vomiting,\nnausea, abdominal pain (see graphics in original). The 1st to be\naffected were from the coastal province. The provincial director of\nLos Rios province, Carlos Paz, confirmed to this newspaper that 10\npeople had been affected, and another 25-year-old man died [of it] in\nthe Luis Vernaza hospital of Guayaquil on 22 Jul 2008. Martini\nmaintains in his 21-page report that this is the 1st record of\ninfection in rats by the parasite _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in\nEcuador and in South America. [Not the 1st for S. America -- see\ncomment below. - Mod.JW]\n\nAccording to history, the parasite was 1st described by HT Chen in\n1935 and was the 1st rat lungworm. In 1937, another worm was obtained\nfrom a rat in Taiwan, a new species. This infection has also appeared\nin Egypt and in Southeast Asia, in Pacific Rim countries such as\nThailand, Vietnam, Japan, and in Hawaii.\n\nOn Mon 22 Dec 2008 there was a meeting of all health authorities to\ndetermine what action to take, because the problem also involves\ncommerce, the export of snails. Paz denied that the species which is\nused for human consumption is involved, because only wild-caught\nsnails were infected. Therefore, the official cautioned that he has\nset up an \"epidemiological barrier\" to prevent spread of the parasite.\n\nUsually, it lives in the pulmonary arteries of rats. Martini does not\nknow exactly how it came into the country. \"It most likely came in\nsnails imported by the domestic industry. When improperly handled on\nfarms, they were accessible to wild rats which became infected for the\n1st time.\"\n\nLos Rios is not only affected but also Santo Domingo de las Tsachilas.\nThe director of the Eugenio Espejo hospital in Quito [the capital],\nMarco Ortega, confirmed yesterday that 3 weeks ago 2 people in that\njurisdiction had this health problem. On 18 Nov 2008, 3 people were\nvisiting an area near Santo Domingo, where they collected at least 3\npounds of snails, which they ate raw with lemon and salt.\n\nDays later, one of them, a 20-year-old man, had abdominal pain, fever\nand pain in knees and hips. He was admitted to Eugenio Espejo hospital\non 26 Nov 2008. After 12 days his symptoms worsened, adding slightly\nstiff neck and alteration of consciousness. Doctors diagnosed severe\nmeningitis caused by the parasite, _A. cantonensis_, which lives in\nsnails. He remains hospitalized.\n\nHis brother, aged 17, entered this hospital on 1 Dec 2008, with\nsimilar symptoms. He, according to Flores, ate fewer snails. \"He was\ndischarged 15 days ago and is out of danger,\" doctors said. \"But he\nhas a lot of pain when walking.\" The 3rd person was not admitted to\nhospital; he had only tasted the flavored juice of the snails.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are the 1st human cases of angiostrongyliasis in humans from\nEcuador. All had been eating snails. Previously, the parasite has been\ndemonstrated in naturally infected snails of various genera and\nspecies in northeastern Brazil, which has also reported cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the same areas. As is well known, _A.\ncantonensis_ has repeatedly been reported as a cause of human disease\nin the Caribbean, particularly in Cuba, and reported previously by\nProMED from Dominica, Brazil, and the USA. It is a potential risk in\nNorth and Central America, where there are snails and rodents infected\nwith the parasite.\n\nPicture and life cycle of Agiostrongylus:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>\n- Mods.JT/EP]\n\n[A map showing the location of Ecuador in South America is available at:\n<http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcecuador.htm>\n- CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - Brazil (ES) 20070414.1244\n1998\n----\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis - USA (LA & MS) 19981113.2193\n1997\n----\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (05) 19970619.1306\n....................jt/ep/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Martini\nmaintains in his 21-page report that this is the 1st record of\ninfection in rats by the parasite _Angiostrongylus cantonensis_ in\nEcuador and in South America. [Not the 1st for S. America -- see\ncomment below. - Mod.JW]\n\nAccording to history, the parasite was 1st described by HT Chen in\n1935 and was the 1st rat lungworm. In 1937, another worm was obtained\nfrom a rat in Taiwan, a new species. This infection has also appeared\nin Egypt and in Southeast Asia, in Pacific Rim countries such as\nThailand, Vietnam, Japan, and in Hawaii.\n\nOn Mon 22 Dec 2008 there was a meeting of all health authorities to\ndetermine what action to take, because the problem also involves\ncommerce, the export of snails. Paz denied that the species which is\nused for human consumption is involved, because only wild-caught\nsnails were infected. Therefore, the official cautioned that he has\nset up an \"epidemiological barrier\" to prevent spread of the parasite.\n\nUsually, it lives in the pulmonary arteries of rats. Martini does not\nknow exactly how it came into the country. \"It most likely came in\nsnails imported by the domestic industry. When improperly handled on\nfarms, they were accessible to wild rats which became infected for the\n1st time.\"\n\nLos Rios is not only affected but also Santo Domingo de las Tsachilas.\nThe director of the Eugenio Espejo hospital in Quito [the capital],\nMarco Ortega, confirmed yesterday that 3 weeks ago 2 people in that\njurisdiction had this health problem. On 18 Nov 2008, 3 people were\nvisiting an area near Santo Domingo, where they collected at least 3\npounds of snails, which they ate raw with lemon and salt.\n\nDays later, one of them, a 20-year-old man, had abdominal pain, fever\nand pain in knees and hips. He was admitted to Eugenio Espejo hospital\non 26 Nov 2008. After 12 days his symptoms worsened, adding slightly\nstiff neck and alteration of consciousness. Doctors diagnosed severe\nmeningitis caused by the parasite, _A. cantonensis_, which lives in\nsnails. He remains hospitalized.\n\nHis brother, aged 17, entered this hospital on 1 Dec 2008, with\nsimilar symptoms. He, according to Flores, ate fewer snails. \"He was\ndischarged 15 days ago and is out of danger,\" doctors said. \"But he\nhas a lot of pain when walking.\" The 3rd person was not admitted to\nhospital; he had only tasted the flavored juice of the snails.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[These are the 1st human cases of angiostrongyliasis in humans from\nEcuador. All had been eating snails. Previously, the parasite has been\ndemonstrated in naturally infected snails of various genera and\nspecies in northeastern Brazil, which has also reported cases of\neosinophilic meningitis in the same areas. As is well known, _A.\ncantonensis_ has repeatedly been reported as a cause of human disease\nin the Caribbean, particularly in Cuba, and reported previously by\nProMED from Dominica, Brazil, and the USA. It is a potential risk in\nNorth and Central America, where there are snails and rodents infected\nwith the parasite.\n\nPicture and life cycle of Agiostrongylus:\n<http://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx/HTML/angiostrongyliasis.htm>\n- Mods.JT/EP]\n\n[A map showing the location of Ecuador in South America is available at:\n<http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcecuador.htm>\n- CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\n2007\n----\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - Brazil (ES) 20070414.1244\n1998\n----\nAngiostrongylus cantonensis - USA (LA & MS) 19981113.2193\n1997\n----\nAngiostrongylus costaricensis - Dominica (05) 19970619.1306\n....................jt/ep/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-22 00:00:00", "1935-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "2008-12-16 00:00:00", "2008-11-18 00:00:00", "2008-11-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2008-12-01 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los Rios", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Comercio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dominica", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Domingo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cuba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Eduardo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quito", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ventanas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vietnam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los R\u00edos", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "131507", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, children - Russia: (RYA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=131507", "date": "2008-02-25 03:00:16", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: MENINGITIS BELT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Feb 2008\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2008_02_22a/en/index.html>\n\n\nThe WHO Multi-Disease Surveillance Centre in Ouagadougou (MDSC - Burkina\nFaso) is monitoring the meningitis situation in the African meningitis belt\nthroughout the epidemic season and, in particular, in 13 countries under\nenhanced seasonal surveillance: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central\nAfrican Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the\nCongo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger, Nigeria and Togo.\n\nPreliminary reports from these countries are of a total of 2312 cases (324\ndeaths) occurring between 1 Jan and 10 Feb 2008. These figures are 29 per\ncent lower than those reported in the same 6 week period in 2007 (3274\ncases, 413 deaths) indicating lower levels of meningitis activity so far in\n2008.\n\nAmong countries reporting cases to the MDSC, Burkina Faso, the Central\nAfrican Republic and the Democratic Republic of the Congo have been\nreporting outbreaks since the beginning of the season. Other countries\nreporting meningitis activity without reaching the epidemic threshold at\ndistrict level include Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger,\nNigeria and Togo. Cameroon and Chad have not reported any cases. Burkina\nFaso is the most affected country with a total of 1422 cases, including 204\ndeaths (case fatality ratio [CFR] 14.3 per cent) reported from 1 Jan to 10\nFeb 2008. These cases represent more than 61 per cent of all cases reported\nto MDSC in 2008 (against 64 per cent for the same period in 2007).\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ [seogroup] A (Nm A) was identified as the\ncausative agent in Mangodara and Sapouy districts. Vaccination was carried\nout in these districts as well as in Gaoua, targeting the 2 to 29 year old\npopulation. A cross border assessment is being carried out on the situation\nin Ivory Coast in the area neighboring Mangodara district. Although the\nepidemiological trend in Burkina Faso is similar to the one observed last\nyear [2007], the 1st 6 weeks of 2007 saw more cases reported in total as\nwell as more districts reaching the epidemic threshold (8 as against 2 in\n2008).\n\nThe Ministry of Health in the Central African Republic is launching\nreactive mass vaccination campaigns in some of the communes that have\nreached the epidemic threshold in the northern prefecture of Nana-Gribizi.\nA total of 45 cases, including 5 deaths (CFR 11.1 per cent) had been\nreported by the end of week 6, and Nm A has been identified as the\nresponsible pathogen. International partners including WHO and the\nInternational Coordination Group (ICG) are providing support for the\nvaccination campaigns.\n\nIn the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a situation assessment is being\ncarried out in Aru district (that neighbours Arua district in Uganda),\nwhere 167 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 10.2 per cent) were reported\nduring the period from 1 Jan to 10 Feb 2008. The most affected areas\ninclude Laybo, Ariwara and Aungba health zones. The Aru district also\nexperienced an outbreak in early 2007.\n\nIn southern Sudan, a situation assessment is being carried out in areas\nwhere suspected cases were reported, including in Awerial, Bor, Jur River\nand Torit Counties. Uganda experienced an outbreak in Arua district, West\nNile region, with a total of 380 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 4.5 per\ncent) reported from 13 Dec 2007 to 28 Jan 2008. A sharp decline in the\nweekly case count was observed following a mass vaccination campaign that\nwas implemented in week 4. No suspected cases have been reported from other\ncountries within the meningitis belt, namely Eritrea, Guinea, the Gambia,\nKenya, Mauritania and Senegal.\n\nSo far in 2008, the ICG has provided 40 000 vaccine doses, injection\nmaterial and safety disposal boxes for vaccination campaigns in the Central\nAfrican Republic. The current ICG stockpile, available for outbreak\nresponse in this meningitis season stands at 7 million doses of bivalent\npolysaccharide A/C vaccine and 3.3 million doses of trivalent\npolysaccharide vaccine A/C/W135.\n\nFor more information on submitting requests for vaccines through the ICG\nand regional meningitis surveillance, see links below.\n- International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic\nMeningitis Control\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/icg/en/index.html>\n- Epidemiological information\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/epidemiological/en/index/html>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a nice up to date summary from WHO concerning the ongoing\nmeningococcal meningitis outbreak in the African bacterial meningitis belt.\nSee prior ProMED-mail posts listed below for more information. A map of the\nAfrican bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Italy (Veneto) 20071222.4120\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\nMeningitis - Namibia (North): RFI 20070906.2942\n2000\n---\nMeningitis - Namibia (North) 20001214.2182\n\n..................ml/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2312-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1422-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-01-28 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eritrea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaoua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Ouagadougou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laybo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gambia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ivory Coast", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ariwara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mangodara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Awerial", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "127445", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Angiostrongylus meningitis - Viet Nam", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=127445", "date": "2008-02-25 03:00:16", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: MENINGITIS BELT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Feb 2008\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2008_02_22a/en/index.html>\n\n\nThe WHO Multi-Disease Surveillance Centre in Ouagadougou (MDSC - Burkina\nFaso) is monitoring the meningitis situation in the African meningitis belt\nthroughout the epidemic season and, in particular, in 13 countries under\nenhanced seasonal surveillance: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central\nAfrican Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the\nCongo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger, Nigeria and Togo.\n\nPreliminary reports from these countries are of a total of 2312 cases (324\ndeaths) occurring between 1 Jan and 10 Feb 2008. These figures are 29 per\ncent lower than those reported in the same 6 week period in 2007 (3274\ncases, 413 deaths) indicating lower levels of meningitis activity so far in\n2008.\n\nAmong countries reporting cases to the MDSC, Burkina Faso, the Central\nAfrican Republic and the Democratic Republic of the Congo have been\nreporting outbreaks since the beginning of the season. Other countries\nreporting meningitis activity without reaching the epidemic threshold at\ndistrict level include Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger,\nNigeria and Togo. Cameroon and Chad have not reported any cases. Burkina\nFaso is the most affected country with a total of 1422 cases, including 204\ndeaths (case fatality ratio [CFR] 14.3 per cent) reported from 1 Jan to 10\nFeb 2008. These cases represent more than 61 per cent of all cases reported\nto MDSC in 2008 (against 64 per cent for the same period in 2007).\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ [seogroup] A (Nm A) was identified as the\ncausative agent in Mangodara and Sapouy districts. Vaccination was carried\nout in these districts as well as in Gaoua, targeting the 2 to 29 year old\npopulation. A cross border assessment is being carried out on the situation\nin Ivory Coast in the area neighboring Mangodara district. Although the\nepidemiological trend in Burkina Faso is similar to the one observed last\nyear [2007], the 1st 6 weeks of 2007 saw more cases reported in total as\nwell as more districts reaching the epidemic threshold (8 as against 2 in\n2008).\n\nThe Ministry of Health in the Central African Republic is launching\nreactive mass vaccination campaigns in some of the communes that have\nreached the epidemic threshold in the northern prefecture of Nana-Gribizi.\nA total of 45 cases, including 5 deaths (CFR 11.1 per cent) had been\nreported by the end of week 6, and Nm A has been identified as the\nresponsible pathogen. International partners including WHO and the\nInternational Coordination Group (ICG) are providing support for the\nvaccination campaigns.\n\nIn the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a situation assessment is being\ncarried out in Aru district (that neighbours Arua district in Uganda),\nwhere 167 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 10.2 per cent) were reported\nduring the period from 1 Jan to 10 Feb 2008. The most affected areas\ninclude Laybo, Ariwara and Aungba health zones. The Aru district also\nexperienced an outbreak in early 2007.\n\nIn southern Sudan, a situation assessment is being carried out in areas\nwhere suspected cases were reported, including in Awerial, Bor, Jur River\nand Torit Counties. Uganda experienced an outbreak in Arua district, West\nNile region, with a total of 380 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 4.5 per\ncent) reported from 13 Dec 2007 to 28 Jan 2008. A sharp decline in the\nweekly case count was observed following a mass vaccination campaign that\nwas implemented in week 4. No suspected cases have been reported from other\ncountries within the meningitis belt, namely Eritrea, Guinea, the Gambia,\nKenya, Mauritania and Senegal.\n\nSo far in 2008, the ICG has provided 40 000 vaccine doses, injection\nmaterial and safety disposal boxes for vaccination campaigns in the Central\nAfrican Republic. The current ICG stockpile, available for outbreak\nresponse in this meningitis season stands at 7 million doses of bivalent\npolysaccharide A/C vaccine and 3.3 million doses of trivalent\npolysaccharide vaccine A/C/W135.\n\nFor more information on submitting requests for vaccines through the ICG\nand regional meningitis surveillance, see links below.\n- International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic\nMeningitis Control\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/icg/en/index.html>\n- Epidemiological information\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/epidemiological/en/index/html>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a nice up to date summary from WHO concerning the ongoing\nmeningococcal meningitis outbreak in the African bacterial meningitis belt.\nSee prior ProMED-mail posts listed below for more information. A map of the\nAfrican bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Italy (Veneto) 20071222.4120\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\nMeningitis - Namibia (North): RFI 20070906.2942\n2000\n---\nMeningitis - Namibia (North) 20001214.2182\n\n..................ml/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Brazil: (SP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=108146", "date": "2008-02-25 03:00:16", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: MENINGITIS BELT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Feb 2008\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2008_02_22a/en/index.html>\n\n\nThe WHO Multi-Disease Surveillance Centre in Ouagadougou (MDSC - Burkina\nFaso) is monitoring the meningitis situation in the African meningitis belt\nthroughout the epidemic season and, in particular, in 13 countries under\nenhanced seasonal surveillance: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central\nAfrican Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the\nCongo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger, Nigeria and Togo.\n\nPreliminary reports from these countries are of a total of 2312 cases (324\ndeaths) occurring between 1 Jan and 10 Feb 2008. These figures are 29 per\ncent lower than those reported in the same 6 week period in 2007 (3274\ncases, 413 deaths) indicating lower levels of meningitis activity so far in\n2008.\n\nAmong countries reporting cases to the MDSC, Burkina Faso, the Central\nAfrican Republic and the Democratic Republic of the Congo have been\nreporting outbreaks since the beginning of the season. Other countries\nreporting meningitis activity without reaching the epidemic threshold at\ndistrict level include Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger,\nNigeria and Togo. Cameroon and Chad have not reported any cases. Burkina\nFaso is the most affected country with a total of 1422 cases, including 204\ndeaths (case fatality ratio [CFR] 14.3 per cent) reported from 1 Jan to 10\nFeb 2008. These cases represent more than 61 per cent of all cases reported\nto MDSC in 2008 (against 64 per cent for the same period in 2007).\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ [seogroup] A (Nm A) was identified as the\ncausative agent in Mangodara and Sapouy districts. Vaccination was carried\nout in these districts as well as in Gaoua, targeting the 2 to 29 year old\npopulation. A cross border assessment is being carried out on the situation\nin Ivory Coast in the area neighboring Mangodara district. Although the\nepidemiological trend in Burkina Faso is similar to the one observed last\nyear [2007], the 1st 6 weeks of 2007 saw more cases reported in total as\nwell as more districts reaching the epidemic threshold (8 as against 2 in\n2008).\n\nThe Ministry of Health in the Central African Republic is launching\nreactive mass vaccination campaigns in some of the communes that have\nreached the epidemic threshold in the northern prefecture of Nana-Gribizi.\nA total of 45 cases, including 5 deaths (CFR 11.1 per cent) had been\nreported by the end of week 6, and Nm A has been identified as the\nresponsible pathogen. International partners including WHO and the\nInternational Coordination Group (ICG) are providing support for the\nvaccination campaigns.\n\nIn the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a situation assessment is being\ncarried out in Aru district (that neighbours Arua district in Uganda),\nwhere 167 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 10.2 per cent) were reported\nduring the period from 1 Jan to 10 Feb 2008. The most affected areas\ninclude Laybo, Ariwara and Aungba health zones. The Aru district also\nexperienced an outbreak in early 2007.\n\nIn southern Sudan, a situation assessment is being carried out in areas\nwhere suspected cases were reported, including in Awerial, Bor, Jur River\nand Torit Counties. Uganda experienced an outbreak in Arua district, West\nNile region, with a total of 380 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 4.5 per\ncent) reported from 13 Dec 2007 to 28 Jan 2008. A sharp decline in the\nweekly case count was observed following a mass vaccination campaign that\nwas implemented in week 4. No suspected cases have been reported from other\ncountries within the meningitis belt, namely Eritrea, Guinea, the Gambia,\nKenya, Mauritania and Senegal.\n\nSo far in 2008, the ICG has provided 40 000 vaccine doses, injection\nmaterial and safety disposal boxes for vaccination campaigns in the Central\nAfrican Republic. The current ICG stockpile, available for outbreak\nresponse in this meningitis season stands at 7 million doses of bivalent\npolysaccharide A/C vaccine and 3.3 million doses of trivalent\npolysaccharide vaccine A/C/W135.\n\nFor more information on submitting requests for vaccines through the ICG\nand regional meningitis surveillance, see links below.\n- International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic\nMeningitis Control\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/icg/en/index.html>\n- Epidemiological information\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/epidemiological/en/index/html>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a nice up to date summary from WHO concerning the ongoing\nmeningococcal meningitis outbreak in the African bacterial meningitis belt.\nSee prior ProMED-mail posts listed below for more information. A map of the\nAfrican bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Italy (Veneto) 20071222.4120\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\nMeningitis - Namibia (North): RFI 20070906.2942\n2000\n---\nMeningitis - Namibia (North) 20001214.2182\n\n..................ml/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2312-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1422-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-01-28 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eritrea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaoua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Ouagadougou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laybo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gambia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ivory Coast", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ariwara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mangodara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Awerial", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "107499", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Enterovirus infection, meningitis - Russia: (Vladivostok)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=107499", "date": "2008-02-25 03:00:16", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: MENINGITIS BELT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Feb 2008\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2008_02_22a/en/index.html>\n\n\nThe WHO Multi-Disease Surveillance Centre in Ouagadougou (MDSC - Burkina\nFaso) is monitoring the meningitis situation in the African meningitis belt\nthroughout the epidemic season and, in particular, in 13 countries under\nenhanced seasonal surveillance: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central\nAfrican Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the\nCongo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger, Nigeria and Togo.\n\nPreliminary reports from these countries are of a total of 2312 cases (324\ndeaths) occurring between 1 Jan and 10 Feb 2008. These figures are 29 per\ncent lower than those reported in the same 6 week period in 2007 (3274\ncases, 413 deaths) indicating lower levels of meningitis activity so far in\n2008.\n\nAmong countries reporting cases to the MDSC, Burkina Faso, the Central\nAfrican Republic and the Democratic Republic of the Congo have been\nreporting outbreaks since the beginning of the season. Other countries\nreporting meningitis activity without reaching the epidemic threshold at\ndistrict level include Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger,\nNigeria and Togo. Cameroon and Chad have not reported any cases. Burkina\nFaso is the most affected country with a total of 1422 cases, including 204\ndeaths (case fatality ratio [CFR] 14.3 per cent) reported from 1 Jan to 10\nFeb 2008. These cases represent more than 61 per cent of all cases reported\nto MDSC in 2008 (against 64 per cent for the same period in 2007).\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ [seogroup] A (Nm A) was identified as the\ncausative agent in Mangodara and Sapouy districts. Vaccination was carried\nout in these districts as well as in Gaoua, targeting the 2 to 29 year old\npopulation. A cross border assessment is being carried out on the situation\nin Ivory Coast in the area neighboring Mangodara district. Although the\nepidemiological trend in Burkina Faso is similar to the one observed last\nyear [2007], the 1st 6 weeks of 2007 saw more cases reported in total as\nwell as more districts reaching the epidemic threshold (8 as against 2 in\n2008).\n\nThe Ministry of Health in the Central African Republic is launching\nreactive mass vaccination campaigns in some of the communes that have\nreached the epidemic threshold in the northern prefecture of Nana-Gribizi.\nA total of 45 cases, including 5 deaths (CFR 11.1 per cent) had been\nreported by the end of week 6, and Nm A has been identified as the\nresponsible pathogen. International partners including WHO and the\nInternational Coordination Group (ICG) are providing support for the\nvaccination campaigns.\n\nIn the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a situation assessment is being\ncarried out in Aru district (that neighbours Arua district in Uganda),\nwhere 167 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 10.2 per cent) were reported\nduring the period from 1 Jan to 10 Feb 2008. The most affected areas\ninclude Laybo, Ariwara and Aungba health zones. The Aru district also\nexperienced an outbreak in early 2007.\n\nIn southern Sudan, a situation assessment is being carried out in areas\nwhere suspected cases were reported, including in Awerial, Bor, Jur River\nand Torit Counties. Uganda experienced an outbreak in Arua district, West\nNile region, with a total of 380 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 4.5 per\ncent) reported from 13 Dec 2007 to 28 Jan 2008. A sharp decline in the\nweekly case count was observed following a mass vaccination campaign that\nwas implemented in week 4. No suspected cases have been reported from other\ncountries within the meningitis belt, namely Eritrea, Guinea, the Gambia,\nKenya, Mauritania and Senegal.\n\nSo far in 2008, the ICG has provided 40 000 vaccine doses, injection\nmaterial and safety disposal boxes for vaccination campaigns in the Central\nAfrican Republic. The current ICG stockpile, available for outbreak\nresponse in this meningitis season stands at 7 million doses of bivalent\npolysaccharide A/C vaccine and 3.3 million doses of trivalent\npolysaccharide vaccine A/C/W135.\n\nFor more information on submitting requests for vaccines through the ICG\nand regional meningitis surveillance, see links below.\n- International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic\nMeningitis Control\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/icg/en/index.html>\n- Epidemiological information\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/epidemiological/en/index/html>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a nice up to date summary from WHO concerning the ongoing\nmeningococcal meningitis outbreak in the African bacterial meningitis belt.\nSee prior ProMED-mail posts listed below for more information. A map of the\nAfrican bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Italy (Veneto) 20071222.4120\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\nMeningitis - Namibia (North): RFI 20070906.2942\n2000\n---\nMeningitis - Namibia (North) 20001214.2182\n\n..................ml/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Burkina\nFaso) is monitoring the meningitis situation in the African meningitis belt\nthroughout the epidemic season and, in particular, in 13 countries under\nenhanced seasonal surveillance: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central\nAfrican Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the\nCongo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger, Nigeria and Togo.\n\nPreliminary reports from these countries are of a total of 2312 cases (324\ndeaths) occurring between 1 Jan and 10 Feb 2008. Other countries\nreporting meningitis activity without reaching the epidemic threshold at\ndistrict level include Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger,\nNigeria and Togo. Cameroon and Chad have not reported any cases. Burkina\nFaso is the most affected country with a total of 1422 cases, including 204\ndeaths (case fatality ratio [CFR] 14.3 per cent) reported from 1 Jan to 10\nFeb 2008. Vaccination was carried\nout in these districts as well as in Gaoua, targeting the 2 to 29 year old\npopulation. A cross border assessment is being carried out on the situation\nin Ivory Coast in the area neighboring Mangodara district. Although the\nepidemiological trend in Burkina Faso is similar to the one observed last\nyear [2007], the 1st 6 weeks of 2007 saw more cases reported in total as\nwell as more districts reaching the epidemic threshold (8 as against 2 in\n2008).\n\nThe Ministry of Health in the Central African Republic is launching\nreactive mass vaccination campaigns in some of the communes that have\nreached the epidemic threshold in the northern prefecture of Nana-Gribizi.\nA total of 45 cases, including 5 deaths (CFR 11.1 per cent) had been\nreported by the end of week 6, and Nm A has been identified as the\nresponsible pathogen. International partners including WHO and the\nInternational Coordination Group (ICG) are providing support for the\nvaccination campaigns.\n\nIn the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a situation assessment is being\ncarried out in Aru district (that neighbours Arua district in Uganda),\nwhere 167 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 10.2 per cent) were reported\nduring the period from 1 Jan to 10 Feb 2008. The most affected areas\ninclude Laybo, Ariwara and Aungba health zones. The Aru district also\nexperienced an outbreak in early 2007.\n\nIn southern Sudan, a situation assessment is being carried out in areas\nwhere suspected cases were reported, including in Awerial, Bor, Jur River\nand Torit Counties. Uganda experienced an outbreak in Arua district, West\nNile region, with a total of 380 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 4.5 per\ncent) reported from 13 Dec 2007 to 28 Jan 2008. A sharp decline in the\nweekly case count was observed following a mass vaccination campaign that\nwas implemented in week 4. No suspected cases have been reported from other\ncountries within the meningitis belt, namely Eritrea, Guinea, the Gambia,\nKenya, Mauritania and Senegal.\n\nSo far in 2008, the ICG has provided 40 000 vaccine doses, injection\nmaterial and safety disposal boxes for vaccination campaigns in the Central\nAfrican Republic. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2312-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1422-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-01-28 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eritrea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaoua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Ouagadougou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laybo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gambia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ivory Coast", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ariwara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mangodara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Awerial", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "61103", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Africa: meningitis belt", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=61103", "date": "2008-02-25 03:00:16", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - AFRICA: MENINGITIS BELT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Feb 2008\nSource: WHO Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and Response (EPR) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2008_02_22a/en/index.html>\n\n\nThe WHO Multi-Disease Surveillance Centre in Ouagadougou (MDSC - Burkina\nFaso) is monitoring the meningitis situation in the African meningitis belt\nthroughout the epidemic season and, in particular, in 13 countries under\nenhanced seasonal surveillance: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, the Central\nAfrican Republic, Chad, Cote d'Ivoire, the Democratic Republic of the\nCongo, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger, Nigeria and Togo.\n\nPreliminary reports from these countries are of a total of 2312 cases (324\ndeaths) occurring between 1 Jan and 10 Feb 2008. These figures are 29 per\ncent lower than those reported in the same 6 week period in 2007 (3274\ncases, 413 deaths) indicating lower levels of meningitis activity so far in\n2008.\n\nAmong countries reporting cases to the MDSC, Burkina Faso, the Central\nAfrican Republic and the Democratic Republic of the Congo have been\nreporting outbreaks since the beginning of the season. Other countries\nreporting meningitis activity without reaching the epidemic threshold at\ndistrict level include Benin, Cote d'Ivoire, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mali, Niger,\nNigeria and Togo. Cameroon and Chad have not reported any cases. Burkina\nFaso is the most affected country with a total of 1422 cases, including 204\ndeaths (case fatality ratio [CFR] 14.3 per cent) reported from 1 Jan to 10\nFeb 2008. These cases represent more than 61 per cent of all cases reported\nto MDSC in 2008 (against 64 per cent for the same period in 2007).\n\n_Neisseria meningitidis_ [seogroup] A (Nm A) was identified as the\ncausative agent in Mangodara and Sapouy districts. Vaccination was carried\nout in these districts as well as in Gaoua, targeting the 2 to 29 year old\npopulation. A cross border assessment is being carried out on the situation\nin Ivory Coast in the area neighboring Mangodara district. Although the\nepidemiological trend in Burkina Faso is similar to the one observed last\nyear [2007], the 1st 6 weeks of 2007 saw more cases reported in total as\nwell as more districts reaching the epidemic threshold (8 as against 2 in\n2008).\n\nThe Ministry of Health in the Central African Republic is launching\nreactive mass vaccination campaigns in some of the communes that have\nreached the epidemic threshold in the northern prefecture of Nana-Gribizi.\nA total of 45 cases, including 5 deaths (CFR 11.1 per cent) had been\nreported by the end of week 6, and Nm A has been identified as the\nresponsible pathogen. International partners including WHO and the\nInternational Coordination Group (ICG) are providing support for the\nvaccination campaigns.\n\nIn the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a situation assessment is being\ncarried out in Aru district (that neighbours Arua district in Uganda),\nwhere 167 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 10.2 per cent) were reported\nduring the period from 1 Jan to 10 Feb 2008. The most affected areas\ninclude Laybo, Ariwara and Aungba health zones. The Aru district also\nexperienced an outbreak in early 2007.\n\nIn southern Sudan, a situation assessment is being carried out in areas\nwhere suspected cases were reported, including in Awerial, Bor, Jur River\nand Torit Counties. Uganda experienced an outbreak in Arua district, West\nNile region, with a total of 380 cases, including 17 deaths (CFR 4.5 per\ncent) reported from 13 Dec 2007 to 28 Jan 2008. A sharp decline in the\nweekly case count was observed following a mass vaccination campaign that\nwas implemented in week 4. No suspected cases have been reported from other\ncountries within the meningitis belt, namely Eritrea, Guinea, the Gambia,\nKenya, Mauritania and Senegal.\n\nSo far in 2008, the ICG has provided 40 000 vaccine doses, injection\nmaterial and safety disposal boxes for vaccination campaigns in the Central\nAfrican Republic. The current ICG stockpile, available for outbreak\nresponse in this meningitis season stands at 7 million doses of bivalent\npolysaccharide A/C vaccine and 3.3 million doses of trivalent\npolysaccharide vaccine A/C/W135.\n\nFor more information on submitting requests for vaccines through the ICG\nand regional meningitis surveillance, see links below.\n- International Coordinating Group (ICG) on Vaccine Provision for Epidemic\nMeningitis Control\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/icg/en/index.html>\n- Epidemiological information\n<http://www.who.int/csr/disease/meningococcal/epidemiological/en/index/html>.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a nice up to date summary from WHO concerning the ongoing\nmeningococcal meningitis outbreak in the African bacterial meningitis belt.\nSee prior ProMED-mail posts listed below for more information. A map of the\nAfrican bacterial meningitis belt can be found at\n<http://www.medic8.com/images/map4-9.gif>. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI 20080212.0567\nMeningitis, meninges - Africa: W. Africa, Congo DR 20080125.0309\n2007\n---\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Italy (Veneto) 20071222.4120\nMeningitis, meningococcal - Uganda (Arua) 20071207.3954\nMeningitis - Namibia (North): RFI 20070906.2942\n2000\n---\nMeningitis - Namibia (North) 20001214.2182\n\n..................ml/msp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2312-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1422-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-01-28 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Democratic Republic of the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eritrea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gaoua", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "W. Africa", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Ouagadougou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laybo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}, {"location": "Mali", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mauritania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gambia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ivory Coast", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ariwara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mangodara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Awerial", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "58468", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal, drug resistant - USA (MN, ND)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=58468", "date": "2007-07-16 22:00:02", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA (MISSOURI)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 16 Jul 2007\nSource: KFVS 12 Heartland News [edited]\n<http://www.kfvs12.com/global/story.asp?s=6771896>\n\nThere have been 14 confirmed cases of viral meningitis in Perry\nCounty in less than a month. Usually, experts say doctors only report\na couple of cases a year.\nViral meningitis is the less serious form of meningitis. Health\nexperts say it can be spread in a variety of ways: through water,\nthrough saliva, mucus or fecal matter of an infected person. Right\nnow, they have not isolated a common cause among the 14 cases and say\nthey are working on it. In the meantime, they hope you wash your\nhands frequently, don't eat or drink after one another [i.e. don't\nshare food and drink], and avoid swallowing water from pools, creeks\nor lakes.\nA mother in Perryville said her 8-year-old son was one of the 14\ninfected, and she immediately took him to their family doctor when he\nbegan feeling nauseous and started vomiting. \"They did a spinal tap\non him to draw out the spinal fluid and see what kind of meningitis\nhe had, and turns out, he had viral meningitis,\" she said. Her son\nwas treated at a Cape Girardeau hospital and is doing fine now, but\nshe was very worried while he was ill. \"You always think of the worst\nwhen you hear the word meningitis,\" she said. Her son is now back\nhome safe and sound.\nMeanwhile, a spokesperson for the Perry County Memorial Hospital said\npatients have been canceling their appointments for fear of\ncontracting the virus. She said to keep in mind that the virus is not\nairborne, so please do keep your scheduled appointment.\n[Byline: C. J. Cassidy]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Meningitis is an illness in which there is inflammation of the\ntissues that cover the brain and spinal cord. Viral or \"aseptic\"\nmeningitis, which is the most common type, is caused by an infection\nwith one of several types of viruses. In the United States, there are\nbetween 25 000 and 50 000 hospitalizations due to viral meningitis\neach year. The more common symptoms of meningitis are fever, severe\nheadache, stiff neck, bright lights hurting the eyes, drowsiness or\nconfusion, and nausea and vomiting. In babies, the symptoms may\ninclude fever, fretfulness or irritability, difficulty in awakening\nthe baby, or the baby refuses to eat.\nViral meningitis is serious but rarely fatal in persons with normal\nimmune systems. Usually, the symptoms last from 7 to 10 days, and the\npatient recovers completely. Bacterial meningitis, on the other hand,\ncan be very serious and result in disability or death if not treated\npromptly. Often, the symptoms of viral meningitis and bacterial\nmeningitis are the same. For this reason, healthcare specialists\nadvise that whenever there is suspicion of meningitis in a child, a\ndoctor should be consulted without delay.\nMany different viruses can cause meningitis. About 90 percent of\ncases of viral meningitis are caused by enteroviruses, such as\ncoxsackieviruses and echoviruses. But herpesviruses and mumps virus\ncan also cause viral meningitis. There is no specific treatment for\nviral meningitis other than supportive care. Enteroviruses are\ntransmitted by contact predominantly through direct contact with\nrespiratory and other secretions (e.g., saliva, sputum, or nasal\nmucus) of an infected person. The incubation period for enteroviruses\nis usually between 3 and 7 days. Frequent and thorough hand washing\nis the best protection from infection.\nOutbreaks of viral meningitis are frequently indicative of fecal\ncontamination of food products, deficiencies in the supply of clean\ndrinking water or the inadequate treatment and disposal of sewage. In\nthe case of the Missouri outbreak, the source of the infection has\nnot been established so far.\nFurther information can be obtained from the U.S. CDC (Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention) website at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/viral_meningitis.htm>.\nFor the location of Perry County, Missouri, see:\n<http://www.perryvillemo.com>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nViral meningitis - USA (UT) 20050724.2137\n2003\n----\nViral meningitis update 2003 (03) 20031008.2522\nViral meningitis update 2003 (02) 20030915.2335\nViral meningitis update 2003 (01) 20030816.2047\n...........................................cp/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perryville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Girardeau", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perry County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "57592", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Central African Republic: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=57592", "date": "2007-07-16 22:00:02", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA (MISSOURI)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 16 Jul 2007\nSource: KFVS 12 Heartland News [edited]\n<http://www.kfvs12.com/global/story.asp?s=6771896>\n\nThere have been 14 confirmed cases of viral meningitis in Perry\nCounty in less than a month. Frequent and thorough hand washing\nis the best protection from infection.\nOutbreaks of viral meningitis are frequently indicative of fecal\ncontamination of food products, deficiencies in the supply of clean\ndrinking water or the inadequate treatment and disposal of sewage. In\nthe case of the Missouri outbreak, the source of the infection has\nnot been established so far.\nFurther information can be obtained from the U.S. CDC (Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention) website at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/viral_meningitis.htm>.\nFor the location of Perry County, Missouri, see:\n<http://www.perryvillemo.com>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nViral meningitis - USA (UT) 20050724.2137\n2003\n----\nViral meningitis update 2003 (03) 20031008.2522\nViral meningitis update 2003 (02) 20030915.2335\nViral meningitis update 2003 (01) 20030816.2047\n...........................................cp/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perryville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Girardeau", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perry County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "44557", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Italy (Veneto)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=44557", "date": "2007-07-16 22:00:02", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA (MISSOURI)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 16 Jul 2007\nSource: KFVS 12 Heartland News [edited]\n<http://www.kfvs12.com/global/story.asp?s=6771896>\n\nThere have been 14 confirmed cases of viral meningitis in Perry\nCounty in less than a month. Usually, experts say doctors only report\na couple of cases a year.\nViral meningitis is the less serious form of meningitis. Health\nexperts say it can be spread in a variety of ways: through water,\nthrough saliva, mucus or fecal matter of an infected person. Right\nnow, they have not isolated a common cause among the 14 cases and say\nthey are working on it. In the meantime, they hope you wash your\nhands frequently, don't eat or drink after one another [i.e. don't\nshare food and drink], and avoid swallowing water from pools, creeks\nor lakes.\nA mother in Perryville said her 8-year-old son was one of the 14\ninfected, and she immediately took him to their family doctor when he\nbegan feeling nauseous and started vomiting. \"They did a spinal tap\non him to draw out the spinal fluid and see what kind of meningitis\nhe had, and turns out, he had viral meningitis,\" she said. Her son\nwas treated at a Cape Girardeau hospital and is doing fine now, but\nshe was very worried while he was ill. \"You always think of the worst\nwhen you hear the word meningitis,\" she said. Her son is now back\nhome safe and sound.\nMeanwhile, a spokesperson for the Perry County Memorial Hospital said\npatients have been canceling their appointments for fear of\ncontracting the virus. She said to keep in mind that the virus is not\nairborne, so please do keep your scheduled appointment.\n[Byline: C. J. Cassidy]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Meningitis is an illness in which there is inflammation of the\ntissues that cover the brain and spinal cord. Viral or \"aseptic\"\nmeningitis, which is the most common type, is caused by an infection\nwith one of several types of viruses. In the United States, there are\nbetween 25 000 and 50 000 hospitalizations due to viral meningitis\neach year. The more common symptoms of meningitis are fever, severe\nheadache, stiff neck, bright lights hurting the eyes, drowsiness or\nconfusion, and nausea and vomiting. In babies, the symptoms may\ninclude fever, fretfulness or irritability, difficulty in awakening\nthe baby, or the baby refuses to eat.\nViral meningitis is serious but rarely fatal in persons with normal\nimmune systems. Usually, the symptoms last from 7 to 10 days, and the\npatient recovers completely. Bacterial meningitis, on the other hand,\ncan be very serious and result in disability or death if not treated\npromptly. Often, the symptoms of viral meningitis and bacterial\nmeningitis are the same. For this reason, healthcare specialists\nadvise that whenever there is suspicion of meningitis in a child, a\ndoctor should be consulted without delay.\nMany different viruses can cause meningitis. About 90 percent of\ncases of viral meningitis are caused by enteroviruses, such as\ncoxsackieviruses and echoviruses. But herpesviruses and mumps virus\ncan also cause viral meningitis. There is no specific treatment for\nviral meningitis other than supportive care. Enteroviruses are\ntransmitted by contact predominantly through direct contact with\nrespiratory and other secretions (e.g., saliva, sputum, or nasal\nmucus) of an infected person. The incubation period for enteroviruses\nis usually between 3 and 7 days. Frequent and thorough hand washing\nis the best protection from infection.\nOutbreaks of viral meningitis are frequently indicative of fecal\ncontamination of food products, deficiencies in the supply of clean\ndrinking water or the inadequate treatment and disposal of sewage. In\nthe case of the Missouri outbreak, the source of the infection has\nnot been established so far.\nFurther information can be obtained from the U.S. CDC (Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention) website at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/viral_meningitis.htm>.\nFor the location of Perry County, Missouri, see:\n<http://www.perryvillemo.com>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nViral meningitis - USA (UT) 20050724.2137\n2003\n----\nViral meningitis update 2003 (03) 20031008.2522\nViral meningitis update 2003 (02) 20030915.2335\nViral meningitis update 2003 (01) 20030816.2047\n...........................................cp/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perryville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Girardeau", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perry County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "17807", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - USA (MO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=17807", "date": "2007-07-16 22:00:02", "main_text": "VIRAL MENINGITIS - USA (MISSOURI)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 16 Jul 2007\nSource: KFVS 12 Heartland News [edited]\n<http://www.kfvs12.com/global/story.asp?s=6771896>\n\nThere have been 14 confirmed cases of viral meningitis in Perry\nCounty in less than a month. Usually, experts say doctors only report\na couple of cases a year.\nViral meningitis is the less serious form of meningitis. Health\nexperts say it can be spread in a variety of ways: through water,\nthrough saliva, mucus or fecal matter of an infected person. Right\nnow, they have not isolated a common cause among the 14 cases and say\nthey are working on it. In the meantime, they hope you wash your\nhands frequently, don't eat or drink after one another [i.e. don't\nshare food and drink], and avoid swallowing water from pools, creeks\nor lakes.\nA mother in Perryville said her 8-year-old son was one of the 14\ninfected, and she immediately took him to their family doctor when he\nbegan feeling nauseous and started vomiting. \"They did a spinal tap\non him to draw out the spinal fluid and see what kind of meningitis\nhe had, and turns out, he had viral meningitis,\" she said. Her son\nwas treated at a Cape Girardeau hospital and is doing fine now, but\nshe was very worried while he was ill. \"You always think of the worst\nwhen you hear the word meningitis,\" she said. Her son is now back\nhome safe and sound.\nMeanwhile, a spokesperson for the Perry County Memorial Hospital said\npatients have been canceling their appointments for fear of\ncontracting the virus. She said to keep in mind that the virus is not\nairborne, so please do keep your scheduled appointment.\n[Byline: C. J. Cassidy]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Meningitis is an illness in which there is inflammation of the\ntissues that cover the brain and spinal cord. Viral or \"aseptic\"\nmeningitis, which is the most common type, is caused by an infection\nwith one of several types of viruses. In the United States, there are\nbetween 25 000 and 50 000 hospitalizations due to viral meningitis\neach year. The more common symptoms of meningitis are fever, severe\nheadache, stiff neck, bright lights hurting the eyes, drowsiness or\nconfusion, and nausea and vomiting. In babies, the symptoms may\ninclude fever, fretfulness or irritability, difficulty in awakening\nthe baby, or the baby refuses to eat.\nViral meningitis is serious but rarely fatal in persons with normal\nimmune systems. Usually, the symptoms last from 7 to 10 days, and the\npatient recovers completely. Bacterial meningitis, on the other hand,\ncan be very serious and result in disability or death if not treated\npromptly. Often, the symptoms of viral meningitis and bacterial\nmeningitis are the same. For this reason, healthcare specialists\nadvise that whenever there is suspicion of meningitis in a child, a\ndoctor should be consulted without delay.\nMany different viruses can cause meningitis. About 90 percent of\ncases of viral meningitis are caused by enteroviruses, such as\ncoxsackieviruses and echoviruses. But herpesviruses and mumps virus\ncan also cause viral meningitis. There is no specific treatment for\nviral meningitis other than supportive care. Enteroviruses are\ntransmitted by contact predominantly through direct contact with\nrespiratory and other secretions (e.g., saliva, sputum, or nasal\nmucus) of an infected person. The incubation period for enteroviruses\nis usually between 3 and 7 days. Frequent and thorough hand washing\nis the best protection from infection.\nOutbreaks of viral meningitis are frequently indicative of fecal\ncontamination of food products, deficiencies in the supply of clean\ndrinking water or the inadequate treatment and disposal of sewage. In\nthe case of the Missouri outbreak, the source of the infection has\nnot been established so far.\nFurther information can be obtained from the U.S. CDC (Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention) website at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/viral_meningitis.htm>.\nFor the location of Perry County, Missouri, see:\n<http://www.perryvillemo.com>.\n- Mod.CP]\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nViral meningitis - USA (UT) 20050724.2137\n2003\n----\nViral meningitis update 2003 (03) 20031008.2522\nViral meningitis update 2003 (02) 20030915.2335\nViral meningitis update 2003 (01) 20030816.2047\n...........................................cp/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "mumps", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perryville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Girardeau", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perry County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "17806", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Viral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=17806", "date": "2006-10-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - CHINA (04)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 30 Sep 2006\nFrom: Lynda Bramham <lynda.bramham@masta.org\nSource: BBC Press search: Text of Xinhua report, 24 Sep 2006 [edited]\n\nBeijing has confirmed a new case of \"snail infection\", bringing the\ntotal number of cases to 132. The 31-year-old man saw doctors at\nabout 8 city hospitals before finally being diagnosed with a type of\nangiostrongyliasis at Beijing Friendship Hospital on Friday.\nLike most of the other patients, he ate snails at the Shuguo Yanyi\nRestaurant, which serves Sichuan-style dishes, on 11 Jul and\ndeveloped symptoms of headache and fever on 27 Jul, said a doctor\nsurnamed Yin at the hospital. Yin said the 8 who were hospitalized\nat the Friendship Hospital were recovering well and would all be\ndischarged next week. The hospital is offering checkups every Monday,\nWednesday and Friday morning to ensure the patients' complete recovery.\nThe disease caused by parasites can affect the brain and spinal cord,\nand also lead to meningitis. The Friendship Hospital has diagnosed\n112 cases and admitted 71 patients since 24 Jun. No deaths have been reported.\nThe Amazonian snail culprits have been traced back to southern\nChina's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, according to the\ninvestigation by Beijing Health Bureau. Amazonian snails originated\nin South America and first came to China in the 1980s as a delicacy.\nThe first report of a person falling ill after eating the snails came\nfrom Guangzhou, capital city of the southern province of Guangdong.\nUntil recently, the big black snails were a hot-selling aquatic\nproduct in big Chinese cities like Beijing.\n--\nLynda Bramham\n<lynda.bramham@masta.org\n[In our last report from 26 Aug 2006, 87 people were reported to have\nbeen infected. The number has now increased to 132, and the outbreak\nmay not yet be under control. - Mod.EP]\nSee Also\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - China (03) 20060826.2423\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - China (02) 20060822.2362\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - China: RFI 20060821.2354\n.................. ep/pg/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The 31-year-old man saw doctors at\nabout 8 city hospitals before finally being diagnosed with a type of\nangiostrongyliasis at Beijing Friendship Hospital on Friday.\nLike most of the other patients, he ate snails at the Shuguo Yanyi\nRestaurant, which serves Sichuan-style dishes, on 11 Jul and\ndeveloped symptoms of headache and fever on 27 Jul, said a doctor\nsurnamed Yin at the hospital. Yin said the 8 who were hospitalized\nat the Friendship Hospital were recovering well and would all be\ndischarged next week. The hospital is offering checkups every Monday,\nWednesday and Friday morning to ensure the patients' complete recovery.\nThe disease caused by parasites can affect the brain and spinal cord,\nand also lead to meningitis. The Friendship Hospital has diagnosed\n112 cases and admitted 71 patients since 24 Jun. No deaths have been reported.\nThe Amazonian snail culprits have been traced back to southern\nChina's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, according to the\ninvestigation by Beijing Health Bureau.
