The 31-year-old man saw doctors at\nabout 8 city hospitals before finally being diagnosed with a type of\nangiostrongyliasis at Beijing Friendship Hospital on Friday.\nLike most of the other patients, he ate snails at the Shuguo Yanyi\nRestaurant, which serves Sichuan-style dishes, on 11 Jul and\ndeveloped symptoms of headache and fever on 27 Jul, said a doctor\nsurnamed Yin at the hospital. Yin said the 8 who were hospitalized\nat the Friendship Hospital were recovering well and would all be\ndischarged next week. The hospital is offering checkups every Monday,\nWednesday and Friday morning to ensure the patients' complete recovery.\nThe disease caused by parasites can affect the brain and spinal cord,\nand also lead to meningitis. The Friendship Hospital has diagnosed\n112 cases and admitted 71 patients since 24 Jun. No deaths have been reported.\nThe Amazonian snail culprits have been traced back to southern\nChina's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, according to the\ninvestigation by Beijing Health Bureau. Amazonian snails originated\nin South America and first came to China in the 1980s as a delicacy.\nThe first report of a person falling ill after eating the snails came\nfrom Guangzhou, capital city of the southern province of Guangdong.\nUntil recently, the big black snails were a hot-selling aquatic\nproduct in big Chinese cities like Beijing.\n--\nLynda Bramham\n<lynda.bramham@masta.org\n[In our last report from 26 Aug 2006, 87 people were reported to have\nbeen infected. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-09-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guangzhou", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region", "country": "China"}, {"location": "sichuan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3306", "headline": "PRO> Meningitis, enterovirus - Italy (Piemonte) ex India (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3306", "date": "2006-10-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "ANGIOSTRONGYLUS MENINGITIS - CHINA (04)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat, 30 Sep 2006\nFrom: Lynda Bramham <lynda.bramham@masta.org\nSource: BBC Press search: Text of Xinhua report, 24 Sep 2006 [edited]\n\nBeijing has confirmed a new case of \"snail infection\", bringing the\ntotal number of cases to 132. The 31-year-old man saw doctors at\nabout 8 city hospitals before finally being diagnosed with a type of\nangiostrongyliasis at Beijing Friendship Hospital on Friday.\nLike most of the other patients, he ate snails at the Shuguo Yanyi\nRestaurant, which serves Sichuan-style dishes, on 11 Jul and\ndeveloped symptoms of headache and fever on 27 Jul, said a doctor\nsurnamed Yin at the hospital. Yin said the 8 who were hospitalized\nat the Friendship Hospital were recovering well and would all be\ndischarged next week. The hospital is offering checkups every Monday,\nWednesday and Friday morning to ensure the patients' complete recovery.\nThe disease caused by parasites can affect the brain and spinal cord,\nand also lead to meningitis. The Friendship Hospital has diagnosed\n112 cases and admitted 71 patients since 24 Jun. No deaths have been reported.\nThe Amazonian snail culprits have been traced back to southern\nChina's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, according to the\ninvestigation by Beijing Health Bureau. Amazonian snails originated\nin South America and first came to China in the 1980s as a delicacy.\nThe first report of a person falling ill after eating the snails came\nfrom Guangzhou, capital city of the southern province of Guangdong.\nUntil recently, the big black snails were a hot-selling aquatic\nproduct in big Chinese cities like Beijing.\n--\nLynda Bramham\n<lynda.bramham@masta.org\n[In our last report from 26 Aug 2006, 87 people were reported to have\nbeen infected. The number has now increased to 132, and the outbreak\nmay not yet be under control. - Mod.EP]\nSee Also\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - China (03) 20060826.2423\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - China (02) 20060822.2362\nAngiostrongylus meningitis - China: RFI 20060821.2354\n.................. ep/pg/mpp\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Kosovo National\nHealth Institute in Pristina said 123 new cases of meningitis were\nregistered over the past week, raising the number of people infected with\nthe disease to 553, Belgrade's Beta news agency reported on Wed 30 Aug 2006.\nDrinking water contaminated with waste is the main cause of meningitis\noutbreaks in the predominantly ethnic-Albanian province of Kosovo. Ilir\nBegolli, Director of the Health Institute, said the number of new cases has\nbeen decreasing but not at a satisfactory pace, the agency said. He said\nabout 90 patients stricken with meningitis are in Pristina's clinical center.\nThe epidemic, which is spreading mainly among children, is under control,\nand hospitals in Kosovo are well-equipped with doctors, equipment, and\nmedicine, Begolli said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This outbreak has still to be contained, suggesting that improvements in\nsocial infrastructure and the provision of clean drinking have yet to be\nachieved. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMeningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) 20060830.2471\nMeningitis - Serbia (Kosovo) 20060819.2328\nViral meningitis - Spain (Madrid) 20060801.2128\n2005\n---\nViral meningitis - France (02) 20050911.2692\nViral meningitis - France 20050910.2680\nViral meningitis - USA (UT) 20050724.2137\nViral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) (02) 20050724.2134\nViral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) 20050719.2081\n2003\n---\nViral meningitis update 2003 (03) 20031008.2522\nViral meningitis update 2003 (02) 20030915.2335\nViral meningitis update 2003 (01) 20030816.2047\n..................mpp/cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Kosovo National\nHealth Institute in Pristina said 123 new cases of meningitis were\nregistered over the past week, raising the number of people infected with\nthe disease to 553, Belgrade's Beta news agency reported on Wed 30 Aug 2006.\nDrinking water contaminated with waste is the main cause of meningitis\noutbreaks in the predominantly ethnic-Albanian province of Kosovo. Ilir\nBegolli, Director of the Health Institute, said the number of new cases has\nbeen decreasing but not at a satisfactory pace, the agency said. He said\nabout 90 patients stricken with meningitis are in Pristina's clinical center.\nThe epidemic, which is spreading mainly among children, is under control,\nand hospitals in Kosovo are well-equipped with doctors, equipment, and\nmedicine, Begolli said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This outbreak has still to be contained, suggesting that improvements in\nsocial infrastructure and the provision of clean drinking have yet to be\nachieved. - Mod.CP]\nSee Also\nMeningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) 20060830.2471\nMeningitis - Serbia (Kosovo) 20060819.2328\nViral meningitis - Spain (Madrid) 20060801.2128\n2005\n---\nViral meningitis - France (02) 20050911.2692\nViral meningitis - France 20050910.2680\nViral meningitis - USA (UT) 20050724.2137\nViral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) (02) 20050724.2134\nViral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) 20050719.2081\n2003\n---\nViral meningitis update 2003 (03) 20031008.2522\nViral meningitis update 2003 (02) 20030915.2335\nViral meningitis update 2003 (01) 20030816.2047\n..................mpp/cp/msp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. edited]\n<http://www.interfax.ru/r/B/ural/289.html?menu=3&id_issue=11405404>\n\nAccording to the Sverdlovsk Regional Office of the Russian\n(Health) Protection Agency (Rospotrebnadzor], the number of\npeople in the Sverdlovsk region suffering from serous\n[viral?] meningitis at the present time has reached 48.\nResidents of Sverdlovsk have been admitted to hospital\nsuffering from viral meningitis over a period of 6 weeks.\nThe cause of the outbreak is [consumption of] unboiled\nwater.\nEpidemiologists have carried out an analysis of materials\nfrom Sverdlovsk and have discovered that those who have\nfallen ill have used unboiled water obtained from water\npipes from an [artesian] well. The cause of the outbreak has\nnot been made public yet.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Sverdlovsk region is located between the Central and\nNorthern Urals adjoining the Siberian plain. The total area\nis 194 000 square kilometers, and the population is 4.4\nmillion. Sverdlovsk is a city of 34 700 thousand\ninhabitants. - ProMED-mail Russian correspondents.\nSerous (or aseptic) meningitis is a term commonly used to\ndescribe non-bacterial (viral) meningitis. Serous meningitis\nis usually indicative of enteroviral infection, and the term\nviral meningitis is now the norm. However, in the absence of\nconfirmation of viral infection, the direct Russian\ntranslation is retained. Further information is awaited. -\nMod.CP]\nSee Also\nViral meningitis - France (02)20050911.2692\nViral meningitis - France 20050910.2680\nViral meningitis - USA (UT) 20050724.2137\nViral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) (02) 20050724.2134\nViral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) 20050719.2081\n2003\n---\nViral meningitis update 2003 (03) 20031008.2522\nViral meningitis update 2003 (02) 20030915.2335\nViral meningitis update 2003 (01) 20030816.2047\n.......................np/cp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The cause of the outbreak has\nnot been made public yet.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Sverdlovsk region is located between the Central and\nNorthern Urals adjoining the Siberian plain. The total area\nis 194 000 square kilometers, and the population is 4.4\nmillion. Sverdlovsk is a city of 34 700 thousand\ninhabitants. - ProMED-mail Russian correspondents.\nSerous (or aseptic) meningitis is a term commonly used to\ndescribe non-bacterial (viral) meningitis. The cause of the outbreak has\nnot been made public yet.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Sverdlovsk region is located between the Central and\nNorthern Urals adjoining the Siberian plain. The total area\nis 194 000 square kilometers, and the population is 4.4\nmillion. Sverdlovsk is a city of 34 700 thousand\ninhabitants. - ProMED-mail Russian correspondents.\nSerous (or aseptic) meningitis is a term commonly used to\ndescribe non-bacterial (viral) meningitis. Serous meningitis\nis usually indicative of enteroviral infection, and the term\nviral meningitis is now the norm. However, in the absence of\nconfirmation of viral infection, the direct Russian\ntranslation is retained. Further information is awaited. -\nMod.CP]\nSee Also\nViral meningitis - France (02)20050911.2692\nViral meningitis - France 20050910.2680\nViral meningitis - USA (UT) 20050724.2137\nViral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) (02) 20050724.2134\nViral meningitis - Russia (Khabarovsk) 20050719.2081\n2003\n---\nViral meningitis update 2003 (03) 20031008.2522\nViral meningitis update 2003 (02) 20030915.2335\nViral meningitis update 2003 (01) 20030816.2047\n.......................np/cp/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The conjugated vaccines are\nall effective in infants, children, and adults, with immunization starting\nat 2 months of age:\n_Streptococcus pneumoniae_: polysaccharides of 7 serotypes conjugated to\nCRM197 protein (Prevnar);\n_Haemophilus influenzae_ type b: PRP polysaccharide conjugated to either\ntetanus toxoid, CRM 197, diphtheria toxoid, or meningococcal outermembrane\nprotein;\nSerogroup C _Neisseria meningococcus_: serogroup C polysaccharide\nconjugated to tetanus toxoid or CRM197 protein. [This conjugated vaccine is\nnot available in the USA. - Mod.LL]\nPolysaccharide vaccines exist against pneumonoccus (23 serotypes) and\nmeningococcus (either bivalent A/C or tetravalent A/C/Y/W135).\nAlthough group A meningococcal vaccines are effective in infants starting\nat 2 months of age, the other polysaccharide vaccines are not sufficiently\nimmunogenic in infants less than 2 years of age.\nMost recent outbreaks of meningococcal disease in Western Europe have been\nassociated with serogroup C meningococcus.\n--\nRonald Gold, MD, MPH\nProfessor Emeritus of Pediatrics\nThe Hospital for Sick Children\nToronto, Ontario\n<ronald.gold@sympatico.ca>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Gold for his comments on the different types of vaccines\navailable for the major etiologies of bacterial meningitis. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nMeningitis - Russia (Mariy El): RFI 20031112.2807\nMeningitis, meningococcal type A - Russia (Moscow) 20031029.2696\n.............................ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Georgia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "GEORGIA", "country": "Georgia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204284", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, viral - USA (Georgia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204284", "date": "2002-06-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, VIRAL - PANAMA (CHIRIQUI)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 27 Jun 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Agencia EFE via COMTEX 26 Jun 2002 21:54 EST [edited]\n\nPanama declares meningitis epidemic along border with Costa Rica\n----------------------------------------------------\nPanamanian health authorities on Wednesday declared an epidemic of viral\nmeningitis in the province of Chiriqui, on the border with Costa Rica, where\n186 cases have been reported in the past 3 weeks. General health director\nEsteban Morales, flanked by epidemiologists, said that 237 cases of viral\nmeningitis had been recorded throughout the country in children under 15\nyears old.\nMorales told a news conference at a Panama City hospital that the Health\nMinistry was aware of only one case of bacterial meningitis. Health\nauthorities explained that viral meningitis is benign, while bacterial\nmeningitis is fatal in 15 percent of the cases, and results in lingering\nproblems in the brains of 40 percent of the patients. Most of the 20 or so\nchildren who are currently in hospital with viral meningitis are between one\nand 6 years old, Morales said.\nHe added that schools in the province of Chiriqui would remain closed to\navoid contagion, since there is no vaccine against the disease and the only\nway to prevent it is by practicing thorough personal hygiene.\nMorales said that viral meningitis is caused by an enterovirus that lodges\nin the intestinal wall, and he added that it spreads through oral contagion\nand poor hygienic practices. He described meningitis as an infection or\nswelling of the membrane that covers the brain and the spinal cord. Symptoms\nusually include severe headaches, vomiting, and neck pain and stiffness. A\nhealth official said that bacterial meningitis must be immediately treated\nwith specific antibiotics, but that there is no specific treatment for viral\nmeningitis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Viral meningitis is usually associated with enterovirus infection, in\nparticular, coxsackieviruses (A and B types) and some echoviruses. More\ninformation on this outbreak from official sources, including the type of\nvirus responsible, would be appreciated. - Mods.CP/MPP]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, viral - USA (Texas) 20020605.4410\nMeningitis, echoviruses 13 & 30 - Europe 20020214.3563\n2001\n----\nMeningitis, echovirus 13 - USA 20010914.2219\nMeningitis, echovirus 30 - Singapore: 1997-2001 20010918.2257\nMeningitis, echoviruses 13 & 30 - Australia (West.) 20010917.2247\nMeningitis, echoviruses 9, 13 & 30 - Australia (NSW) 20010926.2351\nMeningitis, viral - Bulgaria 20010728.1478\nMeningitis, viral - Germany 20010913.2212\n1999\n----\nMeningitis, viral - Hungary ex Romania? 19990819.1433\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (NE), Moldova: Correction 19990822.1466\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast) (02) 19990902.1542\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast), Moldova 19990819.1432\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast): ECHO 19990830.1514\n1996\n-----\nWest Nile virus meningitis - Romania 19960926.1628\nWest Nile virus meningitis - Romania (4) 19961015.1738\n.............................mpp/jw/cp/mpp/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["west nile virus", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2002-06-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chiriqui", "country": "Panama"}, {"location": "hungary", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Costa Rica", "country": "Costa Rica"}, {"location": "Panama City", "country": "Panama"}, {"location": "Panama", "country": "Panama"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204034", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, viral - USA (Idaho)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204034", "date": "2002-06-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, VIRAL - PANAMA (CHIRIQUI)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 27 Jun 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Agencia EFE via COMTEX 26 Jun 2002 21:54 EST [edited]\n\nPanama declares meningitis epidemic along border with Costa Rica\n----------------------------------------------------\nPanamanian health authorities on Wednesday declared an epidemic of viral\nmeningitis in the province of Chiriqui, on the border with Costa Rica, where\n186 cases have been reported in the past 3 weeks. General health director\nEsteban Morales, flanked by epidemiologists, said that 237 cases of viral\nmeningitis had been recorded throughout the country in children under 15\nyears old.\nMorales told a news conference at a Panama City hospital that the Health\nMinistry was aware of only one case of bacterial meningitis. Health\nauthorities explained that viral meningitis is benign, while bacterial\nmeningitis is fatal in 15 percent of the cases, and results in lingering\nproblems in the brains of 40 percent of the patients. Most of the 20 or so\nchildren who are currently in hospital with viral meningitis are between one\nand 6 years old, Morales said.\nHe added that schools in the province of Chiriqui would remain closed to\navoid contagion, since there is no vaccine against the disease and the only\nway to prevent it is by practicing thorough personal hygiene.\nMorales said that viral meningitis is caused by an enterovirus that lodges\nin the intestinal wall, and he added that it spreads through oral contagion\nand poor hygienic practices. He described meningitis as an infection or\nswelling of the membrane that covers the brain and the spinal cord. Symptoms\nusually include severe headaches, vomiting, and neck pain and stiffness. A\nhealth official said that bacterial meningitis must be immediately treated\nwith specific antibiotics, but that there is no specific treatment for viral\nmeningitis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Viral meningitis is usually associated with enterovirus infection, in\nparticular, coxsackieviruses (A and B types) and some echoviruses. More\ninformation on this outbreak from official sources, including the type of\nvirus responsible, would be appreciated. - Mods.CP/MPP]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, viral - USA (Texas) 20020605.4410\nMeningitis, echoviruses 13 & 30 - Europe 20020214.3563\n2001\n----\nMeningitis, echovirus 13 - USA 20010914.2219\nMeningitis, echovirus 30 - Singapore: 1997-2001 20010918.2257\nMeningitis, echoviruses 13 & 30 - Australia (West.) 20010917.2247\nMeningitis, echoviruses 9, 13 & 30 - Australia (NSW) 20010926.2351\nMeningitis, viral - Bulgaria 20010728.1478\nMeningitis, viral - Germany 20010913.2212\n1999\n----\nMeningitis, viral - Hungary ex Romania? 19990819.1433\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (NE), Moldova: Correction 19990822.1466\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast) (02) 19990902.1542\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast), Moldova 19990819.1432\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast): ECHO 19990830.1514\n1996\n-----\nWest Nile virus meningitis - Romania 19960926.1628\nWest Nile virus meningitis - Romania (4) 19961015.1738\n.............................mpp/jw/cp/mpp/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. General health director\nEsteban Morales, flanked by epidemiologists, said that 237 cases of viral\nmeningitis had been recorded throughout the country in children under 15\nyears old.\nMorales told a news conference at a Panama City hospital that the Health\nMinistry was aware of only one case of bacterial meningitis. Health\nauthorities explained that viral meningitis is benign, while bacterial\nmeningitis is fatal in 15 percent of the cases, and results in lingering\nproblems in the brains of 40 percent of the patients. Most of the 20 or so\nchildren who are currently in hospital with viral meningitis are between one\nand 6 years old, Morales said.\nHe added that schools in the province of Chiriqui would remain closed to\navoid contagion, since there is no vaccine against the disease and the only\nway to prevent it is by practicing thorough personal hygiene.\nMorales said that viral meningitis is caused by an enterovirus that lodges\nin the intestinal wall, and he added that it spreads through oral contagion\nand poor hygienic practices. He described meningitis as an infection or\nswelling of the membrane that covers the brain and the spinal cord. Symptoms\nusually include severe headaches, vomiting, and neck pain and stiffness. A\nhealth official said that bacterial meningitis must be immediately treated\nwith specific antibiotics, but that there is no specific treatment for viral\nmeningitis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Viral meningitis is usually associated with enterovirus infection, in\nparticular, coxsackieviruses (A and B types) and some echoviruses. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["west nile virus", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2002-06-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chiriqui", "country": "Panama"}, {"location": "hungary", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "Romania", "country": "Romania"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Costa Rica", "country": "Costa Rica"}, {"location": "Panama City", "country": "Panama"}, {"location": "Panama", "country": "Panama"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202631", "headline": "PRO> Fungal meningitis, contaminated drug - USA: alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202631", "date": "2002-06-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, VIRAL - PANAMA (CHIRIQUI)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 27 Jun 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Agencia EFE via COMTEX 26 Jun 2002 21:54 EST [edited]\n\nPanama declares meningitis epidemic along border with Costa Rica\n----------------------------------------------------\nPanamanian health authorities on Wednesday declared an epidemic of viral\nmeningitis in the province of Chiriqui, on the border with Costa Rica, where\n186 cases have been reported in the past 3 weeks. General health director\nEsteban Morales, flanked by epidemiologists, said that 237 cases of viral\nmeningitis had been recorded throughout the country in children under 15\nyears old.\nMorales told a news conference at a Panama City hospital that the Health\nMinistry was aware of only one case of bacterial meningitis. Health\nauthorities explained that viral meningitis is benign, while bacterial\nmeningitis is fatal in 15 percent of the cases, and results in lingering\nproblems in the brains of 40 percent of the patients. Most of the 20 or so\nchildren who are currently in hospital with viral meningitis are between one\nand 6 years old, Morales said.\nHe added that schools in the province of Chiriqui would remain closed to\navoid contagion, since there is no vaccine against the disease and the only\nway to prevent it is by practicing thorough personal hygiene.\nMorales said that viral meningitis is caused by an enterovirus that lodges\nin the intestinal wall, and he added that it spreads through oral contagion\nand poor hygienic practices. He described meningitis as an infection or\nswelling of the membrane that covers the brain and the spinal cord. Symptoms\nusually include severe headaches, vomiting, and neck pain and stiffness. A\nhealth official said that bacterial meningitis must be immediately treated\nwith specific antibiotics, but that there is no specific treatment for viral\nmeningitis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Viral meningitis is usually associated with enterovirus infection, in\nparticular, coxsackieviruses (A and B types) and some echoviruses. More\ninformation on this outbreak from official sources, including the type of\nvirus responsible, would be appreciated. - Mods.CP/MPP]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, viral - USA (Texas) 20020605.4410\nMeningitis, echoviruses 13 & 30 - Europe 20020214.3563\n2001\n----\nMeningitis, echovirus 13 - USA 20010914.2219\nMeningitis, echovirus 30 - Singapore: 1997-2001 20010918.2257\nMeningitis, echoviruses 13 & 30 - Australia (West.) 20010917.2247\nMeningitis, echoviruses 9, 13 & 30 - Australia (NSW) 20010926.2351\nMeningitis, viral - Bulgaria 20010728.1478\nMeningitis, viral - Germany 20010913.2212\n1999\n----\nMeningitis, viral - Hungary ex Romania? 19990819.1433\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (NE), Moldova: Correction 19990822.1466\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast) (02) 19990902.1542\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast), Moldova 19990819.1432\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast): ECHO 19990830.1514\n1996\n-----\nWest Nile virus meningitis - Romania 19960926.1628\nWest Nile virus meningitis - Romania (4) 19961015.1738\n.............................mpp/jw/cp/mpp/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. General health director\nEsteban Morales, flanked by epidemiologists, said that 237 cases of viral\nmeningitis had been recorded throughout the country in children under 15\nyears old.\nMorales told a news conference at a Panama City hospital that the Health\nMinistry was aware of only one case of bacterial meningitis. Health\nauthorities explained that viral meningitis is benign, while bacterial\nmeningitis is fatal in 15 percent of the cases, and results in lingering\nproblems in the brains of 40 percent of the patients. Most of the 20 or so\nchildren who are currently in hospital with viral meningitis are between one\nand 6 years old, Morales said.\nHe added that schools in the province of Chiriqui would remain closed to\navoid contagion, since there is no vaccine against the disease and the only\nway to prevent it is by practicing thorough personal hygiene.\nMorales said that viral meningitis is caused by an enterovirus that lodges\nin the intestinal wall, and he added that it spreads through oral contagion\nand poor hygienic practices. He described meningitis as an infection or\nswelling of the membrane that covers the brain and the spinal cord. Symptoms\nusually include severe headaches, vomiting, and neck pain and stiffness. A\nhealth official said that bacterial meningitis must be immediately treated\nwith specific antibiotics, but that there is no specific treatment for viral\nmeningitis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Viral meningitis is usually associated with enterovirus infection, in\nparticular, coxsackieviruses (A and B types) and some echoviruses. More\ninformation on this outbreak from official sources, including the type of\nvirus responsible, would be appreciated. - Mods.CP/MPP]\nSee Also\nMeningitis, viral - USA (Texas) 20020605.4410\nMeningitis, echoviruses 13 & 30 - Europe 20020214.3563\n2001\n----\nMeningitis, echovirus 13 - USA 20010914.2219\nMeningitis, echovirus 30 - Singapore: 1997-2001 20010918.2257\nMeningitis, echoviruses 13 & 30 - Australia (West.) 20010917.2247\nMeningitis, echoviruses 9, 13 & 30 - Australia (NSW) 20010926.2351\nMeningitis, viral - Bulgaria 20010728.1478\nMeningitis, viral - Germany 20010913.2212\n1999\n----\nMeningitis, viral - Hungary ex Romania? 19990819.1433\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (NE), Moldova: Correction 19990822.1466\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast) (02) 19990902.1542\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast), Moldova 19990819.1432\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast): ECHO 19990830.1514\n1996\n-----\nWest Nile virus meningitis - Romania 19960926.1628\nWest Nile virus meningitis - Romania (4) 19961015.1738\n.............................mpp/jw/cp/mpp/pg/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. 19990819.1433\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (NE), Moldova: Correction 19990822.1466\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast) (02) 19990902.1542\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast), Moldova 19990819.1432\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast): ECHO 19990830.1514\n1996\n----\nMeningitis, viral - Cyprus 19960731.1357\nMeningitis, viral - Cyprus (4) 19960823.1466\nMeningitis, viral - Romania 19960903.1504\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (7) 19960929.1644\nDate: Mon 17 Sep 2001 13:53:40 +0800\nFrom: Peter McMinn <peterm@ichr.uwa.edu.au> [edited\n\nEchoviruses 13 & 30 in Relation to Aseptic Meningitis in Western Australia\n-------------------------------------------\nI note with interest the posting on the recent increase in prevalence of\nechovirus 13 in the USA [see: Meningitis, echovirus 13 - USA\n20010914.2219. Similarly to the USA, echovirus 13 had been a rare sporadic\nenterovirus isolate in Australia prior to 2001, when we began to identify\nit in a high proportion of healthy preschool-aged children and in children\nadmitted to hospital with aseptic meningitis in Western Australia.\nWe have identified echovirus 13 in a large proportion of healthy children\nparticipating in a community enterovirus surveillance project undertaken\nbetween March and July 2001 in Western Australia and in a small proportion\nof cases of aseptic meningitis admitted to our hospital over the same time\nperiod. Of 150 healthy children enrolled in the surveillance project, 15\n(10%) yielded an enterovirus isolate from a throat swab. Echovirus 13 was\nthe commonest isolate (7 isolates; 46%) identified in the healthy children.\nA large seasonal outbreak of aseptic meningitis occurred concurrently with\nthe surveillance project, with approximately 60 children meeting the case\ndefinition of aseptic meningitis admitted to our hospital. Echovirus 30 was\nthe predominant serotype isolated from the CSF or throat swabs (12 of 21\nisolates; 57%) of cases of aseptic meningitis, although 4 cases (19%) were\nidentified as due to echovirus 13. Neither echovirus 30 nor echovirus 13\nhad been identified from cases of aseptic meningitis in Western Australia\nin the 4 years preceding the 2001 season.\n--\nDr Peter McMinn\nClinical Virologist\nPrincess Margaret Hospital for Children\nPerth WA Australia\n<peterm@ichr.uwa.edu.au>\n--\n[These data from Peter McMinn complement those obtained in Europe and the\nUSA. ProMED-mail would welcome reports from elsewhere in the world\nregarding the prevalence of echoviruses 13 and 30 in relation to aseptic\nmeningitis at the present time. - Mod.CP\n................cp/pg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Similarly to the USA, echovirus 13 had been a rare sporadic\nenterovirus isolate in Australia prior to 2001, when we began to identify\nit in a high proportion of healthy preschool-aged children and in children\nadmitted to hospital with aseptic meningitis in Western Australia.\nWe have identified echovirus 13 in a large proportion of healthy children\nparticipating in a community enterovirus surveillance project undertaken\nbetween March and July 2001 in Western Australia and in a small proportion\nof cases of aseptic meningitis admitted to our hospital over the same time\nperiod. Echovirus 13 was\nthe commonest isolate (7 isolates; 46%) identified in the healthy children.\nA large seasonal outbreak of aseptic meningitis occurred concurrently with\nthe surveillance project, with approximately 60 children meeting the case\ndefinition of aseptic meningitis admitted to our hospital. Echovirus 30 was\nthe predominant serotype isolated from the CSF or throat swabs (12 of 21\nisolates; 57%) of cases of aseptic meningitis, although 4 cases (19%) were\nidentified as due to echovirus 13. Neither echovirus 30 nor echovirus 13\nhad been identified from cases of aseptic meningitis in Western Australia\nin the 4 years preceding the 2001 season.\n--\nDr Peter McMinn\nClinical Virologist\nPrincess Margaret Hospital for Children\nPerth WA Australia\n<peterm@ichr.uwa.edu.au>\n--\n[These data from Peter McMinn complement those obtained in Europe and the\nUSA. ProMED-mail would welcome reports from elsewhere in the world\nregarding the prevalence of echoviruses 13 and 30 in relation to aseptic\nmeningitis at the present time. - Mod.CP\n................cp/pg/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. 19990819.1433\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (NE), Moldova: Correction 19990822.1466\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast) (02) 19990902.1542\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast), Moldova 19990819.1432\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (northeast): ECHO 19990830.1514\n1996\n----\nMeningitis, viral - Cyprus 19960731.1357\nMeningitis, viral - Cyprus (4) 19960823.1466\nMeningitis, viral - Romania 19960903.1504\nMeningitis, viral - Romania (7) 19960929.1644\nDate: Mon 17 Sep 2001 13:53:40 +0800\nFrom: Peter McMinn <peterm@ichr.uwa.edu.au> [edited\n\nEchoviruses 13 & 30 in Relation to Aseptic Meningitis in Western Australia\n-------------------------------------------\nI note with interest the posting on the recent increase in prevalence of\nechovirus 13 in the USA [see: Meningitis, echovirus 13 - USA\n20010914.2219. Similarly to the USA, echovirus 13 had been a rare sporadic\nenterovirus isolate in Australia prior to 2001, when we began to identify\nit in a high proportion of healthy preschool-aged children and in children\nadmitted to hospital with aseptic meningitis in Western Australia.\nWe have identified echovirus 13 in a large proportion of healthy children\nparticipating in a community enterovirus surveillance project undertaken\nbetween March and July 2001 in Western Australia and in a small proportion\nof cases of aseptic meningitis admitted to our hospital over the same time\nperiod. Of 150 healthy children enrolled in the surveillance project, 15\n(10%) yielded an enterovirus isolate from a throat swab. Echovirus 13 was\nthe commonest isolate (7 isolates; 46%) identified in the healthy children.\nA large seasonal outbreak of aseptic meningitis occurred concurrently with\nthe surveillance project, with approximately 60 children meeting the case\ndefinition of aseptic meningitis admitted to our hospital. Echovirus 30 was\nthe predominant serotype isolated from the CSF or throat swabs (12 of 21\nisolates; 57%) of cases of aseptic meningitis, although 4 cases (19%) were\nidentified as due to echovirus 13. Neither echovirus 30 nor echovirus 13\nhad been identified from cases of aseptic meningitis in Western Australia\nin the 4 years preceding the 2001 season.\n--\nDr Peter McMinn\nClinical Virologist\nPrincess Margaret Hospital for Children\nPerth WA Australia\n<peterm@ichr.uwa.edu.au>\n--\n[These data from Peter McMinn complement those obtained in Europe and the\nUSA. Cosgriff <mcosgriff@hotmail.com>\nSource: Panafrican News Agency, 13 Dec 2000 [edited\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200012130391.html>\n\nMeningitis Kills 70 People In Huambo\n------------------------------------\nMeningitis has killed at least 70 people in Angola's central Huambo\nprovince, since January, a health official said. Ribeiro Isaias, Head of\nthe hygiene and epidemiology section of the province's Health Services,\nsaid the main victims were people under age 45. He disclosed that over the\nsame period, several medical centres in the province treated 376 cases of\nthe epidemic. According to Isaias, the Caala municipality, some 23 km from\nHuambo, the province's chief town, is the worst affected, recording about\n75 percent of the afflictions. He said a total of 834 people also died at\nthe Huambo hospital over the same period from various diseases, including\nmalaria, acute diarrhoea and respiratory complications.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Angola is outside the \"meningitis belt\" of sub-Saharan Africa. Further\ninformation about the laboratory characterization of the etiologic agent of\nthis outbreak would be helpful.\nAccording to the GIDEON database, prior to 1986 fewer than 150 cases of\nmeningococcal disease were reported annually, except in 1977 when 1151\ncases were reported. 173 cases were reported in 1986; 321 in 1987; 318 in\n1988; 658 in 1989; 823 in 1990; 1106 in 1991; 1440 in 1992; 2260 in 1993;\n3310 in 1994 (from Cuene, Huila and Lunda Sud Provinces); 1007 in 1995\n(from 7 provinces).\nAn epidemic originated in Moxico (26 cases) in July 1996, and spread to\nCuanza Norte (at least 10 cases per day with 90% case-fatality rate), and\nLunda Norte.\n1266 cases (129 fatal) of group A meningococcal meningitis were reported\nduring in 1998 - most in Bie, Malange, Lunda Norte and Huambo Provinces.\nDuring August to September 1999, an outbreak of meningococcal disease (253\ncases, 147 fatal) was reported in Yambala. - Mod.ES\n......................................ds/jw/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Further\ninformation about the laboratory characterization of the etiologic agent of\nthis outbreak would be helpful.\nAccording to the GIDEON database, prior to 1986 fewer than 150 cases of\nmeningococcal disease were reported annually, except in 1977 when 1151\ncases were reported. 173 cases were reported in 1986; 321 in 1987; 318 in\n1988; 658 in 1989; 823 in 1990; 1106 in 1991; 1440 in 1992; 2260 in 1993;\n3310 in 1994 (from Cuene, Huila and Lunda Sud Provinces); 1007 in 1995\n(from 7 provinces).\nAn epidemic originated in Moxico (26 cases) in July 1996, and spread to\nCuanza Norte (at least 10 cases per day with 90% case-fatality rate), and\nLunda Norte.\n1266 cases (129 fatal) of group A meningococcal meningitis were reported\nduring in 1998 - most in Bie, Malange, Lunda Norte and Huambo Provinces.\nDuring August to September 1999, an outbreak of meningococcal disease (253\ncases, 147 fatal) was reported in Yambala. - Mod.ES\n......................................ds/jw/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Cosgriff <mcosgriff@hotmail.com>\nSource: Panafrican News Agency, 13 Dec 2000 [edited\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200012130391.html>\n\nMeningitis Kills 70 People In Huambo\n------------------------------------\nMeningitis has killed at least 70 people in Angola's central Huambo\nprovince, since January, a health official said. Ribeiro Isaias, Head of\nthe hygiene and epidemiology section of the province's Health Services,\nsaid the main victims were people under age 45. He disclosed that over the\nsame period, several medical centres in the province treated 376 cases of\nthe epidemic. According to Isaias, the Caala municipality, some 23 km from\nHuambo, the province's chief town, is the worst affected, recording about\n75 percent of the afflictions. He said a total of 834 people also died at\nthe Huambo hospital over the same period from various diseases, including\nmalaria, acute diarrhoea and respiratory complications.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Angola is outside the \"meningitis belt\" of sub-Saharan Africa. Further\ninformation about the laboratory characterization of the etiologic agent of\nthis outbreak would be helpful.\nAccording to the GIDEON database, prior to 1986 fewer than 150 cases of\nmeningococcal disease were reported annually, except in 1977 when 1151\ncases were reported. 173 cases were reported in 1986; 321 in 1987; 318 in\n1988; 658 in 1989; 823 in 1990; 1106 in 1991; 1440 in 1992; 2260 in 1993;\n3310 in 1994 (from Cuene, Huila and Lunda Sud Provinces); 1007 in 1995\n(from 7 provinces).\nAn epidemic originated in Moxico (26 cases) in July 1996, and spread to\nCuanza Norte (at least 10 cases per day with 90% case-fatality rate), and\nLunda Norte.\n1266 cases (129 fatal) of group A meningococcal meningitis were reported\nduring in 1998 - most in Bie, Malange, Lunda Norte and Huambo Provinces.\nDuring August to September 1999, an outbreak of meningococcal disease (253\ncases, 147 fatal) was reported in Yambala. - Mod.ES\n......................................ds/jw/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. He disclosed that over the\nsame period, several medical centres in the province treated 376 cases of\nthe epidemic. According to Isaias, the Caala municipality, some 23 km from\nHuambo, the province's chief town, is the worst affected, recording about\n75 percent of the afflictions. He said a total of 834 people also died at\nthe Huambo hospital over the same period from various diseases, including\nmalaria, acute diarrhoea and respiratory complications.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Angola is outside the \"meningitis belt\" of sub-Saharan Africa. Further\ninformation about the laboratory characterization of the etiologic agent of\nthis outbreak would be helpful.\nAccording to the GIDEON database, prior to 1986 fewer than 150 cases of\nmeningococcal disease were reported annually, except in 1977 when 1151\ncases were reported. 173 cases were reported in 1986; 321 in 1987; 318 in\n1988; 658 in 1989; 823 in 1990; 1106 in 1991; 1440 in 1992; 2260 in 1993;\n3310 in 1994 (from Cuene, Huila and Lunda Sud Provinces); 1007 in 1995\n(from 7 provinces).\nAn epidemic originated in Moxico (26 cases) in July 1996, and spread to\nCuanza Norte (at least 10 cases per day with 90% case-fatality rate), and\nLunda Norte.\n1266 cases (129 fatal) of group A meningococcal meningitis were reported\nduring in 1998 - most in Bie, Malange, Lunda Norte and Huambo Provinces.\nDuring August to September 1999, an outbreak of meningococcal disease (253\ncases, 147 fatal) was reported in Yambala. - Mod.ES\n......................................ds/jw/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The local epidemiologists have yet to determine what has caused\nthe mass-scale spread of infection. It is believed that one of the main\ncauses is poor drinking water. Doctors have warned the population that\nchildren should be prevented from bathing in ponds, lakes and flooded\nquarries in which bacteria proliferate in this summer's uncommonly hot\nweather. Quarantine has been imposed on countryside recreation camps.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In view of the enteroviral activity in the Khabarovsk and Primorsk Regions\nreported earlier (see above), it is probable that this outbreak in\nKomsomolsk-na-Amure has been confirmed as aseptic (enteroviral) meningitis.\nIn view of the suspicion that the epidemic is due to a water-borne\npathogen, the restriction on bathing outdoors as a containment measure is\nsensible. The reference to increased bacterial proliferation, however,\nsuggests some uncertainty in the diagnosis.\nAseptic meningitis in children is the most common manifestation of\nenteroviral infection. Although the onset of illness is dramatic and\nsudden, virtually all children recover without significant morbidity.\nChildren under one year may be at greater risk of neurological sequelae. In\ntemperate climates aseptic meningitis is commonest in summer and autumn.\nThe outbreaks in the Russian Far East fit the expected pattern,\nparticularly the association with summer holiday camps. Many different\nenteroviruses can be responsible for outbreaks of aseptic meningitis and it\ncannot be assumed that the same agent is responsible for separate outbreaks\neven in the same locality. Likewise previous exposure to infection does not\nprovide immunity to reinfection. - Mod.CP\n.......................................jw/cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The local epidemiologists have yet to determine what has caused\nthe mass-scale spread of infection. It is believed that one of the main\ncauses is poor drinking water. Doctors have warned the population that\nchildren should be prevented from bathing in ponds, lakes and flooded\nquarries in which bacteria proliferate in this summer's uncommonly hot\nweather. Quarantine has been imposed on countryside recreation camps.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In view of the enteroviral activity in the Khabarovsk and Primorsk Regions\nreported earlier (see above), it is probable that this outbreak in\nKomsomolsk-na-Amure has been confirmed as aseptic (enteroviral) meningitis.\nIn view of the suspicion that the epidemic is due to a water-borne\npathogen, the restriction on bathing outdoors as a containment measure is\nsensible. The reference to increased bacterial proliferation, however,\nsuggests some uncertainty in the diagnosis.\nAseptic meningitis in children is the most common manifestation of\nenteroviral infection. Although the onset of illness is dramatic and\nsudden, virtually all children recover without significant morbidity.\nChildren under one year may be at greater risk of neurological sequelae. In\ntemperate climates aseptic meningitis is commonest in summer and autumn.\nThe outbreaks in the Russian Far East fit the expected pattern,\nparticularly the association with summer holiday camps. Many different\nenteroviruses can be responsible for outbreaks of aseptic meningitis and it\ncannot be assumed that the same agent is responsible for separate outbreaks\neven in the same locality. Likewise previous exposure to infection does not\nprovide immunity to reinfection. - Mod.CP\n.......................................jw/cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The local epidemiologists have yet to determine what has caused\nthe mass-scale spread of infection. It is believed that one of the main\ncauses is poor drinking water. Doctors have warned the population that\nchildren should be prevented from bathing in ponds, lakes and flooded\nquarries in which bacteria proliferate in this summer's uncommonly hot\nweather. Quarantine has been imposed on countryside recreation camps.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In view of the enteroviral activity in the Khabarovsk and Primorsk Regions\nreported earlier (see above), it is probable that this outbreak in\nKomsomolsk-na-Amure has been confirmed as aseptic (enteroviral) meningitis.\nIn view of the suspicion that the epidemic is due to a water-borne\npathogen, the restriction on bathing outdoors as a containment measure is\nsensible. The reference to increased bacterial proliferation, however,\nsuggests some uncertainty in the diagnosis.\nAseptic meningitis in children is the most common manifestation of\nenteroviral infection. Although the onset of illness is dramatic and\nsudden, virtually all children recover without significant morbidity.\nChildren under one year may be at greater risk of neurological sequelae. In\ntemperate climates aseptic meningitis is commonest in summer and autumn.\nThe outbreaks in the Russian Far East fit the expected pattern,\nparticularly the association with summer holiday camps. Many different\nenteroviruses can be responsible for outbreaks of aseptic meningitis and it\ncannot be assumed that the same agent is responsible for separate outbreaks\neven in the same locality. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Primorsk Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Khabarovsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2198240", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Enteroviral meningitis - Russia (Primorsk Region) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198240", "date": "2000-07-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "ENTEROVIRAL MENINGITIS - RUSSIA (PRIMORSK REGION) (02)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nSee Also\nEnteroviral meningitis - Russia (Primorsk Region) 2000.2862\nDate: 13 Jul 2000\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ITAR-TASS news agency, Moscow, in English 0603 GMT 11 Jul 2000 [edited\n\nMeningitis outbreak widens in Russian Far East\n------------------------------------------------\nKOMSOMOLSK-NA-AMURE: 126 children have been hospitalized in\nKomsomolsk-na-Amure, 78 of them have been diagnosed with [aseptic?\nmeningitis. The local epidemiologists have yet to determine what has caused\nthe mass-scale spread of infection. It is believed that one of the main\ncauses is poor drinking water. Doctors have warned the population that\nchildren should be prevented from bathing in ponds, lakes and flooded\nquarries in which bacteria proliferate in this summer's uncommonly hot\nweather. Quarantine has been imposed on countryside recreation camps.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In view of the enteroviral activity in the Khabarovsk and Primorsk Regions\nreported earlier (see above), it is probable that this outbreak in\nKomsomolsk-na-Amure has been confirmed as aseptic (enteroviral) meningitis.\nIn view of the suspicion that the epidemic is due to a water-borne\npathogen, the restriction on bathing outdoors as a containment measure is\nsensible. The reference to increased bacterial proliferation, however,\nsuggests some uncertainty in the diagnosis.\nAseptic meningitis in children is the most common manifestation of\nenteroviral infection. Although the onset of illness is dramatic and\nsudden, virtually all children recover without significant morbidity.\nChildren under one year may be at greater risk of neurological sequelae. In\ntemperate climates aseptic meningitis is commonest in summer and autumn.\nThe outbreaks in the Russian Far East fit the expected pattern,\nparticularly the association with summer holiday camps. Many different\nenteroviruses can be responsible for outbreaks of aseptic meningitis and it\ncannot be assumed that the same agent is responsible for separate outbreaks\neven in the same locality. Likewise previous exposure to infection does not\nprovide immunity to reinfection. - Mod.CP\n.......................................jw/cp/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. As of 5 Jan 2000, 30 cases and 4 deaths had been\nreported (case-fatality rate, 13.3%).\nThe National Epidemiology Centre in Budapest has confirmed _Neisseria\nmeningitidis_ groups B and C.\nProtection and prevention measures include chemoprophylaxis of close\ncontacts with rifampicin and immunization (with bivalent A/C serogroup\nvaccine).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Note that there is no approved vaccine against group B - Mod.JW]\n............................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2000-01-07 00:00:00", "2000-01-07 00:00:00", "2000-01-07 00:00:00", "2000-01-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hungary", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "Budapest", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2197092", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis - Hungary: alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2197092", "date": "1999-03-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - SUDAN\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nMeningitis - Sudan (Khartoum) 990223232750\nMeningitis - Sudan (North Darfur) 990109152700\nMeningitis - Sudan (North Darfur) (02) 990112133528\nDate: Thu, 4 Mar 1999 23:17:41 -0500\nFrom: George A. Robertson <grobertson@erols.com>\n\nSudan Meningitis Epidemic Spreads\n\nA meningitis epidemic spreading through Sudan has reached alarming levels\nin six states, killing at least 233 people, the International Federation of\nRed Cross and Crescent Societies reported Thursday. The aid agencies said\n1,762 cases have been reported and warned that unless vaccination campaigns\nare accelerated, the disease will spread further.\nVaccination campaigns are under way, but a vaccine shortage has prevented\ncomprehensive coverage in the worst-affected states and people have begun\nto panic, it said. Streams of frightened people are now besieging aid\noffices, asking for vaccinations.\nThe disease has reached southern Sudan, where infection rates are expected\nto be extremely high due to population movement caused by the African\nnation's civil war.\nThe groups appealed for funds to immunize over 1.3 million people in the\nsix states, bolster treatment in medical centers and train volunteers to\nprevent and identify meningitis. The Red Crescent has been fighting the\ndisease since the first outbreak was reported in the western state of North\nDarfur in December, and is now on full alert in 26 states.\nMeningococcal meningitis is an infection of the membranes around the brain\nand spinal cord. The illness is spread through direct exposure such as\nkissing, sharing utensils, coughing and sneezing. Symptoms include fever,\nheadache, nausea and vomiting, neck stiffness, and skin rash.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[This thread was originally started because news out of Sudan is scarce, &\nin the beginning it wasn't clear whether this outbreak was meningococcal or\nviral encephalitis. Now we know it is meningococcal & forms part of the\nsad pandemic that sweeps across the \"meningitis belt\" of sub-Saharan Africa\nevery year, some years worse than others, always acompanied by vaccine\nshortages. In other words, not an emerging disease. So this thread is now\ncut - Mod.JW\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-12-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sudan", "country": "Sudan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2196407", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, viral - Romania (northeast) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2196407", "date": "1999-03-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - SUDAN\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nMeningitis - Sudan (Khartoum) 990223232750\nMeningitis - Sudan (North Darfur) 990109152700\nMeningitis - Sudan (North Darfur) (02) 990112133528\nDate: Thu, 4 Mar 1999 23:17:41 -0500\nFrom: George A. Robertson <grobertson@erols.com>\n\nSudan Meningitis Epidemic Spreads\n\nA meningitis epidemic spreading through Sudan has reached alarming levels\nin six states, killing at least 233 people, the International Federation of\nRed Cross and Crescent Societies reported Thursday. The aid agencies said\n1,762 cases have been reported and warned that unless vaccination campaigns\nare accelerated, the disease will spread further.\nVaccination campaigns are under way, but a vaccine shortage has prevented\ncomprehensive coverage in the worst-affected states and people have begun\nto panic, it said. Streams of frightened people are now besieging aid\noffices, asking for vaccinations.\nThe disease has reached southern Sudan, where infection rates are expected\nto be extremely high due to population movement caused by the African\nnation's civil war.\nThe groups appealed for funds to immunize over 1.3 million people in the\nsix states, bolster treatment in medical centers and train volunteers to\nprevent and identify meningitis. The Red Crescent has been fighting the\ndisease since the first outbreak was reported in the western state of North\nDarfur in December, and is now on full alert in 26 states.\nMeningococcal meningitis is an infection of the membranes around the brain\nand spinal cord. The illness is spread through direct exposure such as\nkissing, sharing utensils, coughing and sneezing. Symptoms include fever,\nheadache, nausea and vomiting, neck stiffness, and skin rash.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[This thread was originally started because news out of Sudan is scarce, &\nin the beginning it wasn't clear whether this outbreak was meningococcal or\nviral encephalitis. Now we know it is meningococcal & forms part of the\nsad pandemic that sweeps across the \"meningitis belt\" of sub-Saharan Africa\nevery year, some years worse than others, always acompanied by vaccine\nshortages. In other words, not an emerging disease. So this thread is now\ncut - Mod.JW\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It showed the\nincreasing of rates (1997 almost duplicate 1990) and the prevalence of\nserogroup B in all States and Territories; it could be [of concern because\n[of the lack of serogroup B effective vaccines. Unfortunately the control\nmeasures implemented and their results are not mentioned. Australia is a\nvery large country and it seems to me that massive interventions might be\ndifficult.\nIn Cuba we had an IMD epidemic [that started in the 1970s predominantly to\nserogroup C, and nationwide massive vaccination in the high risk groups\n(population under 20 years old) in 1979 with a capsular polysaccharide A-C\nvaccine (Merieux Laboratories) with a coverage of 80% reduced substantially\nmeningococcus [serogroup C infections. Despite this intervention, the\nincidence rate continued to rise, but [with a change [of the prevailing\nserogroup to B (78.4%). The peak of the epidemic occurred in 1983.\nLater(1987-1988) and based on encouraging results in the efficacy trials\nwith VA-MENGOC-BC, another massive vaccination [campaign was carried out\nin the same age groups, achieving 95 % coverage (>3 million vaccinated)\nwith remarkable success in the control of IMD. In 1991 the vaccine was\nincluded in the National Immunization Program (NIP) for all infants (first\ndose at 3 + months and the second at 5 + months), and since then the rates\nare very low and continue [to decrease.\nStudies of anti-meningococcal BC vaccination under epidemic conditions in\nother countries (Boslego et al. 1995,Noronha et al. 1995) suggest low\nefficacy for VA-MENGOC-BC vaccine in serogroup B IMD, especially in\nchildren under 5 years of age. In contrast our experience reveal a dramatic\ndecrease of epidemic after vaccination with type specific vaccine. This is\nan important difference with regard to other countries which used\nvaccination only as a punctual measure in epidemic control. Perhaps these\nexperiences would be useful for control of IMD in others countries taking\ninto account the circulating serogroups, serotypes and subtypes.\n--\nDr. Felix Dickinson\nEpidemiologist\nInstituto de Medicina Tropical \"Pedro Kouri\"\ne-mail: dickinson@ipk.sld.cu\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It showed the\nincreasing of rates (1997 almost duplicate 1990) and the prevalence of\nserogroup B in all States and Territories; it could be [of concern because\n[of the lack of serogroup B effective vaccines. Unfortunately the control\nmeasures implemented and their results are not mentioned. Australia is a\nvery large country and it seems to me that massive interventions might be\ndifficult.\nIn Cuba we had an IMD epidemic [that started in the 1970s predominantly to\nserogroup C, and nationwide massive vaccination in the high risk groups\n(population under 20 years old) in 1979 with a capsular polysaccharide A-C\nvaccine (Merieux Laboratories) with a coverage of 80% reduced substantially\nmeningococcus [serogroup C infections. Despite this intervention, the\nincidence rate continued to rise, but [with a change [of the prevailing\nserogroup to B (78.4%). The peak of the epidemic occurred in 1983.\nLater(1987-1988) and based on encouraging results in the efficacy trials\nwith VA-MENGOC-BC, another massive vaccination [campaign was carried out\nin the same age groups, achieving 95 % coverage (>3 million vaccinated)\nwith remarkable success in the control of IMD. In 1991 the vaccine was\nincluded in the National Immunization Program (NIP) for all infants (first\ndose at 3 + months and the second at 5 + months), and since then the rates\nare very low and continue [to decrease.\nStudies of anti-meningococcal BC vaccination under epidemic conditions in\nother countries (Boslego et al. 1995,Noronha et al. 1995) suggest low\nefficacy for VA-MENGOC-BC vaccine in serogroup B IMD, especially in\nchildren under 5 years of age. In contrast our experience reveal a dramatic\ndecrease of epidemic after vaccination with type specific vaccine. This is\nan important difference with regard to other countries which used\nvaccination only as a punctual measure in epidemic control. Perhaps these\nexperiences would be useful for control of IMD in others countries taking\ninto account the circulating serogroups, serotypes and subtypes.\n--\nDr. Felix Dickinson\nEpidemiologist\nInstituto de Medicina Tropical \"Pedro Kouri\"\ne-mail: dickinson@ipk.sld.cu\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It showed the\nincreasing of rates (1997 almost duplicate 1990) and the prevalence of\nserogroup B in all States and Territories; it could be [of concern because\n[of the lack of serogroup B effective vaccines. Unfortunately the control\nmeasures implemented and their results are not mentioned. Australia is a\nvery large country and it seems to me that massive interventions might be\ndifficult.\nIn Cuba we had an IMD epidemic [that started in the 1970s predominantly to\nserogroup C, and nationwide massive vaccination in the high risk groups\n(population under 20 years old) in 1979 with a capsular polysaccharide A-C\nvaccine (Merieux Laboratories) with a coverage of 80% reduced substantially\nmeningococcus [serogroup C infections. Despite this intervention, the\nincidence rate continued to rise, but [with a change [of the prevailing\nserogroup to B (78.4%). The peak of the epidemic occurred in 1983.\nLater(1987-1988) and based on encouraging results in the efficacy trials\nwith VA-MENGOC-BC, another massive vaccination [campaign was carried out\nin the same age groups, achieving 95 % coverage (>3 million vaccinated)\nwith remarkable success in the control of IMD. In 1991 the vaccine was\nincluded in the National Immunization Program (NIP) for all infants (first\ndose at 3 + months and the second at 5 + months), and since then the rates\nare very low and continue [to decrease.\nStudies of anti-meningococcal BC vaccination under epidemic conditions in\nother countries (Boslego et al. 1995,Noronha et al. 1995) suggest low\nefficacy for VA-MENGOC-BC vaccine in serogroup B IMD, especially in\nchildren under 5 years of age. In contrast our experience reveal a dramatic\ndecrease of epidemic after vaccination with type specific vaccine. This is\nan important difference with regard to other countries which used\nvaccination only as a punctual measure in epidemic control. Perhaps these\nexperiences would be useful for control of IMD in others countries taking\ninto account the circulating serogroups, serotypes and subtypes.\n--\nDr. Felix Dickinson\nEpidemiologist\nInstituto de Medicina Tropical \"Pedro Kouri\"\ne-mail: dickinson@ipk.sld.cu\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It showed the\nincreasing of rates (1997 almost duplicate 1990) and the prevalence of\nserogroup B in all States and Territories; it could be [of concern because\n[of the lack of serogroup B effective vaccines. Unfortunately the control\nmeasures implemented and their results are not mentioned. Australia is a\nvery large country and it seems to me that massive interventions might be\ndifficult.\nIn Cuba we had an IMD epidemic [that started in the 1970s predominantly to\nserogroup C, and nationwide massive vaccination in the high risk groups\n(population under 20 years old) in 1979 with a capsular polysaccharide A-C\nvaccine (Merieux Laboratories) with a coverage of 80% reduced substantially\nmeningococcus [serogroup C infections. Despite this intervention, the\nincidence rate continued to rise, but [with a change [of the prevailing\nserogroup to B (78.4%). The peak of the epidemic occurred in 1983.\nLater(1987-1988) and based on encouraging results in the efficacy trials\nwith VA-MENGOC-BC, another massive vaccination [campaign was carried out\nin the same age groups, achieving 95 % coverage (>3 million vaccinated)\nwith remarkable success in the control of IMD. In 1991 the vaccine was\nincluded in the National Immunization Program (NIP) for all infants (first\ndose at 3 + months and the second at 5 + months), and since then the rates\nare very low and continue [to decrease.\nStudies of anti-meningococcal BC vaccination under epidemic conditions in\nother countries (Boslego et al. 1995,Noronha et al. 1995) suggest low\nefficacy for VA-MENGOC-BC vaccine in serogroup B IMD, especially in\nchildren under 5 years of age. In contrast our experience reveal a dramatic\ndecrease of epidemic after vaccination with type specific vaccine. This is\nan important difference with regard to other countries which used\nvaccination only as a punctual measure in epidemic control. Perhaps these\nexperiences would be useful for control of IMD in others countries taking\ninto account the circulating serogroups, serotypes and subtypes.\n--\nDr. Felix Dickinson\nEpidemiologist\nInstituto de Medicina Tropical \"Pedro Kouri\"\ne-mail: dickinson@ipk.sld.cu\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It showed the\nincreasing of rates (1997 almost duplicate 1990) and the prevalence of\nserogroup B in all States and Territories; it could be [of concern because\n[of the lack of serogroup B effective vaccines. Unfortunately the control\nmeasures implemented and their results are not mentioned. Australia is a\nvery large country and it seems to me that massive interventions might be\ndifficult.\nIn Cuba we had an IMD epidemic [that started in the 1970s predominantly to\nserogroup C, and nationwide massive vaccination in the high risk groups\n(population under 20 years old) in 1979 with a capsular polysaccharide A-C\nvaccine (Merieux Laboratories) with a coverage of 80% reduced substantially\nmeningococcus [serogroup C infections. In 1991 the vaccine was\nincluded in the National Immunization Program (NIP) for all infants (first\ndose at 3 + months and the second at 5 + months), and since then the rates\nare very low and continue [to decrease.\nStudies of anti-meningococcal BC vaccination under epidemic conditions in\nother countries (Boslego et al. 1995,Noronha et al. 1995) suggest low\nefficacy for VA-MENGOC-BC vaccine in serogroup B IMD, especially in\nchildren under 5 years of age. In contrast our experience reveal a dramatic\ndecrease of epidemic after vaccination with type specific vaccine. This is\nan important difference with regard to other countries which used\nvaccination only as a punctual measure in epidemic control. Perhaps these\nexperiences would be useful for control of IMD in others countries taking\ninto account the circulating serogroups, serotypes and subtypes.\n--\nDr. Felix Dickinson\nEpidemiologist\nInstituto de Medicina Tropical \"Pedro Kouri\"\ne-mail: dickinson@ipk.sld.cu\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Despite this intervention, the\nincidence rate continued to rise, but [with a change [of the prevailing\nserogroup to B (78.4%). The peak of the epidemic occurred in 1983.\nLater(1987-1988) and based on encouraging results in the efficacy trials\nwith VA-MENGOC-BC, another massive vaccination [campaign was carried out\nin the same age groups, achieving 95 % coverage (>3 million vaccinated)\nwith remarkable success in the control of IMD. In 1991 the vaccine was\nincluded in the National Immunization Program (NIP) for all infants (first\ndose at 3 + months and the second at 5 + months), and since then the rates\nare very low and continue [to decrease.\nStudies of anti-meningococcal BC vaccination under epidemic conditions in\nother countries (Boslego et al. 1995,Noronha et al. 1995) suggest low\nefficacy for VA-MENGOC-BC vaccine in serogroup B IMD, especially in\nchildren under 5 years of age. In contrast our experience reveal a dramatic\ndecrease of epidemic after vaccination with type specific vaccine. This is\nan important difference with regard to other countries which used\nvaccination only as a punctual measure in epidemic control. Perhaps these\nexperiences would be useful for control of IMD in others countries taking\ninto account the circulating serogroups, serotypes and subtypes.\n--\nDr. Felix Dickinson\nEpidemiologist\nInstituto de Medicina Tropical \"Pedro Kouri\"\ne-mail: dickinson@ipk.sld.cu\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
