It showed the\nincreasing of rates (1997 almost duplicate 1990) and the prevalence of\nserogroup B in all States and Territories; it could be [of concern because\n[of the lack of serogroup B effective vaccines. Unfortunately the control\nmeasures implemented and their results are not mentioned. Australia is a\nvery large country and it seems to me that massive interventions might be\ndifficult.\nIn Cuba we had an IMD epidemic [that started in the 1970s predominantly to\nserogroup C, and nationwide massive vaccination in the high risk groups\n(population under 20 years old) in 1979 with a capsular polysaccharide A-C\nvaccine (Merieux Laboratories) with a coverage of 80% reduced substantially\nmeningococcus [serogroup C infections. Despite this intervention, the\nincidence rate continued to rise, but [with a change [of the prevailing\nserogroup to B (78.4%). The peak of the epidemic occurred in 1983.\nLater(1987-1988) and based on encouraging results in the efficacy trials\nwith VA-MENGOC-BC, another massive vaccination [campaign was carried out\nin the same age groups, achieving 95 % coverage (>3 million vaccinated)\nwith remarkable success in the control of IMD. In 1991 the vaccine was\nincluded in the National Immunization Program (NIP) for all infants (first\ndose at 3 + months and the second at 5 + months), and since then the rates\nare very low and continue [to decrease.\nStudies of anti-meningococcal BC vaccination under epidemic conditions in\nother countries (Boslego et al. 1995,Noronha et al. 1995) suggest low\nefficacy for VA-MENGOC-BC vaccine in serogroup B IMD, especially in\nchildren under 5 years of age. In contrast our experience reveal a dramatic\ndecrease of epidemic after vaccination with type specific vaccine. This is\nan important difference with regard to other countries which used\nvaccination only as a punctual measure in epidemic control. Perhaps these\nexperiences would be useful for control of IMD in others countries taking\ninto account the circulating serogroups, serotypes and subtypes.\n--\nDr. Felix Dickinson\nEpidemiologist\nInstituto de Medicina Tropical \"Pedro Kouri\"\ne-mail: dickinson@ipk.sld.cu\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. So far 7,595\ncases have been reported from the WHO African Region in 1998. However\nnot all countries are experiencing this generally reduced level of\nactivity and recent weeks have witnessed a large outbreak in Chad. In\nthe period 29th December 1997 to 22nd of March 1998 there have been 2835\ncases and 239 deaths reported from Chad which is more than twice the\nannual total number of cases reported in Chad in 1996 (1,079 cases) and\n1997 (1,123 cases).\nThe district of Bokoro reached the epidemic attack rate of 15\ncases/100,000 per week in week 3 (12-18 January) with the capital\nN'Djamena crossing that threshold in week 8 (16-22 February).\nVaccination campaigns have been carried out in districts where the\nweekly attack rate has exceeded 5 cases/100,000 population. This has\nresulted in 1,650,000 vaccinations carried out in 13 of 15 Prefectures.\nThe security stock of meningococcal vaccine in place in order to respond\nto epidemic meningitis has been exhausted and additional vaccine has\nbeen supplied through MSF-Belgium and WHO.\nThe very real threat of epidemics of cerebrospinal meningitis during the\nhot dry season from late December to early May means that the countries\nof the \"African meningitis belt\" must continue to strengthen\nsurveillance, reporting systems and rapid laboratory confirmation of the\netiology. Having a security stock of vaccine is useful but early\ndetection is crucial to mounting a response that can cut short these\ndevastating epidemics.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. So far 7,595\ncases have been reported from the WHO African Region in 1998. However\nnot all countries are experiencing this generally reduced level of\nactivity and recent weeks have witnessed a large outbreak in Chad. In\nthe period 29th December 1997 to 22nd of March 1998 there have been 2835\ncases and 239 deaths reported from Chad which is more than twice the\nannual total number of cases reported in Chad in 1996 (1,079 cases) and\n1997 (1,123 cases).\nThe district of Bokoro reached the epidemic attack rate of 15\ncases/100,000 per week in week 3 (12-18 January) with the capital\nN'Djamena crossing that threshold in week 8 (16-22 February).\nVaccination campaigns have been carried out in districts where the\nweekly attack rate has exceeded 5 cases/100,000 population. This has\nresulted in 1,650,000 vaccinations carried out in 13 of 15 Prefectures.\nThe security stock of meningococcal vaccine in place in order to respond\nto epidemic meningitis has been exhausted and additional vaccine has\nbeen supplied through MSF-Belgium and WHO.\nThe very real threat of epidemics of cerebrospinal meningitis during the\nhot dry season from late December to early May means that the countries\nof the \"African meningitis belt\" must continue to strengthen\nsurveillance, reporting systems and rapid laboratory confirmation of the\netiology. Having a security stock of vaccine is useful but early\ndetection is crucial to mounting a response that can cut short these\ndevastating epidemics.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. So far 7,595\ncases have been reported from the WHO African Region in 1998. However\nnot all countries are experiencing this generally reduced level of\nactivity and recent weeks have witnessed a large outbreak in Chad. In\nthe period 29th December 1997 to 22nd of March 1998 there have been 2835\ncases and 239 deaths reported from Chad which is more than twice the\nannual total number of cases reported in Chad in 1996 (1,079 cases) and\n1997 (1,123 cases).\nThe district of Bokoro reached the epidemic attack rate of 15\ncases/100,000 per week in week 3 (12-18 January) with the capital\nN'Djamena crossing that threshold in week 8 (16-22 February).\nVaccination campaigns have been carried out in districts where the\nweekly attack rate has exceeded 5 cases/100,000 population. This has\nresulted in 1,650,000 vaccinations carried out in 13 of 15 Prefectures.\nThe security stock of meningococcal vaccine in place in order to respond\nto epidemic meningitis has been exhausted and additional vaccine has\nbeen supplied through MSF-Belgium and WHO.\nThe very real threat of epidemics of cerebrospinal meningitis during the\nhot dry season from late December to early May means that the countries\nof the \"African meningitis belt\" must continue to strengthen\nsurveillance, reporting systems and rapid laboratory confirmation of the\netiology. Having a security stock of vaccine is useful but early\ndetection is crucial to mounting a response that can cut short these\ndevastating epidemics.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. So far 7,595\ncases have been reported from the WHO African Region in 1998. However\nnot all countries are experiencing this generally reduced level of\nactivity and recent weeks have witnessed a large outbreak in Chad. In\nthe period 29th December 1997 to 22nd of March 1998 there have been 2835\ncases and 239 deaths reported from Chad which is more than twice the\nannual total number of cases reported in Chad in 1996 (1,079 cases) and\n1997 (1,123 cases).\nThe district of Bokoro reached the epidemic attack rate of 15\ncases/100,000 per week in week 3 (12-18 January) with the capital\nN'Djamena crossing that threshold in week 8 (16-22 February).\nVaccination campaigns have been carried out in districts where the\nweekly attack rate has exceeded 5 cases/100,000 population. This has\nresulted in 1,650,000 vaccinations carried out in 13 of 15 Prefectures.\nThe security stock of meningococcal vaccine in place in order to respond\nto epidemic meningitis has been exhausted and additional vaccine has\nbeen supplied through MSF-Belgium and WHO.\nThe very real threat of epidemics of cerebrospinal meningitis during the\nhot dry season from late December to early May means that the countries\nof the \"African meningitis belt\" must continue to strengthen\nsurveillance, reporting systems and rapid laboratory confirmation of the\netiology. Having a security stock of vaccine is useful but early\ndetection is crucial to mounting a response that can cut short these\ndevastating epidemics.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. So far 7,595\ncases have been reported from the WHO African Region in 1998. However\nnot all countries are experiencing this generally reduced level of\nactivity and recent weeks have witnessed a large outbreak in Chad. In\nthe period 29th December 1997 to 22nd of March 1998 there have been 2835\ncases and 239 deaths reported from Chad which is more than twice the\nannual total number of cases reported in Chad in 1996 (1,079 cases) and\n1997 (1,123 cases).\nThe district of Bokoro reached the epidemic attack rate of 15\ncases/100,000 per week in week 3 (12-18 January) with the capital\nN'Djamena crossing that threshold in week 8 (16-22 February).\nVaccination campaigns have been carried out in districts where the\nweekly attack rate has exceeded 5 cases/100,000 population. This has\nresulted in 1,650,000 vaccinations carried out in 13 of 15 Prefectures.\nThe security stock of meningococcal vaccine in place in order to respond\nto epidemic meningitis has been exhausted and additional vaccine has\nbeen supplied through MSF-Belgium and WHO.\nThe very real threat of epidemics of cerebrospinal meningitis during the\nhot dry season from late December to early May means that the countries\nof the \"African meningitis belt\" must continue to strengthen\nsurveillance, reporting systems and rapid laboratory confirmation of the\netiology. Having a security stock of vaccine is useful but early\ndetection is crucial to mounting a response that can cut short these\ndevastating epidemics.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. So far 7,595\ncases have been reported from the WHO African Region in 1998. However\nnot all countries are experiencing this generally reduced level of\nactivity and recent weeks have witnessed a large outbreak in Chad. In\nthe period 29th December 1997 to 22nd of March 1998 there have been 2835\ncases and 239 deaths reported from Chad which is more than twice the\nannual total number of cases reported in Chad in 1996 (1,079 cases) and\n1997 (1,123 cases).\nThe district of Bokoro reached the epidemic attack rate of 15\ncases/100,000 per week in week 3 (12-18 January) with the capital\nN'Djamena crossing that threshold in week 8 (16-22 February).\nVaccination campaigns have been carried out in districts where the\nweekly attack rate has exceeded 5 cases/100,000 population. This has\nresulted in 1,650,000 vaccinations carried out in 13 of 15 Prefectures.\nThe security stock of meningococcal vaccine in place in order to respond\nto epidemic meningitis has been exhausted and additional vaccine has\nbeen supplied through MSF-Belgium and WHO.\nThe very real threat of epidemics of cerebrospinal meningitis during the\nhot dry season from late December to early May means that the countries\nof the \"African meningitis belt\" must continue to strengthen\nsurveillance, reporting systems and rapid laboratory confirmation of the\netiology. Having a security stock of vaccine is useful but early\ndetection is crucial to mounting a response that can cut short these\ndevastating epidemics.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. So far 7,595\ncases have been reported from the WHO African Region in 1998. However\nnot all countries are experiencing this generally reduced level of\nactivity and recent weeks have witnessed a large outbreak in Chad. In\nthe period 29th December 1997 to 22nd of March 1998 there have been 2835\ncases and 239 deaths reported from Chad which is more than twice the\nannual total number of cases reported in Chad in 1996 (1,079 cases) and\n1997 (1,123 cases).\nThe district of Bokoro reached the epidemic attack rate of 15\ncases/100,000 per week in week 3 (12-18 January) with the capital\nN'Djamena crossing that threshold in week 8 (16-22 February).\nVaccination campaigns have been carried out in districts where the\nweekly attack rate has exceeded 5 cases/100,000 population. This has\nresulted in 1,650,000 vaccinations carried out in 13 of 15 Prefectures.\nThe security stock of meningococcal vaccine in place in order to respond\nto epidemic meningitis has been exhausted and additional vaccine has\nbeen supplied through MSF-Belgium and WHO.\nThe very real threat of epidemics of cerebrospinal meningitis during the\nhot dry season from late December to early May means that the countries\nof the \"African meningitis belt\" must continue to strengthen\nsurveillance, reporting systems and rapid laboratory confirmation of the\netiology. Having a security stock of vaccine is useful but early\ndetection is crucial to mounting a response that can cut short these\ndevastating epidemics.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. So far 7,595\ncases have been reported from the WHO African Region in 1998. However\nnot all countries are experiencing this generally reduced level of\nactivity and recent weeks have witnessed a large outbreak in Chad. In\nthe period 29th December 1997 to 22nd of March 1998 there have been 2835\ncases and 239 deaths reported from Chad which is more than twice the\nannual total number of cases reported in Chad in 1996 (1,079 cases) and\n1997 (1,123 cases).\nThe district of Bokoro reached the epidemic attack rate of 15\ncases/100,000 per week in week 3 (12-18 January) with the capital\nN'Djamena crossing that threshold in week 8 (16-22 February).\nVaccination campaigns have been carried out in districts where the\nweekly attack rate has exceeded 5 cases/100,000 population. This has\nresulted in 1,650,000 vaccinations carried out in 13 of 15 Prefectures.\nThe security stock of meningococcal vaccine in place in order to respond\nto epidemic meningitis has been exhausted and additional vaccine has\nbeen supplied through MSF-Belgium and WHO.\nThe very real threat of epidemics of cerebrospinal meningitis during the\nhot dry season from late December to early May means that the countries\nof the \"African meningitis belt\" must continue to strengthen\nsurveillance, reporting systems and rapid laboratory confirmation of the\netiology. Having a security stock of vaccine is useful but early\ndetection is crucial to mounting a response that can cut short these\ndevastating epidemics.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-01-18 00:00:00", "2021-02-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chad", "country": "Chad"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2193119", "headline": "PRO> Meningitis, meningococcal - USA (Rhode Island) (10)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2193119", "date": "1998-03-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL: VENEREAL TRANSMISSION\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Wed, 04 Mar 1998 12:07:48 -0800\nFrom: Paul Millikin <millikin@mtco.com>\n\nDogma has it that _Neisseria meningitidis_ inhabits the mouth and pharynx\nand somehow invades the blood stream and meninges from there. However,\n_Neisseria meningitis_ can also infect the urethra and uterine cervix, as\nshown\nby the references below.\nThere is documentation of its transfer from mouth to urethra via oral sex,\nso why not transfer from urethra to mouth via the same mechanism? I could\nfind no data on transfer from mouth to mouth, i.e. by kissing, but that seems\nat least theoretically possible. In other words, the evidence strongly\nsuggests that [meningococcal] meningitis may sometimes be acquired\nvenereally, from\nurethra to mouth to blood and meninges.\nConceivably that information might be useful to any physician who is faced\nwith a meningitis outbreak among young people, as on university campuses or\nin armed forces basic training centers. That's one situation where temporary\nabstinence might be a helpful control measure, provided the students or\nrecruits were made aware of it.\nIncidentally, correct identification of the organism in acute male urethritis\nmight occasionally save a marriage, when the organism is _N. meningitidis_\nfrom\nthe wife's throat rather than _N. gonorrheae_ from extracurricular sources.\nDoes anyone have any personal experience with such an outbreak?\nREFERENCES\nTI: Urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ in a London genitourinary\nmedicine clinic population.\nAU: Maini M, French P, Prince M, Bingham JS,\nSO: Int J STD AIDS 1992 Nov-Dec;3(6):423-5\n10 out of 5571 homosexual men.\n0 out of 8892 heterosexual men\n0 out of 15976 cervical cultures.\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_: a case report.\nAU: Quarto M, Barbuti S, Germinario C, Vena GA, Foti C,\nSO: Eur J Epidemiol 1991 Nov;7(6):699-701\n1 case in a heterosexual male, acquired by fellatio\nTI: _Neisseria meningitidis_ in specimens from urogenital sites. Is increased\nawareness necessary?\nAU: Hagman M, Forslin L, Moi H, Danielsson D,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1991 Oct-Dec;18(4):228-32\n1 man, 2 women, all heterosexual. 1 woman had acute salpingitis\nTI: Urogenital infection due to meningococcus in men and women.\nAU: Conde-Glez CJ, Calderon E,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1991 Apr-Jun;18(2):72-5\n5 heterosexual men, 1 homosexual. 3 prostitutes with acute cervicitis\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ [letter; comment]\nAU: Shanmugaratnam K, Pattman RS,\nCM: Comment on: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nTI: Meningococcal urethritis.\nAU: Faigel HC,\nSO: J Adolesc Health Care 1990 Jul;11(4):355-7\n1 heterosexual male. Urethritis acquired by fellatio\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ group B: a case\nreport.\nAU: Hartmann AA, Elsner P,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1988 Jul-Sep;15(3):150-1\n1 heterosexual man. Onset 5 days after casual fellatio by a female\nTI: [Isolation of _Neisseria meningitidis_ from the urethra and cervix]\nAU: Bohler-Sommeregger K, Poitschek C, Furnsinn G, Schuller-Petrovic S,\nHirschl A,\nSO: Wien Klin Wochenschr 1987 Jan 9;99(1):25-7\nReview and discussion\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ [letter; comment]\nAU: Shanmugaratnam K, Pattman RS,\nCM: Comment on: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ group A acquired\nby oro-genital contact: case report [letter]\nAU: Hay PE, Murphy SM, Chinn RJ,\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Aug;65(4):285-6\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ group A acquired\nby orogenital contact: case report [see comments]\nAU: Wilson AP, Wolff J, Atia W,\nCM: Comment in: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nCM: Comment in: Genitourin Med 1990 Aug;66(4):305-6\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nTI: Isolation of _Neisseria meningitidis_ from anogenital sites in\nadolescents: clinical implications.\nAU: Jaffe LR, Stavis JA,\nSO: J Adolesc Health Care 1983 Sep;4(3):171-3\nTI: Isolation of _N. meningitidis_ from patients in a gonorrhea screen\nprogram: a four-year survey in New York City.\nAU: Faur YC, Wilson ME, May PS,\nSO: Am J Public Health 1981 Jan;71(1):53-8\n964 strains from GU tract or anal canal over 4 years\nTI: Prevalence and site-pathogen studies of _Neisseria meningitidis_\nand _N. gonorrhoeae_ in homosexual men.\nAU: Janda WM, Bohnoff M, Morello JA, Lerner SA,\nSO: JAMA 1980 Nov 7;244(18):2060-4\n6 urethral and 16 anal positive cultures in 815 homosexual men\n--\nPaul D. Millikin, MD\ne-mail: millikin@mtco.com\n[While venereal transmission has been shown to occur, oropharyngeal\ntransmission between two people in that sort of close contact is likely to\nbe the primary route - Mod.JW]\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "5571-03-16 00:00:00", "8892-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1988-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1983-03-16 00:00:00", "1981-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "London", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Prince M", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hay PE", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2193117", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - Nigeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2193117", "date": "1998-03-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL: VENEREAL TRANSMISSION\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Wed, 04 Mar 1998 12:07:48 -0800\nFrom: Paul Millikin <millikin@mtco.com>\n\nDogma has it that _Neisseria meningitidis_ inhabits the mouth and pharynx\nand somehow invades the blood stream and meninges from there. However,\n_Neisseria meningitis_ can also infect the urethra and uterine cervix, as\nshown\nby the references below.\nThere is documentation of its transfer from mouth to urethra via oral sex,\nso why not transfer from urethra to mouth via the same mechanism? I could\nfind no data on transfer from mouth to mouth, i.e. by kissing, but that seems\nat least theoretically possible. In other words, the evidence strongly\nsuggests that [meningococcal] meningitis may sometimes be acquired\nvenereally, from\nurethra to mouth to blood and meninges.\nConceivably that information might be useful to any physician who is faced\nwith a meningitis outbreak among young people, as on university campuses or\nin armed forces basic training centers. That's one situation where temporary\nabstinence might be a helpful control measure, provided the students or\nrecruits were made aware of it.\nIncidentally, correct identification of the organism in acute male urethritis\nmight occasionally save a marriage, when the organism is _N. meningitidis_\nfrom\nthe wife's throat rather than _N. gonorrheae_ from extracurricular sources.\nDoes anyone have any personal experience with such an outbreak?\nREFERENCES\nTI: Urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ in a London genitourinary\nmedicine clinic population.\nAU: Maini M, French P, Prince M, Bingham JS,\nSO: Int J STD AIDS 1992 Nov-Dec;3(6):423-5\n10 out of 5571 homosexual men.\n0 out of 8892 heterosexual men\n0 out of 15976 cervical cultures.\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_: a case report.\nAU: Quarto M, Barbuti S, Germinario C, Vena GA, Foti C,\nSO: Eur J Epidemiol 1991 Nov;7(6):699-701\n1 case in a heterosexual male, acquired by fellatio\nTI: _Neisseria meningitidis_ in specimens from urogenital sites. Is increased\nawareness necessary?\nAU: Hagman M, Forslin L, Moi H, Danielsson D,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1991 Oct-Dec;18(4):228-32\n1 man, 2 women, all heterosexual. 1 woman had acute salpingitis\nTI: Urogenital infection due to meningococcus in men and women.\nAU: Conde-Glez CJ, Calderon E,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1991 Apr-Jun;18(2):72-5\n5 heterosexual men, 1 homosexual. 3 prostitutes with acute cervicitis\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ [letter; comment]\nAU: Shanmugaratnam K, Pattman RS,\nCM: Comment on: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nTI: Meningococcal urethritis.\nAU: Faigel HC,\nSO: J Adolesc Health Care 1990 Jul;11(4):355-7\n1 heterosexual male. Urethritis acquired by fellatio\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ group B: a case\nreport.\nAU: Hartmann AA, Elsner P,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1988 Jul-Sep;15(3):150-1\n1 heterosexual man. Onset 5 days after casual fellatio by a female\nTI: [Isolation of _Neisseria meningitidis_ from the urethra and cervix]\nAU: Bohler-Sommeregger K, Poitschek C, Furnsinn G, Schuller-Petrovic S,\nHirschl A,\nSO: Wien Klin Wochenschr 1987 Jan 9;99(1):25-7\nReview and discussion\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ [letter; comment]\nAU: Shanmugaratnam K, Pattman RS,\nCM: Comment on: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ group A acquired\nby oro-genital contact: case report [letter]\nAU: Hay PE, Murphy SM, Chinn RJ,\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Aug;65(4):285-6\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ group A acquired\nby orogenital contact: case report [see comments]\nAU: Wilson AP, Wolff J, Atia W,\nCM: Comment in: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nCM: Comment in: Genitourin Med 1990 Aug;66(4):305-6\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nTI: Isolation of _Neisseria meningitidis_ from anogenital sites in\nadolescents: clinical implications.\nAU: Jaffe LR, Stavis JA,\nSO: J Adolesc Health Care 1983 Sep;4(3):171-3\nTI: Isolation of _N. meningitidis_ from patients in a gonorrhea screen\nprogram: a four-year survey in New York City.\nAU: Faur YC, Wilson ME, May PS,\nSO: Am J Public Health 1981 Jan;71(1):53-8\n964 strains from GU tract or anal canal over 4 years\nTI: Prevalence and site-pathogen studies of _Neisseria meningitidis_\nand _N. gonorrhoeae_ in homosexual men.\nAU: Janda WM, Bohnoff M, Morello JA, Lerner SA,\nSO: JAMA 1980 Nov 7;244(18):2060-4\n6 urethral and 16 anal positive cultures in 815 homosexual men\n--\nPaul D. Millikin, MD\ne-mail: millikin@mtco.com\n[While venereal transmission has been shown to occur, oropharyngeal\ntransmission between two people in that sort of close contact is likely to\nbe the primary route - Mod.JW]\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. However,\n_Neisseria meningitis_ can also infect the urethra and uterine cervix, as\nshown\nby the references below.\nThere is documentation of its transfer from mouth to urethra via oral sex,\nso why not transfer from urethra to mouth via the same mechanism? I could\nfind no data on transfer from mouth to mouth, i.e. by kissing, but that seems\nat least theoretically possible. In other words, the evidence strongly\nsuggests that [meningococcal] meningitis may sometimes be acquired\nvenereally, from\nurethra to mouth to blood and meninges.\nConceivably that information might be useful to any physician who is faced\nwith a meningitis outbreak among young people, as on university campuses or\nin armed forces basic training centers. That's one situation where temporary\nabstinence might be a helpful control measure, provided the students or\nrecruits were made aware of it.\nIncidentally, correct identification of the organism in acute male urethritis\nmight occasionally save a marriage, when the organism is _N. meningitidis_\nfrom\nthe wife's throat rather than _N. gonorrheae_ from extracurricular sources.\nDoes anyone have any personal experience with such an outbreak?\nREFERENCES\nTI: Urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ in a London genitourinary\nmedicine clinic population.\nAU: Maini M, French P, Prince M, Bingham JS,\nSO: Int J STD AIDS 1992 Nov-Dec;3(6):423-5\n10 out of 5571 homosexual men.\n0 out of 8892 heterosexual men\n0 out of 15976 cervical cultures.\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_: a case report.\nAU: Quarto M, Barbuti S, Germinario C, Vena GA, Foti C,\nSO: Eur J Epidemiol 1991 Nov;7(6):699-701\n1 case in a heterosexual male, acquired by fellatio\nTI: _Neisseria meningitidis_ in specimens from urogenital sites. Is increased\nawareness necessary?\nAU: Hagman M, Forslin L, Moi H, Danielsson D,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1991 Oct-Dec;18(4):228-32\n1 man, 2 women, all heterosexual. 1 woman had acute salpingitis\nTI: Urogenital infection due to meningococcus in men and women.\nAU: Conde-Glez CJ, Calderon E,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1991 Apr-Jun;18(2):72-5\n5 heterosexual men, 1 homosexual. 3 prostitutes with acute cervicitis\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ [letter; comment]\nAU: Shanmugaratnam K, Pattman RS,\nCM: Comment on: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nTI: Meningococcal urethritis.\nAU: Faigel HC,\nSO: J Adolesc Health Care 1990 Jul;11(4):355-7\n1 heterosexual male. However,\n_Neisseria meningitis_ can also infect the urethra and uterine cervix, as\nshown\nby the references below.\nThere is documentation of its transfer from mouth to urethra via oral sex,\nso why not transfer from urethra to mouth via the same mechanism? That's one situation where temporary\nabstinence might be a helpful control measure, provided the students or\nrecruits were made aware of it.\nIncidentally, correct identification of the organism in acute male urethritis\nmight occasionally save a marriage, when the organism is _N. meningitidis_\nfrom\nthe wife's throat rather than _N. gonorrheae_ from extracurricular sources.\nDoes anyone have any personal experience with such an outbreak?\nREFERENCES\nTI: Urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ in a London genitourinary\nmedicine clinic population.\nAU: Maini M, French P, Prince M, Bingham JS,\nSO: Int J STD AIDS 1992 Nov-Dec;3(6):423-5\n10 out of 5571 homosexual men.\n0 out of 8892 heterosexual men\n0 out of 15976 cervical cultures.\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_: a case report.\nAU: Quarto M, Barbuti S, Germinario C, Vena GA, Foti C,\nSO: Eur J Epidemiol 1991 Nov;7(6):699-701\n1 case in a heterosexual male, acquired by fellatio\nTI: _Neisseria meningitidis_ in specimens from urogenital sites. Urethritis acquired by fellatio\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_ group B: a case\nreport.\nAU: Hartmann AA, Elsner P,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1988 Jul-Sep;15(3):150-1\n1 heterosexual man. Onset 5 days after casual fellatio by a female\nTI: [Isolation of _Neisseria meningitidis_ from the urethra and cervix]\nAU: Bohler-Sommeregger K, Poitschek C, Furnsinn G, Schuller-Petrovic S,\nHirschl A,\nSO: Wien Klin Wochenschr 1987 Jan 9;99(1):25-7\nReview and discussion\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ [letter; comment]\nAU: Shanmugaratnam K, Pattman RS,\nCM: Comment on: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ group A acquired\nby oro-genital contact: case report [letter]\nAU: Hay PE, Murphy SM, Chinn RJ,\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Aug;65(4):285-6\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ group A acquired\nby orogenital contact: case report [see comments]\nAU: Wilson AP, Wolff J, Atia W,\nCM: Comment in: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nCM: Comment in: Genitourin Med 1990 Aug;66(4):305-6\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nTI: Isolation of _Neisseria meningitidis_ from anogenital sites in\nadolescents: clinical implications.\nAU: Jaffe LR, Stavis JA,\nSO: J Adolesc Health Care 1983 Sep;4(3):171-3\nTI: Isolation of _N. meningitidis_ from patients in a gonorrhea screen\nprogram: a four-year survey in New York City.\nAU: Faur YC, Wilson ME, May PS,\nSO: Am J Public Health 1981 Jan;71(1):53-8\n964 strains from GU tract or anal canal over 4 years\nTI: Prevalence and site-pathogen studies of _Neisseria meningitidis_\nand _N. gonorrhoeae_ in homosexual men.\nAU: Janda WM, Bohnoff M, Morello JA, Lerner SA,\nSO: JAMA 1980 Nov 7;244(18):2060-4\n6 urethral and 16 anal positive cultures in 815 homosexual men\n--\nPaul D. Millikin, MD\ne-mail: millikin@mtco.com\n[While venereal transmission has been shown to occur, oropharyngeal\ntransmission between two people in that sort of close contact is likely to\nbe the primary route - Mod.JW]\n......................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. However,\n_Neisseria meningitis_ can also infect the urethra and uterine cervix, as\nshown\nby the references below.\nThere is documentation of its transfer from mouth to urethra via oral sex,\nso why not transfer from urethra to mouth via the same mechanism? I could\nfind no data on transfer from mouth to mouth, i.e. by kissing, but that seems\nat least theoretically possible. In other words, the evidence strongly\nsuggests that [meningococcal] meningitis may sometimes be acquired\nvenereally, from\nurethra to mouth to blood and meninges.\nConceivably that information might be useful to any physician who is faced\nwith a meningitis outbreak among young people, as on university campuses or\nin armed forces basic training centers. That's one situation where temporary\nabstinence might be a helpful control measure, provided the students or\nrecruits were made aware of it.\nIncidentally, correct identification of the organism in acute male urethritis\nmight occasionally save a marriage, when the organism is _N. meningitidis_\nfrom\nthe wife's throat rather than _N. gonorrheae_ from extracurricular sources.\nDoes anyone have any personal experience with such an outbreak?\nREFERENCES\nTI: Urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ in a London genitourinary\nmedicine clinic population.\nAU: Maini M, French P, Prince M, Bingham JS,\nSO: Int J STD AIDS 1992 Nov-Dec;3(6):423-5\n10 out of 5571 homosexual men.\n0 out of 8892 heterosexual men\n0 out of 15976 cervical cultures.\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_: a case report.\nAU: Quarto M, Barbuti S, Germinario C, Vena GA, Foti C,\nSO: Eur J Epidemiol 1991 Nov;7(6):699-701\n1 case in a heterosexual male, acquired by fellatio\nTI: _Neisseria meningitidis_ in specimens from urogenital sites. Is increased\nawareness necessary?\nAU: Hagman M, Forslin L, Moi H, Danielsson D,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1991 Oct-Dec;18(4):228-32\n1 man, 2 women, all heterosexual. 1 woman had acute salpingitis\nTI: Urogenital infection due to meningococcus in men and women.\nAU: Conde-Glez CJ, Calderon E,\nSO: Sex Transm Dis 1991 Apr-Jun;18(2):72-5\n5 heterosexual men, 1 homosexual. 3 prostitutes with acute cervicitis\nTI: Acute urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ [letter; comment]\nAU: Shanmugaratnam K, Pattman RS,\nCM: Comment on: Genitourin Med 1989 Apr;65(2):122-3\nSO: Genitourin Med 1989 Dec;65(6):401-2\nTI: Meningococcal urethritis.\nAU: Faigel HC,\nSO: J Adolesc Health Care 1990 Jul;11(4):355-7\n1 heterosexual male. However,\n_Neisseria meningitis_ can also infect the urethra and uterine cervix, as\nshown\nby the references below.\nThere is documentation of its transfer from mouth to urethra via oral sex,\nso why not transfer from urethra to mouth via the same mechanism? I could\nfind no data on transfer from mouth to mouth, i.e. by kissing, but that seems\nat least theoretically possible. In other words, the evidence strongly\nsuggests that [meningococcal] meningitis may sometimes be acquired\nvenereally, from\nurethra to mouth to blood and meninges.\nConceivably that information might be useful to any physician who is faced\nwith a meningitis outbreak among young people, as on university campuses or\nin armed forces basic training centers. That's one situation where temporary\nabstinence might be a helpful control measure, provided the students or\nrecruits were made aware of it.\nIncidentally, correct identification of the organism in acute male urethritis\nmight occasionally save a marriage, when the organism is _N. meningitidis_\nfrom\nthe wife's throat rather than _N. gonorrheae_ from extracurricular sources.\nDoes anyone have any personal experience with such an outbreak?\nREFERENCES\nTI: Urethritis due to _Neisseria meningitidis_ in a London genitourinary\nmedicine clinic population.\nAU: Maini M, French P, Prince M, Bingham JS,\nSO: Int J STD AIDS 1992 Nov-Dec;3(6):423-5\n10 out of 5571 homosexual men.\n0 out of 8892 heterosexual men\n0 out of 15976 cervical cultures.\nTI: Urethritis caused by _Neisseria meningitidis_: a case report.\nAU: Quarto M, Barbuti S, Germinario C, Vena GA, Foti C,\nSO: Eur J Epidemiol 1991 Nov;7(6):699-701\n1 case in a heterosexual male, acquired by fellatio\nTI: _Neisseria meningitidis_ in specimens from urogenital sites. However,\n_Neisseria meningitis_ can also infect the urethra and uterine cervix, as\nshown\nby the references below.\nThere is documentation of its transfer from mouth to urethra via oral sex,\nso why not transfer from urethra to mouth via the same mechanism? I could\nfind no data on transfer from mouth to mouth, i.e. by kissing, but that seems\nat least theoretically possible. In other words, the evidence strongly\nsuggests that [meningococcal] meningitis may sometimes be acquired\nvenereally, from\nurethra to mouth to blood and meninges.\nConceivably that information might be useful to any physician who is faced\nwith a meningitis outbreak among young people, as on university campuses or\nin armed forces basic training centers. - Burkina Faso 970131144055\nMeningitis, meningococcal? - Ghana, Mali 970131144049\nDate: Wed, 4 Feb 1998 16:57:45 -0600\nFrom: Martin Hugh-Jones <mehj2020@vt8200.vetmed.lsu.edu>\nSource: Africa Online, Ghana Focus (summarized by - Mod.ES)\n\nGhana's acting Director of medical Services, Albert Asamoah-Baah, has\nreported that sporadic outbreaks of bacterial meningitis [presumed to be of\nmeningococcal etiology -ES are occurring now that hot and dry weather\nconditions prevail in northern Ghana. He indicated that, historically,\nsuch outbreaks have been common during such weather patterns, especially in\nthe northern regions.\nThis year the disease seems to be reaching farther into southern Ghana with\neight deaths reported in the Aflao area near the Togo border. Last year\nthere was a serious problem with bacterial meningitis in the northern,\nupper eastern, and upper western parts of Ghana resulting in many deaths.\nMinistry officials report that medical supplies are adequate. Tourists\nvisiting Burkina Faso for the African Nations Cup Tournament should\nconsider vaccination for [meningococcal meningitis and also for yellow fever.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[Reports of microbiological characterization of the etiologic agent of\nthese outbreaks of meningitis would be helpful. - Mod.ES\n......................................es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. [Type unspecified, presumably\nmeningococcal; WHO has not yet got it up on their Outbreaks Page as of this\nhour - Mod.JW\n\nIn Kamina, in the southern province of Shaba, the outbreak began in March\n1997, and there have been 25 cases including 7 deaths.\nThe epidemic in Kindu, in the central Maniema province, began 9 days ago,\nwith 21 cases reported, including 9 deaths.\nWHO said both epidemics had been brought under control.\n............................................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. May 2, 1997\n------------------------------------------------------------------------\nMay 2, 1997 - WER - Vol 72/ No. 18\nMeningitis in the WHO African Region Update, January-April 1997:\nIn Togo, the epidemic of cerebrospinal meningitis is completely over.\nThe weekly number of reported cases in Burkina Faso, the Gambia, Ghana\nand Mali has steadily decreased since the thirteenth week of 1997, and\nit is hoped that with the immunization activities being carried out and\nthe recent rain in most affected areas, the epidemic may soon be under\ncontrol.\nThis report includes a Table showing the cumulative number of\ncases/deaths notified from 1 January to 28 April 1997.\n............................................................jw\n--\nSend all items for posting to: promed@usa.healthnet.org (NOT to an\nindividual moderator). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Ghana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gambia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burkina Faso", "country": "Burkina Faso"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190630", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningitis, meningococcal - West Africa: Correction", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190630", "date": "1997-03-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "MENINGITIS, MENINGOCOCCAL - BURKINA FASO, GHANA, TOGO\n=====================================================\nDate: Fri, 14 Mar 1997 11:57:07 -0800\nFrom: \"Dr. James Chin\" <jchin@cdpc.com>\n\nSource: CDPC E-mail Service - March 14, 1997\nMarch 14, 1997 - WER [WHO Weekly Epidemiological Record] - Vol 72/ No. 11\nMeningitis in Africa Epidemic situation, January - March 1997:\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nThree countries (Togo, Ghana and Burkina Faso) have reached the epidemic\nthreshold since the beginning of the 1997 meningitis season in early\nNovember 1996.\nTogo was the first country to report an increased number of meningitis\ncases in the Savanes Region neighbouring Burkina Faso. The first\ncases were reported in late December 1996 and the epidemic threshold was\nreached on 5 January 1997 in Tone District. Mass immunization activities\nhave covered 159 000 persons (100% of the population) in the Tandjouare\nand Oti areas neighbouring Tone District. In other areas, efforts are\nbeing made to convince the population still reluctant towards\nvaccination.\nBurkina Faso: The epidemic threshold has been reached in 5 districts\nsince the second week of 1997. The weekly reported number of cases\ncontinued to increase; the epidemic has extended to more than 10\ndistricts and continues to spread. Intensive vaccination campaigns are\nunder way, as well as social mobilization to convince more people to be\nvaccinated in the affected areas.\nGhana: Cases have been reported from northern Ghana since the beginning\nof November 1996. The threshold was reached during the last week of\nJanuary. Since then, the epidemic has continued to spread. The weekly\nattack rates are over 15 per 100 000 population in 6 districts in the\nUpper East and Northern Regions. The population at greatest risk is\nestimated at more than 1.7 million. The national crisis committee\nmonitors the epidemic situation and determines the needs. Intensive\nvaccination campaigns are in progress. Other countries [in the region]\nhave reported sporadic cases. National health authorities have been re-\nquested to reinforce disease surveillance and initiate vaccination\nactivities as soon as the epidemic threshold is reached.\n(Based on: A report from the WHO Regional Office for Africa.)\nWER Editorial Note: An international Appeal has been launched by WHO\njointly with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent\nSocieties, Medecins sans Frontieres and UNICEF to raise funds for the\ncontrol of meningitis in Africa in the 1997 epidemic season. The funds\nare being used to purchase vaccine, treatment drugs and autodestruct\ninjection material. Requests for vaccine are evaluated according to\ncriteria set by an International Coordinating Group, to ensure that\noptimal use is made of the vaccine currently available.\n.............................................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The first\ncases were reported in late December 1996 and the epidemic threshold was\nreached on 5 January 1997 in Tone District. Mass immunization activities\nhave covered 159 000 persons (100% of the population) in the Tandjouare\nand Oti areas neighbouring Tone District. In other areas, efforts are\nbeing made to convince the population still reluctant towards\nvaccination.\nBurkina Faso: The epidemic threshold has been reached in 5 districts\nsince the second week of 1997. The weekly reported number of cases\ncontinued to increase; the epidemic has extended to more than 10\ndistricts and continues to spread. Intensive vaccination campaigns are\nunder way, as well as social mobilization to convince more people to be\nvaccinated in the affected areas.\nGhana: Cases have been reported from northern Ghana since the beginning\nof November 1996. The threshold was reached during the last week of\nJanuary. Since then, the epidemic has continued to spread. The weekly\nattack rates are over 15 per 100 000 population in 6 districts in the\nUpper East and Northern Regions. The population at greatest risk is\nestimated at more than 1.7 million. The national crisis committee\nmonitors the epidemic situation and determines the needs. Intensive\nvaccination campaigns are in progress. Other countries [in the region]\nhave reported sporadic cases. National health authorities have been re-\nquested to reinforce disease surveillance and initiate vaccination\nactivities as soon as the epidemic threshold is reached.\n(Based on: A report from the WHO Regional Office for Africa.)\nWER Editorial Note: An international Appeal has been launched by WHO\njointly with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent\nSocieties, Medecins sans Frontieres and UNICEF to raise funds for the\ncontrol of meningitis in Africa in the 1997 epidemic season. The funds\nare being used to purchase vaccine, treatment drugs and autodestruct\ninjection material. Requests for vaccine are evaluated according to\ncriteria set by an International Coordinating Group, to ensure that\noptimal use is made of the vaccine currently available.\n.............................................................jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The weekly\nattack rates are over 15 per 100 000 population in 6 districts in the\nUpper East and Northern Regions. The population at greatest risk is\nestimated at more than 1.7 million. The national crisis committee\nmonitors the epidemic situation and determines the needs. Intensive\nvaccination campaigns are in progress. Other countries [in the region]\nhave reported sporadic cases. National health authorities have been re-\nquested to reinforce disease surveillance and initiate vaccination\nactivities as soon as the epidemic threshold is reached.\n(Based on: A report from the WHO Regional Office for Africa.)\nWER Editorial Note: An international Appeal has been launched by WHO\njointly with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent\nSocieties, Medecins sans Frontieres and UNICEF to raise funds for the\ncontrol of meningitis in Africa in the 1997 epidemic season. No only that, but\nelimination of these strains was durable. I'll have to look up the times in\nthe data but it was surprising. I think that the role of chemoprophylaxis (or\nthe lack of it) in populations is largely a matter of conjecture. It is true\nthat when there is no germ there is no meningitis and than certain\nantibiotics can get rid of carriage. When carriage rates are up around 30%\nantibiotics might have a role for Group B strains. The current\nrecommendations in textbooks and from the CDC et al are based on secondary\nattack rates in small groups. They are conservative and justified based on\nwhat we know about these settings. It is difficult to go beyond these data\nin a positive or negative way and be on firm ground.\n--\nJBL McClain\ne-mail: T10B9@aol.com\n[Because PROMED-EDR is for reports of disease outbreaks or emergency measures,\nin order to maintain the selectivity of EDR any further discussion on this\ntopic will now be switched to the \"regular\" PROMED list after this\nposting. Subscribers are cordially invited to continue the discussion there.\n-- Mod. (SSM)]\n..............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. No only that, but\nelimination of these strains was durable. I'll have to look up the times in\nthe data but it was surprising. I think that the role of chemoprophylaxis (or\nthe lack of it) in populations is largely a matter of conjecture. It is true\nthat when there is no germ there is no meningitis and than certain\nantibiotics can get rid of carriage. When carriage rates are up around 30%\nantibiotics might have a role for Group B strains. The current\nrecommendations in textbooks and from the CDC et al are based on secondary\nattack rates in small groups. They are conservative and justified based on\nwhat we know about these settings. It is difficult to go beyond these data\nin a positive or negative way and be on firm ground.\n--\nJBL McClain\ne-mail: T10B9@aol.com\n[Because PROMED-EDR is for reports of disease outbreaks or emergency measures,\nin order to maintain the selectivity of EDR any further discussion on this\ntopic will now be switched to the \"regular\" PROMED list after this\nposting. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2190284", "headline": "PRO> Meningococcal meningitis, reporting (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190284", "date": "1996-03-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "From: T10B9@aol.com\nDate: Sun, 17 Mar 1996 21:04:07 -0500\nMENINGITIS, CONTROL (3)\n=======================\nWe did a longitudinal survey of meningococcal carriage in Iquique Chile and\nfound that carriage of epidemic strains was pretty static. No only that, but\nelimination of these strains was durable. I'll have to look up the times in\nthe data but it was surprising. I think that the role of chemoprophylaxis (or\nthe lack of it) in populations is largely a matter of conjecture. It is true\nthat when there is no germ there is no meningitis and than certain\nantibiotics can get rid of carriage. When carriage rates are up around 30%\nantibiotics might have a role for Group B strains. The current\nrecommendations in textbooks and from the CDC et al are based on secondary\nattack rates in small groups. They are conservative and justified based on\nwhat we know about these settings. It is difficult to go beyond these data\nin a positive or negative way and be on firm ground.\n--\nJBL McClain\ne-mail: T10B9@aol.com\n[Because PROMED-EDR is for reports of disease outbreaks or emergency measures,\nin order to maintain the selectivity of EDR any further discussion on this\ntopic will now be switched to the \"regular\" PROMED list after this\nposting. Subscribers are cordially invited to continue the discussion there.\n-- Mod. (SSM)]\n..............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2190281", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Meningococcal meningitis: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190281", "date": "1996-03-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "From: T10B9@aol.com\nDate: Sun, 17 Mar 1996 21:04:07 -0500\nMENINGITIS, CONTROL (3)\n=======================\nWe did a longitudinal survey of meningococcal carriage in Iquique Chile and\nfound that carriage of epidemic strains was pretty static. No only that, but\nelimination of these strains was durable. I'll have to look up the times in\nthe data but it was surprising. I think that the role of chemoprophylaxis (or\nthe lack of it) in populations is largely a matter of conjecture. It is true\nthat when there is no germ there is no meningitis and than certain\nantibiotics can get rid of carriage. When carriage rates are up around 30%\nantibiotics might have a role for Group B strains. The current\nrecommendations in textbooks and from the CDC et al are based on secondary\nattack rates in small groups. They are conservative and justified based on\nwhat we know about these settings. It is difficult to go beyond these data\nin a positive or negative way and be on firm ground.\n--\nJBL McClain\ne-mail: T10B9@aol.com\n[Because PROMED-EDR is for reports of disease outbreaks or emergency measures,\nin order to maintain the selectivity of EDR any further discussion on this\ntopic will now be switched to the \"regular\" PROMED list after this\nposting. It is true\nthat when there is no germ there is no meningitis and than certain\nantibiotics can get rid of carriage. I think that the role of chemoprophylaxis (or\nthe lack of it) in populations is largely a matter of conjecture. It is true\nthat when there is no germ there is no meningitis and than certain\nantibiotics can get rid of carriage. When carriage rates are up around 30%\nantibiotics might have a role for Group B strains. The current\nrecommendations in textbooks and from the CDC et al are based on secondary\nattack rates in small groups. They are conservative and justified based on\nwhat we know about these settings. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2188126", "headline": "PROMED: Meningitis-Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Niger", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2188126", "date": "1996-03-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "From: estevesk@who.ch\nDate: Fri, 01 Mar 96 16:52:02 CET\nMENINGITIS - NIGERIA (4)\n========================\nSubject: WHO Communicable disease news 1 March 1996\nDisease outbreaks reported\n\nCerebrospinal meningitis - Nigeria.\nIn the outbreaks of meningitis in the northern part of the\ncountry, 8 423 cases with 1 181 deaths (case fatality rate 14%) had\nbeen reported as at 29 February. Case fatality rates ranged from 2.5%\nto 30% in the different States. The cases were reported in Adamawa,\nBauchi, Kano, Kaduna, Katsina, Kebbi, Kwara, Niger, Sokoto and Taraba\nStates. Deaths from meningitis had also been registered in Cross\nRiver. Most cases were reported in Bauchi (2 504 cases, 461 deaths),\nKaduna (2 000 cases, 50 deaths), and Katsina (1 590 cases, 297\ndeaths). Preliminary laboratory investigations of 5 cases have\nidentified Neisseria meningitidis serogroup A in 3 cases and serogroup\nB in 1. Samples are being further investigated. The Ministry of\nHealth has sent teams to the affected areas and experts from WHO,\nUNICEF and MSF have joined the teams in their support to control\nactivities.\nThe epidemic in Bauchi State may have started in early January\n1996. By 24 February almost all administrative areas had been\naffected, and 5 of them severely and one LGA, Itas-Gadu reporting an\nincidence rate of 369.8 per 100 000. Case fatality rates have ranged\nfrom 6.5% to 33.9% with many areas reporting high mortality rates The\nnumber of cases reported in Bauchi State in the first 2 months of 1996\nwas far greater than the number of cases reported annually in previous\nyears. Mass immunization has started with 250 000 doses issued by the\nFederal Ministry of Health, the State Ministry of Health and local\ngovernment services have order additional 380 000 doses of vaccine.\nThe State Ministry of Health has started a campaign to inform the\ngeneral public about the outbreak.\nIn Kano State, 12 LGS have reported cases of cerebrospinal\nmeningitis with incidence rates ranging from 14 to 309 cases per 100\n000 population. Rates above 300 were reported in and 2 LGS, Bagwai\nand Dawakin Tofa. Up to 24 February, over 300 000 doses of vaccine\nhad been distributed among school children, armed forces and prison\ninmates. Patients were treated with penicillin and chloramphenicol.\n\n.........................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Case fatality rates ranged from 2.5%\nto 30% in the different States. The cases were reported in Adamawa,\nBauchi, Kano, Kaduna, Katsina, Kebbi, Kwara, Niger, Sokoto and Taraba\nStates. Deaths from meningitis had also been registered in Cross\nRiver. Most cases were reported in Bauchi (2 504 cases, 461 deaths),\nKaduna (2 000 cases, 50 deaths), and Katsina (1 590 cases, 297\ndeaths). Preliminary laboratory investigations of 5 cases have\nidentified Neisseria meningitidis serogroup A in 3 cases and serogroup\nB in 1. Samples are being further investigated. The Ministry of\nHealth has sent teams to the affected areas and experts from WHO,\nUNICEF and MSF have joined the teams in their support to control\nactivities.\nThe epidemic in Bauchi State may have started in early January\n1996. By 24 February almost all administrative areas had been\naffected, and 5 of them severely and one LGA, Itas-Gadu reporting an\nincidence rate of 369.8 per 100 000. Case fatality rates have ranged\nfrom 6.5% to 33.9% with many areas reporting high mortality rates The\nnumber of cases reported in Bauchi State in the first 2 months of 1996\nwas far greater than the number of cases reported annually in previous\nyears. Mass immunization has started with 250 000 doses issued by the\nFederal Ministry of Health, the State Ministry of Health and local\ngovernment services have order additional 380 000 doses of vaccine.\nThe State Ministry of Health has started a campaign to inform the\ngeneral public about the outbreak.\nIn Kano State, 12 LGS have reported cases of cerebrospinal\nmeningitis with incidence rates ranging from 14 to 309 cases per 100\n000 population. Rates above 300 were reported in and 2 LGS, Bagwai\nand Dawakin Tofa. Up to 24 February, over 300 000 doses of vaccine\nhad been distributed among school children, armed forces and prison\ninmates. Patients were treated with penicillin and chloramphenicol.\n\n.........................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Case fatality rates ranged from 2.5%\nto 30% in the different States. The cases were reported in Adamawa,\nBauchi, Kano, Kaduna, Katsina, Kebbi, Kwara, Niger, Sokoto and Taraba\nStates. Deaths from meningitis had also been registered in Cross\nRiver. Most cases were reported in Bauchi (2 504 cases, 461 deaths),\nKaduna (2 000 cases, 50 deaths), and Katsina (1 590 cases, 297\ndeaths). Preliminary laboratory investigations of 5 cases have\nidentified Neisseria meningitidis serogroup A in 3 cases and serogroup\nB in 1. Samples are being further investigated. The Ministry of\nHealth has sent teams to the affected areas and experts from WHO,\nUNICEF and MSF have joined the teams in their support to control\nactivities.\nThe epidemic in Bauchi State may have started in early January\n1996. By 24 February almost all administrative areas had been\naffected, and 5 of them severely and one LGA, Itas-Gadu reporting an\nincidence rate of 369.8 per 100 000. Case fatality rates have ranged\nfrom 6.5% to 33.9% with many areas reporting high mortality rates The\nnumber of cases reported in Bauchi State in the first 2 months of 1996\nwas far greater than the number of cases reported annually in previous\nyears. Rates above 300 were reported in and 2 LGS, Bagwai\nand Dawakin Tofa. Up to 24 February, over 300 000 doses of vaccine\nhad been distributed among school children, armed forces and prison\ninmates. Case fatality rates ranged from 2.5%\nto 30% in the different States. The cases were reported in Adamawa,\nBauchi, Kano, Kaduna, Katsina, Kebbi, Kwara, Niger, Sokoto and Taraba\nStates. Deaths from meningitis had also been registered in Cross\nRiver. Most cases were reported in Bauchi (2 504 cases, 461 deaths),\nKaduna (2 000 cases, 50 deaths), and Katsina (1 590 cases, 297\ndeaths). Preliminary laboratory investigations of 5 cases have\nidentified Neisseria meningitidis serogroup A in 3 cases and serogroup\nB in 1. Samples are being further investigated. The Ministry of\nHealth has sent teams to the affected areas and experts from WHO,\nUNICEF and MSF have joined the teams in their support to control\nactivities.\nThe epidemic in Bauchi State may have started in early January\n1996. By 24 February almost all administrative areas had been\naffected, and 5 of them severely and one LGA, Itas-Gadu reporting an\nincidence rate of 369.8 per 100 000. Case fatality rates have ranged\nfrom 6.5% to 33.9% with many areas reporting high mortality rates The\nnumber of cases reported in Bauchi State in the first 2 months of 1996\nwas far greater than the number of cases reported annually in previous\nyears. Mass immunization has started with 250 000 doses issued by the\nFederal Ministry of Health, the State Ministry of Health and local\ngovernment services have order additional 380 000 doses of vaccine.\nThe State Ministry of Health has started a campaign to inform the\ngeneral public about the outbreak.\nIn Kano State, 12 LGS have reported cases of cerebrospinal\nmeningitis with incidence rates ranging from 14 to 309 cases per 100\n000 population. Rates above 300 were reported in and 2 LGS, Bagwai\nand Dawakin Tofa. Up to 24 February, over 300 000 doses of vaccine\nhad been distributed among school children, armed forces and prison\ninmates. Deaths from meningitis had also been registered in Cross\nRiver. Genetik\nDate: Thu, 25 Jan 1996 12:53:58 MET +0100\n\nMENINGITIS & INVASIVE MENINGOCOCCAL INFECTION - FLORIDA, USA (3)\n================================================================\nIn a recent publication of mine (Trends in Microbiology,\n3:186-192, 1995; reprints available), I summarized data\ncompatible with meningococcal outbreaks being\nassociated with outbreaks of a second, unrecognized\nimmunomodulating microorganism. I also speculated on epidemic\nspread and increases in frequency of carriage rate also being\ndependent on an unrecognized microorganism, which\nmight differ from the one responsible for immunomodulation.\nUnder circumstances where the bacteria present in the carrier\npopulation are clonally homogeneous, or where they are rapidly\nspreading and colonizing numerous individuals, meningococci\nisolated from disease outbreaks will be clonally\nhomogeneous. Under conditions where the carrier bacteria\ncontain several clones capable of causing invasive disease,\ndisease outbreaks will be clonally heterogeneous. Examples\nof major epidemics which are clonally homogeneous as\nwell as other which were clonally heterogeneous exist.\nA general summary of the global epidemiology of epidemic\ndisease may also be found in a different recent\npublication of mine (Meningococcal disease, edited by\nK. Cartwright, John Wiley, 1995, pp. 159-175; the book\nis a wonderful compendium of review articles;\nreprints of my article are also available).\n--\nMark Achtman\nMax-Planck-Institut fuer molekulare Genetik,\nD-14195 Berlin Germany\nE-mail: achtman@MPIMG-Berlin-Dahlem.MPG.DE\nPhone (+49) 30 8413 1262\nFax (+49) 30 8413 1387 (or 1385)\n...........................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Genetik\nDate: Thu, 25 Jan 1996 12:53:58 MET +0100\n\nMENINGITIS & INVASIVE MENINGOCOCCAL INFECTION - FLORIDA, USA (3)\n================================================================\nIn a recent publication of mine (Trends in Microbiology,\n3:186-192, 1995; reprints available), I summarized data\ncompatible with meningococcal outbreaks being\nassociated with outbreaks of a second, unrecognized\nimmunomodulating microorganism. I also speculated on epidemic\nspread and increases in frequency of carriage rate also being\ndependent on an unrecognized microorganism, which\nmight differ from the one responsible for immunomodulation.\nUnder circumstances where the bacteria present in the carrier\npopulation are clonally homogeneous, or where they are rapidly\nspreading and colonizing numerous individuals, meningococci\nisolated from disease outbreaks will be clonally\nhomogeneous. Under conditions where the carrier bacteria\ncontain several clones capable of causing invasive disease,\ndisease outbreaks will be clonally heterogeneous. Examples\nof major epidemics which are clonally homogeneous as\nwell as other which were clonally heterogeneous exist.\nA general summary of the global epidemiology of epidemic\ndisease may also be found in a different recent\npublication of mine (Meningococcal disease, edited by\nK. Cartwright, John Wiley, 1995, pp. 159-175; the book\nis a wonderful compendium of review articles;\nreprints of my article are also available).\n--\nMark Achtman\nMax-Planck-Institut fuer molekulare Genetik,\nD-14195 Berlin Germany\nE-mail: achtman@MPIMG-Berlin-Dahlem.MPG.DE\nPhone (+49) 30 8413 1262\nFax (+49) 30 8413 1387 (or 1385)\n...........................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1996-01-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "1385-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FLORIDA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2187835", "headline": "PROMED: Meningitis, meningococcal - Florida USA (5)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2187835", "date": "1996-01-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "From: \"Mark Achtman\" <Mark@Novell-MPIMG1.RZ-Berlin.MPG.DE>\nOrganization: Max Planck Inst. fuer mol. Genetik\nDate: Thu, 25 Jan 1996 12:53:58 MET +0100\n\nMENINGITIS & INVASIVE MENINGOCOCCAL INFECTION - FLORIDA, USA (3)\n================================================================\nIn a recent publication of mine (Trends in Microbiology,\n3:186-192, 1995; reprints available), I summarized data\ncompatible with meningococcal outbreaks being\nassociated with outbreaks of a second, unrecognized\nimmunomodulating microorganism. I also speculated on epidemic\nspread and increases in frequency of carriage rate also being\ndependent on an unrecognized microorganism, which\nmight differ from the one responsible for immunomodulation.\nUnder circumstances where the bacteria present in the carrier\npopulation are clonally homogeneous, or where they are rapidly\nspreading and colonizing numerous individuals, meningococci\nisolated from disease outbreaks will be clonally\nhomogeneous. Under conditions where the carrier bacteria\ncontain several clones capable of causing invasive disease,\ndisease outbreaks will be clonally heterogeneous. Examples\nof major epidemics which are clonally homogeneous as\nwell as other which were clonally heterogeneous exist.\nA general summary of the global epidemiology of epidemic\ndisease may also be found in a different recent\npublication of mine (Meningococcal disease, edited by\nK. Cartwright, John Wiley, 1995, pp. 159-175; the book\nis a wonderful compendium of review articles;\nreprints of my article are also available).\n--\nMark Achtman\nMax-Planck-Institut fuer molekulare Genetik,\nD-14195 Berlin Germany\nE-mail: achtman@MPIMG-Berlin-Dahlem.MPG.DE\nPhone (+49) 30 8413 1262\nFax (+49) 30 8413 1387 (or 1385)\n...........................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Hopkins, MD, MSPH\nState Epidemiologist, HSDE\n904-488-2905\nryh8@wonder.em.cdc.gov\nNeisseria meningitidis disease in Okaloosa County.\nOkaloosa County has had at least 5 confirmed cases of invasive meningococcal\ndisease since Dec 30. All have been in children and all are recovering. Two\nof the children were siblings with simultaneous onset. Two others are\nunrelated children at Eglin AFB [Air Force Base]. The Okaloosa CPHU [County\nPublic Health Unit?] is taking vigorous, well-targeted preventive action\nwith close contacts of cases.\nIsolates so far have been of three different serogroups. Aside\nfrom the two siblings, none of the other cases have been epi-linked. The\nvariety of serogroups is extremely important in confirming that the cases are\nnot connected. Why cases of several different serogroups would appear\nsimultaneously is not understood. Co-infection with another agent, such as\ninfluenza virus, is a possible explanation.\n--\nRichard S. Hopkins, MD, MSPH\nState Epidemiologist, HSDE\nTel.: +(1) 904-488-2905\ne-mail: ryh8@wonder.em.cdc.gov\n\n[The UK recently reported several cases of invasive meningococcal disease.\nDo any subscribers believe they are seeing more cases of invasive\ndisease than they would normally expect, based on historical data? - Mod.]\n............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Hopkins, MD, MSPH\nState Epidemiologist, HSDE\n904-488-2905\nryh8@wonder.em.cdc.gov\nNeisseria meningitidis disease in Okaloosa County.\nOkaloosa County has had at least 5 confirmed cases of invasive meningococcal\ndisease since Dec 30. All have been in children and all are recovering. Two\nof the children were siblings with simultaneous onset. Two others are\nunrelated children at Eglin AFB [Air Force Base]. The Okaloosa CPHU [County\nPublic Health Unit?] is taking vigorous, well-targeted preventive action\nwith close contacts of cases.\nIsolates so far have been of three different serogroups. Aside\nfrom the two siblings, none of the other cases have been epi-linked. The\nvariety of serogroups is extremely important in confirming that the cases are\nnot connected. Why cases of several different serogroups would appear\nsimultaneously is not understood. Co-infection with another agent, such as\ninfluenza virus, is a possible explanation.\n--\nRichard S. Hopkins, MD, MSPH\nState Epidemiologist, HSDE\nTel.: +(1) 904-488-2905\ne-mail: ryh8@wonder.em.cdc.gov\n\n[The UK recently reported several cases of invasive meningococcal disease.\nDo any subscribers believe they are seeing more cases of invasive\ndisease than they would normally expect, based on historical data? - Mod.]\n............................................................................\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.
